HEADLINE: Watch Out for a War To Aid Bush's Ratings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Plan Now for the Next Iraqi Test" (editorial, July 28) and "Saddam and Gore," A. M.Rosenthal's column the same day, discuss the temporary resolution in Iraqi compliance with the United Nations resolutions that ended the fighting in the Persian Gulf. But both fail to alert the American people to the potential of election-year "dirty tricks" by President Bush. White House strategists, down in the polls almost 30 percentage points, have again resorted to deployment of American forces to the gulf area both to wave the flag and divert the electorate from the country's economic problems in the global economy. 
 The team that brought us the ill-conceived, unnecessary invasions of Grenada and Panama, and for 10 years aided and abetted the growth of Saddam Hussein's military power (now the subject of Congressional investigation), also failed to criticize or counteract Saddam Hussein's use of chemical weapons against Kurds and Shiites in Iraq.
In August 1990, President Bush deployed more than 200,000 members of the United States armed forces with the deceptive words of "for defensive action only." My greatest fear now is that in an election-year diversion, he might again authorize the use of American forces without Congressional authorization or endorsement, as well as independent of Security Council sanction and approval. Why has there been no movement by the United States at the Security Council in the last few weeks? Why meet with United States "national security advisers" at Camp David? Where does Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali stand on these matters?
While Congress investigates the Republican campaign team's possible theft of the 1980 election, let's be sure no new dirty tricks steal the 1992 election.
 
MAURICE S. PAPRIN
President, Fund for
New Priorities in America
New York, July 28, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Town Says No Thanks To Curbside Mail Drops

BYLINE: By Charles Strum

DATELINE: WESTFIELD, N.J.

 BODY:
HERE in ZIP code 07090, where nearly every variety of tree has a street named for it and nearly every street seems to have been an ancient breeding ground for gracious colonial architecture, mail carriers make their way down sidewalks and up front stoops, just as they have for generations.
And this is how it will remain, despite what some citizens construed as momentary insanity on the part of the United States Postal Service, whose eagerness to speed delivery and cut costs resulted in a plan that raised eyebrows here the way scantily clad Bikini Weenie hot dog vendors widened eyes in Yonkers. 
 On one side was the economy-minded postmaster, James Rosa Jr., who reasoned that no one could object to speedier delivery and, through resulting savings, the potential to help maintain the cost of first-class postage at 29 cents. His plan: gradually wean the town from doorstep delivery and toward a system of sidewalk service that mimics mailbox drop-offs on country roads.
On the other side was the Westfield Board of Realtors, which quickly made allies on the Town Council. And if there is a moral in all this it surely must be that the only thing worse than waking a sleeping baby is getting on the wrong side of a suburban real-estate agent.
"Somebody came up with a zany idea that was designed to save a little money," said Pinky Luerssen, president of the realty board and an agent for Burgdorff Realty. "This is an executive town, and they're making it look like a rural town."
From the start, the plan seemed simple, merely a variation on 1978 Postal Service guidelines to promote more efficient service. In June, the postmaster decreed that any house for sale here or in neighboring Mountainside would lose at-the-door delivery once it was sold. In its place the new homeowner would be given a breadbox-style mailbox and a wrought iron post to mount it on. The boxes would be installed at the end of the front walk or driveway.
Newly built houses or condominium developments would get cluster mailboxes, devices known in the Postal Service as N.D.C.B.U.'s, or neighborhood delivery collection box units. Typically, these are 12 locked post office boxes mounted together on a pole in the courtyard of an apartment complex.
Martin Roberts, a spokesman for the Postal Service in Washington, said there was ample fiscal evidence to support sidewalk delivery and cluster boxes. Each delivery to the door costs the postal service $177, he said. But sidewalk drop-off saves steps and is only $125, he said, and cluster boxes bring the cost down to $106.
The cluster system has worked well, according to reports from postal officials in Westchester County, Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey. Customarily, postal officials approach developers before new housing goes up and work out a cluster or sidewalk delivery plan ahead of time.
But postmasters in the region said they could not recall any effort to retrofit a mature community that has had mail delivered to its front doors for decades. Though similar programs have been reported elsewhere in the country, in Westfield, a Union County community where large old homes with opulent landscaping bring prices of $450,000 and up, real-estate agents take curb appeal seriously. Ranks of mailboxes do not fit the proper profile.
The battle began shortly after Mrs. Luerssen received a letter from the Postal Service announcing the change and seeking addresses of all vacant properties.
"We sent a copy of the letter to the councilmen and to our Senators to try to get it halted," Mrs. Luerssen said. "We thought the boxes were ugly and totally inappropriate. In Westfield, a 70- by 150-foot lot is standard. We don't have acre zoning."
"My big thing is safety," she said. "If you're putting mailboxes outside of vacant houses, you're sending a signal and inviting trouble."
But until the issue hit the weekly paper, The Westfield Leader, last week, most people in Westfield and Mountainside did not know much about it, Mrs. Luerssen said.
In a letter to The Leader that accompanied a front-page article, Councilman Norman N. Greco threatened to take the fight all the way to the Postal Service Board of Governors.
Referring to the mailboxes as tin cans on a post, Mr. Greco said they offered invitations to thieves and vandals. "Gee, won't Mischief Night be that much more fun," he wrote.
Even mail carriers grumbled, wondering how many jobs would be lost if, as envisioned, 10 minutes a day could be cut from delivery time on each of Westfield's 46 mail routes.
And so, the march of progress became a shuffle and finally a retreat. Although the Board of Realtors said it was still awaiting a formal announcement from the Postal Service that the plan had been scrapped, local postal officials have conceded defeat.
Only 11 new mailboxes were installed, said Mike French, the collection delivery supervisor in Westfield. And if anyone complains, he said, the post office will remove the offending mailbox and resume front-door service.
"We're here to serve the public," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 8, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The headline on the "Our Towns" column yesterday about mail delivery in Westfield, N.J., misstated the Postal Service action in some editions. The service has abandoned a plan for curbside mail delivery and will continue delivering mail to front doors.

DISSENSION AT. U.N. OVER BOSNIA
President Bush's effort to get the United Nations to authorize force to get humanitarian aid into Bosnia and Herzegovina ran into resistance from Britain and France. The nations questioned the military value of Mr. Bush's offer to provide air cover for relief convoys. 1
 
Bosnia's President says his country needs arms, not just food. 5

EUROPE PONDERS WAR CAMPS
Horrified by pictures of emaciated inmates of camps in the Balkans, some Europeans have called on their governments to take a firmer line against Serbian aggression in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Reminded of Nazi-era camps, many fear that history may be repeating itself, but there have been no mass petitions. 1

The United Nations Secretary General recommended to the Security Council that 30 observers be sent to South Africa to help defuse violence and ease the way for further negotiations on democracy. 2
 
VETERAN'S TALE DISCOMFITS TOKYO
A 78-year-old veteran's report that Japan organized kidnapping squads to keep wartime brothels supplied with tens of thousands of coerced Korean women has become something of a nightmare for the Japanese Government. 3

JOBLESS RATE A BIT BETTER
The unemployment rate edged down to 7.7 percent in July from 7.8 percent in June. But the improvement was too slight to suggest that the economic recovery was picking up much strength. 1
 
BUS COMPANIES IN FARE WAR
In a ruthless fare war, the nation's two largest bus companies have knocked down the price of a trip from Manhattan to Washington three times in the last three weeks. The current fare: $5, less than such a trip cost in 1939. 1
 
FADE OUT FOR DRIVE-INS
In the last two decades, the number of drive-in theaters has fallen steeply. But for the people who drive to Neligh, Neb., to see the latest Hollywood releases, the Starlite Drive-In, is the only game in town. 6

In an effort to increase the turnout of Asian, Hispanic and American Indian voters, the Senate passed a bill that requires more state and local governments to provide bilingual ballots. 7
 
CONGRESS'S EFFORT TO CUT COSTS

CLINTON'S CALL FOR COURAGE
Until recently, Governor Clinton's campaign has used the public's yearning for change to score political points. Now, aware that the desire for change sometimes brings the fear of change, he is begun stressing a new theme: courage. 8
 
NEW THEMES ON BUS TOUR

HEADLINE: The File of a Refugee: One Haitian's Account

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
In a Manhattan law office, Angelot Cyriac rifled through an accordion folder, the only possession he carried aboard a leaky sailboat for his journey last April from Haiti to the United States. From its folds, he brought forth laminated identification cards, membership certificates, diplomas and photographs -- a paper trail of the political ties that landed him in a Coney Island apartment, on the lam from the Haitian military.
By the standards of refugees seeking political asylum, this folder was gold. Many Haitian refugees tell United States immigration authorities of relatives slain by soldiers, of their own torture in prison, of their ardent support for the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. And the authorities say: Where is the body? Where is the scar? Where is the proof of persecution? 
 "What this man has is some evidence," said James DeBrosse, a lawyer who represents many Haitians looking for asylum here.
 
A Man, Not Numbers
 What this man has is the vivid account of an immigrant's odyssey, the kind of account that usually gets lost in the public debate over the fate of Haitian refugees. Federal judges, politicians and lawyers rarely speak of the individuals who have left Haiti since the military coup that deposed President Aristide last fall. Instead, they talk in numbers: the 38,000 intercepted at sea, the 27,000 repatriated, the 11,o00 admitted to the United States to apply for asylum.
But behind those statistics lies a thicket of human drama.
And behind the closed doors of hundreds of New York apartments, the newest Haitian refugees, like Mr. Cyriac, struggle with a future that is by no means assured. They have only been provisionally allowed into the United States, where they are concentrated in South Florida, the New York area, Boston and Los Angeles. They have to fight for the right to stay, and history would suggest the odds are against them. Between 1983 and 1991, only about 2 percent of Haitian applicants were granted political asylum.
In a Coney Island apartment, Mr. Cyriac, who arrived a month ago, spends his days watching the television in his sister's apartment. He watches anything and everything, listlessly, not understanding the English. The life of Angelot Cyriac (pronounced ahn-je-LOW see-ree-AK) is not here, on the seventh floor of a Neptune Avenue apartment building. His life, for the moment, still lies in the accordion folder whose contents tell his tale.
Mr. Cyriac rifled through the papers.
Here was a photo of Mr. Cyriac in uniform, a baby-faced soldier, before he got in trouble with the men who protected the former President for Life, Jean-Claude Duvalier. Here was a membership card in the anti-Duvalier association of former military men. Here was Mr. Cyriac at work in what he says are the archives of the National Palace, before President Aristide was overthrown last fall.
And here was a family portrait, Mr. Cyriac and the wife and children he left behind -- his wife doe-eyed and serious, his little girl in ruffles and bows, his little boy in a starched white shirt.
"We have had virtually no love life or home life for years," said Mr. Cyriac, who is 28 years old. "I never stay in one place for long enough."
The Bush Administration maintains that the majority of Haitians fleeing by boat are economic migrants, not political refugees. Advocates for Haitians, however, claim there are many more Haitians fleeing political persecution than the Government acknowledges.
 
Sergeant Cyriac
 While Mr. Cyriac's story is by no means generic, it is not unique. Like many passionately political Haitian men, Mr. Cyriac boarded a boat, he said, to save his life. He has no desire to settle in the United States, he said. He is only seeking temporary haven.
"I didn't fight for Haiti all these years to live abroad," he said. "I fought to live at home."
Raised in Maissade, a town in the Artibonite Valley where his mother cultivated rice and cotton, Mr. Cyriac enjoyed local fame as a high-scoring soccer forward. His prowess caught the eye of an army lieutenant who recruited him at age 16 to beef up an army team. Mr. Cyriac said he thought, naively, that he could learn woodworking in the Haitian Army.
By the time that Jean-Claude Duvalier held a referendum in 1985 to endorse himself as President for Life, Mr. Cyriac, then Sergeant Cyriac, knew that things were rotten in Haiti. When President Duvalier visited Mr. Cyriac's army post and gave him a wad of cash to insure that the voting went smoothly, Mr. Cyriac took the money -- and voted against Mr. Duvalier, he said. He told the peasants who asked him how to vote to "vote their conscience, like I was doing," he said.
By Duvalier's count, 99.9 percent of Haitians approved his presidency for life. But in Sergeant Cyriac's district, the vote was heavily negative. That was the beginning of his troubles. He was seized by military men, blindfolded and flown to Port-au-Prince, where he was imprisoned and tortured, he said.
"I felt I was going to be a martyr, like Dessalines," he said, referring to Jean-Jacques Dessalines, the hero of Haiti's independence struggle.
But his torturer also opposed Duvalier, so he survived, Mr. Cyriac said. And after two and a half months, Dr. Roger Lafontant, then the Minister of the Interior, freed 275 soldiers in prison, handing them $25 each and attempting to secure himself a loyal cadre, Mr. Cyriac said.
 
Dangerous Activism
 The former soldiers banded together in an anti-Duvalier association, which provoked a showdown with the Tontons Macoute, Duvalier's agents. Mr. Cyriac's house was burned to the ground, and he and his neighbors, in turn, surrounded 10 Tontons Macoute, placed tires around their necks and set the tires on fire, he said.
Then began a life of political activism on the run, of imprisonment and escape, of attacks and retaliation. In the 1987 elections, he said, he was working at the Ecole Argentine de Bellegarde polling place where 34 people were shot and hacked to death. Before the violence began, he was arrested, stuffed in the trunk of a car and taken to prison, from which he escaped.
"Every time I was beaten, I would wash my wounds in the ocean and then rub them down with limes, and I was good as new," he said.
In 1990, he worked as a security guard for the electoral council executives organizing the elections that brought Father Aristide to power, he said. Even though he was "apolitical" as an election official, he was a "marked man" again, he said. Once Father Aristide was elected, however, he was given a job in the election archives in the basement of the National Palace, Mr. Cyriac said.
"It was like taking a bath and starting life again, clean," he said.
After the coup d'etat, Mr. Cyriac was imprisoned by his former enemies and released after a few months by an old army buddy, who also told him to keep on the move, he said. He traveled northward, gathering the photos and documents for his folder with the help of friends and relatives. When he got to La Gonave, the island that most boats left from, the sailboat Victoria was departing. And, just like that, he said, he jumped on and headed to America. It was April 21.
 
'Where Else Could I Go?'
 "I prayed to God and to all the saints and spirits to save me, because where else could I go?" he said. "If we died, well, we would be dust returning to dust."
The seas were pitching, the sky black and blue and some 250 Haitians were crushed against each other in the leaky sailboat. One man decided that evil spirits were chasing him, endangering the others on his boat. So, Mr. Cyriac said, the man jumped overboard to his death.
And then, Mr. Cyriac said, the seas calmed. And, within two weeks, Victoria sailed into Guantanamo Bay, where the United States Coast Guard met them and transported them to the tent city for Haitian refugees at the United States Naval Base in Cuba.
Most of the other passengers on Mr. Cyriac's boat were eventually returned, against their will, to Haiti.
"Alas," he said. "I think of them and imagine some are already dead."
The government agents believed that Mr. Cyriac had a credible fear of persecution, so he was flown through Miami to New York, where his sister works as a nurse's aide.
 
Two Granted Asylum
 In this country, like thousands of others arriving from Guantanamo, he will tell his story to immigration authorities, who are overwhelmed by a backlog of political-asylum applications.
Of 2,000 applications filed so far by the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has granted asylum to 2 Haitians and sent letters of intent to deny asylum to about 30 others. All other cases are pending. (The Catholic immigration clinic is representing and resettling about 60 percent of the Haitians.)
And the wait makes the Haitians nervous, said the Rev. Thomas Wenski of the Haitian-Catholic Center in Miami -- particularly as the Supreme Court prepares to rule on whether the Bush Administration is within its rights to halt Haitians at sea and forcibly return them to their homeland.
"The back and forth of the courts makes their position, their future feel more precarious," Father Wenski said.
And while their cases are on hold, the Haitians live in a state of limbo, torn between their troubled homeland and their troubles here.
"They're pretty down," said Marie Cerat, who runs English and literacy classes for the refugees at the St. Francis of Assisi-St. Blaise Church on Maple Street in Flatbush, Brooklyn. "I don't think they knew what they'd be facing. All they knew was that they wanted out."
All the Haitian refugees received a one-time grant of $600 from the Federal Government, along with the authorization to work. But Mr. Cyriac, like many others, has had no luck finding a job. In fact, the Haitian political activist, who, by his account, has withstood seven years of threats against his life, rarely leaves his sister's Brooklyn apartment.
"I'm afraid of getting lost," he said.

HEADLINE: Iran Said to Commit $7 Billion to Secret Arms Plan

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Iran has committed more than $7 billion to acquire fighter jets, missiles, tanks and nuclear technology from China, North Korea and Russia, according to Arab, French and other officials who monitor the country's efforts.
The secretive program, which began in 1988, has been so costly that a Western European embassy in Teheran told its Government this week that the Iranian economy was so overstretched that it doubted it could honor its debts. 
 The Western European country, whose officials insisted on anonymity, strongly recommended that letters of credit no longer be opened for Iranian businesses.
The Iranian effort has been largely eclipsed by other world events including the preoccupation over the last two years with the confrontation between the West and neighboring Iraq and lately the Yugoslav crisis.
 
Aided by Rising Oil Revenues
 But Saudi and French intelligence officials have signaled over the last few months that the Iranian plan to rebuild the country's armed forces, which began after the end of the eight-year war with Iraq in 1988, has been aided by rising oil revenues and a determination to achieve military superiority in the Persian Gulf region.
In November the American Department of Defense said that Iran's plans included the purchase of conventional weapons as well as a continuing effort to acquire nuclear technology, an assertion Teheran vehemently denied.
But Saudi and French officials say they are sure Iran is working on plans to build atomic weapons as well as increasing its conventional arsenal, despite an assertion by the United Nations International Agency for Atomic Energy, based in Vienna, that an inspection team found "nothing suspicious" on a February inspection tour.
 
Gathering of Intelligence
 Western officials have yet to find credible evidence of an Iranian attempt to acquire nuclear weapons, but there is little doubt that the purchase of conventional weapons is soaring.
The Arab and French intelligence officials have gathered evidence backed by independent groups like the International Institute for Strategic Studies, based in London, which asserts that the Iranian Air Force, nearly nonexistent at the end of the war with Iraq, is now much stronger and equipped offensively and defensively.
The Saudi and French officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Iran spent or committed $3.2 billion on arms in 1988 and 1989, primarily to the former Soviet Union for MIG fighters and tanks.
In 1990 and 1991, these officials say, Iran spent or pledged $4 billion more to buy tanks, missiles and fighter jets from China, North Korea, Russia and some Eastern European countries.
These weapons most of which have been acquired, include 24 MIG-31's, 24 MIG 27's, 68 MIG-29's, 12 Tupolev-22 M bombers and several radar-detecting Ilyushin 76's, largely bought from the former Soviet Union and from Russia.
The yearly Strategic Survey of the International Institute of Strategic Studies added in May that Iran had also ordered 72 F-fighter airplanes from China and 200 T-72 tanks.
In addition, Iran has acquired at least 100 Iraqi fighter jets, mostly Russian MIG's, and military transport aircraft, which sought refuge in various Iranian cities in the last days of the allied bombing campaign in the gulf war. The Iranians have said they would keep those planes as part of the compensation they are demanding from Iraq for the 1980-88 war.
Altogether these purchases have substantially raised the offensive ability of the Iranian Air Force.
In March 1992, a North Korean vessel that carried an unknown number of advanced Scud-C missiles was tracked by United States satellites as it docked in Bandar Abbas, an Iranian port.
At the moment, officials say, Iran is negotiating the acquisition from Russia and other Eastern European countries of SAM-5, SAM-11 and SAM-13 antiaircraft missiles.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Bush Says Any U.S. Action Must Come Through U.N.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
President Bush vowed today that he would not rest until Serbian-run prison camps were opened to outside inspection, but he stopped short of threatening to bomb Serbian positions and targets to gain access.
On the question of military action to keep relief supplies flowing, which the United States is pressing the United Nations to authorize, Mr. Bush insisted that any American involvement must be part of a United Nations effort. But the British and the French are both resisting a United Nations authorization vote. 
 "We are -- everyone has been -- reluctant for very understandable reasons to use force," the President told reporters in the White House briefing room, as calls for action mounted at home and abroad. "There's a lot of voices out there in the United States today that say use force, but they don't have the responsibility for sending somebody else's son or somebody else's daughter into harm's way, and I do."
 
Not in 'Political Arena'
 That sounded like a jab at Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, who has been advocating air strikes. But Mr. Bush insisted, "I am not going to get engaged in the political arena" on the subject of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the former Yugoslav republic that has been under Serbian attack.
Still, the President's discussion with the reporters was full of political spin. He implied strongly that only he, and not Mr. Clinton, was qualified to weigh the alternatives in the Balkans, and he said he would continue to "speak with measured confidence" in his dealings with Iraq -- a pair of comments in keeping with his campaign theme of "trust and experience."
He interpreted a slight fall in the nation's unemployment rate, which most private economists called rather insignificant, as evidence that the country was "poised for recovery."
Later, at a ceremony marking the 50th anniversary of the start of the battle of Guadalcanal in the South Pacific, the electioneering tone continued.
 
Praised by Cheney
 Introducing the President, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney noted that Mr. Bush had fought in World War II, then praised him as a wartime leader: "When this nation faced the challenge to freedom in the Persian Gulf, he stood up for America's principles. He refused to reward aggression. That's because he understands, just as the veterans of Guadalcanal understand, the precious value of freedom."
Mr. Clinton has been criticized in some quarters for having managed to avoid combat service in Vietnam. Mr. Cheney did not serve there, either.
In his discussion of the ethnic strife in the Balkans, Mr. Bush emphasized that he had made no decision yet about military action against Serbian troops bombarding the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, or against targets on Serbian territory.
Referring to the Vietnam war, the President added: "We are thinking it out very carefully. I do not want to see the United States bogged down in any way into some guerrilla warfare. We've lived through that once already."
 
Stung by Thatcher Article
 Senior White House officials said that Mr. Bush had been stung by an article in The New York Times on Thursday, written by his old ally, former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. It bore the headline, "Stop the Excuses. Help Bosnia Now." But the President was said to be haunted by the prospect of Vietnam-style escalation, in which failure of a bombing campaign would be followed by calls for the commitment of substantial allied ground forces.
"The world cannot shed its horror at the prospect of concentration camps," Mr. Bush said in his second such statement in two days."The shocking brutality of genocide in World War II, in those concentration camps, are burning memories for all of us, and that can't happen again. And we will not rest until the international community has gained access to any and all detention camps."
Refugees from northern Bosnia have told interviewers of rapes, killings and starvation diets in Serbian-run prison camps, and television footage has shown gaunt figures with ribs protruding in scenes reminiscent of Nazi concentration camps.
In Iraq, a new United Nations weapons inspection team has arrived and repeated its demand to inspect any site it chooses under the terms of the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf War. But President Saddam Hussein says they will be barred from entering any Government ministry because that would compromise Iraqi sovereignty.
With deadlock looming once again, Mr. Bush said he could not tell yet "how much of this is bluster" and "how much on their part is determination to provoke confrontation." But he insisted that Mr. Hussein "is going to comply" with all of the relevant United Nations resolutions.
Asked if the problems overseas might make it more difficult to bring Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d into the White House to oversee his re-election campaign, as expected, the President replied, "When I have something to say about what Secretary Baker might or might not do, I'll let everybody here know about it, but I have great confidence in him and in the department on the diplomatic side."
Aides said Mr. Baker's changeover might be delayed until late this month, but was still planned.
Speaking to reporters in LaCrosse, Wis., this morning, Mr. Clinton offered careful, limited praise of the President's statements on the Balkan situation.
"I think it's a step in the right direction," he said. "I think it's time they contemplated air support."
Asked if he believed that the United States should push for broadening the air support mission to include the bombing of artillery positions that have been shelling civilian areas, Mr. Clinton said: "I think they need to look at their military options, whether they can actually do that in Bosnia without taking a lot of civilian casualties, too. I think we ought to wait until we get some sense of what is posssible, but I think that is where they ought to be thinking."
Mr. Bush said he had no problem with Mr. Clinton's "offering advice on these matters," but said he was "not going to get engaged in the political arena when we are trying to do something that really has a tremendous humanitarian aspect." Foreign policy, he said, was too serious for politics.

HEADLINE: Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez, Former Spanish Official, 62, Dies

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez, who helped remold Spain's image in the post-Franco era and served as Foreign Minister from 1985 until June, died today at his home in Madrid. He was 62 years old.
He died of cancer of the colon and liver, according to his doctor, Carlos Sanz. His body lay in state this afternoon at the Foreign Ministry in Madrid. 
 Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez, who used the nickname Paco, helped reorient Spain's business and political goals during the transition to democracy after the death of the dictator Franco in 1975. He oversaw Spain's integration into the European Community and NATO in the mid-1980's.
Born on June 22, 1930, in Madrid, Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez studied at Harvard in the United States and earned a law degree at the University of Madrid. He began his career as a tax inspector and moved to the Finance Ministry in 1969.
He held civil service posts in the Franco dictatorship, heading the Government-run National Institute of Industry, but soon joined the growing democratic opposition to Franco's rule and took part in talks aimed at restoring democracy after Franco'sdeath.
As Finance Minister from 1977 to 1979 in the centrist Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez was responsible for passage of controversial income-tax reforms, introducing graduated taxation. The number of taxpayers rose from 1.5 million people in 1977 to more than 12 million over the years.
In 1979 he was appointed Justice Minister in the centrist Government of Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, where he drew bitter criticism from conservative politicians for the legalization of divorce in 1981. The divorce law was the harbinger of separation of church and state in Spain.
He was named chairman of Spain's state-controlled export-financing bank, Banco Exterior, in 1983 and was appointed Foreign Minister in 1985, two years after Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and the Socialists came to power.
Considered more pro-American than his predecessor, Fernando Moran, Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez campaigned for NATO membership, a step that Spanish voters approved in a referendum. He guided the country to membership in the European Community in 1986 and continued to campaign for greater European integration, championing the Maastricht treaty on political and economic union, which is now awaiting ratification by the 12 community nations.
Attending his first meeting of European Community foreign ministers in the mid-1980's, Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez was reported to have said, "Just call me Paco," a phrase that became his trademark introduction on policy missions throughout the world.
Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez was widely credited in his country for having placed Spain on the map of modern international politics. He helped pave the way for restoration of diplomatic ties with Israel in 1986 and gave the Palestine Liberation Organization mission in Madrid what is described by some envoys as de facto diplomatic status.
He was perhaps most proud of Spain's role as host in the first round of Middle East peace talks in Madrid last October.
He said he had circled the world 150 times as a diplomat, although his illness, which he never publicly acknowledged, began to take its toll this year. After a final trip in May to Chile and Argentina, Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez canceled all appointments, citing exhaustion. Mr. Gonzalez accepted his resignation on June 22, Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez's 62d birthday.
King Juan Carlos described Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez today as "an exemplary minister" and one of Spain's "finest statesmen."
Mr. Fernandez-Ordonez is survived by his wife, Mari Paz Garcia Mayo.

HEADLINE: Weary Firefighting Army Holds Line in the Northwest

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEDFORD, Ore., Aug. 7

 BODY:
Ponderosa pines ignited and popped like matchsticks today in a fire that is consuming a forest about 80 miles northeast of here, while helicopters dumped 3,000-gallon buckets of fluid and bulldozers scraped dirt boundaries to halt the flames of burning forests throughout the Northwest.
The fires, covering nearly 30,000 acres, are among thousands that have roared across more than a million acres in the parched Northwest so far this year. Nearly 100,000 acres are still in flames today as 13,000 firefighters battle fires in six states. But the fires have caused less destruction than expected. 
 No deaths or serious injuries have been reported, and animals appear to have escaped the fires. The authorities put the number of homes destroyed at seven, far fewer than the number burned in previous years, and people who had been evacuated in Oregon were allowed to return home today.
But for the unluckiest, the numbers provide little comfort. Fred Klotz, a 42-year-old woodworker who lived in a log cabin in the hills 80 miles northeast of this city in southwest Oregon, pointed Thursday to twisted metal and piles of ashes. "That's where I lived," he said ruefully.
As the fire raced up the hill toward his small cabin late Tuesday, Fred and Kathryn Klotz loaded some tools, books and clothes into the back of a pickup truck and fled.
"It's all gone," said Mr. Klotz, a bearded man in suspenders and jeans. "You can't cry about it."
Kathryn Klotz interjected: "Oh, I don't know about that. I did some crying."
 
Dry Forests Burn Easily
 Nationwide, firefighters are battling 11 major fires today in Washington, California, Idaho, Montana and Nevada as well as Oregon, but they expect to contain seven of them by Sunday. The vast majority of the fires during this fire season, which began in the spring and will end in late summer, have been attributed to lightning. But the forests are so dry that even the spark from a burning cigarette can cause a serious fire.
About 75 homes were evacuated Thursday near a blaze that has been named the Skookum Fire in south-central Washington. In the last several days it has consumed 3,000 acres and brought 1,345 firefighters to the scene to battle it. And in the rugged terrain of the Los Padres National Forest, 40 miles south of Monterey, Calif., firefighters are plagued by a lack of roads and by erratic winds that whip flames in every direction. The fire there has burned about 600 acres.
After the warmest winter on record and one of the driest springs in a century, fire experts say they have been braced for a season of devastating fires. The region has endured drought for seven years.
Under the Palmer Drought Index, which the Government uses to measure the degree of dryness, the eastern side of the Pacific Northwest is drier than at any time in 50 years. A reading of minus-4 on the index would mean that a region had suffered an extreme drought; plus-4 would be described as wet. Parts of Oregon are assigned an index of nearly minus-9.
Arnold Hartigan, a spokesman for the Boise Interagency Fire Center in Idaho, which coordinates firefighting throughout the West, credited quick, smart work by firefighters, as well as cooler temperatures later in the week, for the lack of widespread destruction.
"We've been very lucky," Mr. Hartigan said. But he added, "Having said that, the fire season is nowhere near being over."
About 65,000 fires in the Northwest have burned 1.1 million acres this season. About 800 million acres of forest in the area are under state and Federal control, but many of the fires this year have burned on private land. At this time last year, 54,000 fires had consumed more than 1.9 million acres.
Experts say fires are part of the natural cycle in the West. In fact, some trees, like lodgepole pines, need severe heat to germinate.
Melanie Miller, a fire ecologist at the Boise Center, described fire as "nature's cleansing agent."
Land managers have historically been too willing to fight fires, she said, and that has led to dangerous conditions. Smaller fires were often snuffed out before they were able to clear out some of the undergrowth, she said. As a result, fires tend to be harder to control because they are fed by so much undergrowth.
Firefighting efforts in recent years have been complicated by the building of houses in remote areas. "Everybody wants to have a nice rustic home with a wood-shingled roof, right up under the trees in these nice narrow bushy canyons," Mr. Hartigan said.
Ina Rist, a 53-year-old motel worker, lives in a mobile home in such a wooded, hidden region, 20 miles northeast of Chilloquin, Ore. She stepped out of her front door on Wednesday and saw flames marching toward her home.
"It was coming across the flat -- red all over," she said. Ms. Rist's home was untouched by flames, but just a few miles away, singed trees and blackened ground marked the path of the fire. Julie DeYoung, a Forest Service worker, sprayed the hot ground with retardant foam, a white flaky substance that left this section of the forest with a Christmas-like look.
For the army of firefighters, the work is dirty and tiring. But for people like Dave Marina, a veteran of the Persian Gulf war who has been unemployed since his discharge last September, it has meant a paycheck.
"I'd rather be home with my 8-year-old daughter," said Mr. Marina, who spread out a bedroll on the ground in the fire camp on Thursday, trying to recoup after a night shift in the forest. "But they're paying $6.75 an hour. I couldn't pass that up."

"It's all gone," Mr. Klotz said after authorities allowed residents to return to the area. (Bill McClain for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Medals Are Not The Point

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain

 BODY:
IN THE wake of a run of bad luck by United States athletes this week, there was a brief, mad scramble to determine what had gone wrong with Team U.S.A.: Michael Johnson, the sprinter, failed to qualify in the 200-meter dash; Dave Johnson, the decathlete, nearly wrecked a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign; the Dreamettes, as the United States women's basketball team used to be called, were stunned by the Unified Team in a semifinal; American boxers and baseball players were mercilessly pummeled by Cubans.
With two days remaining before the end of competition, however, the medal count reflects the world order more than an impending athletic disaster for the United States: The Unified Team, made up mostly of what used to be the Soviet Union, has won 42 gold medals and 100 medals over all, compared with 31 gold and 96 total for the United States. 
 A look through the glitter of medals, however, presents a clearer sense of the challenge that faces the United States at a time when fresh flows of freedom are making the world's track-and-field teams more competitive than ever.
Fifty-three of the United States medals -- more than half -- are divided between swimming and track and field. The Unified Team's medals are more evenly distributed, with two or more golds sprinkled over seven sports.
But a look beyond the superpowers reveals the tremendous strides that have been made with a rigorous focus on development. African athletes, for example, are not only tightening their dominance in distance running, but also beginning to move down to shorter races, with Kenyans winning gold and silver in the men's 800 meters.
American athletes have maintained a certain high level, but what has become apparent in the first non-boycotted Olympics since 1972, is that the world has gotten better.
Indeed, the United States, for all the talent at its disposal, has faltered in the crucial area of development, the process of identifying and training young talent.
Cuba, with its 10 million people, has become a model of resourcefulness, utilizing an extensive provincial sports school system to insure that the island's best athletes are identified first then placed into sports. By the time they reach Olympic competition, Cuban athletes have endured a grueling regimen of competitions since age 12.
But for all of Cuba's success, 1992 may represent its high-water mark. With a deepening economic crisis, Cuba may be at or near its ceiling.
Then there is Africa, which is just be beginning to explore a seemingly limitless potential. The gold- and silver-medal performances of Ethiopa's Derartu Tulu and South Africa's Elana Meyer in the 10,000 meters last night, coupled with the dominance of Kenyan runners, appears to signal the awakening of a giant.
A measure of the growing sense of potential is reflected in a push by Claude Grinaker, director of the African Athletic Federation, to bring a grand-prix track event to Africa in a effort to keep African athletes on their own continent.
The irony, given South Africa's racist history and the passionate embers that still burn over race, is that South Africa may be the financial hub of an African track-and-field renaissance. The extent of the battle over who controls the distribution of funds and the organization of meets could determine whether the promise of African potential will be fulfilled.
The United States, on the other hand, must simply determine whether developing untapped potential is a priority.
Outside of track and field, basketball and boxing, the other Olympic sports remain outside the reach of too many potential athletes in the States. For all the country's wealth of human resources, the United States has failed to establish a coherent national policy pertaining to amateur sport. The ambivalence is reflected in the presence in Barcelona of an ultra professional Dream Team that wins by an average margin of 50 points while amateurs in other sports are up to their necks in competition.
After watching Cuban boxers and baseball players perform, a number of journalists have bemoaned the fact that the Cubans will never have an opportunity to fight or play for millions of dollars in the United States.
But it is precisely the lure of professional sports that has had a weakening force in the United States, especially in amateur boxing, where talented fighters are snapped up by managers like barracudas, in many cases before they are ready.
If the United States takes anything away from Barcelona, it should be a renewed commitment to development. That challenge goes beyond a count of medals.

A VIVID TALE OF PERSECUTION
In a Manhattan law office, Angelot Cyriac rifled through an accordion folder, the only possession he carried aboard a leaky sailboat for his journey last April from Haiti to the United States. From its folds, he brought forth laminated identification cards, membership certificates, diplomas and photographs -- a paper trail of the political ties that landed him in a Coney Island apartment, on the lam from the Haitian military. His story is an immigrant's odyssey, the kind of story that usually gets lost in the public debate over the fate of Haitian refugees. Page 1.

HEADLINE: County Chief O'Rourke Waits for Judge O'Rourke

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, has become the Man Who Could Not Leave.
It is not that he wants to remain as the Republican chief executive of this suburban county: for some two years he has made it clear that he would much prefer the seat on the Federal District Court in Manhattan for which President Bush formally nominated him in November. 
 But with no action yet on the nomination by the United States Senate and none expected before the Senate recesses next week, it is likely that Mr. O'Rourke will not be confirmed before his nomination expires in January, and it is far from certain whether he will be renominated after that.
While he waits, some people in government and politics here say Westchester's official life has shifted into an "on hold" position -- along with Mr. O'Rourke's career.
"Politically, it has caused organized confusion," said Sal J. Prezioso, president of Westchester 2000, a nonpartisan planning group, who is a former deputy county executive.
"Everybody's scrambling for position," Mr. Prezioso said. "There's only one top position, and that's the county executive position."
 
Some Problems Acknowledged
 In an interview this week, Mr. O'Rourke said the county government remained one of the healthiest in the state. But he acknowledged that his judicial nomination might have caused some problems in people's perception of him.
"Once people think you might leave, people start looking for who your successor is going to be," he said. "But I don't think that's hard to overcome if you say you're going to run again."
He acknowledged that it was unlikely he would be approved for the Federal Court before January. "I guess where there's life, there's hope," he said. "But in this case I don't think there's a great deal of hope."
If he were to be confirmed by Sept. 20, a near impossibility, a special election for his replacement would be scheduled. If he were approved after Sept. 20, the Republican-controlled majority on the County Board of Legislators would select a successor for the job, which pays $119,085 a year.
A result of Mr. O'Rourke's faltering judicial hopes is a near pile-up of county office seekers idling their political engines. There are increasing assertions by some that the county government is adrift. And even some Republicans have become comfortable hurling criticism at Mr. O'Rourke, a onetime candidate for Governor who has been county executive since 1983.
"He could do more, and that's being kind," said Angelo Martinelli, a former Mayor of Yonkers who is considered a front-runner for the Republican nomination for County Executive if Mr. O'Rourke moves on.
 
Commitment Questioned
 Mr. Martinelli, like other politicians, said Mr. O'Rourke had appeared less than fully committed to his job here. "If this was his only thing -- being County Executive -- it would be better for the county," he said.
Paul J. Feiner, a Democrat who is Supervisor of Greenburgh, the largest town in the county, said Mr. O'Rourke had become aloof as his tenure stretched on. Mr. Feiner said he had difficulty obtaining an appointment this spring to discuss a housing issue.
"There's a sense," Mr. Feiner said, "that, 'We don't need you. We don't care.' "
Some in county politics said Mr. O'Rourke's appointments to important executive positions had been less than first-rate, reflecting the difficulties of any chief executive in drawing talented people at the end of an administration.
 
Power Can Be Elusive
 But some said the difficulties in governing the county go deeper. "He's in a very difficult position right now because he can't get the authority he needs as County Executive," said Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat who preceded Mr. O'Rourke as County Executive and who this week resigned as Mr. O'Rourke's "economic growth czar."
"You can order people around," Mr. DelBello said, "but in the position he's in, he really can't initiate major programs."
Mr. O'Rourke said that he was running the county "better than Al DelBello ever did" and pointed to 10 years of budget surpluses.
Mr. O'Rourke, 58, said that in a new term President Bush could renominate him to the bench. If not, he said, he will decide sometime after the Presidential election whether to run for re-election in November 1993.
He said his nomination had foundered, like many others, simply because of Washington politics.
But some who had been tracking the nomination said it had been kept on the slow track because Mr. O'Rourke lacked the credentials of some other candidates.
 
Primarily A Politician
 Although Mr. O'Rourke has practiced law, he has been primarily a politician for years. On a Judiciary Committee questionnaire that asked for a description of 10 significant cases handled by the applicant for the bench, Mr. O'Rourke listed only three.
The American Bar Association found him qualified.
But one lobbying group of public-interest organizations, the Alliance for Justice, placed him on its list of the "worst of the worst" judicial nominees. The group cited, among other things, his votes while a Yonkers City Councilman to prohibit low-income housing in predominantly white areas of the city.
George Kassouf, the director of the Judicial Selection Project for the Washington-based Alliance, said nominees with questionable qualifications had been processed more slowly than others, and Mr. O'Rourke was one of them.
Mr. O'Rourke defended his qualifications, saying he had written legal articles and taught in law school. When he said that, he sounded less like a candidate for re-election and more like a judicial nominee.
"I'm still playing it," he said, "as though I might get it."

HEADLINE: Brown Resignation Highlights High Turnover Among Chiefs

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Lee P. Brown's departure after two and a half years as New York City's top police official is -- in one sense, at least -- typical of an emerging pattern across the nation: with increasing frequency police chiefs are lasting only a short time in the job.
In the last five years, the heads of the police departments in 41 of the 50 largest cities in the country have resigned or been dismissed, according to an analysis by the Police Executive Research Forum in Washington. Thirteen cities have replaced their chiefs twice in that time, and Chicago, San Francisco and Dallas have each had three different police executives. 
 "They're burning out, dropping out, getting fired or having health problems," said Robert Trojanowicz, a professor of criminal justice at Michigan State University and a co-author of the forthcoming book, "Police Management for the 21st Century."
Part of the reason for this, criminal-justice experts say -- and perhaps a consideration in Mr. Brown's desire to spend more time with his wife, who is seriously ill -- is that the job has grown far more demanding. Running a big-city police department is no longer simply a matter of commanding troops and catching criminals. Trying to get at the root of crime, cope with shrinking budgets and respond to conflicting demands, the police chief must be a blend of diplomat, coach, drill sergeant and community organizer, on the streets at dawn, commending a precinct commander at noon, speaking at a church at night.
Reviewing his tenure in New York with a reporter the other day, Mr. Brown acknowledged that he had jousted with budget officials in City Hall and with the press and noted, without a hint of regret, that he had often worked 16-hour days. Still, his relish at serving at what he portrayed as the pinnacle of policing in the United States came through vividly, and he made it clear that he was not leaving because he had been unhappy in the job. "The time I can spend with my wife is the issue," he said.
Criminal-justice experts also say that a subtler issue may be at work, one that has also dogged school superintendents: Police chiefs are being asked to work within a society struggling with problems, like homelessness and high unemployment, that are far beyond their control.
"People look to the police chief for the answers to all the problems of society," said C. Roland Vaughn, the Chief of Police in an affluent suburb of Atlanta and the president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police, which represents 8,000 police executives in the United States.
 
'The Court of Last Resort'
 "We're sort of like the court of last resort for a lot of people who need help," said Patrick S. Fitzsimons, the Chief of Police in Seattle. "We're being asked to intercede and find shelter, to take people out of squatters' situations. We're in the middle on something created by the economy. You have to take a humane approach."
The high turnover in police chiefs has led many criminal-justice experts to call for the creation of formal contracts that would give the chiefs some insulation from the whims of a mayor, an angry public or electoral change. Mr. Trojanowicz has suggested, for example, that a chief be guaranteed that he or she would serve at least two years into the mayoral term following his or her appointment.
Many modern police leaders, like Mr. Brown, have come to resemble chief executive officers of major corporations, more likely to be seen in dark suits and ties than star-studded uniforms, more likely to be armed with law degrees and Ph.D.'s than guns.
Mr. Brown has a Ph.D. in criminology from the University of California at Berkeley and his chief deputy, Raymond W. Kelly, who has been named acting head of the department, has a law degree from St. John's University, a master's in law from New York University and a master's in public administration from Harvard.
"The chief has to be a person with vision, a manager, a leader and an interpreter of political policy," said Joseph D. McNamara, the retired Chief of Police in San Jose, Calif., who has a Ph.D. from Harvard and is a research fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University.
 
Higher Salaries
 With better education and greater responsibilities, criminal-justice experts say, the pay of police chiefs has been gradually rising. Mr. Brown, for example, was paid $110,000 a year. The job pays $85,000 in Philadelphia and more than $150,000 in Los Angeles, said Darrel Stephens, the executive director of the Police Executive Research Forum.
After the mayor's job, said Gerald W. Lynch, the president of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, "nothing in the city demands more time and energy and total commitment."
Not many chiefs can stand the heat for long. "A good 40 percent of them either resign or are fired under pressure," said Mr. Stephens, who made the analysis for the police forum. "A lot of the other people, after they've been in the job two or three or four years or so, start feeling the conflicting pressures, and they just retire, drop out. Very few grow old in the job."
Though there are no comparable statistics on the length of service of police chiefs in the top 50 cities prior to the Police Executive Research Forum analysis, both Mr. Stephens and Mr. Trojanowicz said they believed the turnover had greatly increased.
Reuben Greenberg, the Police Chief in Charleston, S.C., agreed. "The job has so many pressures," he said. "In some cases a civilian group or the mayor is trying to run the department. You have very little leverage."
 
Changing of the Guard
 For years, Mr. Trojanowicz said, police chiefs came up through the ranks. They knew the politics of their community, and they tended to be less aggressive and innovative than the new breed of police chief. New chiefs tend to be better educated and often take the top spot in a department after having served for 10 years or so in another city, in a kind of apprenticeship.
"Years ago," Mr. Trojanowicz said, "there wasn't so much boat-rocking."
There was no sign of dissatisfaction with Mr. Brown from City Hall and, by all accounts, he was enthusiastically pressing ahead with a transformation of the department, putting thousands of officers on foot patrol in what he calls community policing. But his wife, Yvonne, had become seriously ill and, an aide said, he felt there could be no compromising in his "totally consuming job."
Like many police executives who step down these days, Mr. Brown is returning to the campus. He will teach at Texas Southern University. Many others take jobs as directors of security for private companies, and some become consultants.
Mr. Stephens said he knew of only two chiefs who had been given leaves of absence in recent years -- one to recover from a heart attack, the other for a year of study at Harvard -- and Mr. Brown apparently did not consider asking for one. "It's the nature of the job," Mr. Stephens said. "There's an expectation that whoever is in charge is going to be able to be there and do the job."
Mr. Vaughn said the high visibility of the police chief takes a toll on his family. "He has to be accessible all the time and has to be accountable all the time," Mr. Vaughn said. "Like the preacher's kids, the chief's children are expected to adhere to a higher standard. It's difficult for a wife to share her views for fear people will think they're the chief's views, too. It becomes somewhat of a guarded life."
Mr. Brown said that after serving in New York, he considered his police career finished. "I think 17 years of being a c.e.o. of law enforcement is enough," he said. "When you leave as the Police Commissioner of New York, where else do you go?"

HEADLINE: Bronx Group Opposes Site Of New Juvenile Center

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
A group of civic and political leaders in the South Bronx is mounting a last-minute campaign to stop the Dinkins administration from building a juvenile detention center in a busy commercial district that is a focus of a revitalization plan.
The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said the 124-bed secure detention center, for which contracts have been awarded and construction is expected to begin within months, would work against the borough's Bronx Center Plan. The plan is a blueprint for commercial, residential and institutional development in a 300-square-block area that includes the Hub, the Bronx's second-largest business district. 
 The detention center is planned for a lot at Westchester and Brook Avenues, on the eastern fringe of the Hub and near neighborhoods slowly bouncing back with new housing. It is one of two intended to replace the outdated Spofford Juvenile Center in Hunts Point, in the Bronx; the other will be in East New York, Brooklyn.
Members of the group, the Bronx Center Steering Committee, said they were not opposed to a new center in the Bronx. But they said there were other sites where such a center would have a less harmful effect.
 
'We Have No Vision'
 "You are taking prime, income-producing land and turning it into nothing," said Mr. Ferrer, who is one of two chairmen of the steering committee. "Besides sending a message to the community that any old place will do, you're also sending a message to the business community that we have no vision, and are throwing away potential sources of revenue for the future."
The group, which says it wants to meet with Mr. Dinkins, made its concerns known in a letter they sent to him yesterday.
Yesterday afternoon, a spokesman for the Mayor said his office had not yet received the letter. "Obviously, we're always concerned and interested in hearing the voices of local elected officials," John Beckman, the spokesman, said. "It is also a serious concern of ours to make sure that facilities such as this, which are designed and planned to give kids a second chance, are constructed and operating in a timely fashion."
Spofford, built in 1957, is the city's only detention center for offenders under 15 years of age. Officials at the city's Department of Juvenile Justice said that Spofford's design made it difficult to provide rehabilitative programs and proper supervision, and that its location, a long walk from the No. 6 subway line, made it hard to reach.
The Hub, with bustling stores lining the crossroads of East 149th Street and Third Avenue, is served by many subway and bus lines.
Mr. Ferrer said that he and the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, opposed the project when it came before the city's Board of Estimate in August 1989. He said that he had proposed other sites, including the former Wedtech factory on Gerard Avenue, south of Yankee Stadium.
But the assistant commissioner for planning and program development at the Department of Juvenile Justice, Ann B. Siegel, said the other sites were too small and that the Wedtech site was privately owned and would cost $8 million. She said the city guidelines called for the center to be built on city-owned land.
She noted that the project had been approved by the appropriate city agencies.
But the issue resurfaced on Wednesday when the Bronx Center Plan Steering Committee reviewed private and public projects being developed for the area.
Richard Kahan, the steering committee's other chairman, does not dispute the need for new investment in criminal justice institutions.
"It's not a question of it not being in the Bronx," he said. "It's a question of why public policies have to contradict one another."
The borough's plan was intended to tap into the increased buying power fueled by a slight jump in population.
Bernd Zimmerman, the director of planning and development at the Bronx Borough President's Office, said that major retailers, including a supermarket chain and a home-furnishings store, had expressed interest in the site where the juvenile center is planned because its size would accommodate sprawling parking lots.
Another concern is that the detention center would make it more difficult to market the new town houses that have been slowly, with the help of city subsidies, reclaiming blocks in formerly desolate neighborhoods.
"Even with the sea of housing, the city shot itself in the foot," said William Bollinger, the director of commercial revitalization for Sobro, a private economic development organization. "They spend millions on new housing in this community, but private developers have to market that housing. It's tough enough when you make a life-savings investment when two blocks away there is a juvenile detention center."

HEADLINE: Teen-Ager Shot in Quarrel Says He'll Continue to Oppose Drugs

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7

 BODY:
A little more than a year ago, a gang of drug dealers down the block invited two of Patsy and Winfred Rembert's sons to join their thriving trade.
The boys, Edgar, now 14 years old, and Winfred Jr., 16, said no. Well-schooled on the topic by their parents, they said no to the girls they were told their new wealth would attract, no to the prospect of expensive sneakers and fashionable running suits, and no to the gold jewelry and fancy cars they were promised if they would only agree to sell illegal drugs. That was when the trouble started. 
 It culminated last Sunday when Winfred Jr. was shot trying to defend Edgar, who had gotten into a fight with the gang after they had roughed him up and damaged his bicycle. A single bullet tore through Winfred's abdomen, damaging his pancreas, spleen and a kidney before bursting through his back.
Today, at a news conference at the Hospital of St. Raphael, the youth, whose family calls him Junior, said he would continue to stand up to the gang. "I was doing something I believe in, so I shouldn't be afraid," he said.
 
'Just Leave Us Alone'
 In a city that has recorded 21 homicides so far this year, many of them drug-related, the story of the Rembert family is stark evidence of the draining, uphill battle parents wage in trying to shield their children from drugs. While firmly believing that they could teach them to reject that enormous temptation that pervades urban -- as well as suburban -- life, the Remberts have found themselves persecuted for their approach. Drugs, it seems, will not leave them alone.
"What hurts most of all," said Mrs. Rembert in an interview earlier this week, the tears spilling from her eyes, "is that we try to stay to ourselves. We're not bothering them. Just leave us alone, that's all I asked. But now my kids can't even play outside in front. When other children come over, we have to screen them before they come into the yard. We have to ask, 'you got a gun?' Because we don't know what these people will try to do."
At the news conference today, Junior said few children in the neighborhood could resist the gang.
"They'll walk up to you, $100 up front, and they'll show you $100," he said. "Usually, if you say 'No,' they'll put down $200 and they'll just keep pressing."
He said he refused to join because "I want a better life."
On Tuesday, the police arrested a 15-year-old boy and charged him with the shooting; because of his age, his name was not made public. The Rembert family says the suspect was involved in selling drugs along with the rest of the gang in the neighborhood.
The Remberts moved to Beers Street, on one of the nicer blocks of this city's dilapidated Dwight-Kensington section, five years ago, fleeing the chaos of a Bridgeport housing project. Their white frame house was quiet and spacious, all they had hoped for.
There they are raising seven children (the youngest is 5) and caring for Mrs. Rembert's 80-year-old mother. Mr. Rembert, a former longshoreman, works as a heavy-equipment operator on construction sites. Lately, though, work has been scarce, and he struggles to make ends meet by repairing cars and vans. His unemployment benefits just ended.
"When we moved here, there wasn't a drug dealer around," Mr. Rembert said. "We had the option of another place, but we chose this one for that reason."
Along the paved front walk, marigolds are struggling up from the earth. Down the block, where Beers crosses Edgewood, young men affiliated with the Kensington Street International gang surround cars to peddle drugs.
It is the derailing of their son's dreams -- he wanted to be a basketball star and planned to try out for his high school football team -- that has devastated the Remberts, even more than the sight of him lying in a hospital bed with tubes and needles piercing his once-athletic body.
 
Fears and Tears
 The shooting has received considerable attention here, prompting offers of help to the family. A private New Haven college, Albertus Magnus, has promised Junior a four-year scholarship for showing the courage "to do the right thing." He said today that he would probably accept the offer.
The Remberts say that the last year has been hell on their nerves and that their children have been persecuted by drug dealers who have snatched basketballs, hats and bicycles from them.
"We escort them now wherever they go," said Mrs. Rembert. "We go to three different schools every day to pick them up. Sometimes Junior says to me, 'Mom, this is so embarrassing. You can just let me walk.' But I'm so scared. When they go alone to a movie, or downtown to the jazz festival, I'm just worried the whole time."
Mrs. Rembert said she had not campaigned to get drug dealers off her street or antagonized them in other ways. "We're just saying, we want to live this way," she said. "I'm trying to be good. It's hard to get them to do what we say -- I'm always learning. There's so much out there they want and we can't afford to give them right now."
The older children share the same anxieties about what might happen to them. "I think about it when I go to school, or after school," Edgar said, his face cradled in his hands. "I worry about my family. And sometimes, I cry."
 
The Price of Opportunity
 Mr. Rembert, an energetic barrel of a man in his mid-40's, sounds like anybody's proud father as he discusses other aspects of his life. He talks happily of his children's ambitions -- Lillian, now 15, won admission to a competitive enrichment program at Yale and wants to be a lawyer; Edgar thinks of going into teaching if his first choice, professional basketball, does not work out. "Junior," their father says, "is a real good mover to the basket, sort of a Clyde Drexler-type player."
He embraces his little ones and says he would go back to Albany, Ga., where he and his wife met and married 20 years ago, if it were not for the New Haven schools. He believes there is a better opportunity for his children here, if the violence on their street will spare them.
In general, the police support the Remberts' story, although they could not confirm that the problems with the gang began because the Rembert children refused to sell drugs.
"As far as we know, the boys were not involved in drugs," said Lieut. Melvin H. Wearing, the chief of detectives. He added, "I can't remember this type of case coming across my desk before, where the family got directly involved and things happened as a result."
Lieutenant Wearing said that the drug trade where the Remberts live was "mostly powdered cocaine, a little marijuana."
"That area is sort of a hot spot, where a lot of people congregate," he said. "We have officers stationed on those corners."
Most of the clientele come from out of town, he added. "It's a lot of suburbanites," he said. "That street is a main artery to come through. You can make a purchase and be on your way out of there."
Mr. Rembert said the police had been extremely helpful since his son was shot, but he does not expect them to be able to solve the problem. Instead, he said, he plans to remain on guard for what he fears will be a drive-by, nighttime attack on his house. "Either that, or they'll decide to just leave us alone," he said.
The family thinks the trouble is not over.
"Once you move out of the projects, you think you won't have to encounter any of this," Mrs. Rembert said. "It seems that we've got no place to go."

HEADLINE: Welfare Experts Skeptical of Cuomo Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 7

 BODY:
As New York State prepares to create thousands of temporary, low-skill jobs for welfare recipients, many welfare experts say the program will do little to reduce the welfare rolls without a larger investment in job-training and placement programs.
Starting next month, the new state program will require single adults and childless couples to work part time for state agencies or lose their Home Relief welfare grants. The Cuomo administration says the program will help break welfare dependency by giving the people job training and experience. 
But a broad range of welfare experts question the value of such workfare programs, saying that without proper training and supervision, the programs are simply punitive measures that often do little to prepare welfare recipients for the real-world job market.
"What these programs usually do is fill up people's time," said Kathryn H. Porter, research director for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington-based group that studies welfare issues. "There is no research I know of that shows they actually increase people's job skills."
William Grinker, a former head of the New York City Human Resources Administration, who supports work-for-welfare programs, said such programs work only when they are coupled with extensive job-placement programs that help move the welfare recipients into permanent jobs.
 
'Need the Combination'
 State officials said they have no plans to expand existing job-placement programs. Consequently, the burden of providing such programs will remain with municipalities and counties, which, Mr. Grinker and other welfare experts said, are struggling with limited budgets and cannot provide adequate programs now.
"You need the combination of services, training and job placement to build on work experience," Mr. Grinker said. "There's some of that out there, but not enough, especially for Home Relief recipients."
About 370,000 New York State residents, most of them single adults who live in New York City, receive Home Relief, which averages about $350 a month per person. The state estimates that about 190,000 of them are employable.
Without extensive educational components, workfare programs can still have some benefits, the experts said. For instance, the programs can discourage a small amount of welfare cheating. They can also help the long-term unemployed become accustomed to the workplace.
"There are clients who say, 'I'm afraid of the job market; I need to get my feet back on the ground,' " said Gordon Berlin, senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, which has studied welfare-reform issues. "For them, this program can make sense. The question is, what happens after the first three months?"
 
Earlier Program
 The new state program, called Working Toward Independence, is in many ways an expansion of an existing New York City workfare program. That program requires Home Relief recipients to work and receive training in city agencies, mostly in clerical or maintenance jobs.
Mary R. Nakashian, a deputy commissioner in New York City's Human Resources Administration, said the 10,000 Home Relief recipients in the program at any one time learn work skills, such as word processing, as well as job-hunting skills. At the end of the six-month program, many participants enter "job clubs," which help them look for permanent positions.
But data on the program's effectiveness remain sparse and open to conflicting interpretations. Last year, 1,152 Home Relief recipients reported getting permanent jobs after leaving the H.R.A. program. While some experts said the figure was low, city officials said it demonstrated that the program had been effective in getting a large number of people off welfare.

HEADLINE: Refitting Groton's Military-Based Economy for Peacetime

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., Aug. 7

 BODY:
Officials from the state, local utilities and a fledgling Florida corporation today unveiled three small steps they have taken toward converting the military-dependent economy of New London County to peacetime industry.
In a garage at the Groton Department of Public Utilities, three pickup trucks were parked with their hoods up, showing off the work of people laid off from Electric Boat, the nuclear-submarine maker. Teams of the retrained workers had removed the gasoline engines and fitted the trucks with electric motors and batteries. 
 Municipal utilities in Groton, Norwich and Wallingford will use the electric trucks and monitor their performance. But for the officials gathered here, the trucks represented much more than a road test. They were southeastern Connecticut's toehold in an industry that may yet prove enormous: electric vehicles.
The demonstration project, officials said, had not only shown how adaptable the skilled work forces of Electric Boat and other military contractors are, but had also given Connecticut a start in establishing a technical-school curriculum and university research to support the electric-vehicle industry.
 
Plans for Production Plant
 It also appeared to have cemented a relationship between Connecticut and the Solar Car Corporation of Melbourne, Fla., a small maker of electric cars and conversion kits that is working with state officials on plans to open a production plant here.
"These are very, very basic vehicles," said Douglas Dobb, the president of Solar Car, which provided conversion kits and technical assistance for the three trucks. "There are many more generations of more highly evolved vehicles to come."
Giant military contractors like General Dynamics, the parent of Electric Boat; Hughes Aircraft and Lockheed are searching for peacetime uses for their sophisticated technology. In several areas of the country, particularly southern California, local and state governments are encouraging electric-vehicle research and production as one solution.
California and several other states with high air-pollution levels are creating a market for the cars by requiring certain percentages of new vehicles to be emissions-free -- in practice, electric -- and more are expected to follow.
 
Military-Dependent Economy
 In southeastern Connecticut, Electric Boat has laid off more than 2,000 employees this year because of cutbacks in the Seawolf nuclear-submarine program, and 17,000 more jobs at its shipyard are at risk. Thanks to Electric Boat, its subcontractors and related businesses, New London has the most military-dependent economy in the nation.
The interest in Solar Car shows the lengths to which state and local officials are willing to go to get in on the ground floor of an industry, even if it creates few jobs initially.
The demonstration project with the pickup trucks was started by the Connecticut Municipal Electric Energy Cooperative, the wholesaler for six municipal utilities in the state, with a $30,000 grant from the American Public Power Association.
The region's Private Industry Council, an arm of the Federal Department of Labor, contributed $27,720 to train workers for the conversion project, and 30 workers, ranging from an electrical engineer to a grinder, were drawn from Electric Boat's Career Transition Center for laid-off employees.
 
Technical Curriculum
 A curriculum was developed and training supervised by instructors at the Waterbury State Technical-Mattatuck Community College, Central Connecticut State University and the Oliver Wolcott Regional Vocational Technical School. And data on the trucks' performance will be analyzed by a center for alternative technologies at the Avery Point campus of the University of Connecticut.
All of these efforts, officials said today, will result in a technical curriculum for Connecticut to train new workers for the electric-vehicle industry and to conduct research to support its growth. For the 30 Electric Boat workers the project is over, but they are expected to be offered Solar Car's first jobs in Connecticut.
"We expect that the first applications and interviews will come from you people," Mr. Dobb told the trainees today.
Still, the courtship of Solar Car shows how interested state economic development officials are in potential: the four-year-old company has only a dozen employees, subcontracting much of its work so far.
Robert Adams, its vice president, said a Connecticut plant would start with about a dozen employees, though the company is talking about a factory that could produce as many as 1,000 electric vehicles a year.
