Some workers, above, laid off from Electric Boat, the nuclear-submarine maker in Groton, Conn., participated in the Solar Car research project and are expected to be offered Solar Car's first jobs. (Bruce Johnson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The jobless rate improved a bit last month, edging down to 7.7 percent from 7.8 percent in June, thanks in part to a Federal summer teen-age jobs program. But the improvement was not enough to signal a stronger economic recovery or to help President Bush politically. Unemployment worsened in New Jersey, jumping to 9.8 percent from 9.2 percent in June, and in New York, rising to 9.4 percent from 9.2 percent. [Page 1.]
Consumers reduced their debt for the fifth straight month in June, the Federal Reserve reported. A $1.02 billion improvement in their balance sheets resulted from a drop in auto loans, which fell by $2.8 billion. [48.]
Another fare war is being fought. The weapons -- $5 bus tickets between Washington and New York -- are being wielded by Greyhound and Peter Pan bus lines, and the jousting is attracting droves of passengers to the Port Authority bus terminal. [1.]
Plans to cut 40,000 postal jobs, three-fourths of them managers, were outlined by Postmaster General Marvin T. Runyon. [9.]
A Federal appeals court blocked a Massachusetts attempt to prevent out-of-state banks from collecting late-payment fees on credit-card bills sent to state residents. [39.]
 
International
A North American free trade agreement was balked by an ugly squabble, but Canadian, Mexican and American negotiators were hopeful that they could strike a comprehensive deal soon. [37.]
 
Companies
Kirk Kerkorian will seek Chrysler board representation. The movie executive, the auto maker's largest individual shareholder, said he was disappointed Lee A. Iacocca was retiring. [37.]
Hewlett-Packard shares were hammered, closing down $12.625, at $58.875, after the company announced its third-quarter earnings would fall below Wall Street analysts' estimates. [37.]
The dismissal of most of Apple's $5.5 billion copyright suit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard over on-screen symbols in its graphical interface was reaffirmed by a Federal judge. [38.]
Carl C. Icahn and the Federal agency that insures T.W.A.'s pension fund have apparently broken off talks over Mr. Icahn's plan to sell the bankrupt carrier to employees and creditors. [39.]
Bellcore said it would lay off up to 750 employees, or about 9 percent of its work force, but no researchers. [39.]
A surprise bid of $385 million for bankrupt Continental Airlines was made by Alfredo Brener, a Houston real estate investor whose father and uncle control a Mexican airline. [39.]
Rembrandt painted self-portraits. Now JVC plans the same for users of its new compact video cameras. [39.]
 
Markets
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.38 percent, its lowest level this year, as credit markets rallied after July jobless data confirmed the economy's growth was sluggish. [40.]
Stocks dropped for the fourth straight session after a late round of futures-related selling wiped out a solid rally. The Dow Jones industrial average gave up 8.38 points to close at 3,332.18. [40.]
The dollar fell, despite repeated Fed intervention. [46.] Soybean futures prices dropped after a private forecasting service predicted the harvest would be the biggest in a decade. [46.]
 
Today's Columns
The campaign phrase "family values" is influencing several provisions of the big tax bill that is expected to reach the Senate floor next week. John H. Cushman Jr.: Your Taxes. [38.]
Inventions for people who want to loaf, lounge and avoid labor include new barbecue aids, a tray for dining while reclining and a broom for lawn mowers. Patents. [38.]

HEADLINE: Yield on 30-Year Bonds Falls to 7.39%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year bond fell to its lowest level of the year as Treasury securities rallied yesterday after July employment data confirmed that the economy continued to grow only sluggishly.
In late trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the yield on the 8 percent bond of 2021 was 7.39 percent, matching the closing low of early January this year. The bond was offered at 1077/32, up almost seven-eighths of a point on the day. The yield was down from Thursday's 7.45. 
 If the yield moves much below this level it will be in rarefied territory. The yield on a 30-year bond has not been below 7 percent since the early 1970's.
On the surface, the unemployment data looked good enough for President Bush to say at a White House news conference: "We are poised for a strong recovery. And we have been growing, albeit anemically." And, in fact, the increase of 198,000 in non-farm payroll jobs was the largest monthly jump in two years.
But underneath, in the webb of detail that makes up the jobs report, the outlook was not upbeat, which is good news for a bond market that likes slow growth and little inflation.
So, in yesterday's trading there seemed to be reason to resume the rally that began in early July when June employment data were reported.
But the rally, which stalled at the end of July, will be tested again next week as the Treasury auctions off $36 billion in 3-year and 10-year notes, and 30-year bonds.
 
Few Signs of Strength
 "It is hard to find any strength in this report," Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said of the unemployment data. Taking the last two months together, he said, the private sector has increased jobs by only 28,000. In an average recovery that would be closer to 400,000, he added.
In other trading, the three-year note was offered at 10311/32, up 11/32 to yield 4.57 percent, compared with 4.69 percent on Thursday. In the pre-auction, or when-issued, market, the new three-year note to be auctioned Tuesday was trading at a yield of 4.71 percent.
The five-year note, with a coupon of 5.5 percent, was offered at 9925/32, up 15/32 to yield 5.50 percent, compared with 5.66 percent on Thursday. This was a big recovery for this note, which was auctioned at a record low average yield of 5.56 percent at the end of July, only to see the price fall so sharply that the yield jumped to 5.82 percent a week ago.
The 10-year note closed up 21/32 at 10625/32 to yield 6.54 percent, compared with 6.63 percent the day before. In the pre-auction market, the new 10-year note to be auctioned Wednesday was trading at a yield of 6.54 percent. The new 30-year bond to be auctioned Thursday was offered in the pre-auction market at a yield of 7.36 percent.

HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE DIPS A NOTCH TO 7.7% IN MIXED SHOWING

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The nation's jobless rate improved marginally last month, edging down to 7.7 percent from 7.8 percent in June, the Government reported yesterday, thanks in part to a Federal summer jobs program for teen-agers. But the improvement was not enough to signal a stronger economic recovery or to help President Bush as he heads into the Republican National Convention.
Indeed, in some areas the employment situation was deteriorating. Unemployment in New Jersey jumped to 9.8 percent in July from 9.2 percent in June, and in New York State the jobless rate grew to 9.4 percent, from 9.2 percent in June. 
 Nationally, nonfarm payrolls climbed by 198,000 jobs in July, including about 75,000 summer positions for teen-agers financed by Federal funds voted after the Los Angeles riots. Even with the gain in payrolls, an unemployment rate of 7.7 percent represents 9.8 million Americans out of work.
 
President Welcomes News
 President Bush, commenting yesterday on the jobs report at a White House news conference devoted mostly to the situation in Bosnia, said that he was pleased. "We are poised for a strong recovery," he said. "And we have been growing, albeit anemically,"
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Mr. Bush's Democratic rival, contended on a campaign bus tour that the economic recovery would not gain momentum as long as Mr. Bush was President.
"I think it's very interesting that just last week the White House refused to take responsibility, and now when there is some economic news they say, 'Here we come, " he told a crowd in La Crosse, Wis. "What we must turn around is the declining economic earnings of the American people. That can't be turned around without a new economic strategy."
The July gain in jobs was a decided improvement over June, when payrolls declined by 63,000, a number revised upward yesterday from the decline of 117,000 originally reported. The June jobless rate, at 7.8 percent, was the highest in eight years.
Yesterday's report gave no suggestion that the economic recovery was breaking out of its painfully slow pace or, more important, that job growth was picking up enough to push the unemployment rate down signficantly before the election in November.
"There couldn't be worse political news for George Bush," said Peter Hart, a pollster for Democratic candidates. "He wants the American people to believe prosperity is around the corner, but these numbers show it is way over the horizon."
Republicans were not particularly cheered by the numbers, either. "I'm glad I'm not running for President this year," said Representative Richard Armey, Republican of Texas, who has a Ph.D. in economics. He said, however, that he was cautiously optimistic that consumers would soon become a bit more confident.
 
Stagnant Period Seen
 Most forecasters, looking at the remainder of the year, see more of the same: an economy that is just muddling along. And few think unemployment is likely to drop below 7.5 percent by November.
"June was a bad month," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill. "July was a mediocre month."
Ted Van Dyk, a longtime Democratic policy adviser, said, "The Democrats can't cry depression; on the other hand, President Bush has no valid claim that the economy is strengthening."
Other political analysts agreed that the dip in unemployment in July would not help the President appreciably.
"The fact that the unemployment numbers varied slightly isn't going to change Americans' basic concerns about a stagnating economy and jobs," said Kevin Phillips, a Republican political analyst who has often been at odds with the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
 
Needing a Push
 The trouble, from the President's vantage point, is that few economists see the kind of rebound in spending and hiring that could push unemployment down fast enough to restore consumer confidence to feel-good levels.
"The job growth in July is good news, but the economy needs stronger jobs growth closer to historic norms for recoveries," said the President's chief economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin.
The typical recovery in the years since World War II has pushed the number of private-sector jobs up nearly 5 percent in its first 15 months; in today's economy, that would be four million new jobs. Assuming, as many economists still do, that the recession ended in the spring of 1991, this recovery has produced fewer than 200,000 nongovernment jobs so far.
"The shortfall in jobs is really staggering," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "That's why most Americans still feel like there's a recession."
 
A Seasonal Factor
 Of the 198,000 new nonfarm payroll jobs -- the number that economists watch to gauge whether the economy is expanding or contracting -- 75,000 were temporary summer jobs that will disappear after Labor Day. "There could be some backsliding in the numbers then," Representative Armey said.
Economists focused on the remaining 123,000 new jobs, noting that the economy would have to churn out about that many new jobs each month to prevent another uptick in unemployment. The economy has been generating an average of 75,000 jobs a month since the beginning of the year, and the average pace for the last two months is even lower, 60,000.
As many industries are still losing jobs as are expanding payrolls. Virtually all the job growth has come in the sprawling service sector, which employs four out of five American workers these days. Business services, including temporary-help companies, health care and restaurants, did most of the hiring.
But jobs in construction and manufacturing -- the industries that typically lead job rebounds -- continued to shrink, with military contractors and computer makers announcing layoffs in recent weeks.
"That's normally the driving edge of the economy, and it's not driving," Mr. Wyss said.
 
Some Setbacks Noted
 But the biggest disappointment was that the total number of hours worked by all employees in the private sector was flat. The hours put in by manufacturing workers actually slipped a bit as overtime declined, a sign that industrial production may have remained weak in July.
"The second quarter ended on a very weak note, and the third quarter didn't start on a much stronger one," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
Wages, the Labor Department reported, did not rise either. Average hourly earnings remained at their June level of $10.58, just 2.3 percent above their level a year ago.
While that is good news for inflation prospects, the data suggest that personal income continues to stagnate. Since consumers have already been squeezing their savings in order to spend a little more, weak job growth and flat wages do not bode well for future spending.
"If George Bush had a magic wand, and he could make one wish, it would be to get unemployment below 6 percent," Mr. Hart, the pollster, said. "The news he has gotten today is one more indication that his wish is not going to be granted."

HEADLINE: New York - Washington $5 Is Cheaper Fare Since 1952

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Move over Delta, United and American. Another savage fare war is under way, driving down the price of a bus ride between Manhattan and Washington to $5.
Five dollars. 
 That is the lowest price on the route since 1952, when Truman was President and Greyhound charged $5.05 -- a sale price then, too. And it is less than the trip cost in 1939, when LaGuardia was Mayor and the bus ride down to Washington cost $5.50.
In a money-losing battle, the country's two-largest bus companies, Greyhound and Peter Pan Trailways, have knocked the price down three times in the last three weeks from its $25 starting point.
 
Doesn't Cover the Costs
 The bus industry's rule of thumb is that operating costs average $2 a mile, or roughly $478 for the trip from New York to Washington. At the current fares, a full bus with 47 passengers does not cover even half the expenses.
Travel on the route has quadrupled during the fare war, the bus companies say. Among the travelers was Dorothy Melvin of Jersey City, who left yesterday on a weekend trip to the nation's capital, her first bus ride in more than 50 years.
"I never even thought of going any place," she said, "least of all Washington, where I'm angry with everybody there, anyways." But she could not resist the bargain, she said as she waited at the end of a long Greyhound boarding line at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan.
Yesterday, hundreds of Greyhound and Peter Pan passengers of all ages and races created snaking lines through the terminal.
One was Thomas Knierim of Manhattan, who said his trip to Washington this weekend would be the first time he had traveled by bus since Ronald Reagan's first term. "But with a fare this cheap . . ." he said with a shrug.
The price war has created such a wave of demand that Peter Pan said last night that it had started limiting the $5 fare to the first 20 passengers on each trip, charging the remaining passengers $25.
Peter Pan, the country's largest privately owned bus company, said it was responding to Greyhound's curtailment of service. But Greyhound executives denied they had reduced their service and said the $5 fare remained available for all seats on the route.
Both companies have said the $5 fare will run only through Aug. 16.
"Someday we want to break even and make some money," said Robert J. Schwarz, executive vice president of Peter Pan.
For now, what the companies are losing in revenue, they hope to gain in publicity and customer loyalty. That is especially important to Peter Pan, which is trying to establish its fledgling operation between New York and Washington.
 
How It All Began
 The seeds of the fare war lay in the decision earlier this year by American Coach Lines of Maryland to quit the Washington-New York route. It suffered from low ridership despite its $25 one-way fare.
On June 1, American sold its Washington terminal to Peter Pan, which had been trying to find a way to expand beyond New England, where it has operated quietly and profitably for decades.
Peter Pan kept the $25 fare but soon realized it needed to turn some heads. So on July 24, it introduced a $9.95 one-way special.
Greyhound responded by lowering its fare to $7 from $25, and Peter Pan answered with $6.95. Last Friday Greyhound went to $5, which Peter Pan immediately matched.
"Our message was simple," Mr. Schwarz said of Peter Pan, which is based in Springfield, Mass. "We're in the market to stay, and they're not going to send us home."
The underdog, Peter Pan is trying to secure an edge over its much better-known competitor. Most of its buses on the New York-Washington route show movies, and the company promises it will roll out extra buses -- even for a single passenger. It also promises to give customers advice on how to get to Broadway theaters and the F.A.O. Schwarz toy store -- the New York attractions its riders most frequently inquire about.
But executives of Greyhound say their customer surveys suggest movies are not an important amenity. And the company says it needs at least half a busload before it will send an extra coach down the road. It acknowledges that operators at its telephone information centers in Charlotte, N.C., and Omaha know little about New York geography and theater schedules.
Greyhound, however, likes to point out that it has 11 departures at the discount fare each day, in each direction, while Peter Pan has only 6 each way. On top of the current cut-rate fares, Greyhound is also offering half-price fares for most children, which Peter Pan is not.
 
Clinton's Peter Pan Tour
 Last month, Peter Pan had another opportunity for publicity. The Democratic Party chartered five of the company's buses, including its V.I.P. coach, for the bus tour from New York to St. Louis by Bill Clinton, the Presidential candidate, and his running mate, Al Gore, that followed the party's convention in Madison Square Garden.
"They did not receive any consideration that another customer would not receive for a multiday charter," Mr. Schwarz said.
The buses were part of the backdrop in the candidates' frequent stops on the trip. "We were all over the place," Mr. Schwarz said. "We got the greatest publicity in America."
 
An Industry in Decline
 If nothing else, the fare war has added some excitement to an industry that has been in decline for nearly two decades.
With roughly 70 percent of the market for scheduled bus service, Greyhound, a publicly traded company that operates in 48 states, has felt that decline particularly hard. Through the first six months of the year, its ridership was off more than 10 percent from the comparable period in 1991.
Greyhound, based in Dallas, reported earnings of $300,000 for the second quarter on revenues of $165.3 million, a lackluster report for which the company blamed the recession and the airline fare wars. Greyhound emerged in October after more than a year of operating under bankruptcy protection from its creditors, a status it sought after a violent strike.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Credit-Card Late Payment Fees Backed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court has blocked the attempt by Massachusetts to prevent out-of-state banks from collecting late payment fees on credit-card bills sent to state residents. The Federal Court of Appeals in Boston issued the ruling late Thursday.
The case, which involved the Greenwood Trust Company, a Delaware-based subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company that issues the Discover credit card, was closely watched by bankers. It could have set a precedent allowing other states to enforce local limits on late payment fees and other charges by out-of-state banks. 
 Massachusetts law does not allow late payment fees to be charged on loans. But Greenwood was charging a $10 monthly late-payment fee. Large banks that dominate the credit-card industry have ignored such state limits and contended that they were exempted under Federal law.
 
Fees Generate $1.1 Billion
 Limits on credit-card fees would be a severe blow to one of the banking industry's most profitable lines of business. Last year, annual fees plus other fees for late payments, bounced checks or exceeding credit limits produced revenues of $1.13 billion. That was nearly a third of the $3.5 billion of profit that banks earned from credit cards, according to the Nilson Report, a Santa Monica, Calif., newsletter that monitors the credit card industry.
The opinion by Judge Bruce Selya for the appeals court reversed a decision by a lower court last October. It had ruled that a 1980 Federal law allowing credit-card issuers to charge higher rates than would be allowed under state law did not encompass late fees. In the case of fees, the district court said, state limits would apply. Greenwood Trust, which has 100,000 customers in Massachusetts, quickly appealed that decision.
Judge Selya said that when Congress passed the 1980 law the meaning of the word "interest" was broader than just the numerical interest rate charged on the credit card. He noted other cases where it was found that "interest" also encompassed various kinds of fees charged by lenders.
Because 15 states prohibit late-payment fees, and more than half the states have some sort of limit on various fees charged on credit cards, lawyers considered the district court ruling an opportunity to file class-action lawsuits against other banks. By last February, more than a dozen lawsuits had been filed in four states against Greenwood and other banks that were charging late payment fees in states that did not allow the fees.
Beth Metzler, a spokeswoman for Greenwood, said the most recent Federal court decision "sets a strong precedent in our favor" that should apply to the other lawsuits. She said other lawsuits were pending, but declined to say how many or where.
Thomas Samoluk, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Attorney General, Scott Harshbarger, said state officials had not decided whether to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court.

HEADLINE: Consumers Reduce Debt

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Consumers reduced their outstanding debt for the fifth consecutive month in June, improving their balance sheets by $1.02 billion, the Federal Reserve reported today.
The decline translated into a 1.7 percent reduction at a seasonally adjusted annual rate and came entirely from a drop in auto loans, which fell by $2.8 billion in June. 
 The June decrease followed declines in debt of $893 million in May and a huge $3.58 billion drop in April. The April decrease, which translated into an annual rate of decline of 5.9 percent, was the biggest drop in a decade.
Both consumers and businesses have been reducing huge debt burdens built up during the bustling years of the 1980's. Consumer debt has declined 11 times in the last 14 months.
While this process is laying the groundwork for healthier economic expansion in the future, it has had a depressing effect on the economy over the last year because consumers busy paying off old debts have not been in the mood to increase spending.
 
Auto Loans Fall 12.9%
 Many economists believe that the debt restructuring may last for at least another year.
In June, outstanding automobile loans fell at a 12.9 percent annual rate after a 2.5 percent drop in May.
Revolving credit, which includes credit cards, rose by $850 million, or 4.2 percent at an annual rate, following a 1.5 percent May increase.
All other consumer loans not secured by real estate rose by $925 million, or 5.1 percent at an annual rate, following a decline of $667 million in May.
The various changes left total consumer debt not secured by real estate at $721.9 billion in June, the lowest total since April 1990.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Jobless Data Despite Intervention by Fed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday despite repeated intervention in the market by the Federal Reserve, as traders grew concerned that the Government's July employment data meant lower interest rates were on the way.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $350.30 an ounce, up $1.30 from late Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $351 an ounce, up $1.65. 
 The Labor Department said the unemployment rate fell slightly in July, to 7.7 percent from 7.8 percent in June. Though the report showed strong job growth last month, economists and currency traders said the figures were artificially enhanced by a temporary Federal jobs program.
Over all, they said, the report gave little hope that the economy was significantly improving. That gave rise to concern that the Fed would once again lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. Lower rates make the dollar less valuable compared with other currencies.
The central bank intervened at least three times in the market yesterday, buying dollars in an attempt to bolster the sagging currency. The first time, the intervention had its intended effect, but the Fed's later moves did not stop the dollar's slide, traders said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 127.95 Japanese yen, from 127.53 at Thursday's close. In London, it fell to 127.70 yen. In New York, one dollar bought 127.45 yen, down from 127.65 yen late Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9290, from $1.9080 late Thursday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9295, up from $1.9150 the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4680 German marks, down from 1.4775; 1.3150 Swiss francs, down from 1.3265; 4.9630 French francs, down from 4.9915; 1,111 Italian lire, down from 1,117.25, and 1.18375 Canadian dollars, down from 1.8505.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4660 German marks, down from 1.4815; 1.3145 Swiss francs, down from 1.3305; 4.9490 French francs, down from 5.0060; 1.6515 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6705; 1,108.75 Italian lire, down from 1,120.25, and 1.1825 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1858.
London gold prices increased to a late bid of $351.15 an ounce, up from $348.85 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to $351.10, up from $348.30 bid on Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold was up 97 cents to close at $349.97.

HEADLINE: Immigration Still Makes America What It Is

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Bar the Door" (Op-Ed, July 25) Daniel James tries to make a case for the closing of our borders to legal as well as undocumented immigration. The article represents a naive and uninformed approach to this complex situation. I am an immigration lawyer, and my insights and experience contradict Mr. James's conclusions.
Legal immigration is not the problem he suggests. In every generation there was a minority who felt the current wave of immigration would somehow ruin our country. In post-revolutionary America there was a wave of German immigration. The ethnic English Americans thought the Germans would destroy their society. Later the ethnic English and Germans thought the Irish immigrants would ruin the country. The nativists have always been wrong. 
 Between the Revolutionary War and the Civil War the population of the United States grew 10 times, primarily through immigration, and still we maintained our national character while growing economically, geographically and culturally.
Subsequent generations had their own minority opinion that the immigration of Italians, Jews, Chinese and many others would somehow hurt the United States. We took in these immigrants, and America prospered and grew in ways unimagined at the time. The grandchildren of these immigrants continue to make the United States the most vital society the world has known. These same people are bringing ideas of democracy, freedom, individual equality and fair play to their ethnic cousins all over the world, further increasing our country's security.
Mr. James's call to prevent legal immigration is ill advised and unworkable. Restrictions on legal immigration would only bar those most likely to comply with our laws. Now we are burdened with a complex body of immigration laws and regulations that accomplish little and discourage compliance. Economic realities create a magnet for poor undocumented workers. Mexicans and others who are lucky to earn $5 a day at home will come to a country where they can earn more than that per hour.
An enlightened United States Government policy would understand the realities of the situation and work to harness, legalize and tax these workers. This requires workable procedures. When it becomes more profitable to comply with the law than to flout it, employers and alien workers will comply.
 
HARRY A. DE MELL
New York, July 27, 1992

HEADLINE: Immigration Still Makes America What It Is;
Invisibility Counts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Bar the Door" (Op-Ed, July 25), Daniel James argues that illegal aliens "provided the tinder for rioting in Los Angeles and the Washington Heights section of New York City."
He continues: "About 45 percent of South-Central Los Angeles is Hispanic, the Census Bureau says, and many of the newcomers participated in the riots." 
 The day Mr. James's article appeared, the broadcast media identified street gangs as the main participants in the Los Angeles riots. It makes no sense that an illegal alien would engage in activities that could potentially bring him to the attention of the authorities -- any authority.
If asked, an illegal alien would agree that invisibility is an intrinsic part of his existence. Visibility via another illegal act could bring the unwanted attention of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Border Patrol, the National Guard, the Army or other real and imagined adversaries an illegal alien fears.
Mr. James's xenophobia provides a simplistic explanation of the Los Angeles riots. Illegal aliens are helpless scapegoats. Though subject to every kind of harassment, they are legally unable to claim discrimination, physical abuse, victimization by misguided legislation, unemployment or any of the other substantive causes that led to the events in Los Angeles. Mr. James should have the courage to examine the legal population of his own country.
 
LOURDES LOPEZ
New York, July 29, 1992

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PRATT AND HAMILTON REDUCTIONS IN PAY SEEN

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Executives at Pratt & Whitney and Hamilton Standard face pay cuts as the parent company, the United Technologies Corporation, looks to trim costs, company officials said yesterday. Pratt executives will earn 5 percent less through the end of next year, James G. O'Connor, the engine maker's president, said in a letter to employees. 
 "The continued recession in the commercial airline and general aviation industry and even deeper cuts in the defense budget are now pushing production levels even lower than we anticipated," Mr. O'Connor wrote.
Executives at Hamilton Standard, based in Windsor Locks, Conn., will forfeit a week's pay, Robert M. Kuhn, the president, said in a separate statement.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Quayle Says Clinton's Proposals For Economy Will Destroy Jobs

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Laying the groundwork for a crucial debate on fiscal policy, Vice President Dan Quayle sought to raise fears today that Gov. Bill Clinton's economic and environmental proposals would cost the country almost two million jobs a year.
In doing so, Mr. Quayle became the first member of the Bush Administration to quantify the Republican argument that Democratic proposals for new taxes and stricter Government regulation would break the back of an already fragile economy. But Mr. Quayle's speech to an economic research group in Columbus, Ohio, this morning also signified a grudging recognition within the Bush-Quayle campaign that the 1992 election would be played on what many strategists said was decidedly Democratic turf. 
After recent efforts to focus their campaign on President Bush's foreign policy achievements and Vice President Quayle's family values initiative, both men have now started to critique Mr. Clinton's economic policies with increasing specificity.
 
Making Jobs an Issue
 The tactic is perilous because of the Bush Administration's own lackluster economic record. Mr. Bush has presided over the slowest rate of job creation of any President since World War II.
 But aides to Mr. Quayle said they had accepted the notion that the election would be won or lost on economic issues, and that the Republicans must carry out a two-pronged strategy of blaming the recession on an obstructionist Democratic Congress while feeding fears about Mr. Clinton's policies.
 "Despite the Democrats' new rhetoric, the American people know the substance," Mr. Quayle said in an address to the meeting of Citizens for a Sound Economy, a Washington group that favors market-based solutions to economic problems. "They remember it well from that golden era known as the Carter-Mondale years, that time of double-digit inflation, double-digit unemployment and interest rates approaching 20 percent."
 George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, said Mr. Quayle's attempt to portray the Arkansas Governor as the ideological successor to President Jimmy Carter was predictable but ultimately would not succeed.
 
Democrats Welcome Issue
 Mr. Stephanopoulos also said the Clinton campaign welcomed any focus on economic issues. "If they want to debate about jobs, let's go," he said.
 Government figures show that the number of jobs in the country grew by seven-tenths of one percent during the three and a half years of the Bush Administration, through May. Job growth was 9.8 percent during President Ronald Reagan's second term, 6.3 percent during Mr. Reagan's first term, and 11.2 percent during Mr. Carter's Presidency.
 Mr. Quayle focused his speech on Mr. Clinton's calls for military cuts, a job training tax, a family leave policy and a health care plan. Citing an analysis conducted by the Republican staff of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, Mr. Quayle said those initiatives would result "in a loss of almost two million jobs in a year." His aides said later that the actual figure was 1.7 million jobs.
 Mr. Stephanopoulos accused Mr. Quayle of numerous distortions and omissions in calculating his job-loss estimate. Among other complaints, he said Mr. Quayle did not credit Mr. Clinton for the job growth that he said would result from a middle-class tax cut and an investment tax credit.
 He also said Mr. Quayle included in his estimate the effects of environmental proposals endorsed by Mr. Gore in his book, "Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit," some of which Mr. Clinton has not embraced.
 In Washington today, William K. Reilly, directory of the Environmental Protection Agency, broke ranks with the White House and said Mr. Gore was not an "environmental extremist."
 The Reuters news agency reported that Mr. Reilly said in a videotaped interview for "John McLaughlin's One on One" that he respected Mr. Gore's book and thought the Tennessee Senator would help Democrats win votes in California.
 The program is scheduled to be broadcast this weekend.

PUB-DATE: August 8, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 878 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton, on Bus Tour, Puts New Emphasis on Courage

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Up to now in his campaign for President, Gov. Bill Clinton has used the public's yearning for change as a way of scoring political points. Now, aware that the desire for change can sometimes be outweighed by the fear of it, Mr. Clinton is begun stressing a new theme: courage.
 As his eight-bus motorcade has wound its way along the Mississippi River from Missouri to Minnesota, Mr. Clinton has exhorted crowds to have the fortitude to accept changes and to resist Republican attempts to portray him and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, as "two young guys with strange ideas." 
This country has been around for 200 years because at every pivotal point in our history, we have had the courage to change," Mr. Clinton said at a rally in downtown Minneapolis that ended his three-day bus tour in the upper Middle West.
 The comment was typical of the theme the Democratic nominee struck throughout his five-state tour. It is a message that has cropped up in speeches in good-sized Iowa cities like Bettendorf and Cedar Rapids, and at smaller towns like Elkader, where the candidates spoke to evening visitors to the Clayton County Fair, with a corn field rising on a hill behind them as a backdrop.
 But in making the case for accepting the risk of change, Mr. Clinton seldom tells his crowds what those risks might be, and what, if any, sacrifices they might entail.
 
Gain, but No Pain
 Indeed, except for his appearance at a high school in East St. Louis, Ill., where he told an all-black audience that the poor would have to shoulder a measure of responsibility for alleviating their own plight, Mr. Clinton did little but promise a golden future achieved without pain.
 The shift in Mr. Clinton's basic appeal seems to be an attempt to counter the Republican barrage that is painting the Democratic ticket as at best untried and at worst as disguising a traditional Democratic "tax and spend" program behind the oratory of change.
 "Our opponents in this race, you know what they're going to say," Mr. Clinton said at a morning rally on the banks of the Black River, a tributary of the Mississippi in La Crosse. "They're going to say Clinton and Gore are rookies; they're just two young fellows with a lot of strange ideas and they can make things worse."
 President Bush, in campaign commercials that began this week and in public appearances in New York, Colorado Springs and at a press conference in Washington today, has mounted an offensive against the notion of change for its own sake. In his commercial, the President stares intently into the camera and says he agrees that change is necessary but adds, "Change must be guided by principles."
 Today, Mr. Bush said that after the Republican National Convention "you're going to see hard-hitting attacks that are going to fairly define his positions."
 Aides to Mr. Clinton say his recent comments are not new, but they acknowledge that he is emphasizing the message more forcefully on his bus tour.
 "Change requires some risk and therefore it is somewhat harder to vote for Bill Clinton than it is to vote for George Bush," Dee Dee Myers, the Clinton campaign's press secretary said Thursday outside a metal works factory in Davenport, Iowa.
 Ms. Myers added: "George Bush is trying to make the campaign one that's about who do you trust. If he wants to talk about change he's not very credible and Bill Clinton is trying to redefine trust."
 Yet, as he talks of change and of the fortitude needed to take risks, Mr. Clinton seems to be proffering dual messages: one for largely black audiences and the other for predominantly white ones.
 "If Al Gore and Bill Clinton go to Washington to the White House, our job is to create opportunity," Mr. Clinton said at East St. Louis High School. "Your job is to come up with the responsibility to seize that opportunity and make it work and to find out exactly how to win in this global economy."
 As Mr. Clinton moved up the Mississippi Valley, visiting small towns with overwhelmingly white populations, he gave no hint of any of the kinds of sacrifices or shifts in attitudes that would be asked of those voters.
 He has told crowds in this primarily agricultural region that he does not support cutting farm subsidies, unless the nation's major trading partners also reduce theirs. After listing a number of costly programs that would help middle-class families, including the establishment of a plan to provide basic health insurance, Mr. Clinton said he would pay for them by reining in the nation's health-care costs, increasing taxes on the very rich, shifting money from the military budget and reducing the Federal work force by 100,000 people through attrition.
 When asked what changes a Clinton Presidency might ask voters to accept, Ms. Myers mentioned welfare reform. When asked what else, she mentioned corporations' being asked to pay top executives less money, parents' being asked to become more involved in their children's education and teachers' beingasked to take competency examinations, though she quickly added that Mr. Clinton was not advocating that as Governmental policy.
 Indeed, save for welfare reform, none of the items she listed involved Government policy.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
OSKAR KOKOSCHKA LETTERS: 1905-1976, selected by Olda Kokoschka and Alfred Marnau. (Thames and Hudson, $40.) The great Expressionist shows himself an uninhibited and gifted writer, much concerned with the state of civilization; also a profound egotist, not less concerned with his love life.
THE SELECTED LETTERS OF BERTRAND RUSSELL. Volume One: The Private Years, 1884-1914, edited by Nicholas Griffin. (Houghton Mifflin, $35.) Russell shines here first as lover (especially of Lady Ottoline Morrell), only secondarily as the mathematical philosopher and logician.
THE RISE OF GOSPEL BLUES: The Music of Thomas Andrew Dorsey in the Urban Church, by Michael W. Harris. (Oxford University, $29.95.) How a preacher's son transported blues rhythms and showmanship into the black churches in the 1930's.
EVENING CHATS IN BEIJING: Probing China's Predicament, by Perry Link. (Norton, $24.95.) A cheerless survey of today's China as seen in conversation with its despairing intellectuals.
TURNING BACK THE SUN, by Colin Thubron. (Edward Burlingame/HarperCollins, $20.) Racism, exile, memory and lost identity are the running themes in this thoughtful novel, set in a nameless outback where a disease is turning white people brown.
AFTER MOONDOG, by Jane Shapiro. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) A first novel about a smart, young New Jersey couple who end their marriage and find that without it, nothing coheres.
DOWN FROM TROY: A Doctor Comes of Age, by Richard Selzer. (Morrow, $20.) An arresting, idiosyncratic, lyrical memoir of Troy, N.Y., by a man whose parents battled for his soul, one wanting a doctor, the other an artist; both got what they wanted.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 27; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: Notes With Pleasure

 BODY:

Turning Back to the Classics
Robertson Davies urges us to turn, and turn again, to the great books we first encountered in our youth, in this excerpt from a talk included in "The Tanner Lectures on Human Values: Volume 13, 1992," edited by Grethe B. Peterson (University of Utah). 
 The great sin . . . is to assume that something that has been read once has been read forever. As a very simple example I mention Thackeray's "Vanity Fair." People are expected to read it during their university years. But you are mistaken if you think you read Thackeray's book then; you read a lesser book of your own. It should be read again when you are 36, which is the age of Thackeray when he wrote it. It should be read for a third time when you are 56, 66, 76, in order to see how Thackeray's irony stands up to your own experience of life. Perhaps you will not read every page in these later years, but you really should take another look at a great book, in order to find out how great it is, or how great it has remained, to you. You see, Thackeray was an artist, and artists deserve this kind of careful observation. We must not gobble their work, like chocolates, or olives, or anchovies, and think we know it forever. Nobody ever reads the same book twice.
 
The Uses of Silence
Many Indian tribes were as eloquent in their use of silence as in their oratory, according to Joel Sherzer in an essay in "America in 1492: The World of the Indian Peoples Before the Arrival of Columbus," edited by Alvin M. Josephy Jr. (Knopf).
 
While speaking well and often for long periods of time was a much-noted feature of Native American life, it contrasted strikingly with another frequent use of language, especially in North America: the selective absence of speech -- silence and laconic pithiness. Apaches and other groups living in the present-day U.S. Southwest observed silence in certain moments -- when meeting strangers, during the initial stages of courtship, between relatives and friends after a long period of separation, in response to shouted insults and criticism, in the company of someone whose spouse or kinsman had just died and during the performance of a curing ritual. In addition, many North American Indians, including the Apaches, were celebrated for their pithy, laconic humor. . . . The stereotype of the silent Indian is clearly incorrect and is no doubt based in part on a misunderstanding of Native American rules of verbal and nonverbal etiquette.
 
Writing to Rediscover the World
 Writers, Andrei Bitov suggests, often discover what they know about the world only by writing it down. This is from his memoir "A Captive of the Caucasus" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).
 
Living prose breaks through your personal time and anticipates your experience in many ways. Not only is the new book your life while you're writing it, not only is it the previous life experience that's included in it, but it's also your fate, your future. If you were merely narrating for the reader, it would be sheer boredom, and when you're bored, what can you write? The fact is that if a man writes, he himself comes to know things he didn't know before. Writing is his method of cognition. Geniuses, perhaps, come to know things that no one knew before them. Others rediscover: for themselves, for people like them, for their time. Strictly speaking, a man gives the world nothing new. When he suddenly discovers that there are things in this world he didn't know before, he believes they're new . . . but if he has found them, they already existed. He just didn't know it. New and old do not exist in the world, because everything in it is now.
 
The Velvet No
 The art of the rejection slip, used to return unwanted manuscripts to writers, may have reached its apex with one cited by the British scholar Glyn Daniel in a collection of his columns, "Writing for Antiquity: An Anthology of Editorials From Antiquity" (Thames and Hudson).
 
We have never had a formal rejection slip or letter to send out week after week to the many contributors who kindly send in notes or articles for consideration, and for whose work we sadly cannot or gladly do not want to find space, but we are encouraged to draft one, inspired by that used by the editors of a Chinese economics journal, and referred to in The Times Diary, 9 July 1982:
"We have read your manuscript with boundless delight. If we were to publish your paper it would be impossible for us to publish any work of a lower standard. As it is unthinkable that, in the next thousand years, we shall see its equal, we are, to our regret, compelled to return your divine composition, and to beg you a thousand times to overlook our short sight and timidity."
 
Why We Need Angry Gourmets
 Without short-tempered connoisseurs of cuisine, Waverley Root argues, we'd be perpetually at the mercy of the second-rate. This is from "The Food of France" (Vintage, paper).
 
The Frenchman is an individualist. On its reverse side (every virtue is accompanied by its inseparable vices) this may make him selfish and an egotist. He is thus enabled to be unforgiving if he is badly served. His favorite restaurant may have produced for him a thousand superb meals one after the other, but let the thousand and first be unsatisfactory and he rises in wrath to denounce incompetence. I would rather he did not so when I am present, but I am glad that France is full of his kind to keep French cooks up to snuff. We all know what happens to the perfect little restaurant that is discovered by tourists not educated by a lifetime of exposure to French food to the detection of minor imperfections. When it discovers that it can fill its tables quite as readily without taking nearly as many pains in the kitchen . . . it proceeds, naturally enough, to take less pains in the kitchen. We need the angry gourmet to keep standards up.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Design That Taps Into the 'Informational City'

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
The financial trading firm of D. E. Shaw & Company cannot be accused of asserting too high an urban profile. Lodged on the top two floors of a skyscraper on West 45th Street in midtown Manhattan, the company's new offices are invisible from the street. Inside, it is the city that fades from sight. Though most of the windows command stunning skyline views, this vista is highly selective. It offers no sign of the social disarray that the phrase "urban America" has conjured up in recent months. Yet Steven Holl, who earlier this year received an award from the American Institute of Architects for his design of the Shaw offices, has something important to say about the links between offices and cities. He shows that even an office interior can enlarge our picture of the social and economic forces at work in the city today.
Firms like D. E. Shaw are only partly located in New York. They conduct their business in what Manuel Castells, a professor of planning at the University of California at Berkeley, calls the "informational city" -- the international network of electronic communications that keeps the global economy humming. The "streets" of this city have no potholes. They are paved not with asphalt but with telephone lines and radio waves that stretch between cities and leap across national borders. Plugged into this grid by faxes and modems, executives may have stronger economic and social ties to offices halfway around the world than to crumbling communities on their doorsteps. 
 D. E. Shaw operates almost around the clock, though for much of that time the firm's windowless, hexagonal trading room is unattended by human hands. Machines hold down the fort. Silently, with lights flickering, batteries of computers go about their programmed business, responding to worldwide fluctuations in market values. These machines are the traffic lights of the informational city. Their codes manage the flow of symbols that can be translated by other programs into investments, profits, castles in Spain and skyscrapers in mid-Manhattan.
Steven Holl has translated that flow into design: a work place that evokes the floating, abstract realm in which his client operates. Right at the entrance, Mr. Holl lets us know that we are leaving familiar ground. His reception area offers no ficus trees, no sectional sofas, no corporate art on the walls, no plunging skyline views. Instead, we are ushered into a luminous void: a cube of space, two stories tall, suffused with unearthly light.
The source of the light is hidden. A pale yellow-green accented with blushes of blue and red, it radiates from rectangular notches and recesses cut into the cube's white walls. Like stained glass windows, but without the glass, these luminous panels decompose the walls' solid boundaries. They create the effect of a room pitched halfway between the planes of energy and matter.
Mr. Holl achieves this ethereal effect with remarkable economy of means. He and his project architect, Thomas Jenkinson, have applied bright fluorescent light to the back and bottom surfaces of the rectangular openings, where it is hidden from the eye. A mix of natural and fluorescent light bounces the color onto neutral white walls. Black vinyl floor tiles pick up the reflections, deepening the illusion of dissolving space. The reception area doubles as a central atrium for the two-floor office complex. Corridors lead off to the trading room, a conference room and private offices. Mr. Holl has furnished these rooms handsomely with custom-designed furniture, but, working within a restricted budget, he has concentrated his resources on that grand opening gesture. He has even given it a name -- Spatial Color Reflection -- as though it were a formalist sculpture.
Yet like the work of James Turrell, which they closely resemble, Mr. Holl's panels of light offer more than visually appealing forms. They produce richly evocative content. Poised between the solid and the immaterial, they function metaphorically as windows into the electronic realm where wealth is transformed into abstract blips on a computer screen. The symbolism is not literal here. Mr. Holl's design is not meant to remind us of video terminals. Rather, it offers a poetic interpretation of what Manuel Castells calls "the space of flows" -- the global communications channels through which money sloshes around the world, from New York to Tokyo, Singapore to London.
Of course, for those who are not plugged into the flow, there's no comfort in the idea that wealth is an abstraction. Nor is there anything abstract about the economic barriers that insulate enclaves of plenty from the ravages of inner-city life. Notwithstanding a low budget, Mr. Holl has made a work of art from, and about, the cash flow of the haves. Is this something to applaud at a time when the national conscience is rewakening to the plight of the have-nots?
Yes, if we value art that gives us a clearer picture of the way the world works. And if we've had it up to the skyline with designs that only blur that picture, or paint a false one: nostalgic buildings and retro interiors that blind us to the conditions in which cities find themselves. The "informational city" has produced a crisis for cities like New York. It has drained away economic vitality and helped to widen the gap between rich and poor. Obviously, design cannot solve this crisis. It can't take the place of public policies that might more effectively integrate the global economy with local needs and resources. But design can help to prevent us from slipping into escapism. It can set a creative example.
Mr. Holl's design takes the Shaw offices to a place as novel as the information technology that paid to build them. When we walk in the door of D. E. Shaw, we know we're not in 1960's Manhattan or Colonial New England. For that matter, we've left even much of present-day New York far below on the ground. Standing inside the Holl atrium, we've got our head in the clouds and our feet firmly planted on solid air.

HEADLINE: WHY PARIS WORKS

 BODY:
According to your article, Paris "works" because it receives lavish subsidies from the French Government and because it excludes the poor, who are let into the city only to sweep its streets (by hand!) and to collect its garbage. So what else is new? Have you been to Beverly Hills, Palm Beach or similar affluent enclaves lately? Have you noticed their immaculate streets, beautiful landscaping and low crime rate? Even in our much maligned Manhattan, Park Avenue and Sutton Place compare favorably with any Parisian boulevard.
The article made passing reference to ordinary French workers and immigrants who live in the stark high-rise squalor of the suburbs. Their growing problems of drugs, crime and unemployment sound a lot like those of our American cities. The only difference is that the French have ghettoized their suburbs instead of their cities. 
 I would prefer to read an article about how to make cities work for everyone, rich and poor, native and immigrant, black and white.
 
MADALYN MARGOLES
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Can Wal-Mart Keep Growing at Breakneck Speed?

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Investors have long wondered when some air would start to leak from the amazingly buoyant shares of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., one of the great growth stocks of the last decade.
The market value of the giant discount retailer doubled in 1991 as the stock climbed to an all-time high of $59.875 a share by Jan. 2 this year, from $1.33 a share 10 years earlier. 
 Yet the stock then slumped to below $51 in a period when investors were unloading growth stocks of many varieties. The illness of Wal-Mart's founder, Sam Walton, who died April 5 at age 74, added more uncertainty.
After rising from the backwoods of Arkansas to become the nation's biggest retailer in less than 30 years, has Wal-Mart's bloom begun to fade?
Many retailing analysts and consultants are saying no emphatically. They see growth prospects so strong that Wal-Mart has a shot at dethroning the century-old oil giant, Exxon, within a year as the company with the highest stock-market value in the nation, probably at more than $80 billion. Exxon stands at $79 billion, Philip Morris at $74 billion and Wal-Mart, which closed at $57.375 on Friday, at $66 billion.
"We're a believer that Wal-Mart will reach $200 billion in sales by the end of this decade," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, senior retailing analyst at Salomon Brothers. Mr. Feiner projects sales this year at $55 billion, and $68 billion in 1993.
Wal-Mart appears to be running on all cylinders. Sales in stores open for at least a year rose 12 percent in the six months ended July 31, matching the highest yearly rate since 1986. Operating expenses, including wages and advertising, fell to 15.3 percent of sales last year, the lowest ever for Wal-Mart and far below comparable efficiency readings at rivals K Mart and Sears, Roebuck; the latter has a higher mix of big-ticket goods that require more employee time. Wal-Mart's net income and sales per employee have also risen strongly.
Return on investment was a staggering 30 percent in the last fiscal year, which ended Jan. 31, a slight decline but still remarkable for a company of Wal-Mart's size and more than double the average returns for the Standard & Poor's 500. In spite of a weak economy, Wal-Mart's sales soared by 26 percent in the six months ended in July, compared with a gain of 8.5 percent for K Mart and a decline of 0.6 percent at Sears.
How can Wal-Mart keep growing at this pace through the decade? One answer is that its nimble distribution system has started to penetrate high-population areas in California and the Northeast, as well as Mexico.
Another reason is Wal-Mart's entry into the $300 billion supermarket business through its 12 new Wal-Mart Supercenters, whose wares include soda, dog food and other grocery staples under a private label, Sam's American Choice. A large food distribution center is under construction in Arkansas to support as many as 90 Supercenters. Analysts expect 400 Supercenters by 1996.
The other big growth engine for Wal-Mart is Sam's Wholesale Clubs. Sales in the division, begun in 1983, rose 43 percent last year, to more than $9 billion. The stores, copied by Sam Walton from the Price Company, stock 3,500 items, including computers and birthday cakes. Wal-Mart has 233 of the stores, up from 184 a year ago, and dominates that segment of retailing. Sales rose 31 percent in the six months ended in July, to $5.6 billion.
"We've got more opportunity ahead of us than anything we've ever experienced," said David D. Glass, Wal-Mart's president and chief executive, in a recent interview. "All we've got to do is be smart enough and capable enough to capitalize on it."
For all its prospects, Wal-Mart faces threats from rivals that have copied its discount formula in retailing niches, such as Home Depot in building supplies. And K Mart, Sam Walton's model for the original Wal-Marts, has reaped gains from a $3 billion renovation campaign begun three years ago and a broader move into specialty stores in sporting goods and building supplies, warehouse clubs, and discount stores for drugs, books and office supplies. K Mart's head of investor relations, Orren Knauer, said the Michigan-based retailer's biggest sales gains this year have come in the South, where it battles Wal-Mart more than in any other region.
Yet Wal-Mart retains many advantages, analysts said. Its everyday-low-price strategy has convinced many customers that Wal-Mart does have low prices. The strategy also eliminates periodic sales, which lowers advertising and labor costs.
The $500 million Wal-Mart added to employee profit-sharing accounts since 1986, or 9 percent of net income, has given thousands of hourly paid workers with more than 10 years at the company accounts valued at more than $100,000. Eighty percent of the money was invested in Wal-Mart stock. K Mart is experimenting with a similar plan. Sears has put more than $400 million into an employee profit-sharing plan since 1986.
Wal-Mart's shares, up 9 percent since the low point in April, should add 20 percent more in the next year, said Daniel D. Barry, retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch. Mr. Barry upgraded his Wal-Mart rating to a "buy" last Wednesday, the day before the company announced a sales surge of 28 percent in July from a year earlier.
Wal-Mart shares are pricey, at 38 times earnings and twice the level of the S.& P. 500 index. But sales should rise at a faster rate for the rest of the year, Mr. Barry said, and investors generally will favor growth stocks again in a sluggish economy.

HEADLINE: At Work;
While the Men Wait at Home

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Layoffs are mounting at such a relentless pace this summer that the once securely employed may wonder who put the work force abacus in the hands of the devil. Nervous employees who really want to stare fear in the face should watch the documentary "Fast Food Women" tomorrow night (check local listings) on the public television series "P.O.V." Anne Lewis Johnson's film on women forced by chance and necessity into low-paying, no-benefits jobs in the fast-food industry is a cautionary tale in downward mobility.
It may be going too far to say that Eastern Kentucky, one of the most chronically impoverished regions of the country, could be a bellwether for the American economy in general. But on the topic of jobs, the area is much like many elsewhere in the nation, devastated by the decline of an industry -- coal -- and the consequent reverberations throughout communities and families. 
 In Whitesburg, the small town where Ms. Johnson lives and works, and, in 1989, did most of the filming of "Fast Food Women," the waning of the coal industry has led to 40 to 50 percent unemployment. The jobs paid coal miners, almost always men, salaries of $12 to $17 an hour, depending on whether they worked in union or nonunion mines, as well as medical, vacation and retirement benefits.
The men, naturally enough, want, and wait for, work that allows them to support their families at the level they had come to enjoy. The wives have picked up the pieces.
"We had everything," Sereda Collier, a fast-food cook whose husband was laid off after 17 years in the mines, tells the off-camera interviewer. "Well, we didn't have everything," she laughs. Her uniform includes a trompe l'oeil-hamburger hat. "But he had a good job." Jobs are in the local service economy, which in Appalachia, as in many post-industrial regions, is not dominated by high- or even medium-paid consulting or other "knowledge work" but by fast food.
"Ninety-five percent of the applications I take in are female," says Marion Clark, co-owner and manager of the local branch of the Druthers restaurant chain. Indeed, few men, are in evidence in Mr. Clark's restaurant, or in the McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken or Pizza Hut outlets where Ms. Johnson took her videocamera.
As any woman knows, the absence of men in a workplace is one of the danger signs of low wages, and, indeed, the women's pay ranged at the time of filming from the waiter's minimum wage of $2.05 an hour plus tips to 10 or 15 cents over the standard minimum wage of $3.35. The current range, after an increase in 1990, is $2.13 an hour plus tips to $4.25 an hour.
Like most fast-food industry jobs, these pay no benefits. One company spokesman explains that the teen-agers who generally work behind a fast-food counter aren't looking for a pension and other frills. "Susie is 16 years old. Her father works in the coal mine," says Mike Super, the human resources manager at Druthers' corporate office in Louisville, referring to an archetypal teen-ager. "Susie doesn't need benefits."
Nor, apparently, are teen-agers looking for excitement, at least at work. Industry efficiency experts have reduced the tasks of making fast-food into irreducible elements. The work is hard, repetitive and, true to its name, fast. It presents employees with few challenges and little hope for advancement, financially or otherwise. "We are not looking for creativity as much..." one Druthers executive acknowledges, looking over at a colleague who finishes his thought: "...as looking for somebody that would be more content with following procedures and practices and getting their sense of achievement from an area other than being creative about it."
It is a strength of the film that Ms. Johnson doesn't turn the company representatives into villains or the women into superheroes. But it is impossible to watch the women's tired testimony without wondering about the social costs of a cheap burger.
Not one of the film's fast-food women is making more than 25 cents over the current minimum wage. Nellie Kincer had to leave her long-time cooking job at Kentucky Fried Chicken to have an operation she paid for. She earns about $4.50 an hour and puzzles on camera about how she will manage in old age with only her Social Security "benefits." Her children are on their own but she is helping support her elderly parents. After nine years at Druthers, Sereda Collier is supporting her family on roughly $4.40 an hour. The moment her husband gets a job, she says, she's gone.
 
 
A FILM MAKER FROM COAL COUNTRY
 Anne Lewis Johnson didn't have to look far for the topic of her documentary film "Fast Food Women." One of the fast-food restaurants she filmed was across the street from her office at Appalshop, a filmmaker's collective in Whitesburg, Ky. "We began noticing that the people working at fast-food restaurants were not kids," she said in an interview last week.
She was given access to restaurants for filming, she thinks, because they are owned by local franchisees and because she and Appalshop -- the name is condensed from Appalachian Workshop -- are fixtures in Whitesburg. "I wasn't an outsider looking in," she said. "They had seen our work."
Ms. Lewis has been a film- and video-maker for almost 20 years, much of it "in the coal fields." She was an associate director on "Harlan County U.S.A.," the acclaimed film of a miner's strike, and has won awards for her own work, which includes "On Our Own Land," about strip mining, and, with Mimi Pickering, "Chemical Valley," about a toxic waste spill near Charleston, W.Va.
She allows the women in the film to speak for themselves, without narration. That, to some degree, obscures her own voice, which, if quiet, is nevertheless firm. She has been asked how companies can pay their workers more without having to charge more for a burger. She points out that the burgers have hidden costs because most of the women can't make it without government benefits. "I help pay for food stamps and health care," she said. "They are charging me more."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
E.D.S. Reaches for Japan

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
The Electronic Data Systems Corporation is the world's biggest provider of computer services, with $7 billion in sales last year, and by the year 2000 it wants to be a truly global company, leading in all major markets.
By that measure, E.D.S. has to move quickly in Europe and Asia. Eighty percent of its sales last year were in North America, with half of that coming from its parent, General Motors. By contrast, the worldwide market now produces 40 percent of sales in North America and 30 percent each in Europe and Asia. 
 Dallas-based E.D.S. closed in on the European front-runners -- Cap Gemini Sogeti of France, International Business Machines and Andersen Consulting -- with its acquisition last year of SD-Scicon of Geneva.
But Asia, particularly Japan, has been hard to penetrate. Big computer and telecommunications hardware companies like NTT, Hitachi, Fujitsu and I.B.M.-Japan dominate.
"I.B.M. has been successful in Japan, but it took them almost 40 years," said Gary J. Fernandes, 48, senior vice president and head of E.D.S.'s global acquisitions. "Our challenge is to make the same penetration as I.B.M. in Japan, but in one-tenth of the time."
E.D.S. acquired a 19.9 percent stake in Japan System K.K. last February for about $30 million, giving it a bridge to the company's 700 software programmers and systems engineers. Japan System was reeling from falling orders and, after losing more than $40 million on revenues of $80 million, was desperate for cash.
That is usually the case when a Japanese computer company consents to partial American ownership, said Dan Schwartz, publisher of the Japan M&A Reporter and managing director of Ulmer Brothers Inc., a New York investment firm.
He and others expect E.D.S. eventually to increase its stake in Japan System above 50 percent. E.D.S. has rarely been a passive investor. Mr. Fernandes declined to comment, but said that E.D.S. wants more deals in Japan. Thanks to the slumping Japanese economy, E.D.S. may become a welcome suitor.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
There's Growth, But Not Nearly Enough of It

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Anemia is defined in the dictionary as "lack of vigor or vitality; lifelessness."
That is not a bad definition of the current economic picture. And so it was admirably honest when George Bush told a news conference Friday that the economy "has been anemically growing." 
 To Mr. Bush, of course, the important word in that sentence was "growing." As he said earlier in the week: "The American people think we're in recession and we're not. We've had four quarters of positive growth. Now how did they get that impression?" Mr. Bush's answer was that we in the press keep harping on the bad news.
Or as Donald Kendall, the former Pepsico chairman and now a Republican Party official, said after meeting with Mr. Bush, "Our economy is not in a disaster." Mr. Bush's popularity would improve, he said, "if you in the media start telling the truth."
It is fun to beat up on the press, but if Mr. Bush wants to search out somebody putting out all those bad reports he might start in his own Administration, among the economists who count such things. He might look at the Commerce Department's index of coincident indicators.
He is lucky that index doesn't get the publicity of its cousin, the index of leading indicators, which is supposed to be an economic crystal ball. The coincident one is designed only to describe the present, and seems boring to most reporters. So there was little attention when it was reported that the index of coincident indicators fell in June to its lowest level since July 1987. By that measure of economic activity, there has been no recovery at all.
Now, let's tell the truth, as Mr. Kendall requests. There are reasons not to like those numbers. For reasons that make sense to some but not all statisticians, the Government every month applies a "trend adjustment" factor to the index, automatically lowering it. So if all of the coincident indicators were unchanged in a month, the index would nonetheless drop. Without the trend adjustments, the index bottomed in March 1991, and has done almost nothing since then.
That probably is a fairer picture of the economy, and is one reason trend adjustments have become very controversial within the Commerce Department, and may be dropped next year.
Arguments over statistics are not fascinating stuff, but it is such statistics that must be relied upon in describing the economy. To Mr. Bush, the July employment report was "fairly good news," but it did not show a vibrant private economy. The increase in employment was largely due to hiring by local governments for federally funded summer job programs.
In other words, fiscal policy is helping the economy, while lower interest rates have yet to produce the expected growth. Unfortunately, the huge budget deficits make additional fiscal stimulus difficult. And that is an important reason why Mr. Bush is right when he argues that the economy is growing, but without much vigor or vitality.
