HEADLINE: Patching Up L.A. -- A Corporate Blueprint

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The headquarters of Rebuild Los Angeles, the nonprofit group established after last spring's riots to bring jobs and hope to the city's poorest neighborhoods, is a one-story brick building set between the gleaming corporate towers of downtown and the slums just a few blocks to the south. Casting wary glances in both directions from his office there, Peter V. Ueberroth is issuing perhaps the most direct challenge yet to the business world to tackle the problems of the inner city.
The strategy he is pursuing as the group's chairman is as risky as it is ambitious. Mr. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, said he is counting on considerable help from residents of the community and from the state and Federal governments. But his thrust is clearly to prove that companies, motivated not solely by civic duty but also by cold profit-and-loss calculations, can revive urban America in a way that governments by themselves have failed to do. 
 He sees companies changing the nature of this city's neglected neighborhoods quickly and permanently by opening stores in areas they have shunned, by helping to make bank financing and insurance available, by funding job training and education programs. But perhaps most important, he aims to motivate hundreds of companies to establish small operations in the inner city instead of persuading just a few corporations to set up large plants.
These steps, he said, are critical to achieving his primary goal: the creation of 57,000 permanent new jobs over the next five years in the poorest areas, enough to reduce unemployment to the teens from levels now as high as 60 percent in some of the riot-torn and other neighborhoods.
If he can persuade corporations to heed his call, then their efforts, Mr. Ueberroth insists, can become a blueprint for urban renewal nationwide. Although there have been previous efforts around the country to bring together government, the community and businesses to tackle social problems, none has had the scale or stature of R.L.A. or relied so heavily on the business side. "Frankly, America doesn't solve problems unless it's done by the private sector," said Mr. Ueberroth.
 
Some Who've Joined
 A number of influential companies -- including Hughes Aircraft, the Vons Companies, Mattel and Pioneer Electronics -- have signed on with various degrees of commitment. And Mr. Ueberroth speaks daily with some of the scores of other companies around the country that he says are intrigued by the argument that it is simply good business to operate and create jobs in neglected urban areas.
"I don't think there's a smart, well-managed business that operates in California that hasn't figured out that continued decay in the inner city is real bad for business," Mr. Ueberroth said.
Mr. Ueberroth's initial efforts have been greeted with skepticism and occasional hostility from some community groups and politicians. But as he has scored some successes and repeated endlessly his belief that improvement will involve hundreds of small victories rather than a few headline-grabbing deals, he is gaining a grudging respect even from his critics. And if, as he promises, there are dozens more companies lining up to take part in the effort, he could bring real change to at least some of the city's poorest districts.
"This is a multifaceted program over a long period of time being orchestrated by very creative leadership," said C. Michael Armstrong, chairman of Hughes Aircraft. And the signal effort to persuade companies nationwide to each set up a small inner-city operation, he remarked, "is do-able from the corporate and business world perspective, and it can be successful from the city's point of view."
The group's work has involved considerable effort from Mayor Tom Bradley's administration, as well as community leaders and business executives. But there is no question that Mr. Ueberroth -- who developed an almost mythical reputation here for getting things done when he organized the 1984 Summer Olympics -- is the point man.
He is in many ways an unlikely savior for the inner city. A white Republican from suburban Laguna Beach, the 55-year-old Mr. Ueberroth made a fortune building and then selling a travel business.
He has most recently been a partner in an investment group that has made one major deal, the purchase of HAL Inc., the troubled parent of Hawaiian Airlines. When he was asked by Mayor Bradley and Gov. Pete Wilson to found and lead R.L.A. in early May, he had just finished a report at Governor Wilson's request documenting California's declining economic competitiveness.
 
A Need for Initiative
 To his many critics in Los Angeles political and civic circles, Mr. Ueberroth's approach to running R.L.A. is simply a rehashing of the longstanding -- and in their view, discredited -- conservative formula allowing free-market forces to work their miracles.
"In principle, I have difficulty with the idea of the private sector solving the problems of South Central Los Angeles," said James Johnson, director of the Center for the Study of Urban Poverty at the University of California at Los Angeles. "What is needed in South Central is a WPA-type of initiative where job training is tied to the rebuilding of the community's infrastucture, and only the public sector can do that."
But Mr. Ueberroth -- who serves without pay, has put all his business activities on hold and routinely puts in 14-hour days for R.L.A. -- remains stubbornly optimistic as he criss-crosses the city listening to any community leader with an idea or a request. "It's 80 percent of the time banging your head against the wall," he said, "but there are some signs the wall is beginning to crumble."
Still, the success of R.L.A. is far from assured. Congress and the Bush Administration have moved slowly on their promises to provide significant aid to Los Angeles. And the state government has been so consumed with its fiscal woes that it has barely addressed the needs of Los Angeles.
With the California economy mired in recession and corporations nationwide cutting back, it also remains unclear how many companies will be willing to take part in the kinds of initiatives Mr. Ueberroth is seeking.
The history of corporate involvement in solving urban America's problems is checkered. Some companies, like the Xerox Corporation, have won high marks for their longstanding efforts to be important contributors to the communities in which they do business. Scores of companies nationwide give manpower and money to troubled urban school systems. In Miami, businesses and civic leaders have banded together to create the influential Miami Coalition for a Drug-Free Community.
Mr. Ueberroth argues that even companies that ignore poor and minority customers as a market cannot ignore the social upheaval, and accompanying economic dislocation, that occurs when long-simmering grievances boil over, as they did in Los Angeles in late April.
But many companies have never taken any steps other than routine charitable donations. Among those that have made an effort, there has often been a lack of community and government support or a decline in the company's internal interest, leading to projects that wither or fail. There have also been few efforts to combat discriminatory business practices like insurance redlining. Making insurance available to small businesses that need it is among Mr. Ueberroth's top priorities.
Mr. Ueberroth said he is determined to involve the community in R.L.A., and his program has won reluctant praise from some black, Hispanic and Asian-American leaders who applaud its focus on jobs. There have been concrete, if preliminary, signs that businesses around the country are thinking the same way.
"Companies now feel that they have to become involved in community and societal problems because they have to solve some of them in order to achieve their business goals," said Edmund Burke, the director of the Center for Corporate-Community Relations at Boston College. "If Peter Ueberroth stays away from the social responsibility part of the argument -- because that doesn't help -- he'll find companies more receptive to looking at this as an issue of survival for them."
One such company is Vons, the largest supermarket chain in Southern California. Vons announced in late July that, after decades of largely avoiding doing business in inner-city Los Angeles, it would embark on an accelerated plan to open as many as 12 stores in poor neighborhoods in the next few years. The new stores will create at least 2,000 permanent new jobs, which Vons pledged would be filled largely by local residents.
Vons's chairman, Roger E. Stangeland, said the plan had its roots in a company analysis done late last year in which the chain concluded that by avoiding the inner city it had been passing up an opportunity to serve more than 2 million consumers who had long complained about the lack of local supermarkets. Immediately after the riots, Mr. Stangeland said he met with Mr. Ueberroth seeking guidance from R.L.A. on how Vons could help, and he subsequently "turned up the burners" on the idea of expanding into the poor neighborhoods.
"We had, over many years, just found it easy to drift out of the neglected areas," said Mr. Stangeland. "Shame on us. But we're in the process of acknowledging that we missed an opportunity and we're going about fixing it."
The company's primary motivation, Mr. Stangeland said, was to increase its profits at a time when competition among supermarkets in the region is intense and there are few areas that do not already have more stores than they need.
"First and foremost, it had to be good business strategy, but we saw this as an opportunity to be part of the community process as well as to have a good business transaction," Mr. Stangeland said. "If there had been no riots and no Rebuild L.A., we probably would have gone about it in a fairly leisurely manner. But the civil disobedience placed a kind of magnifying glass over the whole issue and made it apparent to us that we ought to go at this as a fully articulated and fast-paced program."
 
Hughes and Nissan
 Hughes Aircraft and its parent, the General Motors Corporation, agreed in late July to increase by $15 million over the next five years the value of subcontracts it will award to minority-owned businesses in and around the communities hit hardest by the rioting, a step that should support hundreds of new jobs. Despite having announced recently that it would lay off 9,000 workers in the next 18 months because of Pentagon cutbacks, Hughes also agreed to invest $1 million to create new minority-owned businesses and to deposit $1 million in community banks to allow them to increase local business loans.
The Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A., the American arm of the Japanese auto maker, is setting up a $5 million endowment with the proceeds to go to community-based programs that create or support jobs in South Central Los Angeles and surrounding neighborhoods. Nissan developed its plan without consulting Mr. Ueberroth, but used much the same approach he is advocating and is now working with the some of the same community groups as R.L.A.
"What we'd like to see happen is the money going to producing a human being capable of getting a job and staying in the community or creating a job that will keep the money in the community," said Thomas D. Mignanelli, the chief executive of Nissan Motor U.S.A., which is based in Gardena, Calif., just south of the areas hit hardest by the rioting.
"We know that $5 million doesn't solve anybody's problems," Mr. Mignanelli said. "But if each company that was a neighbor or a resident here could do something to create jobs, that would be the best way to help."
His comments echo Mr. Ueberroth's belief that persuading a large number of small operations to participate is the most practical approach. After all, companies can act much more quickly to create an operation with up to 90 jobs, the size Mr. Ueberroth said he has in mind, than to build a 1,000-worker factory. Moreover, he says, the community is better off not being overly dependent on jobs at a handful of large employers.
As part of its commitment to R.L.A., Hughes said it would relocate one of its small operations, with around 60 employees, to a poor neighborhood. Mr. Ueberroth said 10 others, which he declined to name, are making similar commitments.
"These are the basic, stable jobs that will spur the economy," Mr. Ueberroth said. "They will allow people to own their own homes. They will allow minority-owned businesses in the area to thrive, because without those paychecks they won't have any customers. And there's not a company in America that can't participate in that way."
 
 
A SECOND-IN-COMMAND TO BALANCE THE TICKET
 Almost every move made by Peter V. Ueberroth as head of Rebuild Los Angeles has been criticized by one constituency or another, but his choice of Bernard W. Kinsey as the organization's chief operating officer and his second-in-command has won almost unanimous praise.
Mr. Kinsey is a 48-year-old former executive at the Xerox Corporation who was recommended to Mr. Ueberroth by, among others, David Kearns, the former chief executive of Xerox who is now Deputy Secretary of Education in the Bush Administration.
As a black Democrat, Mr. Kinsey provides an important counterpoint to Mr. Ueberroth within R.L.A., community leaders said. And by virtue of his long experience in the corporate world -- he left Xerox after two decades last year to found his own consulting firm -- he provides a crucial bridge between the business world and the inner-city communities.
"Corporations need first to look inward to see if what they are doing inside reflects the same exclusions that are plaguing our cities," said Mr. Kinsey, who served in a series of sales and marketing jobs at Xerox, rising eventually to vice president of advanced marketing strategies. "If their boards and their senior managements up and down the line are white male, they are contributing to the same problems people here are crying about."
At Xerox, Mr. Kinsey pushed top management to open its ranks to black executives and other minorities and helped spur the company's financial support of black educational institutions. Mr. Kinsey said he gives credit to the companies that have approached R.L.A. eager to help. But he said many companies with a stake in inner-city Los Angeles have yet to be heard from. And he said corporate attitudes in too many cases are still driven by stereotypes and fear.
"When I hear someone say they're not investing in a business or a person or an idea because it's in the inner city or because it involves a person of color, I say you're not assessing your risk the right way or in the way you do in other situations," Mr. Kinsey said. "Bankers always say it's a high- risk area, but these are the people who lent to Latin America and bought junk bonds and financed every half-empty high-rise tower in the country."
 
CALIFORNIA, THE JOB KILLER
 "The state of California," said Peter V. Ueberroth, "has developed the most highly tuned, finely honed job-killing machine that this country has ever seen."
That was Mr. Ueberroth's conclusion after leading a commission appointed in December by Gov. Pete Wilson to study California's declining economic competitiveness. The commission's report, issued just before the late-April riots in Los Angeles, found that the state had created "a nightmarish obstacle course for business, job and revenue growth," including over-regulation, a balky bureaucracy and a workers compensation system that was driving companies out of the state or out of business.
Mr. Ueberroth said the report's conclusions are particularly relevant to the efforts of Rebuild Los Angeles to bring economic growth to the inner city. It is minority-owned and small businesses, he said, that are hit the hardest by rapidly escalating workers compensation costs and expensive and time-consuming regulatory requirements relating to air quality, construction and the like.
"If we can't change the business climate in the state, we can't really impact the inner city," he said.
Democratic state legislators, who have long viewed Mr. Ueberroth as a potential Republican gubernatorial candidate, say his approach to improving the business climate would endanger California's hard-won progress in cleaning up its air, among other things. But Mr. Ueberroth said he is not advocating deregulation, simply speeding and streamlining the bureaucracy and regulatory system and recognizing the legitimate needs of business.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Holding the Line on Brazil's Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
With the political future of President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil increasingly in doubt, a showdown is nearing that could determine the future of the country's economy as well.
In the middle of the battle over the economy, Latin America's largest, is a mild-mannered banker who once wrote a book on Machiavelli and Brazilian politics: Marcilio Marques Moreira, the country's 60-year-old economy minister. 
 Hoping to nudge Brazil down a path trod by Latin America's other success stories -- Argentina, Chile and Mexico -- Mr. Moreira advocates privatizing state companies, improving tax collection, maintaining fiscal austerity and making peace with foreign creditors.
But heavy pressure for a populist change in course is coming from Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, the flamboyant Governor of Brazil's impoverished northeastern state of Bahia. Last week, the Governor all but demanded Mr. Moreira's ouster and a return to the free-spending fiscal policies that long gave Brazil the highest inflation rate in the Americas.
In different days, Mr. Magalhaes's demands would be ignored. But these days, the Governor holds the keys to the political survival of President Collor, around whom accusations of influence-peddling and corruption have been swirling for months. As head of the Liberal Party, only Mr. Magalhaes can muster the votes needed to save President Collor from an impeachment trial; a vote seems certain later this month.
The President has responded by urging new spending programs. That prompted the education minister, Jose Goldemberg, to quit early last week and sent the country's markets on a roller-coaster ride.
So far, at least, Mr. Moreira is resisting the call to spend more, offering instead to redirect already approved allocations.
A former ambassador to the United States and a longtime senior executive at Unibanco, Brazil's third-largest private bank, Mr. Moreira has quietly woven a web of alliances that now includes the Government's economic team and several key Cabinet ministers.
Bolstering Mr. Moreira's position last week, the team made a formal one-for-all and all-for-one pact. They will all stay together, they say, and, if necessary, they will all quit together.
But with Liberal Party deputies continuing to demand billions of dollars for pet projects in exchange for party loyalty, Mr. Moreira's knowledge of Machiavelli is still being put to the test.

HEADLINE: All About/Composting;
Two Towns Experiment With the Alchemy of Trash

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Earlier this year, about 400 households in Greenwich and Fairfield, Conn., took a big step forward in their longstanding trash-recycling program. For a month, they set up "wet bags" to collect table scraps, soiled paper and yard clippings. While such garbage is unsuitable for the usual recycling sorting bins, it can be composted.
The results, measured in the further reduction of trash that would otherwise clog landfills and incinerators, make conventional recycling of cans, bottles and paper seem like only a half measure. But the time and space needed for large-scale composting make the chances slim that any but the most dedicated of communities will even experiment with the process. 
 The point of the exercise, which was organized in March by an unusual alliance of the National Audubon Society and the Procter & Gamble Company, was to see how much more household trash could be diverted from landfills and incinerators by adding composting to the usual recycling methods. In the two towns, recycling alone had diverted about 40 percent of household garbage by weight. That still left most for incineration.
The experiment's results exceeded the sponsors' expectations, said Jan Beyea, chief scientist for the Audubon Society.
Using a paper bag lined with cellophane (which resists seepage like plastic, but is derived from plants) for the organic materials allowed families to keep an additional 30 percent of their garbage out of the trash can. That lifted the total recycling rate to 70 percent.
"Everybody seemed to love it," Mr. Beyea said. "We were not prepared for such a positive reaction."
Despite such enthusiasm by sponsors and residents, the experiment is not likely to be repeated or expanded. That is because large amounts of household trash would overwhelm the small municipal composting plant in Fairfield, which is kept busy producing compost from sewage sludge and yard waste like leaves and grass clippings.
Still, Mr. Beyea and other experts on solid-waste disposal say the experiment shows the value of composting garbage and points the way for larger projects in other areas.
 
New in Recycling
Making Compost From Wet Garbage
 The idea in composting is to encourage the naturally occurring bacteria present in carbon-based materials to break complex chunks down into a relatively fine dirt-like substance. In the process the lined paper bag goes the way of its contents.
Biological combustion has the welcome effect of reducing both the mass and volume of material, without dirtying the air the way incinerators do. Compost contains nutrients that are released slowly to plants, making it a useful addition to soils in landscaping, agriculture and nurseries.
Since it retains water well, compost is useful in areas that have sandy, quick-draining soils, as in much of Florida, or where water for irrigation is in short supply, as in some areas of California.
The compost produced in the Connecticut experiment is being tested to determine its purity and effectiveness compared with composts prepared by other methods. Some other methods have resulted in compost too contaminated with bits of plastic or pieces of bone to be used in agriculture. A final report is expected by yearend and it could spark more interest.
Although composting is well known to gardeners, it is only gradually gaining adherence as a method of disposing household trash. Those who like the idea say it should be seen as a form of recycling because it removes material from garbage cans, processes it and creates a product with value.
"We are saying that organics have a value as well as the glass, metal and paper that is now collected for recycling," said Charles Cannon, executive vice president of the Solid Waste Composting Council. The council is a trade group formed by Procter & Gamble, DuPont, Kraft General Foods and other corporations that generate, directly or indirectly, large amounts of waste to promote composting.
 
An Unusual Alliance
Environmentalists And Corporations
 If widely adopted, composting could have a big impact on trash disposal. According to reports prepared for the Environmental Protection Agency, leaves and other yard waste, food scraps and paper that are not likely to be recycled make up about 50 percent of municipal waste nationally. Since all are composed of carbon compounds, they are adaptable to the composting process.
"Conventional recycling is only going to get 15 to 20 percent of solid waste," said Bruce Jones, who is a composting specialist at Procter & Gamble. "But when you look at the organic fraction, it's 50 percent. That could have a big impact on waste management."
He said he and Mr. Beyea had a common interest in the subject and decided on the joint project, thereby forging an alliance between one of the nation's leading environmental groups and one of the largest consumer products companies.
"Jan and I had been talking and we said let's do something to show how effective recycling and composting can be," Mr. Jones said. "We decided to get our hands dirty and show how it could work."
One of the things they did was recruit the Greenwich chapter of the Audubon Society to help coordinate the project and set up a toll-free number for people who had questions or needed more bags. Of the 225 calls logged, only 7 were from people complaining that the extra separation was too much effort.
Although the two organizations collaborated on the project, they do not see eye to eye on everything. To keep compost from becoming contaminated by undesirable materials, like pesticides, that households discard, Mr. Beyea favors separating the organic materials for the compost in the home, as was done in Connecticut. Mr. Jones and P.&G. say that to better assure the purity of the compost, and to save on collection costs, the organic materials can be pulled out of the mix of trash.
"We agreed to disagree," Mr. Beyea said.
 
Dirt that Pays
Balancing the Costs Against the Gains
 Processing trash by composting is still rare among cities, with only 19 having such operations, according to the composting council. But there are more than 2,000 facilities for composting leaves and yard waste across the country, and several hundred communities are planning to include composting in their future waste-disposal plans, association officials said.
Most of the technology used in trash composting programs in this country originated in Europe. There, more densely populated countries ran out of landfill space before it became a problem the United States paid much attention to.
As with most recycling programs, the economics of composting are driven more by the costs of getting rid of trash than by the value of the recovered material.
"The cost of building a facility is $4.5 million to $8 million per hundred tons per day," depending on the technology involved, Mr. Jones said. A publicly owned plant would have to charge a dumping fee of about $50 a ton to operate satisfactorily, while a tax-paying, profit-making private enterprise would probably need to charge nearly $80 a ton.
Once a site has developed a reputation for producing high-quality compost that is low in contaminants and free of visible debris like plastic shards and stones, it could sell the product for $5 to $20 a ton, Mr. Jones said.
Composting is considered a step below recycling in the environmental hierarchy because it converts some materials, like paper, into a lower-value material. So the organizers of the Greenwich-Fairfield program were careful to stress that residents should recycle paper wherever possible, rather than tossing it into the composting bag.
 
 
 
A CLEANER WORLD BUT, OH, THE SMELL
 Despite the admirable service composting plants perform in gobbling up trash and keeping the environment a little cleaner, no one wants one built next door.
At least two major projects, one in Florida and another in Oregon, had to be shut down after nearby residents complained about foul odors coming from the plants.
"Once the neighbors get a whiff from a plant, they do not forget about it," said Charles Cannon of the Solid Waste Composting Council.
For that reason, even those favoring composting as a means of treating household trash, say that composting operations should be located as far away from people as possible. As long as the trash is not left sitting around too long, the process is not inherently particularly smelly. But the compounds produced when biological action takes place in the absence of oxygen tend to be smellier than those formed in an oxygen-rich environment.
In heavily populated areas, the preferred solution is to enclose the process and maintain a slightly negative air pressure inside the building. That way, any random air flow comes from the outside in, not the other way.
Of course, just as with the human lungs, air that is pulled in will eventually have to be exhausted. But by controlling airflow, plant operators can treat it to remove odors before it is released.
The treatment of the air can be done chemically or biologically. In the latter, some composting plants in the United States filter their exhaust air through a thick layer of finished compost, peat moss and leaves.
The microbes present in these materials break down the chemicals that cause the smells.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1764 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 2-7

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A Trade Treaty With Mexico or a 'Transfer of Wealth'? 

For months, President Bush has been doggedly trying to move negotiations forward with Mexico and Canada to create a continent-wide free-trade agreement. But as those negotiations near completion, controversy remains. Canada and the United States have nearly equivalent wage scales, but Mexican workers get only a fraction of what their northern neighbors earn. That discrepancy worries labor groups. "We continue to have factories close down and shops close up and move to Mexico," said Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. "This treaty is essentially a transfer of wealth from working people in America to infrastructure in Mexico," he said. But a study by the Institute for International Economics in Washington says the accord would create tens of thousands of new American jobs and a $10 billion improvement in the American trade balance with Mexico.
 
Temporary Help
 
At first glance the numbers looked good. Unemployment fell to 7.7 percent in July, from 7.8 percent the month before. That means no new recession, economists said. But on closer examination, 60,000 of the 198,000 jobs added to the nation's payroll last month were attributed to a temporary Federal jobs program passed by Congress in June in the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots. "Come September, these temporary workers will all go back to school or to wherever they were before," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. "That will push up September's unemployment number when it comes out in October." Since that will be the last unemployment figure before the election, "it's the one that will be in people's minds when they go into the polling booth," he said.
 
Detecting Just a Whisper
 
The nation's purchasing managers are the economy's windsock: their orders indicate whether the winds of economic growth are blowing. Last month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity had detected a little breeze; it rose to 54.2 percent from 52.8 percent the month before. A reading below 50 indicates recession, while above 50 indicates growth. "It's mildly expansionary," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.

Election-Day Forecast
 
If President Bush is counting on a sudden flurry of economic activity around election time to enhance his chances at the polls, he'd better count again. The Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, which forecasts economic activity six to nine months hence, took a tumble last month. It fell 0.2 percent in June, signaling slow growth through the end of the year.

The Backyard Gas Guzzlers
 
Unbeknownst to most Americans, the nation's lawn mower jockeys are a major source of air pollution (not to mention noise pollution to their hammock-lounging neighbors). Mow the crab grass for an hour and your mower spews as much pollution as a car driven 50 miles. Before it muzzles mower fumes, the Environmental Protection Agency will exchange 1,000 gas mowers now in use for electric models. It will study the old polluting mowers and then write regulations to clean them up. "We certainly could do better," said Dennis C. Dix of the Lawn Mower Institute.

Passing the Buck -- to the Fed
 
With the election looming, the White House is finger-pointing once again. Last month it was Richard Darman, the White House budget director. He blamed Congress, and nearly every other institution inside the beltway, for the economy's woes. Last week it was Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. But Mr. Brady was more specific than Mr. Darman. He told the Senate Banking Committee that blame should fall on the Federal Reserve for waiting too long to lower interest rates. Though the Fed was set up to be independent rather than political, and though it's main job is to keep prices stable not to prod growth, Mr. Brady suggested it was time for Congress to formally review the way the Fed sets policy. He said this despite the fact that the Fed lowered interest rates 23 times in the last three years. "To me, this is an act of desperation and very surprising," said David Jones, chief economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japan's New Explanation
 
When it was first pointed out during recent trade negotiations that Japanese companies were buying too few American-made microprocessors, Tokyo said industry was growing so swiftly that companies had trouble shifting to new suppliers. Last week, when the United States trade representative pointed out again that Japan was importing too few chips -- 14 percent of what it uses, well under its negotiated goal of 20 percent -- the reason was different. Japanese companies are in a slump, Tokyo's negotiators said, and are reluctant to change suppliers because they don't want to risk weakening their business associates further.

Yeltsin the Fund-Raiser
 
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia is one of the world's greatest fund-raisers. He addressed Congress earlier this summer, and last week the House passed a foreign aid package worth $1.2 billion for Russia and the other former Soviet republics, and authorized $12 billion in commitments to increase the capital of the International Monetary Fund. While the I.M.F. money is not earmarked, much of it is expected to go to Russia. Of the direct aid, $790 million will go toward dismantling Russia's nuclear weapons. But while Mr. Yeltsin rakes it in, some lawmakers complained that the funds could be better used at home. "Our citizens are hurting," said Representative Barbara-Rose Collins, Democrat of Michigan.

Fujitsu's First Loss
 
Rather than end by the fall, as Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa promised, Japan's economic slump is worsening. Last week, Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer company, announced its first loss ever: $80 million for the first half of the year. Fujitsu, like its rivals elsewhere, is facing intense pricing pressure on its microprocessors -- it announced it would close its San Diego semiconductor plant last week -- and has seen demand for its mainframe computer slip.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Will Icahn Turn In His Wings?
 
Carl C. Icahn, takeover artist extraordinaire, may love a bargain, but when he bought Trans World Airlines, he got more than he bargained for. The money-losing airline circled for months before landing in Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. It is still losing money -- as much as $1 million a day, analysts said. Last week Mr. Icahn came up with a plan that would turn over 45 percent of the company's stock to its employees in exchange for a 15 percent wage cut and work-rule concessions. T.W.A.'s creditors would forgive about $1 billion of the airline's $1.5 billion in debt in exchange for the remaining 55 percent of Mr. Icahn's stock. As part of the deal, Mr. Icahn would step down as T.W.A.'s chairman, a job he may wish he never had. Analysts estimate Mr. Icahn's losses at about $100 million from his four-year foray into flying.

Giants Follow the Rays
 
Thirty-five years ago New York's teary-eyed baseball fans waved goodbye to the Giants as they left for San Francisco. Now, as those fans retire and move to Florida, they will get a chance to welcome their team back. Giants owner Robert Lurie said he will sell the team to a group of Tampa investors for about $110 million. The team will play in St. Petersburg, Fla. Mr. Lurie had been trying to move the Giants out of frigid Candlestick Park for four years but could not persuade voters to build a new stadium. While yet another set of Giant's fans is teary-eyed, "everybody in Tampa Bay should feel like they're running the bases on air," said Rick Dodge, St. Petersburg's assistant city manager.

Making Factories Work
 
Poke around any factory floor and you will find industrial controls that turn machines on and off, open and close valves and measure temperatures and speeds. The market for these sometimes high-tech, sometimes mundane devices is rich: $18 billion worldwide. Last week, when the Emerson Electric Company agreed to buy Fisher Controls International Inc. for $1.28 billion from the Monsanto Company, it announced a combination that will be the world's largest producer of control devices.

Bell Labs' Data Crunch
 
Storing data on what engineers call "media" -- magnetic tape, disks and optical disks -- is a $40 billion business. The more that can fit on a disk, the more valuable it is. Last week, engineers at the American Telephone & Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories announced a breakthrough. By sending laser light through microscopic-fiber-optic filaments, the scientists said they could squeeze 100 times more data on a compact disk. At that density, Bell scientists said they could store 17 hours of recorded TV programming on a palm-sized optical disk. But scientists don't know yet if the process lends itself to easy manufacture or accurate information retrieval. "There are are still big ifs," said James Porter, president of Disk/Trend Inc., an industry research firm.
 
Milken's Reward
 
When Judge Kimba M. Wood reduced Michael R. Milken's 10-year sentence, making the imprisoned former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert's junk-bond operations eligible for release after serving only two years, she wrote that it was because he had cooperated with the prosecution. "This assistance was substantial and warrants a reduction in sentence," she wrote. She also cited his help in reaching a $1.3 billion global settlement of claims against him and against his former colleagues at Drexel and substantial work tutoring other inmates in jail. Not everyone was satisfied with Judge Wood's decision. "You can rob a billion and get a reduction, but if you rob a 7-Eleven you can get up to a decade in jail," said Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts.

A Drag on G.M. Profits
 
When the General Motors Corporation bought Hughes Aircraft, which does a lot of business with the Pentagon, it was to offset the ups and downs of its car business. But with the cold war over, Hughes has had its share of downs. Early this year it trimmed its work force by 9,000 workers, which resulted in a charge of $749.4 million in the second quarter. That wiped away G.M.'s profit of $392 million from increased automobile sales and gave it a loss of $357.1 million in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: Talking: Leaseholds;
Buying Land Under A Co-op

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
SHAREHOLDERS in leasehold co-ops -- which sit on leased land rather than on lots owned by the co-ops -- have always faced special issues.
Selling an apartment can be difficult, because potential buyers tend to be wary. The lease may have a clause allowing sharp increases in the ground rent, which can play havoc with maintenance charges, and a smaller part of the maintenance charges may be deductible from taxable income because the portion going to pay ground rent does not qualify. 
 Whenever feasible, a leasehold co-op should try to buy the land, and "I can't think of a better moment," said David Clurman, a lawyer in Manhattan who counsels leasehold co-ops.
Some sponsors who held onto the land when they converted rental buildings into co-ops are facing a cash-flow crises. Thus, said Ernest L. Bial, a New York lawyer recently involved in such a deal at 315 East 70th Street, they may be more willing to sell.
Moreover, land values are sufficiently depressed that the land's cost should be substantially lower than in the high-flying 80's. In addition, interest rates are so favorable that a co-op that is otherwise in good shape should be able to finance the deal at a lower cost than at any time in recent memory.
Even so, boards are not being aggressive in pursuing the opportunity, said Mr. Clurman. The reluctance, he maintained, comes not from a detailed analysis of the benefits of making a move now, but from an aversion to making a heavy investment at a time of depreciating values.
Lewis Taishoff, a lawyer in Manhattan who also has represented leasehold co-ops, insists that the sort of landowner most eager to make a deal will probably be an individual sponsor rather than an institution or foundation, which is rarely under the same pressures.
But there could be exceptions. Consider the ground lease at the 54-unit co-op at 139 East 63d Street. The owners, the Beekman Estate Inc., had been shifting towards a policy of owning and operating its own buildings rather than simply owning land leases, said Wright Palmer, Beekman's president. So the timing for a purchase was right when the rent came up for review three years ago.
But a way still has to be found to pay for the land. And even though the co-op may initially shy away because the cost appears prohibitive -- or financing seems unavailable -- there could be more flexibility than many shareholders realize.
At 139 East 63d Street, for example, the two sides had agreed on a value of $8 million for the land after each got its own appraisal. But instead of being paid entirely in cash, Beekman sought -- and got -- title to the five stores and the professional suite in the building, its prime objective in making the deal, leaving only $3.9 million still due from the co-op's coffers.
The swap was achieved by restructuring the co-op into a "condop" comprising three condominium units: the five stores, the professional suite and the residential co-op.
The net result was a maintenance increase to $46 a share, from $30. Even so, shareholders should be better off because they also benefit from higher tax deductions, said William R. Miller, a member of the board.
The co-op had no trouble financing the $3.9 million, although Mr. Miller conceded that the deal was arranged just before lenders became wary of real estate loans.
Board members who think financing will be a problem might look at the deal worked out at 125-unit co-op at 315 East 70th Street. In the late 1980's, Alex DiLorenzo, the president of the company that owned the site, wanted $10 million for it -- far more than the co- op could afford, said lawyers associated with the deal. Even so, they watched and waited for an opening.
THEN, about a year ago, the Di Lorenzo company defaulted on a $1.2 million loan on the parcel. And since land values had also fallen, it reluctantly agreed to sell the site to the co-op for $3.4 million.
Moreover, it was in the interest of Lincoln Savings Bank, holders of the land loan, to exchange its nonperforming loan for a $3.4 million loan to the co-op to help buy the land, said William Lippman, a lawyer in Manhattan who was involved. It also helped that there was no mortgage on the building.
The difference between the monthly cost of the ground rent and the debt service on the new loan has increased maintenance charges by 7.5 percent, said Mr. Lippman. The average went from $227 a room to $249. But shareholders are still better off, he said, because 60 percent of maintenance is now tax-deductible compared to 16 percent before the co-op bought the land. This is because the new totals encompass mortgage interest costs for the land loan and its real estate taxes.
Although there was no default, the 160-unit co-op at 201 East 79th Street also recently bought its site from Mr. Di Lorenzo, said Donald Cohen, a board member. In this case, a total refinancing package of $19 million that folded in the existing underlying mortage on the building was used to pay the $16.5 million purchase price.
"We had no trouble getting the money," said Mr. Cohen.
Maintenance went up 12.7 percent, 67 percent of which became tax deductible compared to 20 percent. And sales have picked up sharply, Mr. Cohen said.
Another way out of any financing problem, said Mr. Taishoff, might be to offer to pay the landowner only part of the money in cash and have him finance the rest.
But Mr. Taishoff warned that funds from a co-op's statutory reserves may not be used for the purchase or a modification of lease terms as they are strictly limited to capital improvements. Only the reserves from an auxiliary capital fund -- which many have been set up to provide greater flexibility -- can be tapped.
Mr. Clurman said that even if some landowners are unwilling to part with their land they may be persuaded to re-negotiate the terms of the lease in exchange for a lump-sum payment to bolster their cash levels.
For example, he said, lengthening the term to 50 years or more with tight caps on any rental increase could go a long way towards making the co-op more financially stable and appealing. Another compromise, he said, might be to pay a lump sum in exchange for an option on the land.
Mr. Miller, who is also president of William B. May Management Corporation, said a board must present its numbers clearly when going before the residents for approval. Shareholders in a few co-ops, he warned, have actually turned down good land deals simply because "they couldn't understand what was going on."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: 125-139 West 93d Street;
Housing Authority Gets A+ for Effort

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE architectural pilgrim will find unlikely exhilaration in a trip up to a New York City Housing Authority project, the nine 1897 rowhouses at 125-139 West 93d Street.
The agency has a track record for modest housing of the most utilitarian finish and intent -- institutional green paint, fortified steel doors and scratched plexiglass windows, all constituent elements of bare brick boxes. But it has turned what could have been a ruthless modernization into a sensitive near-restoration, as the red brick rowhouses are carefully cleaned and their slate mansards and damaged brownstone are repaired. 
 The authority's initial project was First Houses, completed in 1935 at Avenue A and Third Street. The work was unabashedly modern, gutting and stripping inside and out to produce 123 units. The modernist esthetic continued, but the scale quickly changed to new construction with projects like Brooklyn's 3,501-unit Fort Greene Houses of 1941.
By 1954, the agency had built or started 93,983 units, typically in plain high-rise boxes. Many of the projects were funded by the Federal Title I program, which bulldozed large areas in the name of slum clearance.
Both the methods and the results of Title I received growing criticisms and the 1954 National Housing Act introduced a new term, "urban renewal." This new label reflected a desire to halt urban decay "without the wholesale use of the bulldozer" as the Housing Authority's annual report put it the following year. Indeed, one new approach was not new construction at all, but rehabilitation of existing structures, partly through the influence of James Rouse, a Baltimore mortgage banker active in downtown Baltimore redevelopment.
Two years after the National Housing Act, the area along Columbus Avenue from 87th to 97th Streets was designated for urban renewal. In 1950, the area had been 94 percent white with a population of 33,000; in 1956, it had a population of 40,000, of which 58 percent was white. There had been a tremendous in-migration of newly arrived Puerto Ricans; of the 665 rowhouses in the area, 428 had been converted into densely occupied rooming houses.
MOST of the tenements and small apartments in the area were razed to make way for high-rises, but several dozen brownstones were slated for rehabilitation.
Among these were the nine houses at 125-139 West 93d Street. Built in 1887 and designed by William J. Merritt, this row has rock-faced brownstone basements and deep red-brick facades with a varying oriels, terra cotta trim, cornices and roof lines.
The interiors were gutted of oak trim, tile fireplaces and other Victorian elements, but the exteriors were left largely alone, except for the removal of the stoops. The authority's architect for the work was Gustave Iser, who had studied with Clarence Stein, a housing theorist and designer of Fort Greene Houses. Where the stoops were removed, Iser installed a swath of stucco and an airport-modern multi-colored panel of glazed tiles. This was a note of color in a stretch of buildings that were left visibly decayed, with older, soiled paint jobs covering some of the facades and deteriorating windows and roofs.
If the facades were not carefully restored they were at least not disturbed; John Young, a West Side architect, calls it "generic landmark preservation" and indeed it was a giant change for the Housing Authority.
Over time the decay of the row has become pronounced. The bulkhead entry lighting, vandal-proof doors and institutional signs have made the row unmistakably a "project" and the exteriors have become more and more ragged.
Now Neil Cohen, an administrative architect with the Housing Authority, is supervising a comprehensive rehabilitation, inside and out, that for the first time treats the exteriors as something that really counts. Working with the consulting architects, Vincek & Petrocci, and the contractor, Cole Restoration, he has cleaned the row of paint and soil, revealing the rich red brick and brownstone, and agonized over a color for the cornices and the replacement of the missing slate for the small mansards.
"We're treating them like landmarks, even though they're not" he said.
The Housing Authority still favors the mass-produced, so the new doors, window guards, signage and lights are all going to be identical, although improved. But the pragmatic preservationist must give the Housing Authority an A-plus, at least for improvement.

HEADLINE: Environmental Fight in Prime Time

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SENATOR AL GORE, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, visited a motor oil recycling plant in California last week and extolled tough environmental regulations as the key to increasing the efficiency of business, spurring technological innovation and generating millions of new jobs.
Three days later, Vice President Dan Quayle flew to Columbus, Ohio, and delivered a broadside against environmental regulations, declaring that many are unnecessary and that they slow the economy and cost jobs. 
 The appearances marked the start of a long-percolating debate about the ties between the environment and the economy by two politicians who are polar opposites. Never has the dispute been so fully engaged in a Presidential campaign, in part because the ideological foundations have never been defined more clearly by the candidates.
The Administration's Position Mr. Quayle and other conservatives argue that only by lowering environmental regulatory costs and more fully opening the country's natural resources can industry be expected to thrive in an ever-more-competitive world market.
In the last 12 months Mr. Quayle pushed aside the moderates in the White House and seized control of the Administration's environmental policies. With the young staff of his Council on Competitiveness, Mr. Quayle expanded the President's authority to halt new environmental regulations and weaken others by rewriting them without public hearings, and has expressly supported the Administration's actions to remove public interference in Government decisions to open Federal lands for coal mining, oil exploration, timber harvests and grazing.
Underlying the Vice President's attack, say Mr. Quayle's aides, is a convergence of scientific, economic and political trends the Administration hopes to ride to victory in November.
First, a growing number of prominent scientists nationwide have signed a declaration that says the environmental movement is an "irrational ideology" that has exaggerated environmental problems and threatens the ability of scientists and business executives to advance technology.
Second, conservative economists argue that the cost of complying with environmental regulations -- $130 billion to $140 billion annually -- is too high, and fewer, less costly regulations would produce the same theoretical benefits to society.
Such a view is being championed not only by factory owners, but also by some cities. Last year, the health department in Columbus, Ohio, conducted a study and found that complying with rules for providing safe drinking water, disposing of trash and operating sewage treatment plants will triple the average family's payment for such services from $400 annually to more than $1,300.
Third, a coalition of timber industry employees, miners, farmers and property owners -- many of them traditional Republican voters -- has caught the Administration's attention by arguing that they are the ones being hurt the most by all the rules.
In a speech in Columbus on Friday, Mr. Quayle said, "I'm sure that during their bus trip through the area, our opponents never mention their idea to put new taxes on everything from gas and coal to paper and packaging. Well, what about all the jobs and money these plans will cost? What about the Ohio steelworker, the West Virginia coal miner, or the Michigan auto worker thrown out of work?"
The Clinton-Gore Position -- On the opposite side of the spectrum is Mr. Gore, who contends that trading off environmental protection for job growth is an outdated idea that threatens the economy in the 21st century. Mr. Gore says the enactment of the world's most stringent laws for safeguarding air, water, land and public health made manufacturing plants more efficient and gave rise to the environmental cleanup industry, one of the economy's most dynamic sectors. The Department of Commerce says that 65,000 to 70,000 companies in the environmental industry employ almost one million workers and had sales last year of $130 billion.
Mr. Gore also argues that strict environmental regulations have amounted to an undeclared national industrial policy. The chief executive officers of Monsanto, Dow Chemical, Du Pont, 3M, Procter & Gamble and other leading companies are installing manufacturing practices that use energy and natural resources more sparingly, lowering costs for production and for disposing of wastes.
Concern for the environment is a factor, say such executives, but more important are profits and corporate survival. Japanese manufacturers have already moved to make their factories more efficient and now use half as much energy as American manufacturers to produce cars and other appliances.
"The Bush Administration is costing the United States millions of jobs by adopting a strategy that protects the old polluting, inefficient ways of the past," said Mr. Gore in a telephone interview from California. "If their theory is correct that the way to create jobs is to trash the environment, you would think Eastern Europe would be economic leaders of world. You would also think that Japan and Germany would be struggling third world nations."
For supporters of both sides, the stakes could not be higher.
Over the last 11 years, Republican Administrations have influenced how the courts and Congress view the link between the economy and the environment. Having laid that groundwork, President Bush, if re-elected, could rightly claim that he's won a mandate to tear apart the thick web of environmental regulations, which conservative members of the Administration say they are poised to do.
The Federal courts are dominated by Reagan and Bush appointees who are sympathetic to arguments that environmental regulations are based on inaccurate and meager scientific evidence and their cost to business is too high. In the last year, Federal district and appellate courts have thrown out environmental regulations including those that restricted hazardous wastes, banned the use of asbestos and directed the Government to set higher automobile mileage standards.
The Supreme Court also has decided to limit the ability of environmental groups to sue the Government on the basis that the groups have failed to show they suffered direct harm from Federal actions. Thus, the Administration's program of attacking regulations is likely to be sustained by the courts.
Even in the Democratically controlled Congress, the Administration and the coalition of resource-based landowners, employees and executives it has encouraged stirred a backlash against environmentalism that halted efforts this year to strengthen the Endangered Species Act, the Clean Water Act and the nation's hazardous waste law.
Prominent Democrats are helping the Administration to open land and resources to development. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, has proposed legislation that would allow four million acres of wilderness in Montana to be logged and mined.
Mr. Gore said in the interview that he and Bill Clinton hope that if they are elected, they will be able to change the mood of the Congress and the courts. Some environmentalists have been skeptical. Mr. Clinton, after all, acknowledged in an Earth Day speech that during his 11 years as Governor of Arkansas he allowed higher levels of contamination in order to attract industry and jobs to one of the country's poorest states.
In that speech Mr. Clinton also said, though, that he has learned that trading off the environment for jobs was a "false choice" that he vowed not to repeat.
The question that cannot be answered yet, of course, is which candidate has the correct political strategy: the Democrats, who are appealing to suburban voters, or the Republicans, who are courting rural voters. Whatever the outcome, a lesson of the 1992 campaign is that the environment's relationship to the economy is now firmly fixed alongside health care and abortion as an issue that can help decide an election.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Europe Looks at Iraq and Shrugs

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
EVEN THOUGH Saddam Hussein appeared once again last week to be planting new obstacles in the path of United Nations inspections of his weapon capacity, and President Bush was reiterating his vow that Iraq would submit, much of the saber-rattling was barely noticed in Western Europe.
In fact, it has been that way all during this summer of threats and bluffs and compromises. Even during the tensest moments last month, when American aircraft carriers were heading for the Persian Gulf while Mr. Hussein was still resisting any inspection of his Agriculture Ministry by a United Nations team looking for documents on weapons, the same European countries whose armies and navies fought in the war only two years ago largely yawned. 
 Instead, commentators expressed skepticism about the need for another military conflagration. And there were murmurs that George Bush's actions were being dictated more by the rigors of Presidential electioneering than by an objective assessment of the situation.
The European attitude is that Iraq is George Bush's problem, that Saddam Hussein is no longer the threat he used to be and, above all else, that Europe as a whole now faces a far more pressing problem in the Balkans, a problem that requires all of the Continent's energies.
"I think we've had our Iraqi overdose last year," said Christian Testot, an expert at the Center of Middle East Analysis unit at the French Foreign Ministry.
"The feeling among Europeans today is that the issue of Iraq and what might happen there has become far more complex than the relatively clear goal of liberating Kuwait of Iraqi troops last year," Mr. Testot said, adding that "among other things, it is evident that much of the Arab world is rallying to the view that Iraq has been punished enough."
Listening to what the Arab world says has always been considered of greater importance in Europe than in the United States, and the Europeans have always tried to sidestep problems that could put them in conflict with large segments of the region's populations. After all, nearly 5 million North African Arabs live on the Continent and France, Britain, Germany, Italy and Spain are mindful of their vast economic interests in the region, which includes non-Arab Iran and Turkey, as well as the Arab countries across and beyond the Mediterranean.
On the question of acting against Iraq, European officials noted that the Arabs themselves are clearly divided, with only some of the oil-rich Gulf Arabs, most notably the Kuwaitis, favoring more punishment. European analysts also note that Turkey, which enthusiastically supported the gulf war, is now wary of the West's support for Iraq's Kurds. Under the protection of the United States, Britain and France, these Kurds are being allowed pretty much to create an autonomous entity that can only be envied by Turkey's own Kurds -- whose rebellion Turkey is vigorously trying to suppress.
 
An Eye on Arabs and Turks
 "The Europeans cannot be more royalist than the King," said Francois Heisbourg, director of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, in an interview. "If the Arabs are not in favor of military actions against Iraq and the Turks not in favor of promoting Kurdish independence, Europe has no interest in getting itself in trouble or being beastly to the Turks."
Most importantly the tragedy unfolding in the Balkans has mesmerized Europeans in a way that Iraq no longer does. This is partly because of their helplessness to do something about their own neighborhood even as images of massacres flicker over television screens every night from Nice to Stockholm. At the same time, the huge inflow of refugees, perhaps as many as 2 million Yugoslavs, has not even begun to be addressed.
As it stands, if Europeans are contemplating military action anywhere, it is in the direction of the Adriatic Sea, not the Persian Gulf. "There is no need for new military action on the scale of the gulf war anymore," said Patrick Reas, a spokesman for the London-based Western European Union, in a telephone interview. "We are sending our ships and our troops to Yugoslavia instead."
In an editorial published on July 27 as last month's confrontation with Iraq appeared to have been defused, The Financial Times portrayed European views this way: "The sighs of relief in Western capitals last night, after Iraq had climbed down in the crisis with the United Nations over weapons inspections, were almost audible."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Russia, a Familiar Chill in the Political Air

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IN this sped-up, fast-forward century, it's already necessary to ask whether Russia's latest lurch toward the West and all its pretty promises is beginning to come to an end.
Amid increasing disillusion with the West, the $1.2 billion in bilateral aid finally approved by the American Congress last week with such self-satisfaction seems to many here a paltry response, and it comes very late. 
 After the euphoria of the collapse of the Communist Party and -- crucially -- the equally profound humiliation of the loss of the Russian empire without the firing of shot or shell, it was inevitable that strong and unreconstructed political, social and economic forces should re-emerge amid the chaos.
President Boris N. Yeltsin, duly elected, won his fantastic grudge match with the unelected Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and used last August's anti-Gorbachev coup to pull the state out from underneath him.
The new ideology of democratic legitimacy and a free market was crucial to Mr. Yeltsin's successful coup, but this is a country that never had much experience with either. Russia never had the Enlightenment, and its only memorable periods of reform have been at the command of autocratic power. Mr. Yeltsin himself, while inveighing against the "anti-democratic" nature of Parliament (elected in 1990 when the old system held sway), acts, or tries to act, almost purely through decree.
He has supported the radical economic reform designed by Acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar and his Western-oriented team of economists. But with long-promised Western aid only now beginning to be delivered, and then doled out in tiny chunks, the whole idea of these reforms is being discredited by inflation, tight credit, cash shortages, enterprise debt, a crash in industrial and energy production and a grain harvest forecast of only 89 million tons.
Mr. Yeltsin, ever the politician, is paying more attention these days to Arkady I. Volsky, a powerful lobbyist for state enterprise managers, and those around him, who like to speak of the International Monetary Fund, with its strict demands for fiscal and monetary discipline, as a misguided agent of the Western desire to bring Russia to its knees and then buy its wealth on the cheap. And Mr. Gaidar and his team seem to be losing credibility these days where it counts most: with Mr. Yeltsin, though he, as usual, is keeping his own counsel, trying to stay above the fray. "Mr. Gaidar is becoming only a Potemkin Village for the West," an industrial manager in St. Petersburg said. "The day he costs Yeltsin too much, Gaidar is gone."
Periods when Russia has hungered after the West have been followed by periods of retrenchment and defensiveness, when the wounds of Russia's backwardness and passivity have been nursed into a religion of "uniqueness" and "soul" that drives all the claims to transcendence.
Sometimes historians speak of this as the Asian part of the Russian character, rooted in the nation's subservience to and merger with the Tatar "hordes." But more precisely, these days, this tendency is best seen in the industrial managers, bureaucrats and self-styled "patriots" grouped around Mr. Volsky, who describe the Western economic model as a "liberal dream" unsuitable to suffering Russia.
Trying to save their enterprises, however inefficient they may be in Western terms, these conservatives want to stop radical economic reform and thorough privatization and use the state to manage change. Conjuring visions of rioting masses of unemployed amid a charred landscape of bankrupt factories and farms, they have wrung out of Mr. Yeltsin high-level political positions in the Government and costly credits. They have a powerful say in the new and still shadowy Security Council appointed by Mr. Yeltsin, and they now have their candidate, Viktor Gerashchenko, running the Central Bank, which is controlled by Parliament.
In a particularly unattractive display of disunity last week, a press conference to show Government solidarity turned into open argument. Mr. Gaidar's men disagreed about the need for sizable new credits with their new colleagues, drawn from the industrial establishment and closer to Mr. Volsky.
While the Gaidar men seem to have caused Mr. Gerashchenko to pull back from issuing another trillion rubles of credit, they are spending more time fending off challenges and making painful compromises than carrying out a coherent reform.
"The policy of the reform government is about to collapse," Mr. Volsky said last week, while in another of his Cassandra-like interviews, Mr. Gorbachev said that the Government "is at a loss about how to proceed."
And it is only now that the West has just begun to deliver on its many exaggerated promises -- not in the hour of need for Russia's Westernizing reformers, which passed many weeks ago, but in the hour of their despair, when the dream of real market reform is crumbling.
Last week the I.M.F. finally released $1 billion of credits to Russia, supposedly the first tranche of $4 billion, and the World Bank announced a $600 million loan. But Moscow seems unlikely to meet its promises to the Fund of a budget deficit no higher than 5 percent of gross national product, and a limit of 9 percent on monthly inflation by the end of the year, which means that further Fund aid is not likely.
 
Important, but Very Late
 Last week, too, the House of Representatives finally passed the grandly named Freedom Support Act for Russia. But it might better be named "The Paying the I.M.F. What We Owe Them Act," since it essentially provides the Fund new capital to meet its lending obligations to Russia and the other states of the former union.
Though symbolically important, these decisions come very late, feeding Russian criticism that the West's aid is more hortatory than real, and that the West's basic interest is to keep Russia on its knees.
It is a criticism also voiced by one Western diplomat in the former union. There is a lot of scouring of the cities and the countryside by Western diplomats, experts, scholars and businessmen, both legitimate and fly-by-night, he said. But from Washington, he said, "nothing of any real substance, no aid of any real measure, has been provided so far."
There have been telegenic flights of medicine and leftover Meals Ready to Eat, in which the cost of the planes and fuel dwarfed the value of the contents delivered; there has been European Community meat that undercut the price any Russian producer could match; there have been brave efforts by towns and hospitals in America and the West to help needy Russian or Commonwealth institutions.
But for all the talk of more directed assistance, of fancy new portable grain elevators and mini-tractors, of refrigeration trucks and canning factories, very little has actually materialized.
Many Russians are already asking whether the gain is worth the pain: A billion-dollar loan here or there is barely a drop in the desert of Russian need. And while no one expected Russia to turn into the United States, Westerners have a few questions to ask, too. Russia was never there to be "lost," but it is heading in a direction the West may one day soon, in this fast-forward century, come to regret.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1065 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
In a World of Instant Copies, Who Pays for Original Work?

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
THERE are yawning potholes on the road to the information age.
Computer executives, publishers, artists and authors are trying to reconcile 21st-century computer technology with 19th-century laws protecting intellectual property. 
 On the horizon is the promise of even more powerful personal digital technologies, ranging from ultrafast computer networks marrying images, sound and data and delivering vast quantities of information, to a new generation of wireless computers and communicators connecting mobile professionals to their business world. These technologies could make it possible to view virtually any movie or television program on demand and could provide a cornucopia of information services ranging from books and maps to restaurant guides, all in hand-held computers.
But some industry executives fear that many of these services will remain high-tech dreams because traditional publishers, broadcasters and movie companies, fearing their products will be copied easily and copyrights infringed, will refuse to sell digital versions.
"Our current intellectual property laws are in danger of breaking down completely in the face of this digital revolution," said Mitchell D. Kapor, founder and former chairman of Lotus Development Corporation, which publishes software. "Big publishers are hesitant to move forward without more of a feeling of comfort that they have copyright protection in the new digital world."
In the past, new industries like the music business have faced similar problems and have managed to devise workable solutions for protecting intellectual property. But the advent of an all-digital technology has led to a more vexing situation because, unlike traditional books, music and images, information in digital form can be copied perfectly at virtually no cost. Indeed, the impending emergence of global computer networks potentially turns every personal computer into a powerful desktop information factory.
 
Distinctions Blurred
 "The problem is simply that information wants to be free," said Robert Stein, an executive at the Voyager Company, a digital media company in Santa Monica, Calif., that publishes laser disks and electronic books.
High-speed computer networks present problems that are fundamentally different from any that society has previously faced in establishing legal barriers prohibiting photo-copying books and information or taping music and video.
"In the information age a valuable book comes across a network, a person reads it and, by pushing a button, sends a copy to his friend," said Alan Weis, president of Advanced Networks & Services, a computer network company based in Elmsford, N. Y. "He's broken the copyright, and he hasn't thought twice about it."
Easily accessible computer networks will soon blur the distinction between software and information stored in different places -- a frightening development for the nation's largest publishers. This year, for example, when Pacific Bell began deploying high-speed digital telephone lines to business customers, company executives were surprised to find that one of the first experimental uses was for making perfect copies of CD audio disks to digital audio tape, or DAT, players.
Similarly, Apple Computer's Newton, a hand-held personal information system scheduled to be introduced next year, has made wary even publishers who are tempted by the potential market. Each Newton will come with a communications link enabling it to transfer information to another system or to a computer with a push of a button.
"We have been having serious discussions with Apple about ways to make sure that we're likely to be paid for the sharing of information," said Michael Mellin, publisher of Random House's electronic publishing division. "It's unlikely that we'll find a panacea, but we're going to have to figure out some level of copying that we can live with."
Indeed, Apple has already found itself struggling with copyright questions since it introduced Macintosh Quicktime software last year. Quicktime's design makes it easy for personal computer users to add small snippets of digital video to their programs.
"It's really a tough problem to solve," said Doug Camplejohn, Apple's manager of multimedia system software. "Any digital media is going to present copyright questions, especially in a computer where editing is in the hands of the user."
Trying to allay fears of rampant copyright violations, Apple is working on a new version of Quicktime that will automatically embed copyright markings in each digital frame and will enable companies to encrypt their Quicktime digital video material easily, frustrating copiers.
Part of the problem is that most traditional publishers and movie companies have not solved the problem of how to charge for digital versions of their wares. New digital markets are potentially huge, but so too are the risks from illegal copying. As a result some of the largest publishers and movie houses have simply banned electronic publishing or charged exorbitant fees.
Industry executives are divided on whether the push toward new digital media will require a redefinition of modern copyright law. Some argue that the only feasible solution is to educate users to behave ethically. Besides having law enforcement agencies crack down on corporations, schools and software pirates, the Software Publishers Association has begun a campaign in schools that includes a rap music video entitled "Don't Copy That Floppy."
Some people involved with the problem hope that technology will eventually supply methods to prevent illegal copying without interfering with the convenience of using software and digital information. One company, Cryptologics International Inc., a New York City company, has developed a method enabling users to pay only for the information they use in large digital libraries.
But if they are to be successful, such systems must first overcome criticism from industry executives who are skeptical about copy-protection schemes that until now have been universally rejected by personal computer users.
"It's a dilemma," said Denise Caruso, editor of Digital Media, a San Francisco-based multimedia newsletter. "No matter what anyone does there is going to be somebody who finds a way around it. But a way has to be found to protect data if this revolution is going to be real."
