PUB-DATE: August 9, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 41; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1857 words

HEADLINE: Black Cemetery Yields Wealth of History

BYLINE: By E. R. SHIPP

 BODY:
When a few human bones were uncovered during work on a Federal construction site last summer, they were hardly more than a minor curiosity. But in recent months, as hundreds of skeletons were unearthed, experts have come to conclude that the site in lower Manhattan may be one of the nation's most important archeological finds of this century.
The site, a Colonial-era burial ground mostly for enslaved Africans, was the focus of a political dispute in recent weeks as Mayor David N. Dinkins and others fought successfully to halt a Federal construction project. Efforts are being made to designate the cemetery a Federal historic site. 
 Surprisingly preserved more than 20 feet below New York City streets, the Negros Burial Ground, as it was known, is believed to contain the remains of as many as 20,000 people. It once covered roughly five city blocks on the outskirts of 18th-century New York, land one observer described as "unattractive and desolate."
Historians, archeologists and anthropologists are still trying to assess the find, which they say is the oldest municipal and only pre-Revolutionary African cemetery known to exist in the United States.
But they believe the burial ground will yield a wealth of information on what Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, describes as "the daily lives of enslaved Africans for whom there are no other written records."
 
18th-Century Revelations
 Anthropologists like Prof. Michael Blakey of Howard University, using the most modern tools, hope to be able to determine what part of Africa the people came from, what their diets were there and in the New World, what their status was in New York City and how they died.
"We can, in a sense, go back to the actual ancestors themselves and glean from what they have left us in their material representation as much of their experience as we can find," Professor Blakey said.
Preliminary studies of the 415 skeletons removed from the site have already revealed much about life in the 18th century. From the number of skeletons of children for instance, experts have estimated that 50 percent of the black population died at birth or in the first few years of life.
The remains are also raising questions about burial customs and whether they were transported from Africa or borrowed from Europeans.
"There are no mass burials here," said Daniel N. Pagano, the city's urban archeologist. "We know from historic records there were epidemics. There's yellow fever and cholera. But each individual is carefully placed in the ground and with great respect."
Some individuals were buried with coins in their hands or over their eyes. One was buried with a shell next to the head. "That ties into one of the traditional sayings, 'By the sea we came, by the sea we shall go' and was perhaps symbolic of spiritual freedom," Mr. Pagano said.
One man was buried in a British marine officer's uniform. The uniform has decomposed but the buttons remain to offer insight. "This was a person, an African-American, of high status," he said. "It's very clear."
 
'Wealth of Information'
 From the site of the burial ground and from a nearby construction site, more than 1.5 million artifacts of life of New York's common folk have been recovered. North of the burial ground was Five Points, which was a bustling melting pot in the 19th century and a center of black life.
Among the artifacts are pieces of pottery and glassware, tools, children's toys and remnants of food.
"There's just an incredible wealth of information on daily life on individuals not written about in the history books," Mr. Pagano said. "We're not going to find it anywhere else."
Until nearly two weeks ago, however, it seemed there might be nothing of historic value left at the site, as the Federal General Services Administration made it clear that it would continue to remove the human remains to make way for a new Federal office building. The $276 million project would include a 34-story tower and a four-story pavilion housing an auditorium, a day-care center and a pedestrian galleria.
 
Abrupt Change in Course
 But after protests from Representative Gus Savage, an Illinois Democrat whose House subcommittee oversees G.S.A. projects, the agency abruptly changed course. Its head, Richard G. Austin, adopted much of what Mayor Dinkins and others had been seeking for months: an end to construction on the pavilion site and a commitment to honor the memory of the dead through some type of monument or even a museum.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato later persuaded the Senate Appropriations Committee to set aside $3 million "to modify the pavilion foundation, to prevent further deterioration of the burial ground and to appropriately memorialize the site." The full Senate is expected to act later this week.
G.S.A. officials have been criticized for inadequately surveying the construction site before beginning excavation and for assuming that more than a century of building had long ago destroyed the burial ground. What they had not counted on was that 20 feet of landfill covered the cemetery and previous building foundations had not reached that deeply.
Mr. Austin, at a recent news conference in Manhattan, tried to explain the error. They first assumed there was nothing left of the cemetery, he said. Then after work began last summer, a preliminary review suggested there might be 15 skeletons on the site. "The project outgrew us," he said. "What was originally envisioned as no remains, then 15, 20, 25, has now mushroomed to where it now looks like there is something in the neighborhood of 600 remains in that area." Some experts have estimated that as many as 1,000 might be there.
 
Slaves and Free Blacks
 The black contribution to the development of New York City began with the arrival of Dutch explorers. There were slaves and, for a time, a thriving class of free blacks. In 1644, the Dutch gave partial freedom to 11 blacks and granted them plots of land for farming that extended from present-day Canal Street to 34th Street. From this land they supplied the struggling colony with fresh produce. But by 1716 the British adopted laws barring blacks from owning land. The established churches refused to have blacks buried in their cemeteries, making a separate burial ground for blacks necessary.
The 1865 edition of Valentines Manual noted: "So little seems to have been thought of the race that not even a dedication of their burial place was made by the church authorities or any others who might reasonably be supposed to have an interest in the matter. The lands were unappropriated, and though within convenient distance from the city, the locality was unattractive and desolate, so by permission the slave population were allowed to inter their dead there."
Though the earliest burials in the area may have taken place in the late 17th century, the Negros Burial Ground as such is believed to have been in use from about 1710 to 1790. For a time burials also took place in the old Commons, now the land surrounding City Hall.
"There are probably a great number of burials underneath Elk Street, underneath Reade Street, underneath Chambers Street and in City Hall Park," Mr. Pagano said.
 
Proposed Historic District
 The entire area is now part of a proposed city-designated Negros Burial Ground/Common Ground Historic District. The city Landmarks Preservation Commission is scheduled to hold a hearing on Sept. 1.
Professor Blakey, an associate professor of anthropology and curator of Howard University's W. Montague Cobb Collection has submitted a research proposal to the G.S.A. and to Mr. Dinkins's advisory committee suggesting several ways in which the human remains can help the experts "fit some missing pieces into the historical chronicle."
Through studying health factors, he said, "they can determine what the social and economic positions were for these ancestors." But perhaps more exciting, he said, is the possibility of "getting a better handle on exactly where folks came from."
It is presumed that most Africans in New York City were from West Africa. They were taken into captivity then brought across the Atlantic first to Brazil or the Caribbean islands then on to New York City. Professor Blakey said scientists would look for "chemical signatures of environmental exposure" to determine where they were born and where they lived before coming to New York.
 
Education vs. Respect
 "Through one's diet one incorporates particular elements into the bone and into the teeth, also through drinking water," he said. "Some of these elements may be more specific in certain parts of West Africa, South America and the Caribbean. The teeth develop in childhood so that even in these adults we may have a signature of the region that they were from and the diet they had in childhood and then compare that with their adult experience."
Still many people, especially blacks, have mixed emotions about what is essentially raiding a cemetery to learn about the past and illuminate issues of race and class that resonate today. Howard Dodson, for one, said that when he saw the skeletons lying exposed at the construction site, the "scientist-historian" side of him marveled at what could be learned from studying the remains.
"But the 'roots' side of me said, 'You're not supposed to mess with the dead,' " said Mr. Dodson, the chief of the Schomburg Center for Research for Black Culture in Harlem.
Many have protested that a people who received no justice in life were receiving no peace in death.
"So many people were willing to forgo challenging the system in the present life just simply to have a decent afterlife," said Alton H. Maddox Jr., a lawyer and community leader. "So many of our people, because they've been so mistreated in life, really want to rest in peace."
 
Pilgrimages to Site
 But Professor Blakey and others insist that "to learn from archeological sites constitutes another form of respect for our ancestors."
"It has special importance because so much of African-American history has been lost," he said.
A commission to be appointed jointly by Mr. Austin of the G.S.A. and Mr. Dinkins will ultimately determine the future of the site. Suggestions range from leaving the cemetery intact to building a museum on the site and re-interring the 415 human skeletons there.
In the meantime the construction site has become a place of pilgrimage for students, for politicians, even for actors who starred in the television miniseries that is credited with renewing interest in African-American history, "Roots."
"I cried," Noel Pointer, the jazz musician and singer, said of his first visit to the site. Mr. Pointer, who plans to take part in a 26-hour remembrance vigil at the site, beginning at noon today, added: "You hear all about these archeological and scientific terms and you say to yourself, 'This is very interesting.' But until you get down there and you see what the bodies look like -- you see the skeletons of the children laying in the earth -- then you realize that these are people."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidates' Records;
Bush and Congress: Rising Feud Produced a Legislative Deadlock

SERIES: The Bush Record/Last of 10 articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
At almost every campaign stop these days, President Bush blames Congress for the nation's problems: the weak economy, the poor state of public schools, crime and violence and urban decay.
On Capitol Hill, meantime, the President is attacked daily from all directions. Liberal Democrats accuse him of pandering to the wealthy. Conservative Republicans say he has no principles. And moderates in both parties maintain that he has failed to offer the programs or to provide the leadership that the times require. 
 These are the political signs pointing to a reality of the Bush Presidency. Rarely in modern American history, say scholars and politicians in both parties, has the relationship between the President and Congress been as sour and the legislative product as meager.
"Is there one member of Congress who would stand up for him in a pinch? I doubt it," said Terry Eastland, a policy strategist in the Reagan Administration who has just completed a book about Presidents and the Presidency.
Mr. Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, speaks of a "ritual of confrontation" that has frozen the legislative process. Republicans and Democrats argue over who is to blame, but this extraordinary deadlock has sparked a national debate over the merits of "divided government" in which different parties control the Congress and the White House.
Mr. Bush has had some legislative successes, particularly in foreign policy but also occasionally in the domestic area. On balance, however, whether through his own fault or Congress's, he has had a harder time getting his way on legislation than any other President elected since World War II.
With little money to spend because of the large Federal deficit, he has put forward a wide range of domestic policy proposals dealing with Government spending, health, crime, energy, education, banking and many other topics. But they have been offered without passion, without a connecting theme, without any ranking of priorities, and Mr. Bush has hardly lifted a finger to build public support for most of them or to get them enacted.
When Mr. Bush has spoken out, he has emphasized narrow, symbolic steps like tax breaks for wealthy investors, tuition subsidies for students in private schools and an expansion in the number of Federal crimes punishable by death -- measures he knows the Democratic Congress will reject. And when Congress has tried to take matters into its own hands, in areas like parental leave, civil rights, minimum wage and campaign finance, he has been quick to veto.
"I wasn't elected to do it the way liberal Democrats that control Congress want, so I've had to stand up to them," Mr. Bush said in an interview in June with The New York Times.
Congress has responded in kind. In some cases, it has ducked responsibility, as in its refusal to approve essential new money for the savings-and-loan bailout, an ostrich-like position that avoids politically unpopular votes but is costing taxpayers as much as $6 million a day.
In other instances, Congress has sought simply to embarrass Mr. Bush politically, as in its insistence on a surtax on annual incomes of more than $1 million. This proposal is not intended to raise revenue so much as to taunt the President.
Politically, the deadlock has damaged both sides. The latest New York Times/CBS News Polls show that only 30 percent of adult Americans approve of the way President Bush is handling his job, and only 20 percent like the way Congress is performing.
The roots seem to be deeper than the simple fact of divided Government, of a Republican President and a Democratic Congress, a lineup that has become the rule rather than the exception in the last 40 years.
"In other periods when there was partisan conflict," said Mr. Darman, who has served in every Republican Administration since Richard M. Nixon's, the President and Congress went through the motions of confrontation, but then "there was a kind of ritual of compromise that got something done."
But now, Mr. Darman said, "We've fallen into a ritual of confrontation that doesn't get things done."
 
A Promising Beginning
Offering a Hand To the Opposition
 On the steps of the Capitol waiting for his inauguration ceremony to begin, George Bush looked down into the audience, spotted his old friend Dan Rostenkowski, the influential chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, waved conspicuously and shouted, "Hi, Danny!"
Many who witnessed the moment -- who watched Mr. Rostenkowski beam, who recognized Mr. Bush's knack for making meaningful personal gestures -- sensed a period of bipartisan cooperation in the offing. And Mr. Bush's Inaugural Address only heightened those expectations.
To those he called his friends in the loyal opposition, the new President declared: "I put out my hand. I am putting out my hand to you, Mr. Speaker. I am putting out my hand to you, Mr. Majority Leader. For this is the thing: This is the age of the offered hand."
And he went on to say: "Let us negotiate soon, and hard. But in the end, let us produce."
Mr. Bush, said a person who was on his staff then, thought that if lawmakers liked him personally, they would side with him politically. He kept a locker in the House gym. He invited countless senators and representatives, their families and even their favored constituents to the living quarters of the White House for small talk and photos. He wrote scores of friendly notes.
 
Largest Opposition Ever
 But he had misjudged the situation. Democrats had gained Congressional seats in the 1988 election, and Mr. Bush took office facing the largest opposition majority in Congress of any newly elected President in history.
In addition, the overarching problem of the large Federal deficit meant that little money was available for popular new programs. Politicians can usually find ways to cooperate when there are funds to be divvied up, but their instinct is to pass the buck when belts must be tightened.
As if those obstacles were not enough, Mr. Bush made another miscalculation. In his first weeks in office, he pulled out all the stops to get the Senate to confirm John G. Tower, a former Senator from Texas, as Secretary of Defense, making phone calls and promises and taking the steps Presidents usually take when they really want something from Congress. But the nomination was rejected anyway, and this was a serious setback to the new President. (Mr. Tower died in a plane crash in April 1991.)
"He learned a lesson from the Tower fight," a White House official said. "Never again would he go to the mat -- I mean really go all out -- unless he knew in advance he would win."
 
Sporadic Success
Wielding the Veto To Shape Policy
 Even in the face of those disadvantages, Mr. Bush has had some success in dealing with Congress, especially in his first two years in office.
He was quick to deal with the savings-and-loan debacle, an issue that had been swept under the rug during the 1988 campaign, and the plan he pushed through Congress in 1989 now shows signs of resolving the worst disaster in financial regulation since the Great Depression.
He also broke years of inertia, warded off criticism from business interests and the conservative wing of his party and struck a compromise with Congress over revisions in the Clean Air Act, achieving the most comprehensive and expensive environmental statute ever enacted. He also shaped and signed important legislation granting new rights to the disabled.
Mr. Bush won authority to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico, got increased financing for Head Start and new money for farm and housing programs, and ended years of partisan dispute over United States policy in Central America. Just this week, he persuaded lawmakers to back a plan for aid to Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
 
Flurry of Vetoes
 Mr. Bush has also had extraordinary success wielding his veto power. So far, he has vetoed 31 measures and has never been overridden. Surprisingly he has never vetoed any bill on the ground that it cost too much money, a counterweight to his charge that increased Government spending is Congress's fault.
Sometimes he used the veto to get Congress to modify its position. For example, he vetoed a bill to raise the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour from $3.35, and then signed one that put the floor at $4.25.
Other times Congress refused to back down, and Mr. Bush ended up signing bills similar to ones he had vetoed. That was the case with civil rights legislation. And in the face of Congressional pressure and the recession, the President finally agreed to a measure extending unemployment benefits.
Several vetoes were cast on ideological grounds, like those on bills to lift the ban on Federal money for fetal tissue research or to relax restrictions on abortions. Other measures were vetoed for partisan political advantage, like those that would have made voter registration easier and permitted Federal workers to engage in partisan political activities, both of which were thought to benefit Democrats more than Republicans.
But mindful of his experience with the Tower nomination, the President only once vetoed a bill without knowing in advance that he had the votes to prevent Congress from overriding him, a senior staff assistant said.
The one exception was legislation put forth after the massacre in Tiananmen Square in 1989 that would have allowed Chinese students to remain in the United States after their visas expired. Mr. Bush felt it was an intrusion into his ability to conduct foreign policy. The House voted to override by a large margin, but the Senate fell four votes short of the necessary two-thirds' majority.
 
The Budget War
Capital Gains Bill Destroyed a Truce
 Lawmakers say they can count on one hand the issues on which Mr. Bush went all out and took political risks to win his way in Congress. The Tower nomination and the veto override on the Chinese students are two. The resolution permitting him to go to war against Iraq is a third case, and the Clarence Thomas nomination to the Supreme Court is a fourth.
The fifth example is the budget.
A month after taking office, Mr. Bush sent Congress a list of changes he wanted in the budget prepared by the Reagan Administration. He spelled out spending increases in popular programs like education and space exploration and promised to offset the additional costs with spending cuts. But he never specified the cuts, leaving it to Congress to make the politically difficult choices.
This strategy, apparently devised by Mr. Darman, is one that Mr. Bush has embraced throughout his Presidency, not just on budget matters but in health care and many other areas: take sole credit for popular proposals, but force Congress to bear or at least share the blame for painful steps.
It is a strategy that infuriates lawmakers.
"When there's good news to report," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, "the President would like everybody in America to think he has the power of a king. When there's bad news, he would like everybody in America to believe he has no power at all. It's the complete absence of any willingness to assert leadership and assume responsibility."
 
Last Vestige of Cooperation
 But in 1989, Congressional leaders did not want to fight a serious budget battle any more than the President did. They agreed with Mr. Bush that spring to a just-get-me-through-the-night budget that met the legal targets with gimmicks rather than real belt-tightening and that put off hard choices until the next year.
The truce did not last. As part of his deal with Congressional leaders, Mr. Bush had promised to forsake for the rest of 1989 his favorite tax proposal, a cut in the capital gains tax. But when the House of Representatives unexpectedly passed such a plan, Mr. Bush began fighting for it in the Senate.
There were clearly enough votes in the Senate to pass the bill; there usually are for any tax cut. But Senator Mitchell, a die-hard opponent of a capital gains tax reduction, used every parliamentary maneuver available to him as majority leader to prevent a vote, and the measure died.
Democrats were furious because they thought Mr. Bush had broken his word. The President was outraged because he could not get a vote when he had a clear majority on the domestic issue most important to him. The last vestige of cooperation had faded away.
"Things were never the same again," said a top Presidential adviser. "They thought the President was too popular, and they had to bring him down a notch."
By 1990, the deficit could no longer be ignored. For months, Administration officials and lawmakers negotiated to no avail. Mr. Bush stayed as far removed as possible. Congressional leaders say that Mr. Bush presided over every meeting they attended at the White House about the war against Iraq but that except for the opening session, he never attended a meeting on the budget.
Then, to get the talks off square one, Mr. Bush acceded in June to the Democrats' demand that tax increases be part of any budget deal.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, one of the President's closest friends, said Mr. Bush knew that reneging on his no-new-taxes pledge would cost him dearly in the public opinion polls. But Mr. Bush may not have understood how much it would cost him politically within his own party. Dozens of Republican lawmakers had taken the pledge themselves, and party loyalty be damned, they were not about to break it.
The President's relationship with the conservative wing of his party, always strained, was now broken. Faced with a large Democratic majority in the House and Senate, he could no longer count on the votes of lawmakers from his own party.
 
The Leadership Issue
Impulse to Avoid Fighting Congress
 In President Bush's view, the failings of his Administration are due mainly to Congressional inaction and political meddling.
If Congress had cut the capital gains tax and had approved the rest of his economic program, the economy would not have performed worse in his term than in any other President's tenure since World War II.
If Congress had not initiated a political witch hunt, the public would pay no mind to charges that Mr. Bush tried for years to curry favor with Saddam Hussein.
If Congress would pay more attention to jobs and the economy, he would not have had to drag his feet in issuing environmental rules.
If Congress would stop harping on the notion that the best way to improve schools is to spend more money, his own ideas for education, like bolstering private schools, would be taken seriously.
If Congress had not forced him to raise taxes, his political standing would be much higher.
But others believe that the President was simply not interested in leading.
"This President doesn't like the idea of doing battle with Congress," said Representative Vin Weber, a Republican from Minnesota. "And he doesn't like the idea of mobilizing the country to get Congress to change."
Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, who has written widely about the relationship between Presidents and Congress, put the case this way: "What Presidents are supposed to do is provide political cover, to help take the heat for difficult decisions that have to be made. They have the bully pulpit. They can shape public opinion. They can help members of Congress do the right thing.
"Bush never got involved in that aspect of the job."

4. Oct. 21, 1989: Bill that would have allowed Federal financing of abortions for victims of rape or incest.
5. Oct. 27, 1989: Budget measure for the District of Columbia that would have expanded the district's use of Federal and local money to pay for abortions.
6. Nov. 19, 1989: Foreign aid bill that included funds for a United Nations family-planning agency.
7. Nov. 20, 1989: Budget measure for the District of Columbia that allowed funds from local taxes to be spent on abortions.

16. Oct. 22, 1990: Bill that would have reversed Supreme Court decisions that limited the effect of Federal laws against job discrimination; the President said it would lead to job quotas.

HEADLINE: After the Los Angeles Riots: Searching for a Killer and Searching for a Son

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The name "MAE II" is everywhere on the graffiti-covered walls of Eric Fleming's neighborhood in South-Central Los Angeles. It was not until after the riots that Mr. Fleming learned that MAE II had been the "tag" for his oldest son.
"He kept that from me," Mr. Fleming said. "He probably assumed I wouldn't understand. I looked upon it as trashing buildings. We'd walk down the street, and I'd say, 'Oh, look at that,' like it was wrong. Now I see the art in it, but he's gone." 
 The county coroner's office says 47 homicides occurred in the riots that swept through Los Angeles at the end of April, and the first was Mr. Fleming's 18-year-old son, Louis Watson Fleming. He was shot in the temple, just a block from his house, at 6:25 P.M. on April 29, a little more than three hours after the announcement of the verdict acquitting four white Los Angeles police officers in the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King, who is black.
Since then, Mr. Fleming has been searching the streets, not only for his son's killer but also for the son he had not fully known.
"I learned what my son was up against to be a teen-ager on the streets of Los Angeles," said the father, 39, who has sold cars and Christmas trees and raced cars for a living, but is now unemployed. "I didn't know how bad it was."
Mr. Fleming said he had interviewed dozens of people, some of them friends of his son, who were in a crowd of looters and onlookers at the scene of his son's death: a swap meet, an indoor market filled with stalls where vendors sold everything from baby clothes to electronics. "I was out there getting answers that first night," he said. "I saw the firemen putting out fires. I knew the evidence was going to be lost."
 
Clues Lost in the Chaos
 The fires and the chaos of those days have severely hampered the investigations of the riot-related homicides. The two detectives assigned to the triple homicide in which Louis Fleming died said they had relied on his father from the start.
"Our crime scenes were all burned up," said one of the detectives, Oscar Lamarque, so Mr. Fleming helped in the investigation. "Eric was out there flushing everything to us. He pointed us in the direction of witnesses. He gave us names and addresses."
Mr. Lamarque and his partner, Richard Marks, have not made any arrests, but, based on interviews with witnesses, they said they believed that the killer was a member of a Hispanic gang and that he had randomly shot Louis Fleming first, then two others in the crowd that evening: 15-year-old Greg Davis and 42-year-old Dwight Taylor.
Mr. Lamarque, whose parents came here from Mexico, said he felt a bond with Eric Fleming. Mr. Lamarque also has a son, Alonso, who turned 18 on July 17.
Mr. Lamarque said his son was lucky: He has had a suburban childhood, in the San Fernando Valley. The detective himself grew up in South-Central Los Angeles, not far from where Louis Fleming lived.
For a teen-ager in South-Central Los Angeles, Mr. Lamarque said, "You're in the midst of all those gangs. Murder is something you live with."
Louis Fleming was killed 12 days before his 19th birthday. He would not have graduated from high school this year, but he was looking forward to spending this summer in Utah in a Job Corps program.
Mr. Lamarque said Louis Fleming had already accomplished something remarkable: Not only had he stayed alive for 18 years in South-Central Los Angeles, but he had not joined a gang or acquired a rap sheet.
"He was a good kid," Mr. La marque said. "A lot of the other kids put him on a pedestal for standing up to the gangs. He was very well liked."
 
Shunning the Gangs
 Eric Fleming said he had been astonished to find out how popular his son was. More than 600 people -- friends and neighbors, and even the driver of the bus he rode to school -- attended his funeral at the Figueroa Church of Christ in South Los Angeles.
Mr. Fleming, technically Louis Fleming's stepfather, functioned as the boy's father from an early age. He is divorced from his son's mother, Sherry Watson Fleming, who drives a city bus and attends college at night in the hope of becoming a pharmacist or optometrist. The couple share custody of their children, and Mr. Fleming spent a lot of time with Louis and his other three sons, Byron Scott, 4; Renaldo, 14, and Spencer, 8.
"I always told Louis: 'We don't need gangs. We're not followers. We're leaders,' " Mr. Fleming said.
But the pressure to join never let up. "It was always, 'What set you from?' " Mr. Fleming said. "He went from high school to high school, trying to get away from the gangs. He was holding his own. I was proud of him."
His mother said: "If you don't want to be pushed around and shot at, you can't wear certain colors. My son got to the point he would just wear black and gray. Just black and gray."
On the walls, next to "MAE II," Louis had written "W.D.C." for "We Don't Care." That was the name of his group of fellow graffiti artists, and it signified defiance. The translation, according to Mr. Lamarque: "We don't care about gang bangers."
"Whenever a homicide goes down, we cruise by and read the walls," Mr. Lamarque said. "The walls will tell you the story. The shooters love to boast." But Mr. Lamarque said Louis Fleming's killer had not left any graffiti clues.
Six weeks after he was killed, his father and Mr. Lamarque took a walk around the neighborhood.
Pointing out one wall and then another, Mr. Fleming showed the detective the neighborhood's memorial for his son. Next to "MAE II," the graffiti artists had added "R.I.P.": Rest In Peace.

Byron held a photo of his oldest brother, Louis, the first homicide victim in the riots that followed the acquittal of the police officers accused of beating Rodney G. King. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Districts and Loyalties Fueling Black Political Surge in Mississippi

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 7

 BODY:
For many years Ollie Mohammed prospered, presiding over Mohammed's Department Store in the Mississippi Delta city of Belzoni and, after election to the State Senate in 1979, serving in increasingly important posts.
But Mr. Mohammed, who has been president pro tem of the Senate, lost in the Democratic primary this week, the victim of redistricting and changing voting patterns by blacks. Mr. Mohammed, a native Mississippian of Lebanese ancestry, was defeated by a black woman, Barbara Blackmon, who was one of more than a dozen blacks who won in legislative primary races around the state on Tuesday. 
 If Mrs. Blackmon, a 36-year-old tax lawyer, and the other black candidates who are expected to win in November do so, the Mississippi Legislature will be nearly 23 percent black. That would be the largest percentage of blacks in any state legislature in the nation. The Georgia Legislature now has the largest percentage, 18 percent.
 
Behind Louisiana and Alabama
 Since 33 percent of Mississippi's voters are black, the state will still lag behind two of its neighbors, Louisiana and Alabama, in approaching legislative representation that reflects its black population.
The gains by Mississippi's blacks are in a state that had the worst record of minority registration and voting before the Voting Rights Act of 1965. As recently as 1970, it had only one black legislator.
"This is a turning point in state politics, especially in the Delta, where we have traditionally had whites representing blacks," Mrs. Blackmon said. "Redistricting had a lot to do with it, but it was also a coming of age of black voters."
Political leaders and researchers said the expected increases in the numbers of black lawmakers were, in part, a result of court decisions and amendments to the Voting Rights Act, which has given state legislatures more leeway since 1982 in drawing districts to increase minority representation. In addition, they said, the black candidates in the Mississippi races -- among them lawyers, college professors and administrators -- represented an unusual flowering of black talent. And they pointed to higher turnouts by black voters.
Mary Coleman, a political scientist at Jackson State University, said black voting patterns had changed. Over the years, she said, the paternalism and plantation economy of the largely black Mississippi Delta had spawned scores of white leaders, like Mr. Mohammed, who were secure and seemingly untouchable. But now black voters are showing a new willingness to break free of that tradition.
David Bositis, a senior researcher with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization based in Washington, described the political change this way: "Mississippi has historically been the most resistant to change among the states in the region. But now we are seeing a whole generational change in places like Mississippi because of redistricting and the changes in the Voting Rights Act. They didn't do this voluntarily. It was forced on the state."
Before redistricting, blacks held 21 of the 122 seats in the Mississippi House of Representatives and 4 of the 52 seats in the State Senate. Based on the primary results, the House is likely to have 9 new black members, for a total of 30, and the Senate may have 5 new ones, for a total of 9.
Those projections, said Leslie McLemore, a political scientist at Jackson State University, reflect the races in which successful black candidates in the past week's Democratic primaries face no opposition or token Republican or independent opposition in November; the state is overwhelmingly Democratic in local politics. In addition, he said, blacks will face white opponents on Aug. 25 runoffs in three State Senate races and three House races. If those black candidates win, he said, they would also seem assured of victory in November.
Before the latest round of legislative redistricting around the country, a study by the Joint Center for Political Studies found that the nation had 460 black state legislators, 6 percent of the total. Mr. Bositis predicted that the South alone would have as many as 120 additional black state lawmakers after the elections this year, largely because of redistricting.
 
New Generation of Leaders
 Mr. Bositis pointed out that all but 4 of the nation's 460 black legislators were Democrats and that Democrats controlled two-thirds of the nation's legislatures. Consequently, the increase in the number of black legislators will mean an increase in influence for blacks within the Democratic majorities that control state legislatures.
"Plus this is a new generation of black leaders who have not had to accommodate themselves to the same difficult conditions as their predecessors did," Mr. Bositis said. "In many cases they are better trained and more educated, and there are all sorts of long-term implications in that, including the development of more people to run for higher offices and to assume very senior positions down the road."
One new leader who attributed his victory in large part to redistricting is Willie Simmons, a 45-year-old former Mississippi deputy corrections commissioner. He defeated a 21-year veteran legislator, State Senator Robert Crook, who is white. Mr. Crook had taken on the state's largest prison, Parchman, in his home county, as his special cause. But Mr. Simmons, with his background as a corrections official, had the data and insights needed to raise questions about some of Mr. Crook's decisions.
"We are talking about a new Mississippi," Mr. Simmons said of the increases in black representation. "You will see a new focus on change."
 
Low Turnout Among Whites
 Mr. Mohammed attributed his loss to Mrs. Blackmon in part to a heavy turnout by black voters and a low turnout by whites. Mrs. Blackmon won with 53 percent of the vote in a district in which 61 percent of the voting-age population is black.
Mr. Mohammed pointed out that the heaviest concentration of white voters was in Yazoo County, the home of the Republican candidate, Cecil A. Cartwright. "White voters there just stayed away from the polls on Tuesday, and they're waiting to vote for their guy in November," he said. Mr. Mohammed said that he would also support the Republican candidate, contending that Mrs. Blackmon is not a legitimate resident of the district.
Mrs. Blackmon and her husband, Ed Blackmon, a member of the House, maintain a home and law offices in Jackson but legally claim as their official residence a second home and law office in Canton, which is just inside the boundaries of her new State Senate district and his House district.
 
Changing Voting Habits
 Mrs. Blackmon said the redistricting had played a part in her victory, but she said she had also won because she had persuaded blacks to break with old voting habits. She said that many poor blacks to whom Mr. Mohammed had extended credit at his department store had felt compelled to vote for him over the years out of gratitude.
"I told them to keep on taking his credit but to stop voting for his politics," she said. "I told them that they had already made him rich."
Ms. Coleman, the political scientist at Jackson State, said that the main challenge facing the new black legislators was to stand together on issues and then unite with some white legislators to enact laws helpful to the black population. In the past, she said, the smaller number of blacks, along with a number of "progressive white" legislators, had together been able to block bills considered harmful to blacks but had rarely been able to enact programs that addressed their needs, like landlord-tenant laws.
But Ms. Coleman is optimistic that with the right coalitions, skillfully brought together, blacks can persuade the Legislature to tackle these needs. "Coalitions will just form, collapse and reform over different issues," she said.

HEADLINE: A Showdown on Workers' Compensation in Maine

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
What if the law required everybody to buy insurance, but no one wanted to sell it?
That may soon happen in Maine, where after 77 years the workers' compensation insurance system appears to be dissolving. Its failure would be the first collapse of this basic form of social insurance since workers' compensation systems were established early this century. 
 The collapse could be devastating to local employers, many of which say they would have to close without the protection that workers' compensation provides them when employees are injured. And Maine's situation provides a nightmare vision to insurance regulators nationwide, as workers' compensation systems in more than a dozen other states watch costs spin out of control and insurers incur record losses.
Besides Maine, states with highly troubled workers' compensation systems include California, Kansas, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Texas. Most states require employers to buy workers' compensation coverage for their work forces.
 
How Rates Are Set
 The insurers insist that the central question raised by Maine's crisis is whether regulators should set premiums not on the basis of what it costs insurers to provide coverage -- as used to be the practice -- but on what they believe customers can afford. The insurers say state regulators, in their efforts to protect the public from high rates, have put off dealing with the rising underlying costs of insurance, much as Congress has delayed confronting the Federal budget deficit.
Many people in the insurance industry consider Maine to be the most egregious offender. Insurance company after insurance company has left the state, refusing to provide workers' compensation coverage because they say the state, for a decade, has refused to allow them to raise premiums enough to cover skyrocketing health claims and legal costs.
Recently, two of the three primary companies still doing business in Maine formally announced that they would leave at the end of the year. The third company says it, too, will give up by the end of the year unless the Governor and the Legislature do something to reform the system.
For small manufacturers like J. R. Maines in Naples, Me., prospects for the future appear frightening.
 
A Business at Risk
 The tiny maker of wood parts already pays $12 for every $100 of its 30 employees' salaries for workers' compensation. It is in an industry that pays particularly high premiums because of the high risk involved in the work. The company's owner, Richard Dyke, says he cannot afford to pay higher premiums. He also says he would close his doors the moment his coverage disappeared.
"I wouldn't expose myself to that kind of personal liability," Mr. Dyke said, "nor would I expose my workers to the risk."
Regulators say keeping a tight limit on premiums is necessary to protect the public from insurers' bloated rate requests. But as states from New Jersey to California debate how much to hold down prices in workers' compensation and automobile insurance, insurers are increasingly likely to invoke Maine as the extreme example of what happens when premiums do not cover costs.
Orin Kramer, an economist in Princeton, N.J., who specializes in insurance, argued in a recent paper published by an industry trade group that regulation of workers' compensation and private automobile insurance underwent a profound shift in the 1980's. It was then, Mr. Kramer said, that in response to sharp increases in the cost of providing insurance state regulators began to consider rate increases on the basis of what they felt the public could afford.
 
Messengers With Bad News
 Mr. Kramer estimated that the worst losses for insurers in the nation from 1987 through 1989 were in Maine, where the companies paid out $148 in claims for every $100 in premiums.
"We are the messengers who deliver the bad news about what is going on in society, and oftentimes we get shot," said Grover Czech, a vice president of the Maryland Insurance Group, one of the two companies that announced they would abandon the Maine workers' compensation business on Jan. 1. The other company that is leaving at the year's end is Commercial Union of Boston.
Critics of the insurance industry in Maine say they doubt that insurers' losses are as bad as the companies claim. Often, the critics charge, companies squander the public's money in waste and inefficiencies, and they exaggerate their real costs when they request higher premiums. One prominent national critic, Robert Hunter of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, said: "Companies around the country say their costs are so high. In fact, the increases they are asking for often include unacceptable inefficiencies or even considerable profits."
 
Costs Are Growing
 The crises afflicting state workers' compensation systems are almost all fueled by the same destructive cost spiral: growing medical and legal costs, broadening definitions of job-related injuries, and fraud and abuse.
Job-related injuries and sickness cost employers an estimated $62 billion in workers' compensation insurance in the United States in 1991, nearly triple the amount spent in 1980. Insurance company losses for workers' compensation claims were $7.1 billion nationally -- the greatest last year of any time in history, said A. M. Best, the insurance research company.
From the 1960's to the mid-1980's, Maine repeatedly revised its workers' compensation laws, making the system more complex and costly, trying -- as other states were -- to make compensation for workers more humane, and to a series of recommendations in 1972 by a national commission appointed by President Richard M. Nixon.
At one point in Maine, the ceiling on benefits reached twice the average weekly wage in the state, and benefits for partial disabilities could extend for a lifetime with cost-of-living adjustments. If any employer was notified of a workers' injury and did not contest it in 44 days, the insurer was obligated to pay for the injury as long as it lasted.
 
A Hockey Team's Exit
 The result was a surge in litigation, medical bills and in the amount insurers were paying out in claims. For many businesses, the cost of insurance can be unbearable. "It would have been a lot easier to stay in Maine if workers' comp had not gone so high," said Ed Anderson, the chairman and chief executive of the former Maine Mariners Hockey Club, a Boston Bruins farm club that recently moved to Rhode Island. "For the same player, making $60,000, we pay $6,500. In Maine it was $11,000."
Responding to the cries of business, the state did not grant any rate increases from 1981 to 1987 for companies doing business in Maine. In 1985 the Maine Legislature actually reduced workers' compensation premiums by 8 percent.
More and more customers were dropped by private carriers from the so-called voluntary market, and had to buy coverage from a state-operated pool. Such assigned-risk pools were originally intended to provide insurance to a small minority of customers who were rejected by private carriers. But in Maine, with so many insurers fleeing the market, 90 percent have come to buy their insurance from the pool. By law, all licensed carriers in the state must share any losses the pool may incur.
Industry leaders like M. R. Greenberg, the chairman of American International Group, one of the nation's largest insurance companies, said the losses were staggering. In 1987, he said, his company took in $6 million in premiums for policies it chose to write in Maine and paid $61 million for its share of the losses in the assigned-risk pool.
 
Legislative Action
 By 1987, faced by threats from the more than two dozen companies then writing workers' compensation business to leave the state, the Legislature enacted changes that curtailed benefits in order to cut costs and promised to have employers, not insurance companies, pay for the assigned-risk pool losses in 1988. Starting in 1989, the pool's losses were to be split evenly between employers and insurers. More than a dozen insurers were enticed back into the state.
But in the following years the state again granted rate increases far below what insurers said they needed to cover costs. In 1988, when the insurance industry sought to more than double its rates, the superintendent granted an increase of only 25 percent; in 1989 he granted a 22 percent increase, after the insurers had sought 45 percent.
In hindsight, the former insurance superintendent, Joseph Edwards, now says the workers' compensation market in Maine was paying out $250 million more than it was taking in during those years. In setting rates in 1988 and 1989, he says, he overestimated the savings insurers were realizing as a result of the 1987 legislative changes.
 
Critics See Hidden Profits
 Some critics still argue that behind insurers' complex bookkeeping lie hidden profits. Patrick N. McTeague, a counsel for the Maine A.F.L.-C.I.O. who also represents workers with compensation claims, said the severity of Maine's workers' compensation crisis comes from many highly unsafe workplaces and a decision by insurers to make an example of Maine in order to threaten regulators elsewhere.
"I believe that the companies are making money," Mr. McTeague said. "I am absolutely certain they are making money."
In the last four years, as the deficit of the assigned-risk pool increased, and insurers left the burden fell more heavily on those insurance companies that remained. Last year, a dispute between Gov. John R. McKernan and the Legislature over how to reform workers' compensation shut the state government for nearly three weeks.
By this summer, more than 90 percent of workers' compensation customers were in the assigned risk pool, and the latest estimate by the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche placed the net operating loss of the assigned risk pool for the last three years at $574 million.
A state government panel is now studying the situation and Governor McKernan is expected to call a special session of the Legislature after the panel releases its recommendations at the end of August.
But Charles Soltan, a lawyer for Hanover Insurance, the last major insurer that has not yet filed papers to leave the state, says that unless some strong actions are taken quickly, his company is likely to leave as well. One small new company, Acadia Group, based in Portland, has not yet declared its intentions.
Brian Atchinson, the state's superintendant of insurance, said he could not predict what solutions the Governor and the Legislature might reach, if any.
"Insurers want to know who is going to pay the deficit," Mr. Atchinson said. "There is a great concern about not being the last one to turn out the lights."

HEADLINE: Times Square Plan Is on Hold, but Meter Is Still Running

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Although state and city officials are prepared to postpone indefinitely construction of the four Times Square Center office towers, interest continues to grow on the multimillion-dollar loan that the public will eventually have to repay to the developers for site acquisition costs.
Officials are seeking to stop the clock on the interest obligation to the developers, Park Tower Realty and the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Otherwise, the public might be left owing tens of millions of dollars in interest alone, in addition to at least $153 million for condemnation awards and tenant settlements. 
 "We expect to agree, in essence, that the interest on this outstanding balance should not continue to accrue in the period before the office towers are built," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, in an interview yesterday.
Under the agreement the city and state hope to reach with the developers, interest would stop running from the date that the developers were supposed to start building, in late 1993 or early 1994, until the time that they begin. That could be five or 10 years or even longer.
 
Awaiting Market Rebound
 Mr. Weisbrod added that there was also a tentative agreement to increase the interim rent paid by the developers for their building sites, as well as the rent they are to pay in lieu of real-estate taxes when the towers are constructed.
In exchange, the developers would be released from a construction timetable that would have forced them to build at a time when commercial tenants are virtually impossible to find. Rather, the developers would be free to begin Times Square Center when the market dictated.
While the developers have been paying acquisition costs as they arise, they are ultimately liable only for $88 million. The balance amounts to a long-term, interest-bearing loan that is to be repaid with the public share of the project's proceeds. Much of the repayment would come from a 50 percent credit against the rent paid for the office tower sites.
As of last week, $172.5 million had been paid to owners and tenants on the four blocks from Broadway to Eighth Avenue, between 41st and 43d Streets, according to the state Urban Development Corporation.
 
Criticism of Costs
 When all the settlements have been reached, the total might come to $241 million. That means the public would owe the developers at least $153 million, together with interest calculated at the prime rate plus one percent. Currently, that would amount to $10.7 million annually. A year ago, it would have been $14.5 million.
Also, under a 1988 agreement, site acquisition costs are defined as including the environmental impact statement, appraisals, title reports, title insurance premiums, surveys, filing fees, transfer taxes, and certain legal fees incurred by the developers and the government.
The Urban Development Corporation would not disclose the total amount of these costs to date, other than to put it in the millions of dollars.
In the wake of the disclosure last week that Times Square Center would be put on hold indefinitely, there was renewed criticism of the financial arrangement as a needless public subsidy.
State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, said, "We're talking of losses here that could well amount into the hundreds of millions of dollars, without anything being done and with 10, 12 years being lost in cleaning up 42d Street."
 
Call for More Scrutiny
 The City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said any revision of the deal would warrant scrutiny. "We have always had questions about the subsidies here," she said.
But city and state officials continue to believe that both the process and the cost will be justified.
"The reasons for cleaning up 42d Street have never been more compelling," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, a subsidiary of the state development agency. "Times Square is just on the verge of making a comeback and 42d Street is a cancer on that revival."
 
Increasing Costs
 As long as 42d Street was in the hands of dozens of private owners, the officials contend, there was no chance that it could be revitalized. But, they say, the public treasury could not have afforded the condemnation costs and no developer would have taken on the responsibility without some kind of limit to its liability.
"This project was conceived as a means of accomplishing a major public purpose at the same time as not having the city and public liable for a tremendous cash outlay up front," Mr. Weisbrod said.
He said it was essential to have a cap beyond which the developers could recover their costs.
At the time of the deal, he said, it was believed that $88 million would more than cover the cost of acquiring the entire site. "Because this project was delayed by some years of planning and many, many years of litigation," he said, "those land costs rose substantially."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finances;
Spending in Congressional Races Is Up in a Topsy-Turvy Year

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Congressional campaign spending has spurted this year, but political action committees are providing a smaller share of the cash, a Federal Election Commission report showed today.
Spending through June 30 in all House and Senate races reached $288 million, up 50 percent from $192 million two years ago. The increase appeared to be caused largely by two hotly contested Senate races in California, which had none in 1990, and by an increase in House candidates seeking to take advantage of reapportionment. There are 2,247 people in races for the 435 House seats this year, as against 1,372 in 1990. 
 Spencer Abraham, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said "a very anti-incumbent sort of atmosphere" was a major cause in the increased number of candidates and the fund-raising success of many House Republican challengers.
 
Year of the Challenger
 Leslie C. Francis, executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said he thought the opportunities offered by redistricting were the main reason for the surge in both candidates and spending, but he said widespread complaints about Congress meant "this is the year to be running as a challenger."
The report, the commission's last complete look at all House and Senate contests until four days before the Nov. 3 election, shows a much more modest increase in contributions by political action committees.
Their largesse, combined by the commission with relatively small amounts from other political committees, climbed to $98 million in the first 18 months of this election cycle from $89 million between Jan. 1, 1989, and June 30, 1990.
But with overall receipts soaring by 32 percent, to $369 million this year from $279 million two years ago, PAC contributions were only 27 percent of the total, compared to 32 percent in 1990.
 
Money for Incumbents
 As usual, their contributions went heavily to incumbents, who gathered $80 million of the PAC donations.
Mr. Francis said the economy was a major factor. "They've been having a harder time raising money in this economy," he said political action committee officials told him.
Mr. Abraham said he thought the major reason was that political action committees were waiting to see how House races, more uncertain than usual this year because of redistricting, played out before making their choices among nonincumbents. "We've urged PAC's to hold back," he said. That warning has not hurt House incumbents; their average PAC receipts have increased 16 percent.
Comparisons between different two-year cycles in Senate races are less instructive than analyses of House contests, because every two years a different mix of Senate candidates in large and small states is up for election.
 
D'Amato's Bankroll
 For example, total receipts of Senate candidates went from $116 million by June 30, 1990, to $161 million this year, an increase of $46 million or 39 percent. But $37 million was raised by California candidates in two contested primaries in each party. Total Senate spending went from $74 million in 1990 to $123 million this year, an increase of $49 million or 66 percent. But the California candidates spent $42 million.
The Senate figures did show that the incumbent with the biggest bankroll was Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who had $4.2 million on hand as of June 30. Seven other incumbents had more than $2 million.
The Republicans were Bob Packwood of Oregon, $3.0 million; Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, $2.8 million; Bob Dole of Kansas, $2.3 million, and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, $2.1 million. The Democrats were Bob Graham of Florida, $2.2 million; John B. Breaux of Louisiana, $2.1 million; and Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia, $2.0 million.
The figures for House races showed two different financial strategies emerging in what both parties expect to be an uncertain and swiftly changing series of contests. Republicans are making their first serious effort in a decade to compete broadly for control of the House. There are now 268 Democrats, 166 Republicans and one independent.
 
G.O.P. Focuses on Challengers
 Republicans seem more focused on challenging incumbents. In 68 districts with Democratic incumbents, Republicans have candidates who raised a credible $50,000 by June 30. In only 27 Republican districts was there a Democrat who had raised that much.
But Democrats were in stronger financial shape in "open" seats, where no sitting Representative is seeking re-election. They have candidates with $50,000 or more in 56 such seats, compared to 40 for the Republicans.
Both parties' traditional approach to House campaigns has been to concentrate on protecting their own incumbents and to focus secondly on inviting, if expensive, open seats. Serious efforts to help challengers have come third.
That meant, practically speaking, that Republicans were not seriously contesting enough seats to win control of the House. Mr. Abraham said this year's strategy required having "competitive races in 100 or more districts the Republicans didn't control."
On Friday Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, the chairman of the Republican committee, announced donations of $1,000 each to 71 Republican challengers and 36 candidates in open seats.
Mr. Vander Jagt said he would be providing other help, including his own campaigning. He acknowledged that he had more time available than he expected after his own defeat for renomination on Tuesday. But he said his loss was proof "the anti-incumbent wind is not a breeze, it's a hurricane," and one that should help Republicans simply because there are more Democratic incumbents as targets.
But despite the number of Republican challengers who had raised enough money to get them a hearing, the Federal Election Commission data showed that of the 42 House candidates with $500,000 or more in cash on hand as of June 30, all were incumbents and 31 were Democrats.
Two New Yorkers topped that list. Representatives Charles E. Schumer and Stephen J. Solarz, both of Brooklyn, had $2.1 million and $1.9 million respectively. The other Democrats over $1 million were Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, $1.6 million; Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, $1.4 million; Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, $1.2 million, and Michael A. Andrews of Texas, $1.1 million. The Republicans were David Dreier of California, $1.9 million, and James H. Quillen of Tennessee, $1.1 million.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
To Some, Hope Is Just a Drug Too Far Away

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
Many who treat schizophrenia believe clozapine is the most important medication to come along in 30 years. The press is so excited, it keeps using "Awakenings" in headlines, conjuring images of the film star Robert De Niro taking a new medicine and suddenly going from comatose to superstar.
Clozapine isn't quite De Niro, but study after study shows 30 to 60 percent of chronic schizophrenics who do not respond to other medications -- people plagued by voices, paranoia, hallucinations -- improve considerably, with 10 percent making outstanding progress. It means many on back wards of state hospitals can leave for supervised housing, like group homes. 
 At the Buffalo State hospital, 21 of 31 long-term patients treated were discharged; at Bronx State, 27 percent; at Elmira State, one-third. Dr. Sheikh Qadeer of Elmira was struck by how much clozapine reduced violent incidents. Of 785 state hospital patients treated with it, 170 were discharged.
That should be good economic news. It costs $120,000 a year to keep a person at a state hospital versus $35,000 at a group home and $9,000 at a supervised single-room-occupancy center. The savings should easily offset clozapine's cost -- $5,000 per person a year.
You'd think the state would aggressively test clozapine; half of New York's 12,000 mental patients are schizophrenic. But no. Each state hospital gets a tiny quota. A single psychiatrist in private practice in Manhattan, Dr. Robert Levine, has more clozapine patients (55) than Bronx State (25 of 379 schizophrenics) and South Beach State on Staten Island (15 of 175 schizophrenics) combined.
It takes major advocacy just to get on a state waiting list, says Vera Hassner of the Alliance for the Mentally Ill. Grace Mondo, whose son is at the Syracuse state hospital, yelled for two years and finally got him listed in January. He received clozapine in June. "He came home for his regular weekend visit last Sunday," she says, "and for the first time, instead of withdrawing, he sat with me and my sisters and had coffee and spoke. I'm not saying he's normal, but he's better already."
Ed Wilson, who has a long history of suicide attempts, has been on the South Beach State waiting list since January. His father says his most recent suicide try was two months ago. Hospital officials agree he's a good candidate but say there are more pressing cases on the list. If he's lucky, he'll still be alive when his number comes up.
Clozapine was cleared for use by the Federal Government in 1990. For budgetary reasons, New York was one of the last states to approve it for Medicaid, acting only after advocates sued and a state judge ruled clozapine was "impressive," "unique" and "medically necessary."
But state hospitals are not covered by Medicaid. The Legislature appropriated a special clozapine fund of $2 million a year for state hospitals. It is not nearly enough. State officials say 198 patients are on waiting lists and 1,000 more are likely candidates. The numbers are probably conservative. The state permits only a three-month test period to see if the drug helps, but even its own psychiatrists, like Dr. Jean-Pierre Lindenmayer of Bronx State, think that is too short. Dr. Lindenmayer ignores the rules and gives patients six-month trials.
In social services, you must spend money now to save money in the long run and if you don't, you dig yourself in deeper. In a few cases, clozapine causes a drastic loss of white blood cells that may be fatal if not detected. So users must have weekly blood tests. Dr. Lindenmayer estimates that an additional 150 Bronx patients could be tried on clozapine if there was a community-support system insuring that they returned for weekly testing.
The support system is puny because the state did not finance a single new group home last year; because the state promised to build 1,900 supervised units for the city's homeless mentally ill in two years under the "New York-New York" plan and has delivered 264.
Who's to blame? Take your pick: the state Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, for obstructionism on behalf of the suburban Not In My Back Yard crowd; the Mental Health Commissioner, Richard C. Surles, for backing down over and over; Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for making housing the mentally ill less important than building prisons; a public that gets really angry about higher taxes and unregulated cable.
Even if people do not care, they should not forget: There are thousands of New Yorkers -- hundreds of thousands of Americans -- locked away, useless, who, given clozapine, might be something better. Maybe not De Niros, but people who could live less tormented lives, in a group home or an apartment, working part time, enjoying a coffee with family. Keeping them locked away is more costly, and that is not measured only in hard currency.

HEADLINE: North American Trade Talks Focus on Car Parts

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The free-trade talks among the United States, Canada and Mexico dragged on today, as negotiators continued to sort through and resolve the manytechnical details of a North American free-trade agreement.
During the 11th consecutive day of the talks, negotiators focused on how to count the North American components of cars and trucks. Vehicles with three-fifths of their parts produced in North America will qualify for duty-free treatment under the new agreement. 
 The officials are in the final stages of developing a highly complex system for tracing where parts are produced, not only by auto makers but by several layers of subcontractors. If a subcontractor in the United States assembles a piston, piston rod and piston seal using imported parts, for example, only the value of the assembly work is likely to count toward the North American content of the vehicle, a person with detailed information on the talks said.
Traditional practice in international trade dictates that if a product is assembled in a country, the origin of the parts does not matter.
The 1988 United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement used murky language in defining how a vehicle's component mixture should be counted. One result has been a long-running dispute over whether Honda cars assembled in Canada can enter the United States without paying duties. These cars' engines are made in Ohio, but many parts are imported from Japan.
 
Insistence of Canada
 At Canada's insistence, the new rules are being drafted so that automobiles produced at Honda's factory in Alliston, Ontario, will qualify as made in North America.
While the rules on cars are being set, the overall talks are proceeding slowly, in part because each country's lawyers are trying to put the agreement into legal text. In a clash of cultures that says as much about the United States as Mexico, the Mexican delegation has many economists but relatively few lawyers in senior positions to review the evolving document.
The differing backgrounds of the negotiators extends to the very top of each team, but with some similarities. Commerce Secretary Jaime Serra Puche of Mexico and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, both did their graduate work at Yale University. Mr. Serra received a doctorate in economics, Mrs. Hills a law degree.
Lawyers for all three sides are also going through the agreement to check that each product is listed by the correct international tariff number. American imports from Mexico alone fall into 20,000 different categories, with many products, like glassware, falling into several dozen categories defined by such details as size or even heat-resistance.
Precision is very important in tariffs. Congress once passed legislation assessing Customs duties on imported "fruit, trees." But a clerk dropped a comma in transcribing the rule for official publication so that it only covered "fruit trees."
 
Writing Rules for Disputes
 Losses in forgone tariff revenues ran into the millions of dollars before the mistake could be fixed.
The lawyers are mostly done with writing rules for mediating commercial disputes. In cases involving environmental issues, these rules will provide for trilateral arbitration panels. These panels, which will have precedence over international panels, will issue nonbinding rulings, and will rely on public pressure in each country to insure compliance.
The panels will not have the authority to impose trade sanctions, people involved in the negotiations said. This feature may draw criticism in Congress, where Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Subcommittee on International Trade, has called for the panels to have such authority.
