SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2508 words

HEADLINE: Iraq Policy Still Bedevils Bush as Congress Asks: Were Crimes Committed?

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The players in this complex tale include the man accused of masterminding what may be the biggest bank fraud in history, a bulldog Congressman who seems determined to prove that the President's top aides engaged in a vast cover-up, and a beleaguered President who cannot understand why the issue will not go away.
As President Bush's re-election campaign shifts into high gear, it continues to be haunted by the dispute over United States policy toward Iraq before it invaded Kuwait in August 1990. The invasion led to the Persian Gulf war. 
 Under the policy, billions of dollars in American aid was used to try to moderate President Saddam Hussein and turn him into a stabilizing force in the Middle East. And the President has acknowledged that this policy failed.
 
Three Vital Questions
 But in its zeal to influence Mr. Hussein, did the Bush Administration ignore evidence that some of this aid was diverted to Iraq's buildup of weapons? Did it try to delay indictments of high-level Iraqi officials accused in a United States bank fraud? And did the President's aides lie to Congress in an attempt to conceal the full scope of their failed courtship of Iraq?
Those are the questions that lie at the heart of the affair. Mr. Bush accuses Congressional Democrats of "recklessly" distorting the record for political gain and characterizes his policy as an honest error in judgment. The Administration insists that the policy was widely known and generally accepted as a sound one -- by United States allies in the Middle East and even by some of the lawmakers who are now leading the criticism.
The Democrats, however, blame the Administration for "coddling" the Iraqi leader in advance of his invasion of Kuwait, despite mounting evidence that he was building a formidable military machine even after the eight-year Iran-Iraq war ended in 1988. Had the Administration paid more heed to that evidence, they say, the gulf war might never have been necessary.
Beyond the heated public statements, this much is known: In the late 1980's, under a Presidential directive to build closer relations with Baghdad, the United States Government permitted the sale of sophisticated American technology and equipment to Iraq, some of which is believed to have been used to build weapons. At the same time, Iraq was allowed to become a major participant in the Commodity Credit Corporation, through which the United States Government cosigns bank loans for poor countries that want to buy American farm products.
 
Taxpayers May Have to Pay
 The financially strapped Iraqis financed some of the food and technology purchases with loans from the tiny Atlanta branch of an Italian bank, the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. The Iraqis chose this branch, law enforcement officials say, because its officers were willing to take bribes in exchange for making high-risk loans.
The loans made through the agriculture program, on the other hand, were no-risk, as the United States Government would make good on any that Iraq failed to repay. Congressional critics have said the United States taxpayers will ultimately have to repay hundreds of millions of dollars on defaulted loans.
The Congressional panels that are investigating various facets of the Iraq policy have turned up evidence that they say suggests that some of those farm loans may have been channeled into military purchases.
Some lawmakers also maintain that the Government interfered with prosecutors investigating the bribery of the Atlanta bank officials and that it tried to conceal from Congress the extent of Iraq's purchases of technology.
But they have yet to come up with proof of any wrongdoing by public officials. That is why the House Judiciary Committee is eager for a positive reply from Attorney General William P. Barr about its request for the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the charges. Mr. Barr must respond to the request by Monday. He may either approve or reject it or ask for more time for an investigation of his own before deciding.
What follows is a look at which accusations involve possible criminal violations, as opposed to misguided but legal policy issues. These accusations, involving obstruction of justice and lying to Congress, would be the focus of any independent investigation.
 
The Altered Lists
Changes Uncovered At Commerce Dept.
 The strongest indication that a crime may have been committed involves alterations made on a Commerce Department list of high-technology items approved for sale to Iraq between 1985 and 1990. The list was sent in October 1990 to Representative Doug Barnard Jr., Democrat of Georgia, whose Government Operations subcommittee was investigating exports to Iraq.
After Mr. Barnard received an anonymous tip that the Commerce Department had tampered with the list, he asked the department's Inspector General to investigate. The Inspector General concluded in a report that both the copy sent to Congress and the permanent record had been changed in 68 instances to delete references to military designations. It can be illegal to willfully falsify documents presented to Congressional investigators.
In one instance, a description of a 1989 license for frequency synthesizers for a military complex north of Baghdad that made equipment for missiles and atomic bombs was changed to delete the crucial sentence, "According to our information, the end-user is involved in military matters." The synthesizers were designed to test surveillance radar at the complex, which was a primary target of allied bombers in the gulf war.
In another instance, the Inspector General's report said that the deletion of "military" to describe the sale of $1 billion worth of trucks to Iraq was "misleading and unjustified."
Senior Commerce Department officials have testified to Congress that Dennis E. Kloske, who was then Under Secretary of Commerce, was solely to blame. But Mr. Kloske, who resigned in April 1991, told Congressional investigators that White House officials and top aides to former Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher supervised the preparation of the list, although he did not actually accuse his superiors of ordering the changes. The Justice Department says that since it is investigating the alterations, there is no need for an independent counsel.
 
The Officials' Role
Lawmakers Charge They Were Misled
 Beyond the Commerce Department list, Democratic lawmakers are also investigating whether Administration officials purposely misled Congress about Iraq policy, either in public testimony, correspondence or conversations, or by withholding documents.
One line of inquiry involves the Commodity Credit Corporation program through which Iraq made grain purchases. In the fall of 1989 the Bush Administration was locked in a heated debate about whether to go forward with $1 billion in new credits for Iraq. State Department officials argued that the credits were crucial to improving relations with Baghdad. Agriculture Department officials had reservations but wanted to promote American exports. But both the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve were concerned about Iraq's ability and willingness to pay back its debts. Bowing to White House foreign policy concerns, a compromise decision was made to extend the credits in two stages.
Some lawmakers, like Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Agriculture Committee, believe they were misled when they raised questions about the wisdom of the loan guarantees.
For example, in late October 1989, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d telephoned Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter urging him to go forward with $1 billion in credits on "foreign policy grounds," according to an internal State Department memo. But Mr. Yeutter assured Mr. Leahy in a letter in February 1990 that foreign policy considerations did not contribute to the decision-making process.
Other Democratic lawmakers charge that the Administration conspired to mislead Congress by withholding crucial documents. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who has taken the lead in the investigations, has said there was a cover-up formulated in meetings held at the White House by lawyers from various Government agencies to coordinate answers to Congressional demands for documents. He has dubbed the group the "Rostow gang" because its chairman was C. Nicholas Rostow, the legal adviser to the National Security Council and a special assistant to Mr. Bush.
White House officials call the charge absurd, saying that such coordination is routine. But a senior State Department official said that Mr. Baker was indeed upset to learn that Mr. Rostow was trying to control the flow of documents, and ordered Edwin D. Williamson, the legal adviser who represented the State Department at the meetings, to coordinate with no one except Mr. Baker.
 
The Bank Investigation
Did Administration Delay Indictment?
 A third area of concern is whether the Bush Administration illegally interfered with the criminal investigation of the Atlanta branch of Bank Lavoro. Interfering with a criminal investigation can lead to charges of obstruction of justice.
Specifically, Congress is investigating whether the Administration, in an attempt to keep from embarrassing the Iraqi Government by exposing its role in the matter, delayed for a year the indictment of the man who is accused of being the mastermind of the suspected fraud, Christopher P. Drogoul. Mr. Drogoul has acknowledged taking cash and gifts from companies that did business with Iraq and benefited from his loans to Baghdad.
Internal documents show that in the months after the bank was raided by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in August 1989 the prosecutors in Atlanta were telling other Government agencies that they could bring indictments within months. In fact, Gail McKenzie, the aggressive prosecutor who has run the investigation from the beginning, had prepared what one official described as a "bare bones" indictment in January 1990.
But the Justice Department did not announce the indictment until late February 1991, one day after Mr. Bush announced a cease-fire in the gulf war. Documents made public in recent months show that the investigation was the subject of high-level discussions in the State Department, with some officials arguing that the case could jeopardize United States relations with Iraq. Ms. McKenzie has acknowledged receiving a phone call early on from a White House aide inquiring about the status of the investigation.
The White House denies exerting any pressure on prosecutors, and the Justice Department disputes that the indictment was delayed. In interviews, department officials said that prosecutors exaggerated their ability to try the case early because of pressure from the United States Attorney in Atlanta at the time, Robert Barr, who was eager to get the prosecution of the biggest bank fraud case under way before he left office.
"The only reason we would ever seek an indictment is if we believed we had the evidence," said Mr. Barr, a lawyer who is seeking the Republican nomination for the Senate in Georgia. "Whether I or anyone else was leaving the office was irrelevant."
 
The Suspect Loans
A Hint U.S. Money Paid for Iraqi Arms
 Beyond the question of interference, some lawmakers have also charged that some of the American farm loans were used by Iraq to buy military equipment -- an explosive charge that would mean that the United States helped pay for some of the weapons it later went to war to destroy.
In a memo seized on by critics of the Administration's policy, a Commerce Department official, Frank M. Lemay, warned that there was evidence suggesting that some of the loans guaranteed by the farm program may have been diverted into weapons purchases. But no investigation has established that that occurred. And Bush officials note that because of the Federal investigation of the bank, the Administration excluded it from the loan credit program in August 1989.
Misuse of the loans would not constitute a crime by the Government unless it knowingly took part. Even so, lawmakers say the Administration should have been more alert to the warning signs of Iraq's arms procurement program.

HOUSE BANKING, FINANCE & URBAN AFFAIRS
The chairman, Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, began looking at loans to Iraq by the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and came across evidence that he said suggested the bank may have misused United States-backed farm loans to help Iraq acquire military technology. The committee is also investigating Commerce Department licensing of exports of high-technology goods to Iraq, as well as whether the Justice Department tried to delay bringing fraud indictments against the bank, the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro.
 
HOUSE JUDICIARY
The committee is considering whether to grant a request by Representative Gonzalez for appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate whether the Bush policy on Iraq broke the law.
 
HOUSE FOREIGN AFFAIRS Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade
The subcommittee is looking at what militarily useful equipment was sold by the United States to Iraq, at the Bush Administration's prewar policy toward Iraq and at the withholding of information from Congress regarding that policy.
 
GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS
Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs
The panel is investigating American exports to Iraq. Its chairman, Doug Barnard, obtained a Commerce Department list of high-technology items approved for sale to Iraq between 1985 and 1990 and determined that it had been altered in 68 instances to delete references to military applications.
 
ENERGY
Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
The subcommittee is investigating why the Department of Energy and the Bush Administration did not do more to prevent the buildup of Iraq's nuclear weapons program.
 
AGRICULTURE
Subcommittee on Foreign Agriculture
The subcommittee wants to determine whether the commodity credit program that guaranteed loans to Iraq was part of a scheme to finance Iraq's military buildup and whether that program improperly became an instrument in the Bush Administration's foreign policy.

AGRICULTURE

FOREIGN RELATIONS
Senator Jesse Helms, supported by some Democrats, is holding up the nomination of James P. Covey to head a new State Department bureau for South Asia until the department turns over documents relating to Mr. Covey's role in prewar Iraq policy.
 
SELECT COMMITTEE ON INTELLIGENCE
The committee wants to know what the intelligence agencies knew about links between the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro and the farm credit program, and whether either was involved with Iraq's arms network.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Peacemaker's Tribute or Trojan Horseplay?

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

 BODY:
After months of riding roughshod over the minority Democrats in the Legislature and Democratic Gov. Jim Florio, the combative Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, now says he wants to meet regularly with the Governor to plan the course of the ship of state.
In a letter last Wednesday, Mr. Haytaian invited Mr. Florio to meet with him and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco tomorrow and on a "regular, weekly basis" to discuss "various issues of mutual concern." 
 Governor Florio's press secretary, Jon Shure, cited the Governor's full schedule and ruled tomorrow's meeting out, but said the Governor was "always open" to meeting with the legislative leaders.
The overture put the administration in a difficult spot, on the one hand not wanting to appear obdurate, but on the other, being unwilling to establish something that could amount to sharing the governorship. Nor would the administration want to share responsibility for negative effects of Republican budget cuts.
There was also some private trepidation over just how deep the spirit of cooperation goes. Both Mr. Haytaian and Mr. DiFrancesco pledged to cooperate with the Governor when they took veto-proof control of both houses of the Legislature in January, but then attacked, primarily by bashing the Governor relentlessly for his 1990 tax increase.
And even as Mr. Haytaian's letter went out, the Speaker himself was in Colorado Springs at a meeting of the American Legislative Council, where both he and Mr. DiFrancesco picked up "Legislator of the Year" awards.
Mr. Haytaian used the occasion to -- what else? -- bash Jim Florio. "Our once vibrant economy didn't just shut down one day because our free-market system failed," he said. "It came to a grinding halt because it was fed a lethal dose of government overkill."
He stopped just short of calling Mr. Florio a Communist. Just six months into office, he said, "the Governor introduced a new economic agenda that at best could be called Socialist."
He went on to say that "while Eastern Bloc countries were gaining their freedom from governments that denied them opportunities for a better quality of life, Jim Florio was building his version of the Berlin wall in New Jersey."
Perhaps disarmament could be the first item on any meeting agenda.
 
Signals Scrambled
 When the Republicans took control of the New Jersey Legislature, they had a clear mandate to cut taxes and spending, but they also decided there was an implicit message to privatize state government functions. They are studying ways to do that, from returning bus service to the private sector to farming out incarceration -- as is done in some other states -- and auto inspections.
But the Senate President, Mr. DiFrancesco, appeared this week to abandon another privatization scheme: divesting the state of the New Jersey Network and turning the television service over to another nonprofit operator, like WNET Channel 13. The idea was to pare down NJN's annual $8 million state subsidy -- it was cut to $4 million this year, essentially giving the station six months to transfer its operations to WNET or some other operator -- and also divest the network of three of the UHF stations it operates.
But while Channel 13 made it clear they would like nothing better than to broaden its market, it had no intention of paying anything for the network's $53 million in assets, including a brand-new studio in Trenton that alone is worth $23 million. And the Federal Communications Commission quickly threw cold water on Mr. DiFrancesco's idea that the educational UHF stations could be converted to commercial operation and sold for up to $150 million. The F.C.C. made it clear it had never happened and never would.
And a lot of NJN supporters made it known that they looked with considerable disfavor on the whole idea.
On Tuesday, Mr. DiFrancesco threw in the towel. Meeting with editors and reporters of The Record of Hackensack, he conceded the network had a lot more friends than he had thought -- "They have a constituency, I'm finding a lot of opposition" he said -- and announced he would withdraw his plan if the network would come up with some better ways to fund itself and change its programming, "maybe gavel-to-gavel legislative coverage," for example.

HEADLINE: A Test of Mr. Clinton's Backbone

 BODY:
Trade policy is about to burst into the Presidential campaign. President Bush is expected to announce this week a free-trade pact with Mexico and Canada that, he promises, "will mean more jobs, more growth . . ."
But powerful Democrats, led by the House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, have threatened to oppose the agreement. They claim it could destroy jobs and the environment by spurring American corporations to flee to Mexico "to take advantage of cheap labor, lax enforcement of health, safety, environmental and labor laws . . ." 
 The dispute will pose a severe test for Gov. Bill Clinton, who has portrayed himself as a new-generation, pro-market Democrat who won't pander to the traditional Democratic constituents, like organized labor, now clamoring for protection.
If the treaty turns out to be as good as leaked reports say, Mr. Clinton will have to choose between the protectionist politics of old and his pro-growth campaign promises. Voters who want to know if Mr. Clinton would have the backbone, as President, to stand up to powerful Democratic leaders when they're wrong may get a powerful clue this week.
Mr. Gephardt's contention that free trade will destroy American jobs is off base -- as is Mr. Bush's promise that it will create jobs.
There will be selective gains and losses in various industries. But free trade won't affect the total number of employed Americans. At any time the Federal Reserve Board can pump up the economy, and create more jobs, by printing money. But if it goes too far -- by trying to drive unemployment below, say, 5 percent -- it will ignite accelerating rates of inflation. Thus the U.S. will continue to muddle along with unemployment rates above 5 percent in good times, 7 or 8 percent in bad times, free trade pact or not.
The great value of free trade is that it can raise the living standards of most Americans. By redirecting production where it's cheaper, the treaty would help hundreds of millions of consumers.
In the U.S., textiles and sugar production will shrink; chemicals and business services will grow. This will be traumatic for thousands of affected workers. Yet the humane way to address their plight is not to deny everyone else the benefits of free trade but to provide them generous relocation and retraining assistance.
Environmental and health standards are a trickier problem. The danger is that American standards might be challenged by Mexico as unfair trade barriers or lowered to compete with Mexico. But as Keith Bradsher reports in yesterday's Times, the agreement makes impressive strides to block the threat.
Caught up in Presidential politics, the trade pact has been magnified beyond its true importance. The Mexican economy is tiny compared with the U.S., and U.S. tariffs are already low. Dropping them to zero poses little threat to domestic industries. The fear of companies fleeing across the border to hire dollar-an-hour labor is grossly exaggerated. If low wages siphoned away business, Sri Lanka would rule the international economy.
Mr. Bush has determined to reap the gains of free trade. Now Mr. Clinton must decide if he's really for trade -- with generous help for the relative few who will be hurt in the process -- or for the politics of old.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Carl Sommers

 BODY:
Studying Russian in Russia 
Q. I would like to study the Russian language formally in Russia but not for credit. I hold a master's degree in library science. Are there organizations that can assist me? -- Thomas Pkorovo, McLean, Va.
 A. Two organizations that arrange overseas study programs offer Russian-language study for one academic year in St. Petersburg and another offers a year in Moscow. All three say that though the courses can be taken for academic credit, many participants are college graduates. Students should be aware that in many classes textbooks are not used, classes consist almost entirely of lectures by the instructor, and there are few tests or other means of assessing progress before a final exam.
 The American Institute for Foreign Study, 102 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Conn. 06830, (800) 727-2437, offers its program at St. Petersburg State University (formerly Leningrad University). All students must enroll in an intensive Russian language course of 15 hours a week -- no previous study of Russian is required -- plus other classes, which can include history, art history, Russian literature and contemporary Russian life. Participants live in a residence hall. The fall semester begins in late August and ends in mid-December. The spring semester begins in late January and ends in mid-May. Each semester includes a four-day excursion to Moscow. Applications must be received by May 15 for the fall semester and Oct. 15 for the spring. The fee for 1993-94 will be $12,995 for the full year, $6,995 for one semester and $5,270 for a quarter, about a month shorter than a semester. The prices include round-trip air travel from the United States, required, and all meals.
 The Council on International Educational Exchange, University Programs Department, 205 East 42d Street, New York, N.Y. 10017, (212) 661-1414, also offers a year of academic study at St. Petersburg State University, but for people with at least three years of Russian. (The council offers summer and semester programs with less stringent prerequisites.) The program is 38 weeks, from late August to late May. Course work includes 10 hours a week of language instruction, and two other courses chosen with one's academic advisor. The cost for the 1992-93 academic year is $10,600 (a semester costs $6,500), including tuition, room and board (students must stay in a dormitory), transportation to classes, group excursions and round-trip air fare from New York, required. Application deadline is March 1. The organization also has shorter-term programs for students of business, science, social sciences and Slavic languages and literature, in Tver, Novosibirsk and Moscow.
 The American Council of Teachers of Russian, 1776 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20036, (202) 833-7522, offers its program at Moscow State Pedagogical University. The next sessions are Sept. 4, 1992, to June 15, 1993. The fall semester consists of language, history, literature and economics courses and the spring semester comprises a language seminar, two other courses and preparation of a term paper. The cost is $11,000, which includes course work, round-trip air fare from Washington (also required), dormitory room and board, weekly visits with teachers, journalists and other professionals and two one-week trips outside Moscow each semester. The application deadline is March 1.
 
New York Guides in Spanish
 Q. Are there Spanish-language guidebooks to New York City? -- Bonnie DeMeio, Stroudsburg, Pa. A. Berlitz publishes a Spanish-language version of its pocket-size guide to New York. The 1991 edition, $6.95, is 128 pages long and is available at a few bookstores in New York. One is The Complete Traveller, 199 Madison Avenue, (212) 685-9007. Another, New York Bound Bookshop, 50 Rockefeller Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10020, (212) 245-8503, will mail the book. The minimum charge for mailing is $1.50.
 A bit more extensive is the 127-page New York guide in the Guia Naranja (Orange Guide) series, published by Ediciones Tinatvera in Barcelona. The 1990 edition, $24.95, is available from French and European Publications, 115 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10003, (212) 673-7400. The shipping cost is an additional $7.50.
 
Weather in India and Nepal
 Q. I will be touring India and Nepal in October. What will the weather be like? -- Sergio Leyva, New York, N.Y.
 A. Except for the southeastern coast, the Indian monsoon season ends in October. There may be a few rainy days, especially at the beginning of the month, but rainfall is likely to be fairly light. In the Himalayas and their foothills in the north of India, high temperatures generally are in the low 60's and the lows in the low 50's. For example, Darjeeling has an average high of 61 and an average low of 51; there are five rainy days on average and a total rainfall of 5.1 inches. The northern plains are considerably hotter. For example, New Delhi's average high is 89 and the low is 74, with six rainy days and 4.5 inches of rain. In the drier west, Calcutta has an average high of 93 and a low of 65, with only one rainy day and 0.4 inches. The Rajasthan Desert, one of the hottest places in the world, has high temperatures of close to 100 and lows in the mid-60's; any rain in October is rare. On the west coast, Bombay has an average high of 89, a low of 73 and three rainy days with 2.5 inches; the weather in the interior and the south is very similar. In the southeast, the monsoons begin in October and continue into December; Madras has a high of 90, a low of 75 and 11 rainy days with 12 inches total.
 The monsoon season in Nepal is late June to September. In October, Katmandu has an average high of 80, a low of 56 and four rainy days with 1.5 inches of rain.
 
Health Insurance in Canada
 Q. I am planning to do some cycling in Quebec this summer. In Canada, which has a national health care system, what are the payment requirements of United States citizens who need medical treatment? -- Veronica Dee, New York, N.Y.
 A. People who are not citizens of Canada are not covered by the country's national health insurance plan, according to the Quebec tourist office. Travelers should check with their health insurance carrier before they leave. If their insurance does not cover them while in Canada, there are several companies that offer short-term coverage for travelers. Some of them are Access America, 6600 West Broad Street, Richmond, Va. 23230, (800) 284-8300, which charges $49 a person for two weeks; Travel Guard International, 1145 Clark Street, Stevens Point, Wis. 54481, (800) 782-5151, $39 a person for two weeks, and Health Care Abroad, Post Office Box 480, Middleburg, Va. 22117, (800) 237-6615, $3 a day. This type of policy may have a deductible for each claim.

HEADLINE: ART;
Peter Max Is Poised to Replay His 15 Minutes

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Close your eyes and imagine a blank canvas filling with bright colors, fluid lines, delicate forms. That, for the artist Peter Max, is pure creativity.
Now imagine an artist, brush heavy with color, moving with energetic dance steps before the canvas, filling the canvas with sweeping strokes. That, for Mr. Max, is creativity made manifest. 
 Now imagine a cameraman videotaping the artist dancing before the canvas. That is creativity made manifest through many media.
Now imagine that the canvas is not a canvas at all but the Berlin wall in the fall of 1989. That the creative moment reaches its apex when he writes a single word: "Max." That the camera zooms in for a close-up. That the resulting image, part of a longer videotape of Mr. Max and his work, is poised for playing on a bank of 18 screens in his New York studio.
Even in a world where exhibitionism is a way of life, that might smack of self-promotion. Not for Mr. Max. Call it creativity made manifest through many media many times and many ways -- art and ego in synergistic partnership.
Welcome to West 65th Street and the well-lighted studios of Peter Max. This is the 50-something artist whose work, from the "Yellow Submarine" cartoon in 1968 to the multiple Statues of Liberty of recent vintage, serves as a visual time machine spiriting the 40-something generation back to its 20-something (10-something?) roots. Two decades and more after he became a cultural icon, Mr. Max has, figuratively and literally, videotaped his 15 minutes of fame. And he's always ready for a replay.
After 17 years in seclusion, a divorce from the mother of his two children, and endless hours of meditation, Peter Max is back in motion. Since the mid-1980's, he has re-emerged in high-profile venues ranging from the Berlin wall to Moscow (where he got the inspiration for the multiple-panel portrait "40 Gorbys"). He has created stamps for the United Nations to commemorate this year's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. Two large Max murals are featured at the world's fair in Seville.
Yet, though he works at keeping his profile up, he is not the sort for whom the artists and critics who populate the "serious" art world would save a place at the table. "There are enthusiasts with a lot of money out there," said Steven Madoff, executive editor of Art News magazine. "There's a warm nostalgic feeling about Max because of his past as an illustrator. But he is not considered a serious contemporary artist."
But, hey, who needs serious, if you can still have your picture taken with Ronald Reagan, George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev? In any case, Mr. Max's signature has always been the democracy of his images -- you can find them on coffee cups and T-shirts as well as in galleries. Wherever they occur, they evoke the era of flower children, preserving a Zeitgeist in psychedelic hues.
Asked to compare the 1969 model Max with the new, post-seclusion model, he said: "Nineteen sixty-nine was a very big year for me because I felt, you know, this recognition. I was on the cover of Life. It was the year of Woodstock. It was the year of man on the moon. And these are all things that are interesting to me. I was as excited about man going to the moon as me being on the cover of Life, if you can imagine that, because I had always loved astronomy. And it was the year I decided to go on retreat. There were 17 years when I did a lot of contemplation, a lot of meditation. And I worked on my craft every day."
The result is a protean outpouring of primary colors and sinuous forms: mountains that inspire contemplation or female bodies sketched with an economy of line that still permits Maxian flourishes. Or faces, faces, faces, their colors bright, their expressions whimsical, or impassive, or inscrutable and gentle like those of the Buddhist monks who populated Mr. Max's childhood in Tibet. (His parents, a German pearl merchant and his wife, left Nazi Germany in the late 1930's when Peter was an infant and fled to Shanghai. Mr. Max said his 10th and 11th birthdays were passed in Tibet. In 1953, after a sojourn in Israel, the family moved to New York.)
It is unabashed devotion to his swami, or spiritual leader -- he takes time to spell out the name, with pauses, "Swami S-A-T, C-H-I, D-A, N-A-N-D-A" -- that helps make him eerily un-self-conscious, a sort of Maxchild in the Promised Land. Ask him how the Peter Max of today is different from the Peter Max of the 60's, and the response is all about the swami.
He met the swami because an acquaintance put him in touch with a French director who had been "making a film about the meaning of life," Mr. Max said. "This was my biggest question in the 60's: What is the meaning of life? Why am I here? I just couldn't shove these questions aside." The swami was staying with the film crew in Paris, and Mr. Max found some of what he was looking for in the swami's teachings and the discipline of meditation.
This new approach to life led him to collect places to retreat to: from St. John in the Caribbean to upstate New York to, most recently, the hills and meadows of rural Virginia, west of Charlottesville, where he bought 190 acres in 1991. He has said he hopes to build a new studio there. It is close by "Yogaville," the swami's western Virginia retreat, which is a magnet for many young potters and craftsmen.
It is also a far distance from most of the ills that crowd New York's streets, like poverty, homelessness and AIDS. For him, that is just as well.
"Problems have nothing to do with creativity," he said. "Creativity is something that comes from within. It's a creation. A flower grows without any notice of problems in the outside world. Creativity is a flower. It's hidden inside. If you do think about problems in the outside world, as soon as the work comes out it is tainted with these problems. It is not pure creativity.
"Now, as a person I am very sensitive to AIDS, homlessness, animal rights, the Tibetan situation, the rain forests, the rivers, the oceans, indigenous people -- all those things that are boggling the minds of true thinking people in the world today. These are the things that I am aware of." He would like to help change things, he said, and believes that he is doing so. "But as an artist I have to stay pure, you know. I don't paint animals. I don't paint indigenous peoples."
What he does do, undeniably, is create. It seems he never met a medium he didn't like.
His publicist says his works are offered for prices ranging from $1,000 for a lithograph to $1 million for a large canvas now in progress. New York dealers, who find their pool of buyers depleted these days, raise their eyebrows at such figures. But Max works are not auctioned at major houses like Christie's or Sotheby's, which would keep a record of sales prices, so there is no independent way to determine what price they command.
Still, there is no denying the mass appeal of his art. A Japanese businessman signed a $3 million licensing deal with him to open a chain of "Neo Pop" stores in Japan, although a spokesman for Mr. Max said that since the economic downturn in both countries, this project has lain fallow.
It's also hard to deny that his name has cachet. A few years back, President Reagan asked him to do his "Liberty" riff on the White House lawn.
"What I love a lot about art is I've set myself up where I have the variety," he said. "I like every medium. I have seen people make sand castles and I went right in there with my hands and did my own.
"This is a very large confusion about people thinking I'm a commercial artist," he added with a frown. "When you look around here you see me as a total painter."
What comes first, he said, is the image, the creativity. If it fits the postage stamp, the coffee cup, the cause, the sound bite, that's fine, too. "But I don't go around with a sign explaining myself. So there is this false idea about me, about being commercial."
"I love the media," he said. "Media is a billboard, a T-shirt, posters, postcards, a baseball jacket with something on it. That's modern media. If Picasso were alive today, he'd probably work in video. Why couldn't Gaugin want to have one of his images on a baseball jacket?"
Creativity, he said, is what really matters. "Love" is his verb of choice when he discusses it. "I love a thick load of brushes and I like a lot of color on the brush and I love the movement, the fact I am six to eight inches away from my canvas. The first stroke as it lays itself on the canvas -- that is what I love the most. The second most is looking in a mirror and seeing my art far away." In case you missed it, Peter Max is back. Film at 5. And 6. And 7. And . . .

An article on Aug. 9 about the artist Peter Max incorrectly associated him with the animated movie "Yellow Submarine." He did not work on it.

HEADLINE: Planning From the Bottom Up

BYLINE: By Gina Maranto; Gina Maranto writes about the environment for The Amicus Journal and other magazines.

 BODY:

THE NATURE OF DEVELOPMENT
A Report From the Rural Tropics
on the Quest for Sustainable Economic Growth.
By Roger D. Stone.
Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23. 
 IN his 1949 inaugural address, President Harry S. Truman outlined his Point Four Program, which he called a means of "making the benefits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement" of the world's poorer countries. He thus set the stage for an emphasis on Western-style growth as the single most desirable and attainable goal of international aid. Driven by this notion and pursuing an unabashedly top-down strategy, the United States Government and American-backed agencies like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund bankrolled huge dam and canal complexes, roads into jungles, and massive electrification and population resettlement programs from the Nile to the Amazon basin to the Himalayas.
Well into the 1970's, planners were preoccupied with the quest for "takeoff," that elusive, semi-mystical moment when a less developed economy's latent potential suddenly turns into actual growth. As a result, they paid scant heed to the social and environmental dislocations that almost invariably accompanied large-scale public projects.
Over the last two decades, however, experts have begun contemplating how to stimulate the economies of the impoverished nations of the Southern Hemisphere (meaning, by one common definition, those where annual per capita incomes are $370 or less) while simultaneously preserving as much as possible the indigenous cultures, wildlife and landscapes. This shift, as yet perhaps more conceptual than real, has been brought about in part by the efforts of environmentalists along with third world bureaucrats and native peoples who have become increasingly skilled at ecological research and resource management and ever more adept at communicating their needs and opinions.
Roger D. Stone, a 25-year veteran of the international conservation movement and now an environmental consultant to the Council on Foreign Relations and a senior fellow at the World Wildlife Fund, has logged thousands of miles flying, driving, boating and hiking in the third world. Visits to rural outposts between 1988 and 1990 form the basis of "The Nature of Development," which might be called an eco-travelogue. Convinced that economy and ecology must proceed hand in hand, Mr. Stone believes that a sound tactic for solving the problems of the world's poor lies in bottom-up planning, in which farmers and town dwellers participate with on-site specialists in shaping their futures. Describing projects in Central and South America, Asia and Africa, the author explores the particular successes and failures of human-scale attempts to foster ecologically renewable and economically viable development.
Mr. Stone knows the "excruciating difficulty of accomplishing anything in rural work." He sets high standards for success; yet, touring remote portions of the tropics, he does see some signs of it. On the slopes of Kilum Mountain in northwest Cameroon, two British naturalists enlist Oku tribespeople and other villagers to mark boundaries of a 17,000-acre forest that is home to birds like the red-crested Bannerman's touraco, stands of podocarpus trees and other rare species. The pair also sets up an experimental tree nursery, introduces cool weather crops like kale and broccoli and conducts educational workshops on an assortment of topics. In upland Irian Jaya, an Indonesian province abutting Papua New Guinea, fieldworkers help organize groups of the Hatam and Arfak peoples to combat deforestation and soil losses, to diversify agriculture and to protect forests.
The author offers similar stories from Ecuador, Costa Rica, the Caribbean island of St. Lucia, Zambia and Thailand. In each case, representatives of nongovernmental aid agencies, educated nationals or inspired freelancers have joined with locals to implement sound development. At the same time, they have founded or streamlined small business ventures like beekeeping, butterfly ranching or seaweed farming in attempts to provide needed capital and also to husband valued resources.
Mr. Stone's narrative proceeds in somewhat jerky fashion, interrupted by fairly standard if deft accounts of the rise of the conservation movement and the history of development. But his survey is on the whole fascinating and full of surprises, as when he tells of the Brazilian iron mine "where scarlet macaws fly freely over the open ore pits, where brilliantly blue Morpho butterflies flash and flutter" in the virgin forest preserved on company land.
Contending that steps toward healthy development bring into play a "cluster of ideological forces," among them democratic principles and market economics, the author argues for shifts in funding policies that would encourage more small-scale projects, and for more debt-for-nature swaps and similar measures. Making villagers partners in their own betterment and focusing on the demands of what Edward Seaga, the former Prime Minister of Jamaica, once called the "kitchen economy" are vital, the author says, if the South is to move from "despair to stability."

HEADLINE: Tennis Group's Move Cheers Realtors

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: HARRISON

 BODY:
THE United States Tennis Association's purchase last month of a four-story office building off Westchester Avenue here is good news for the county's commercial real estate market, which has been hit hard by difficult economic times. It is part of a trend that has begun to counter the moves of some corporations out of Westchester and the restructuring of others, officials and real-estate agents said.
"In this economic climate, with all the downsizing of corporations, we have been experiencing a high vacancy rate," said Margaret S. Soter, the county's director of Commerce and Economic Development. "But we also have been seeing a trend of mid-size companies moving in." 
 The nonprofit tennis association, which sponsors the United States Open Tennis Championships, will move its headquarters to the 110,000-square-foot building on West Red Oak Lane in January.
The vacancy rate in corporate parks along that stretch of Westchester Avenue, nicknamed the Platinum Mile because 5 of the county's 10 Fortune 500 corporations have offices along it, was 21.9 percent for the first half of this year, said William V. Cuddy, vice president of Rostenberg-Doern Company, a corporate real-estate company.
The tennis association's move, along with the relocation of small and mid-size companies to Westchester, "takes up the slack" left behind by larger corporations, Mr. Cuddy said. Conrans Habitat, a retail chain, has moved its headquarters to White Plains, and National-Gottesman, a paper products company, has moved to Purchase.
 
100 Employees to Move
 About 100 employees from the tennis association's current headquarters on Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan and its offices in Jericho, L.I., and Princeton, N.J., are to move to the new site.
The organization's National Tennis Center, where the yearly tennis championships are held, will remain in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Two years ago the organization was looking to move both its headquarters and the tennis center to Westchester, but that did not materialize, Mrs. Soter said.
Although the association, which is the national governing body for tennis in the United States, decided to expand the 17.3-acre Queens tennis center site, it still needed to consolidate its regional offices, said Joyce Baumgarten, a spokeswoman. It considered leasing larger quarters in New York City, but the building here, along with 5.5 acres, was "too good an opportunity to pass up," she said.
The organization paid $3.3 million for the land and building, said Gregory J. Colosi, the broker representing the building's owner. Mr. Colosi, who is a senior vice president for Friedland Realty in Yonkers, said that four years ago the site was on the market for $20 million.
"In this kind of a real estate market, it is an excellent buy," he said. "They couldn't get comparable value in New York City."
The building, constructed in 1974, was first occupied by General Foods and then by Nynex. But in recent years it had been vacant and went into foreclosure. The Travelers, a Hartford insurance company that financed the original mortgage, took back ownership from a real-estate company this year.
Mr. Colosi said he showed officials from the tennis association other sites in Queens, White Plains and Scarsdale, but the campuslike setting off Westchester Avenue, he said, was most suited to their needs. The association, which plans to occupy two or three floors and lease the rest, may also build tennis courts on the property.
 
Private, but at the Hub
 The site is next to the Stouffer Westchester Hotel, which will serve as a conference center for the association, Mr. Colosi said. It is an eight-minute drive to Westchester Airport and five minutes from downtown White Plains.
"Of all the sites, this one suited their needs perfectly," Mr. Colosi said. "It has a bus stop in front of the building. It is a little remote, so it has some privacy, and it is still at the hub of county."
The building has generated $202,000 a year in state, county and municipal taxes, but as a nonprofit organization the tennis association could file for tax-exempt status. For Harrison, that could mean a loss of $50,000 a year, said James J. Calandruccio, the Town Assessor. The Postal Service recently moved to a building on Westchester Avenue and claimed tax-exempt status, costing the town $440,000 a year.
The 325,000-member tennis association, established in 1881 and governed by a volunteer board of directors, promotes recreational tennis, initiates and maintains rules of play and also promotes amateur and professional tournaments.
In addition to its national headquarters, it has 17 other offices in the United States. The tennis center, where the United States Open is held in the last week of August and the first week of September, has three stadiums and 28 outdoor and nine indoor public tennis courts. It is run by the association for the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. The proposed expansion of the center is expected to cost the association $180 million.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rises in County, Despite Signs Of a Recovery

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
UNEMPLOYMENT continues to climb in Westchester despite some signs of an economic rebound, and labor market analysts are trying to determine why. Perhaps, the economists say, larger forces are at work in the county, causing the employment picture to remain bleak.
"The recession has let go, but when a recovery doesn't behave like an average recovery, there may be something else going on," said Thomas J. Spitznas, an economist in Mount Vernon. "It may mean this is a different ball game from what we are used to." 
 At first glance, indicators suggested that the local economy, while not leaping ahead, might at long last be inching forward. For example, the State Labor Department reported that the number of jobs in the county increased in June by 1.1 percent from May. And average weekly earnings for manufacturing jobs, along with the number of hours worked, were up somewhat from a year before.
But 29,700 people in Westchester were out of work in June, propelling the jobless rate to 6.4 percent, the highest June figure since 1983. The May rate was 5.8 percent; in June 1991, it was 5.4 percent.
But the county's June unemployment figures, which were released 10 days ago, were not as high as New York City's rate of 11.5 percent, or 8.9 percent for the entire state. Even though there were 4,300 more nonagricultural jobs in Westchester in June than in May, most of those jobs reflected seasonal trends and therefore could not be counted on as long-lasting influences, the economists said. They were jobs at golf courses, beaches and other recreational sites and in restaurants and stores that cater to tourists.
During healthy economic times, job growth from month to month averages 6,000 to 8,000, making June 1992 "not the worst of times, but also not the best," said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the State Labor Department. But growth in June was better than it was a year before, he said, when the job base expanded by only 3,900 over May.
Despite the fact that the number of jobs increased in the county, the number of job seekers outstripped the number of available openings, causing the unemployment rate to surge. The market was not able to accommodate a labor force that swelled with college graduates and students looking for work, Mr. Surdey said.
An even more worrisome labor picture emerged when analysts stripped away the seasonal influences, which must be done to understand the full significance of the unemployment figures, they said. Mr. Spitznas, who owns T. J. Spitznas and Associates, an economic consulting concern, estimated that when seasonal adjustments were factored in for June, the county actually lost 2,300 private, nonagricultural jobs, because fewer new jobs came in than would be expected for this time of year.
June's unemployment rate "is as bad as it looks, and worse than it looks," Mr. Spitznas said. When the jobless rates were seasonally adjusted, May's was revised downward to 5.5 percent, and June's remained at 6.4 percent. With those calculations, the increase from May to June becomes almost a full percentage point.
"All of this throws out a caution signal," Mr. Spitznas said. "And what we thought were signs of life in the economy, are not. The employment picture has me worried."
As Mr. Surdey described it, "No matter how you slice it, June was a downer."
Projecting ahead to the July and August figures, the employment picture is likely to be even bleaker, the analysts said, when jobless rates reflect workers laid off in North Tarrytown from the General Motors night shift, and the closings of Alexander's department store in Yonkers and Macy's in New Rochelle. Although Alexander's closed earlier this year, severance packages delayed workers' filing for benefits.
 
Longer Workweek in June
 "These are gray clouds hanging over Westchester," Mr. Surdey said.
In looking at the indicators, analysts were pleased to see that the average work week lengthened in June, and they said that on the surface those figures suggested that the economy was pulling out of the recession.
In June, for example, the workweek for manufacturing averaged 39.6 hours, about 30 minutes longer than a year before. But while the figures indicated that demand for products was up, many companies were relying on overtime and part-time help -- and were not rehiring full-timers -- to meet increased demand for goods, the analysts said.
Noreen L. Preston, a specialist with the County Commerce and Economic Development Department, said many companies were loath to create new jobs because they were still catching up with debts accumulated during the recession.
Also, she said, the employers have not wanted to take on the added costs of benefits packages for full-time workers. And because companies do not feel they can raise prices on their products now, they have to effect savings elsewhere to maintain profits.
"Companies are very much copycats," Ms. Preston said. "They are taking their cues from the big guys, the corporations. They are going to squeeze what they can out of what they have to work with, because they're not going to get it elsewhere."
The analysts explained that the way companies were dealing with the increased demand for products suggested a deeper trend in the economy and provided some clues to why this recovery was not following a typical pattern.
As companies continue to restructure and become "lean and mean," there is little hope that they will restore some of the jobs they shed during the recession years. Not just because of the recession, but also as a result of global competition, many companies will continue to cut costs by paring their work forces, the analysts said.
Mr. Spitznas termed the situation a standoff. "It is between a business cycle that, on the one hand, is slowly improving and structural changes taking place in companies that partly offset the improvements."
"It's a story of crosscurrents" that are acute in Westchester, where many corporations are still restructuring, he said.
The restructuring, Mr. Spitznas said, will likely lead to permanent job losses, specifically for middle-management workers. Any new job generation in the near future will be different from the past and will come mainly from small- and medium-sized business that provide services to the larger corporations.
Middle-management workers therefore may be in what Mr. Spitznas called "situations of permanent unemployment." They will have to develop skills for other types of jobs or try to become entrepreneurs, he said.
While the economists agreed that some national and local indicators were promising, they said that until the jobless rate moved downward in the county, they would not take encouragement from reports that a recovery had arrived.
"New York City has to provide more jobs for Westchester residents, and the national economy has to pick up more steam," Mr. Spitznas said. "Those factors will filter down to people here."
When might a recovery take hold? The analysts were not optimistic.
"I had thought for sure we would see an upturn by the end of the year," Mr. Spitznas said, "but I'm not going to hold my breath."

HEADLINE: Water, Water, Everywhere

BYLINE: By Alexander Frater; Alexander Frater is the chief travel correspondent at The Observer of London and the author of "Chasing the Monsoon."

 BODY:

THE GREAT DEEP
The Sea and Its Thresholds.
By James Hamilton-Paterson.
Illustrated. 300 pp. New York:
Random House. $23. 
 JAMES HAMILTON-PATERSON'S new book is about the mysterious element covering seven-tenths of the world's surface, and he starts by plunging, literally, straight in. A fisherman some distance from land jumps from his outrigger canoe. But the cord attaching his ankle to the prow snaps and the canoe vanishes -- blown away by wind or tide, possibly sunk, but certainly no longer available to carry him safely home.
"I am lost." These are the first words of "The Great Deep," and throughout we return to this abandoned, increasingly desperate figure for reports on his status. In the end the canoe reappears, the fisherman clambers aboard and returns -- with six mackerel -- to the refuge of his island shack. By now it has dawned on us that our lucky castaway is Mr. Hamilton-Paterson himself. What we do not learn is whether he got the idea for his book during those lost, scary hours in the water. It seems likely. He certainly did a lot of hard thinking out there, and his reflections on every conceivable aspect of the oceans serve to underpin this intricate and scholarly survey.
"The Great Deep" is a collection of linked essays covering topics as diverse as reefs, islands, charts, wrecks, fishing, pirates and monsters.
In the Philippines Mr. Hamilton-Paterson learns of a scheme to rebuild damaged reefs with used automobile tires -- an inspired purpose found for some of the world's most useless objects. There, too, he revisits the tiny, obscure, unpopulated, unwatered, beachless offshore island celebrated in his previous book, "Playing With Water," and finds Japanese developers turning it into the Fantasy Elephant Club. Equipped with a transplanted beach, piped water, restaurants, sushi bars, sports facilities and a casino, the establishment will cost its Japanese-only clientele $320 a day for accommodation only; it will cost extra to "be massaged by geishas, recline on vinyl couches to watch porno videos, gamble and sip Chivas Regal." Thus does Japan adroitly extend its restricted territorial boundaries.
Mr. Hamilton-Paterson hitches a lift aboard a United States Geological Survey vessel mapping the seabed contained by the 200-mile American Exclusive Economic Zone and records, north of Hawaii, an underwater range known as the Musicians Seamounts. These substantial peaks include a Strauss and a Mendelssohn, ridges named for Bach and Beethoven, a Mount Mozart that is higher than Fuji.
WE learn about piracy ancient and modern, the latter practiced by Filipino thugs, armed with M-16 rifles, who steal boats, engines, money, cargoes, lives and hostages. (The M-16's, Mr. Hamilton-Paterson reports, are not hard to come by: you enlist in the army, and the moment you've got your gun, you desert.) As for the traditional buccaneers, the legendary Spanish Main brawlers like Blackbeard and William Dampier, Mr. Hamilton-Paterson cites a scholar who offers evidence to suggest they were -- shiver me timbers -- probably gay.
The book's overriding theme is the spoiling of the seas. In Fraserburgh, Scotland, the author boards the Garefowl, a small trawler heading out into the overfished North Sea, and notes the anger and despair in his companions' voices.
The seabed is littered with discarded junk from the oil rigs (one night the nets brought up a life-size sex doll), and catches are diminished by bureaucratic rulings that also diminish the fish stocks. European legislators seem unaware that the smaller fish they decree must be thrown back do not survive the trauma of the net. "The violence of their capture and the hauling up through 60 fathoms has ruptured capillaries, made flotation sacs bulge out of mouths," Mr. Hamilton-Paterson writes. "Those fish with patches of scales torn off will anyway become prey to disease, to worms and saprophytes." Meanwhile, the boats of too many nations anxiously pursue an ever-decreasing harvest.
The situation in the north Pacific is equally grim. Mr. Hamilton-Paterson states that, for six months of the year, 1,500 Japanese, Taiwanese and South Korean ships lay up to 50 miles of drift net each -- a nightly total of up to 50,000 miles, enough to circle the planet twice. Marketable fish are kept, the rest dumped overboard by the ton. Countless sea birds become entangled in the nets and perish. This technique (known as "strip-mining the oceans") will, the Japanese promise, be discontinued next year. But a billion-dollar industry does not just fade away. What will take its place? Who will set the quotas and how will they be enforced?
Mr. Hamilton-Paterson is at his brilliant best when addressing matters like these. Though he always displays erudition and a rippling, sinewy intelligence, some of his other chapters have a deskbound feel. These cover, discursively, all manner of arcane historical and philosophical maritime-related subjects, often in supertanker-length paragraphs that will require the reader's close attention. Out of sight of land, though, the book provides an urgent reminder that the old sailor's hymn needs updating. It is not for those in peril on the sea we should be worrying. The sea itself is now in peril, and "The Great Deep" should be required reading for the decision makers of every maritime nation.

HEADLINE: Pummeling the Professors

BYLINE: By Paul Starr; Paul Starr is a professor of sociology at Princeton University and the editor, with Robert Kuttner, of the magazine The American Prospect. His book "The Logic of Health Care Reform" will be published this fall.

 BODY:

IMPOSTORS IN THE TEMPLE
By Martin Anderson.
255 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster.
$22. 
 THE growth of conservative foundations, think tanks and publications outside the academic world over the last two decades has changed the battleground of ideas in unexpected ways. Today conservatives are better represented among intellectuals outside the academy than in it, and the old right-wing distrust of independent intellectuals as free-floating cosmopolitans of uncertain piety and doubtful patriotism has given way to a more sharply focused attack on the liberal professoriate.
"Impostors in the Temple" is both an example and an exploration of the cleavage in the intellectual world. The author, Martin Anderson, is an economist, a former adviser to Republican Presidents and a fellow of one of the leading conservative research institutes, the privately endowed Hoover Institution in Stanford, Calif. Mr. Anderson describes it as the West Berlin of the academic world -- no doubt because it is a bastion of free-market thought in the middle of the Stanford campus (whose resemblance to East Germany will presumably have struck even the most casual visitor). Following Dinesh D'Souza's "Illiberal Education" and Roger Kimball's "Tenured Radicals," "Impostors in the Temple" shows how broad an assault conservatives are now prepared to make on the academy.
Mr. Anderson divides intellectuals into two classes. He esteems the first group: professional intellectuals to be found in research institutes, the news media and elsewhere. While opinionated, they have to survive by their wits in the marketplace and are therefore hard-working and honest. Almost everything wrong with intellectual life comes from the second, suspect group: academic intellectuals who luxuriate in the lap of quasi-socialist institutions, with job security, high pay, elaborate perks and a system of peer review that protects them from outside scrutiny and the wrath that would undoubtedly descend upon them if the public ever understood their scam.
THE tone of much of Mr. Anderson's criticism is reminiscent of Representative Newt Gingrich's attacks on Congressional pay and privileges. Indeed, Mr. Anderson seems to want to do for the universities what Mr. Gingrich and his confreres have done for the Congress: bring the institution into such disrepute that conservatives, long stuck in minority status, will have a chance at gaining power. It is an old strategy: apres le deluge, nous.
So Mr. Anderson throws everything into his indictment that could conceivably be held against higher education today -- incidents of sexual harassment; abuses of athletic programs; inadequacies in undergraduate teaching; cases of scientific fraud; even boring articles in academic journals -- all of which would vanish, we can be certain, if universities had a properly conservative regime. To Mr. Anderson, the many sins of the academy are evidence not merely of human fallibility but of a deep corruption and the need for a thoroughgoing reformation, including the abolition of tenure, a ban on teaching by graduate students and the appointment of conservative intellectuals like the former Secretary of Education, William Bennett, to the boards of trustees at the elite universities.
Mr. Anderson is right that a lot of the vitality in the intellectual world today is to be found on the non academic side. Conservatives no doubt benefited when they set up independent research institutes and avoided the usual scholarly pretenses and constraints, not to mention teaching obligations, that inhibit many liberal academics from full-fledged ideological combat. But it is a curious thought that conservatives comfortably ensconced in well-endowed, nonprofit institutes are more disciplined by the marketplace and therefore more virtuous than are liberal professors comfortably ensconced in well-endowed, nonprofit universities. If virtue were so predictably aligned with the market, both would be in trouble -- and Vice President Dan Quayle would have nothing to worry about from television sitcoms that have, after all, met one of the market's most exacting tests.
To be sure, Mr. Anderson's complaints about dull and irrelevant academic work have much merit; he is especially harsh on his colleagues in economics, of whom, I should confess, I am quite prepared to believe the worst. Mr. Anderson recalls, for example, that while in the Reagan White House he never heard anyone refer to an article published in an academic economics journal -- and I could not decide whether to enjoy this as a reflection on the Reagan Administration or on the economics profession. Outside of economics, Mr. Anderson does not give evidence of any direct familiarity with the world of scholarship. But, brave man that he is, he is not prevented by a lack of acquaintance with other academic disciplines from condemning them in the most sweeping terms as given equally to arid irrelevance and intellectual dishonesty.
Still, it is an odd echo of the 1960's to hear a conservative demanding greater relevance from academics. After all, relevance is in the eye of the beholder, and Mr. Anderson might not like work that is relevant to achieving goals he disapproves of. Indeed, he would call such work impermissibly politicized. But if relevance is your test, you have given up any battle against a politicized academy.
Mr. Anderson considers it a devastating commentary on scholarly work that a great many academic articles -- in some fields the majority -- are never cited after publication. That is like condemning capitalism because the majority of new businesses fail. The test of intellectual work is not whether the average journal article is a success, but whether the leading achievements -- admittedly rare -- enrich and advance our understanding. And for that process to work, a wide-open publication system is the equivalent of a market with low barriers to entry.
The nation's system of colleges and universities is, in fact, highly competitive and decentralized, and that is the nub of a problem for conservatives. Martin Anderson's reformation would have to be carried out one university at a time, and any institution that dropped tenure and threatened to impose the regime he advocates would face devastating losses among its most eminent faculty. Proposing to increase teaching loads, he suggests, therefore, that "universities and colleges could get together and decide to implement such a policy collectively, so that none would be at a competitive disadvantage." No doubt advising collusion was a hard decision for a free-market economist, but I suppose it shows that at heart he is a pragmatist, willing to recognize that there are limits to the free market after all.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Platform;
BUSH GETS A NUDGE ON HIS TAX POLICY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Asserting that their party needs a dramatically bolder economic policy to win in November, seven leading Republican conservatives are urging President Bush's campaign to adopt a growth-oriented platform that would include sharp cuts in taxes and limits on growth of entitlement spending.
"People are willing to forgive past mistakes, but they won't forgive a lack of vision for the future," the seven conservatives said. Their memorandum was sent Friday to the President and senior campaign strategists as party officials gathered in Houston to craft the platform for next week's Republican convention. 
 "Should the President just resort to old Republican exhortations about the balanced budget amendment or the line-item veto, the American people will quickly lose interest," the group declared. "They are tired of the old cliches."
 
The Seven Signers
 The memorandum, first reported today by The Washington Post, was signed by Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, by Representatives Vin Weber of Minnesota and Newt Gingrich of Georgia and by Senators Connie Mack of Florida, Trent Lott of Mississippi, Bob Kasten of Wisconsin and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming.
In response, Charles R. Black, senior adviser to the Bush campaign, played down the memorandum this evening. "It's not unusual for that group to send a memo to the President with a lot of economic ideas," he said.
Mr. Black added that most of the ideas were consistent with those of both Mr. Bush and Ronald Reagan. He called them "goals everybody shares." Mr. Black said that the magnitude of budget deficits had so far prevented the President from proposing cuts in individual taxes.
Separately, Bush campaign headquarters said today that the Clinton economic program involved "massive hidden taxes" that would destroy jobs, particularly among small businesses.
 
Acceptance Is Predicted
 Mr. Gingrich, the Republican whip, said today in an interview on the Cable News Network that the odds were "very high" that the President would embrace the conservatives' program in his acceptance speech.
The memorandum's signers, who seek to roughly triple recent economic growth rates of 1 percent to 2 percent, call for "a flatter, lower, simpler tax system" in which the present 15 percent income tax bracket would be reduced to a 12 percent bracket and the tax on capital gains eliminated for long-term investments and indexed to inflation by executive order.
"The President has a wonderful opportunity to draw a very dramatic contrast with the redistribution, tax increase, welfare state policies of Bill Clinton, and where we would go if we had control of the House and Senate," Mr. Gingrich said in his television appearance.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
What Price Bosnia?
Atrocity Reports Make West Consider How Far It Should Go to End Violence

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
So far, not a single Western leader has determined what price should be paid, in Western lives and money, to halt the barbarity in what used to be Yugoslavia.
Until now, the unspoken assumption in the West was that as long as Serbs, Croats and Muslims were determined to fight one another, there was little the outside world could do to stop them. 
 But under the impression of powerful reports of atrocities that echo those perpetrated two generations ago by the Nazis, that assumption is beginning to crumble, and the West is asking crucial questions about how far it is willing to go to stop the slaughter.
This weekend, diplomats in London, Paris, and New York were contemplating the first circumscribed steps to be outlined in a Security Council resolution authorizing United Nations forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina to use or call in force to keep food and medicine flowing to the civilian victims.
If such a resolution is adopted, its logic could lead to the commitment of tens or hundreds of thousands of soldiers, according to military experts who estimate that is how many troops would be needed to end depredations that have horrified the world.
 
Is the Threat Empty?
 Whether the mere threat of willingness to go so far could stop the aggressors remains to be seen. Until now, they have clearly not been deterred by empty Western threats, and the West has been reluctant to pay the price of committing those troops.
But Western willingness to become involved could increase if events keep running out of control.
The British, among the most reluctant to send in troops, have called an international conference on the former Yugoslavia in London for Aug. 26 to 28 to try to deal with the causes of the violence, and try to keep it from spreading to Kosovo and Macedonia or dragging in Greece, Turkey or Albania.
"I hope that there will be a Security Council resolution in the next few days which will put the emphasis on the escorting, the protection, of humanitarian help," the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today on B.B.C. radio. "We are talking about the protection of humanitarian help, but it may well involve the use of force."
But President Bush, Prime Minister John Major of Britain and President Francois Mitterrand of France all remain unwilling to send in troops to stop the aggression, which they attribute mainly, but not exclusively, to Serbian nationalist forces.
 
Gulf War Is Cited
 Two years ago, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, there was little reluctance on the part of any of the three countries to consider sending huge numbers of troops, weapons and supplies to the Persian Gulf to expel President Saddam Hussein's forces.
Why, critics like the former Prime Minister of Britain, Margaret Thatcher, have asked, is there such reluctance to consider using military force to aid innocent civilians in Bosnia?
The first reason, as Mr. Hurd said today, is the tangled ethnic weave of the Balkans. "The main fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina is now being done by the people who live there," he said. "The Serbs are mainly responsible, and they are being helped and egged on by help from Belgrade -- that is undoubtedly true. But you cannot actually separate them out in the same way that you could separate the Iraqis from Kuwait or the Argentines from the Falklands."
 
10,000 Troops for Land Corridor
 But even the limited authorization of the use of force by the United Nations troops to protect relief shipments could bring on many complications, according to some military experts.
Gen. Sir Anthony Farrar-Hockley, a former NATO commander, argued in The Sunday Times today that if force were to be used to try to open a land corridor to move food and medicine from the Adriatic port of Split for 100 miles through the mountains to Sarajevo and beyond, it would take three brigades -- around 10,000 soldiers -- and strong helicopter support.
Another former military officer, Maj. Gen. Julian Thompson, wrote in The Observer: "Air cover for humanitarian convoys seems an attractive option. But anyone wishing to disrupt the supply system need only set an ambush in a village full of civilians to pose an agonizing choice for those controlling air retaliation."
And, he pointed out, in the guerrilla warfare for which the Serbian army and the irregular militia forces have been trained for years, "a handful can hold up a host."
Lady Thatcher and others have argued that the use of air power to carry out precise strikes against the mortars and tanks that have pounded Sarajevo would be an effective way of reducing the violence, but skeptical experts say that is illusory, too.
 
Danger of Civilian Casualties
 General Thompson wrote: "Locating even the largest guns and tanks can be difficult in heavily wooded, hilly country, or among buildings. Once found, the target must be struck quickly before it moves, and with precision to avoid 'collateral damage,' a euphemism for destroying adjacent buildings or killing and injuring innocent civilians."
The same risk of inadvertent civilian casualties would be run by an air bombardment campaign against Serbian munitions stores or arms factories on Serbian territory, another option that has been advanced by critics of Western inaction. The Western and Arab allies ran such risks to liberate Kuwait, a major oil producer, because on balance they judged the result, a deterrence of Iraqi aggression, to be worth the risks and the other costs.
The United States was in overall charge during that war, though it was paid for mainly by the Germans and the Japanese, who were not combatants. A year and a half later, the United States and Britain are both sapped by economic recession, the Germans have run out of money, and the Japanese feel a long way, culturally and physically, from Sarajevo.
 
Proposal for Refugee Havens
 At the London peace conference later this month, Mr. Major reportedly plans to propose safe havens for refugees in the Balkans as the first stage toward a cantonization of Bosnia into three separate ethnic regions.
But Edward Cowan, a former British military attache to Yugoslavia, argued in The Sunday Times today that merely securing the perimeter around Sarajevo could take 10 battalions, or 30,000 soldiers. It could take 100,000, he said, to make the entire Muslim-occupied region safe from attack.
These are among the reasons not to go in. The reasons to go in anyway include, as Lady Thatcher wrote in The New York Times last week, "refugees, terrorism, Balkan wars drawing in other countries and worse."
And Mr. Hurd said, "I think it would be morally justified if a way of using force could be devised which would actually bring the suffering to an end, and that of course is the difficulty."
