HEADLINE: Cruise Lines Shrug Off Mishap

 BODY:
The accident involving the Queen Elizabeth 2 is not likely to hurt the finances of the ship's owner, the Cunard Line, or the health of the cruise industry, analysts and company executives say.
Cunard, a subsidiary of Trafalgar House P.L.C. of London, was insured to cover all lost revenue, except for a $100,000 deductible, while the company's flagship is out of service. And Joseph Smyth, executive vice president of operations for the cruise line, said yesterday that no one had called the company to cancel their travel plans on the ship, which represents 1,800 of the company's total 5,000 berths on seven ships. 
 Analysts also said yesterday that they doubted the incident would prompt fears among vacationers. They noted that most cruises followed well-traveled routes in the Caribbean and the Bahamas, as well as Alaska. The QE2 incident occurred off the south coast of Massachusetts on a route that the ship takes only twice a year.
"The likelihood of accidents happening is very small," said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "I don't view it as significant at all for the cruise industry."
Cruise lines have been the bright spot in the travel business in recent years, much more profitable than the airline and hotel industries.
Despite the recession, cruise companies have added capacity to their fleets in recent years, and still managed to attain an occupancy rate of about 90 percent for their 90,000 berths last year. Repeat business rates range from roughly 25 percent to over 50 percent on luxury liners like the QE2.
At the same time, the cruise companies have grown more profitable by introducing larger ships that let them spread costs over more customers.

HEADLINE: 2 'Baby Bells' Reach Agreements With Unions

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Southwestern Bell and Bell South, providers of local telephone service for more than 30 million customers, reached agreement with its unions early yesterday morning, as three other large carriers continued to negotiate past the weekend expiration of their labor contracts.
The tentative labor accord at Southwestern Bell, based in St. Louis, gave 40,000 workers a 12.3 percent wage increase over three years. About 66 percent of Southwestern Bell's work force is union. The agreement at Bell South, based in Atlanta, gave 62,000 workers an 11.3 percent wage increase over the same period. About 64 percent of Bell South's work force is union. Union members will be voting on whether to approve the accord over the next several weeks. 
 Other details of the agreements were sketchy. But the central issues in the talks with Ameritech, Bell Atlantic and the Pacific Telesis Group as well as Southwestern Bell and Bell South talks were health care, wages and pensions.
 
Retrenchment for 'Baby Bells'
 The contract talks with the two unions representing the workers, Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, were held in a time of continuing retrenchment for the former Bell system. As a monopoly provider, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company could turn a blind eye to inefficiencies in one area of the country as long as other areas were more efficient.
With the boom in demand for telecommunications services in the early 1970's, A.T.& T. hired thousands of workers straight out of college or high school.
But since A.T.& T. was split up in 1984, both A.T.& T., now a long-distance carrier and equipment manufacturer, and the regional "Baby Bells" have had to lay off tens of thousands of workers in efforts to cut costs.
The issue in this year's contract talks was not whether workers would lose their jobs but what could be done to ease the pain of laid-off workers in terms of severance and retraining, and increase the productivity, if not the wages, of the workers who stayed.
 
Strikes Not Expected
 Both union and management said strikes were unlikely, not only because the persistent recession made workers wary of walkouts but because modern telecommunications equipment requires fewer workers. Phone company management could, for the most part, step in for striking workers in ways that would be impossible at a steel or automobile plant.
Still negotiating yesterday were Ameritech, based in Chicago; Bell Atlantic, in Philadelphia; and Pacific Telesis, in San Francisco, serving a total of nearly 49 million customers. Union contracts at these carriers, like those of Southwestern Bell and Bell South, expired at midnight Saturday.
The contracts of US West, based in Englewood, Colo., expire next Saturday.
The Nynex Corporation reached agreement with its unions last year. And some contracts for subsidiaries of the GTE Corporation, which was not part of the old Bell system and is the nation's largest local carrier, expired in May, June and July, but contract talks continue. Most of GTE's contracts, including that of California, the largest GTE subsidiary, expire later this year.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush Stirs Fears to Run Against
Trying to Convince Voters That Clinton Would Be a Gamble

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 9

 BODY:
As President Bush struggles to revive his campaign, he is returning to an approach that worked for him in 1988: portraying himself as the less scary of the two Presidential candidates.
At campaign appearances in recent days, Mr. Bush used the same rhetorical techniques he employed against Michael S. Dukakis four years ago, describing threats that he would stand up against and implying, without actually saying so, that his opponent's election would make the threat a reality. 
 It is all part of the announced White House strategy of raising "the fear factor" by pointing out that Gov. Bill Clinton represents a gamble for the voters. Campaigning last week in New York, Georgia, Florida, Nevada and Colorado, Mr. Bush was painting a dark, monochromatic picture of what the losing side of that gamble might look like.
In 1988, he did this by saying frequently that people should vote for him because he was "on the American side," suggesting, presumably, that Governor Dukakis was not.
 
Guarding Against 'Them'
 In the same vein, Mr. Bush has recently assured his audiences that he would prevent "them" from dismantling the veterans' health system, although no one has suggested that that be done. He has said he would work to "establish freedom and democracy" around the world, a task that both Mr. Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, have repeatedly implied is beyond the abilities of the Democrats.
Much of what the President had to say last week was drowned out by his disavowal of a news release reviving accusations about marital infidelity against Mr. Clinton, by rumors about Mr. Bush's health and by the lingering disorganization of his campaign.
Polls still show Mr. Bush lagging far behind Mr. Clinton. But a few cautionary notes might be prudent.
Mr. Bush's re-election effort is showing new life as he gives more focused, ideological speeches and moves to capitalize on the power of his office by calling news conferences, as he did on Friday and again Saturday to talk about a slight dip in unemployment, the Balkan war and tensions in Iraq.
The weapons of fear are also potent ones, and Mr. Bush shows no hesitation in constructing frightening scenarios to place between Mr. Clinton and voters.
At times, Mr. Bush does that directly, as he did Thursday, when he said the Arkansas Governor would raise taxes if he became President. But he also does it through implication.
"As long as I am President, I will not allow a madman to get a finger on the nuclear trigger," Mr. Bush told a group of cheering disabled veterans in Reno last Wednesday.
On some fronts, like abortion, Mr. Clinton has made himself vulnerable. "In some places, a 13-year-old girl cannot get her ears pierced without parental permission -- without bringing her mother and father along," Mr. Bush said at a Knights of Columbus conference in New York on Wednesday. "But some believe that the same girl should be able to get an abortion without parental consent."
Certainly, Mr. Clinton is not encouraging 13-year-old girls to get abortions. But his position on abortion gave Mr. Bush ammunition for the attack: while Mr. Clinton thinks that parents should be notified before their teen-agers have abortions, he does not believe the law should require their advance consent.
Mr. Bush has raised fears about the Democrats on the Presidential ticket and in Congress that have little to do with their policies.
"If, in all this talk about change, Congress sends me legislation to dismantle the V.A. system, I will whip out my veto pen and knock down that incoming Scud missile, that Scud missile aimed right at your very well-being," Mr. Bush told the veterans.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor Congressional Democrats have suggested dismantling the veterans' health-care system.
 
Morality and Religion
 Last week, Mr. Bush was offering subliminal images of fear on another facet of his offensive: morality and religion. "Now that our moral values are victorious around the globe, we cannot and we will not abandon them at home," Mr. Bush said in a speech to the Knights of Columbus gathering. "We didn't stand together to see courageous moral values rise in Russia, only to be ignored here at home."
As in previous years, patriotism and national security are central themes for the Republicans in raising voters' concerns about the Democrats.
Mr. Bush is basing his patriotic appeal in part on the suggestion that because Mr. Clinton and the Democrats have talked about America's declining economy and shrinking exports, they are "running down America" and would allow the nation's exports to collapse.
Addressing workers at a carpet factory in Dalton, Ga., on Monday, Mr. Bush said: "They see these unbelievable opportunities, these vast markets to sell your goods, and they say, 'Well we'd better not try. And the challenge is too great. The odds are too long.' "
Mr. Bush is also using Mr. Clinton's lack of experience in military policy and foreign affairs to imply dire consequences if he became President.
Speaking at a high-technology company in Orange County, Calif., on July 30, Mr. Bush painted a picture of a Democratic administration recklessly slashing military spending. "Someone has to say, even now that we've won the cold war, America is safe, but just so long as America stays strong," Mr. Bush said. "And if we took the course that some recommend, we literally wouldn't know what we're missing until we found it out in the heat of battle."
There are risks to this approach. Mr. Bush's tough, ideological talk may bring back wayward Republicans, but the President must appeal to a broader audience to win in November. After the 1988 campaign, Mr. Bush is also vulnerable to charges of negative campaigning, and the Clinton team is doing everything it can to make Mr. Bush seem guilty of just that.
But the President has made it clear that he intends to press the attack. "After my being hounded and pounded for nine months by my principles being ill-defined and what I stand for being ill-defined, you're going to see some hard-hitting attacks which are going to fairly define his positions," Mr. Bush said Friday. "That's going to be fun."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush greeting supporters during a campaign appearance last week in Dalton, Ga. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
BEHIND THE DEMISE OF TIMES SQUARE PLAN 
The villains were many in the failure to redevelop Times Square: a real-estate glut, a deep recession and, most important, a government campaign to use bulldoze-and-build policies at a time when large-scale development has become a much more intricate art. There was no lack of financial incentives in the drive to replace the cut-rate movie houses, street hustlers and sleaze. What was missing was a major tenant to commit to office space in any of the new buildings. As the years passed, the Times Square project became a case study for planners and government analysts of how the well intentioned urban renewal policies of the 1960's and 1970's would founder in the 1980. News analysis. B3.
 
FIGHTING THEIR CHILD'S FIGHT
After watching their only child die from a disease she battled privately and publicly for years, Jerrold and Carol Gertz took comfort in knowing that Alison never wavered in her determination to win her fight against AIDS. "She never gave in to it," Mrs. Gertz said. "She never thought she was dying, she never thought about her own death, just about what she could do with those last few years." At the age of 26, Alison L. Gertz, a national symbol of the risk of H.I.V. infection to heterosexuals, died on Saturday at her parents' summer home in Westhampton Beach, L.I., surrounded by family and friends who vowed to continue her battle. B5.
 
PARENTS CHARGED IN SON'S DEATH
A Manhattan couple has been arrested in the killing of their 7-year-old son, who died of malnutrition last May. The boy weighed 24 pounds when his parents took him to a hospital in Nassau County, where they were living at the time. B3.
 
TWO MEN KILLED IN QUEENS DISPUTE
Five people were shot -- two fatally -- in their Queens apartment after an attempt by a former roommate and several others to collect a debt resulted in a spray of gunfire, the police said. In a rundown building in Woodside yesterday, no one had cleaned the blood that ran down the steps from the apartment, which six men and one woman, all in their 20's and recent immigrants from China, had shared. B3
 
BIG GAINS AT A SMALL SCHOOL
If there is any proof that the smaller, more specialized public high schools proposed last week for New York City can work, consider the school that Deborah Meier built in East Harlem. Working with largely poor, minority students who other schools have written off, Ms. Meier's project, Central Park East Secondary School, has won widespread praise. In a city where just 38.9 percent of students graduate high school within four years, Central Park East, which opened in 1985, graduated 71 percent of its ninth-grade class in four years. The school's core tenet is that all students, particularly poor students, need a school small enough to instill the sense that someone cares and holds them accountable. B3.
 
REGION
 
THE DEADLY GAME OF CAR THEFT
It might come as some comfort if the thieves in Newark, who have made their city the nation's stolen car capital, were in the business just to make money. The problem is far worse: Not only do the youthful thieves -- some as young as 9 years old -- hot-wire 40 cars each day. But they drive back to their neighborhoods, where they show off their driving skills, performing "doughnuts" on the streets and other bold stunts. To the youths, possessing cars is a rite of passage and a means to gain veneration. To the rest of Newark it has become a deadly and costly abuse. Many residents feel angry and violated. A1.
 
THE ROMANCE OF GOING BY SEA
Tucked behind a tangle of highway ramps and storm fencing, a century-old ferry service in Bridgeport, Conn., seems to be thriving, even as much of the rest of this city falls into disrepair. Founded in 1883 by a group of businessmen, including P. T. Barnum, the Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company traverses Long Island Sound with loads of highway-weary travelers interested in cutting their travel time and experiencing a different way to get around. "It's nice knowing that something like this exists," said Richard Mizdal, an artist from Remsenburg, L.I., who was returning from a visit to New England. "It's not only the efficiency factor, but it's kind of a romantic notion, of travel on the water." Long Island Sound Journal. B2.

HEADLINE: Miscalculations in Times Square;
Project Shows That Renewal Needs More Than Bulldozers

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In the end, the culprit was a real estate glut during a deep recession. But the failure of a 15-year government campaign to redevelop Times Square may rest more squarely on the government's attempt to use bulldoze-and-build urban renewal policies at a time when large-scale development has become a more intricate art.
From its inception in the late 1970's, the project proceeded on the premise that extraordinary financial incentives by city and state agencies could produce towering office buildings to replace the haphazard mix of cut-rate movie houses, street hustlers and sleaze at the south end of Times Square. 
 The developers, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, headed by George Klein, were selected in 1981 to construct four million square feet of new offices in buildings whose height and bulk would have stood out even in midtown Manhattan.
The government incentives were rich: tax abatements from the city extending into the next century. More than that, through New York State's power to condemn property, the Times Square site was supposed to be delivered as clean canvas for development: vacant lots, devoid of cantankerous tenants, and clear of the arduous process of public review.
But by the time the project was put on indefinite hold a week ago, it had become a case study for planners and government analysts of how the urban renewal policies of the 1960's and 1970's would founder in the 1980's.
"As a planning concept, it was badly flawed from the beginning," said Peter Salins, a professor of Urban Planning at Hunter College.
 
City Undermines Itself
 What distinguished the project was what it lacked. Most importantly, no major tenant committed to office space in any of the new buildings, even during New York City's economic boom of the mid-1980's, when banks, securities firms and others were expanding rapidly.
Proponents of the project also failed to anticipate the cascade of public protest and lawsuits that would block construction for at least a decade.
Critics of the project condemned its size and bulk, and more than 40 lawsuits were filed in the early 1980's by environmental groups, property owners and others opposed to the project. By the end of the decade, when the rest of midtown Manhattan was in an office-building boom, the Times Square project was still languishing in court.
And while no one could have predicted the recession, the project's prospects for success were severely undermined by the city itself, which offered zoning incentives to office developers elsewhere in the western half of midtown Manhattan. That put the Times Square project in competition with many others, and in a battle for tenants it was bound to lose.
Now, as the boom in midtown has gone bust, office vacancies have soared and rents have declined. Real estate experts see no market for the huge office towers in Times Square, with or without government help.
"Four million square feet of new office space is simply not going to be built in the next decade by the private sector, and it makes no sense for the city to pour massive subsidies into having it built," said Marc A. Weiss, director of real-estate development research at Columbia University.
 
Successful Plans Elsewhere
 Although developers hold out the hope that the towers will eventually be built, the condemnation process has already changed Times Square. Numerous businesses, including the venerable Nathan's restaurant on the east side of 43d Street and Broadway and several movie houses on 42d Street, have been forced to close.
"This was a back-from-the-dead example of the thoroughly discredited bulldozer urban renewal of the 1960's," said Ada Louis Huxtable, a New York City architecture critic and historian, in a 1990 essay, even before the project collapsed.
The deal for Times Square redevelopment was struck after two decades that had made urban renewal a rallying cry in some of the nation's cities. Beginning in the late 1960's, and backed by huge Federal susbsidies, Boston, Baltimore, Portland, Ore., and Stamford, Conn., for example, had revitalized tawdry downtown and waterfront areas with offices, restaurants and shopping malls.
But by the time the Times Square plan was in final form Federal money for urban renewal had dried up.
City and state officials took a new approach, agreeing to acquire the Times Square site only if the developers would pay for it. Then, upon completion of their office towers, Mr. Klein and Prudential would be paid back not only through tax abatements, but through rent credits.
 
New Strength for Opponents
 Although this financial arrangement may yet prove successful, other roadblocks emerged in the early 1980's. The project was initiated at a time when environmental groups, neighborhood coalitions, and others had begun to emerge as potent new forces in opposing development.
For example, Westway, the proposed highway and commercial project along the Hudson River below 57th Street, collapsed under litigation and citizen protest.
Although public response to the Times Square plan was far from unified, those who opposed it in the 1980's called upon a growing arsenal of legal and public relations skills.
"This is a project that overreached," said Kent Barwick, president of the Municipal Arts Society.
He added, "Everyone loses in these situations. We have seen lots of viable activity in Times Square destroyed for offices we didn't need."
Yet, proponents of the project needed only to look as far as downtown Brooklyn to find a redevelopment scheme that shows strong signs of success. Since 1988, more than four million square feet of offices have been built, or are nearing completion, on a dozen commercial blocks in downtown Brooklyn. Land was condemned by the state, and tax abatements were offered to developers.
 
In Brooklyn, Tenants First

But a major difference in Brooklyn is that corporate tenants, including the Chase Manhattan Bank, Morgan Stanley & Company and the Securities Industry Automation Corporation were courted aggressively by the city and Brooklyn's developers. Long-term leases for most of the new Brooklyn offices were signed before construction began.
In the Times Square redevelopment scheme, no corporate tenants were ever found for any of the proposed new space.
Also, beginning in 1982, the year after its agreement was signed with Mr. Klein and Prudential, New York City adopted zoning inducements to encourage developers to put up office towers elsewhere in the western half of midtown Manhattan.
The intent was to attract new development away from the congested blocks on the east side of midtown, and upgrade the declining blocks around Time Square. Planners thought that there would be more than enough development to fill both the sites on the West Side and the Times Square project.
But the plan backfired. When the city imposed a deadline on the zoning incentives, which allowed buildings larger and bulkier than otherwise, for the end of 1988, developers raced to put their foundations in the ground. More than a dozen large office towers rose near Times Square just as the city was sinking into recession and its real-estate market into a glut.
As a result, experts say, there is a lean market for new offices in Manhattan, and the outlook for Times Square, at least for now, is zero.
"If we do this kind of thing in the future, even in a more robust economy, we are going to have to have a better idea of what the market will bear," said Mr. Salins, the urban planner.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newsprint Makers' Troubles May Haunt Papers One Day

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
THE newsprint business has rarely, if ever, seen worse days. There is a glut of newsprint available for sale, but the demand from newspapers is tepid because of the recession. This huge imbalance in supply and demand has been the status quo for more than two years.
"It's an unmitigated disaster," said George B. Adler, an analyst specializing in paper companies at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. 
Indeed, the newsprint business is so bad that newspapers are extremely concerned about the financial health of newsprint manufacturers, even though they have previously shown no mercy in demanding ever-larger discounts as newsprint supply far outstripped demand.
With leading newsprint companies like Abitibi-Price Inc. and Bowater Inc. losing money, the fear among some newspapers is that by pressing for the lowest possible prices, they may have created a monster that is preparing to attack them.
This theory is that prices have dropped so low that newsprint companies will demand staggering increases as soon as they can get away with it. Though advertising remains generally flat, many newspapers expect a slowly improving economy to increase advertising in the next year or two. And as newspapers run more advertising, in turn, their demand for newsprint increases.
Newspapers have come to depend on low newsprint prices in the last two years, as the recession has eroded their profits.
If newsprint prices were to skyrocket, the prospective gains from improved advertising could be virtually wiped out at all papers, and some weaker papers -- especially the smaller dailies in Chicago, Houston, New York, Denver and other cities with newspaper competition -- could even be forced out of business.
In these cities, the smaller papers already make little if any profit and would probably get less new advertising in an improving economy than the dominant papers. As such, surging newsprint costs would wound the weaker papers much more than the dominant papers.
Nonetheless, there is little evidence that such concerns have encouraged newspapers to pay more than the market will bear for newsprint.
For instance, earlier this year, a number of newsprint companies announced that the price of newsprint would increase on Aug. 1.
The current list price for a metric ton of newsprint is $685, but newspapers actually get an average discount of about 40 percent off the list price. The Aug. 1 increase, in effect, was intended to reduce the discount to 35 percent, which would have increased the price by about $35 a ton.
But as Aug. 1 approached, word rippled through the newspaper industry that the newsprint manufacturers were not going to be able to make the new price stick, because there was so much excess newsprint available.
"I've got a nagging intuition that there is way too much newsprint out there to make this thing happen," said Homer E. Taylor, vice president of supply for Knight-Ridder Inc., owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Miami Herald and one of the largest consumers of newsprint.
Essentially, the economics of producing newsprint make such gluts very difficult to avoid.
Building newsprint mills is very expensive. But once the mill is operating, the cost to the company of producing each ton of newsprint is very small. The newsprint companies need cash to pay for the cost of building the mills, so they produce as much paper as they can and then sell it for whatever the market will bear.
And now, what the market will bear is so low that even highly efficient operations like Bowater cannot sell paper for more than it costs to make and deliver it.
In the first two quarters of this year, Bowater, the nation's largest newsprint manufacturer, reported an overall operating loss for the first time since the company went public in 1984. Though the company makes a profit from products like the coated paper used for magazines, the loss from newsprint dragged the whole operation into the red.
"The industry cannot continue to operate as it has in a money-losing situation," said David G. McMaster, president of Bowater.
Of course, the older and more remote mills, like some of those in Canada, could simply stop producing paper, thus bringing supply and demand more into equilibrium.
But the social costs of such a Darwinian solution in lost jobs and shattered communities has prompted the Canadian Government to step in and save newsprint mills that might otherwise stop production.
For instance, the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company jointly operated a newsprint mill at Spruce Falls in Ontario, about 500 miles north of Toronto. Because it had been unprofitable for years, the owners decided to stop operating it and in December gave it to the employees.
Through loans from the former owners and subsidies from the Canadian Government, the plant is now producing almost as much newsprint as before.
To make the burden on newsprint manufacturers even greater, they are under mounting pressure from newspapers and state and local governments to produce newsprint from recycled used newspapers.
Such recycled newsprint must be turned back into pulp, which requires a de-inking process.
And the capital cost of building such de-inking plants must be born by the newsprint manufacturers, just when they have the least amount of capital to spend.

HEADLINE: Raychem Wins a German Phone Contract

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Raychem Corporation has won a $100 million contract to help provide modern telephone service in the former East Germany and in the process test some of the most advanced features incorporating fiber optics.
Raychem is the only American company to participate in one of the world's most ambitious telecommunications projects: the German Government's $30 billion five-year effort to bring a working telephone system to the backward regions of eastern Germany. 
 Robert J. Saldich, Raychem's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview last week that "the former East Germany, much like West Germany after World War II, has the potential for leapfrogging other countries, this time in telecommunications rather than in manufacturing."
When the Berlin wall fell in 1989, there were only 1.5 million telephone lines in East Germany and a two-decade wait for a telephone to be installed. Many of the telephone lines were unreliable.
"The system in East Germany is a train wreck," Mr. Saldich said. "There were many Western companies, not to speak of West German companies, who simply refused to do business in East Germany because of the lack of working telephones. So the German Government very wisely concluded that the first priority must be to establish modern telecommunications."
By the late 1990's, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom, the state-owned telephone company, plans to install 6 million business and residential lines and replace the existing network, for a total of 7.5 million lines and perhaps more.
About 1.2 million of the new lines will be fiber optic, providing clear voice telephone service as well as future capacity for video and data services. The fiber-optic lines, which transmit via rapid pulses of light over thin glass filaments rather than electric current through copper wire, may cost $2.4 billion or more to manufacture and install.
The German Government awarded contracts for the first 200,000 fiber-optic lines. Three European companies -- Siemens of Germany, Alcatel of France and a consortium led by Philips of the Netherlands -- won contracts for most of the work.
 
A Smaller Contract
 Raynet, a unit of Raychem, won the contract for 48,500 lines in five German cities, including Brandenburg. The lines are scheduled to open in December 1993.
The fiber-optic lines will not provide some of the most advanced services like videoconferencing or rapid use of data bases but will provide digital, and therefore highly reliable, telephone service, as well as 36 to 50 channels of cable television. The main advantage for Raychem is the opportunity to demonstrate its equipment, Mr. Saldich said.
By showing that fiber optics work, the project may help Raychem's sales efforts in West Germany, which has Europe's largest economy, Mr. Saldich said.

HEADLINE: On Stolen Wheels, Newark Youths Defy Authority

SERIES: Growing Up, Stealing Cars -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD with MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The cloak of night had dropped over the city's West District, and that meant it was show time.
A metallic blue Acura lurking in the distance revved its engine to a piercing whine and came hurtling down lamplit Jelliff Avenue. As the car, a translucent gleam, reached the intersection of 18th Avenue the driver stomped on the brakes, yanked the emergency brake and twisted the steering wheel sharply to the left, causing the squealing car to spin in a tight circle and leave behind the telltale black smudges of a "doughnut." 
 The maneuver was expertly executed, and swarms of goggle-eyed friends on the sidewalks registered their zealous approval. Two kids with manic grins gave the thumbs-up sign. One scrawny onlooker screamed out: "Yo, good dough."
The driver of the Acura was a car thief, his vehicle stolen property. And on this hot summer night he and many other youths had fanned out into the emptying streets of Newark to display their profligate talents behind the wheels of hot cars.
"Some kids play sports for identity," said Sgt. Henry Alston of the Newark police auto-theft squad. "Some kids read books to be somebody. And some kids steal cars. So one kid is the quarterback, one kid is the president of the eighth-grade class and one kid is the doughnut man."
Car theft in Newark and neighboring cities has reached epidemic proportions in recent years. Day or night, no automobile is safe. Even the most youthful thieves -- some are as young as 9 years old -- can penetrate any barrier and be behind the wheel in a matter of seconds; soon they are thundering down the road, riding like the wind. Every 24 hours, 40 automobiles disappear, making this troubled city of 275,000 the car-theft capital of the country.
While some of the larceny is for profit, in which the criminals either retag the cars with new license plates and sell them or peddle them to "chop shops" that carve them up for the parts, most of the recent theft here is of a different stripe. It is the work of juveniles and tender adults interested in possessing the cars as a rite of passage and a means to gain veneration in their neighborhoods.
Once they have the cars, it is incumbent upon them to demonstrate their deft driving by doing doughnuts and other bold stunts. After the cars run out of gas or become crippled beyond appeal, they are usually ditched.
To the youths, it is just a daring game, but to the rest of Newark it has become a deadly and costly abuse. Two months ago a 17-year-old car-theft suspect named Howard Caesar was seriously wounded when he was shot -- apparently by a police officer.
The suspect is now in stable condition, and three officers have been charged with conspiring to conceal their actions. Last Thursday another officer who was suspended in the case pleaded guilty to lying on a police report and agreed to testify to a special grand jury.
 
The Price
Damaged Vehicles, Damaged Lives
 The game has also meant that dozens of parked or passing cars have been bashed and pedestrians have been injured and even killed. Some of the thieves have never driven before and learn to operate cars at 70 miles an hour. Some must climb atop phone books or rolled-up floor mats just to see over the wheel. Their bodies are slight, but their feet are lead.
Then there is the wrenching impact on victims who find themselves stranded without transportation, saddled with towing and repair costs and anguished over their sense of violation. A woman who recently moved to Newark from San Francisco with a 1991 Jeep Wrangler allowed her insurance to lapse for a few days while she switched to a new carrier. The day after the insurance expired, her car was stolen. It was recovered with $2,150 worth of damage.
And there are other economic costs. Since New Jersey limits insurance rates in the Newark area, hoping to spread the burden more evenly, every car owner in the state bears part of the cost of the city's myriad stolen cars. Indeed, auto theft is one of the principal reasons the state's insurance rates are the third highest in the country.
It is impossible to calculate all the time and expense mustered against car theft here. But a new task force of officers from Essex County, where Newark, Irvington and East Orange are situated, and neighboring Union County, which includes Elizabeth, costs more than $1 million a year. Meanwhile, the Newark police have about 20 officers assigned full time to fighting car theft, and virtually every member of the department periodically finds himself pitted against a car thief. Auto theft is the most commonly reported major offense in the city, last year accounting for 34 percent of all serious crimes.
 
Stealing Reputations
 The sauciness of the thieves is striking. On the streets, 18-year-old Easy E, whose nickname suggests how simple it is for him to steal cars, boasts of taking 200 vehicles in the last three years and tells how those deeds have fortified his sense of who he is. "I usually wear my shades and driving gloves," he said, because his admirers expect it.
Last year, one youth was brought into a police precinct station house for stealing a car and released on his own recognizance. Not much for taking the bus, he stole a police officer's car to go home.
Several months ago, while the Essex County Prosecutor was busy delivering a talk on auto theft at a Newark church, a thief was busy stealing his car.
As the police and prosecutors have bolstered their efforts to stem the problem -- most notably by forming the task force last December -- the youths have upped the ante. They taunt the police and increasingly ram stolen cars into police cruisers, taking special delight in exploding a cruiser's air bags. During the first seven months of the year, 20 Newark police cars have been smashed in brushes with thieves.
"I hate the word joy riding," said Sgt. Thomas DeCastro, the head of the Essex-Union task force. "They kill others; they kill themselves; they kill us. A teen-age kid with 3,000 pounds of metal under him going 80 miles an hour is not a joy to behold. He's an absolute terror."
Virtually nothing stops the thieves. Stealing a car is easier than breaking into a house. And why break into a house? It doesn't take you anyplace; it doesn't do doughnuts.
 
The Numbers
Leading the Nation In Auto Thefts
 Like any densely populated city, Newark has long been stained by car theft. Not until 1985 did the problem begin to spiral out of control. A decade ago, Newark ranked ninth in car theft per 100,000 people among cities of more than 50,000 population, with 6,424 cars stolen. By 1986, the number had swelled to 12,918, and Newark vaulted to first place, a dubious distinction it has yet to relinquish. New York City, by comparison, ranked 36th in 1990. (New Jersey itself ranks third among states in car theft per capita, behind California and New York.)
Between 1984 and 1989, theft in Newark doubled to 15,674 cars. In each of the last two years, largely because of more vigilant efforts against insurance fraud, the numbers have decreased somewhat, falling to 13,961 last year. So far this year, theft is down an additional 14 percent, a mark that local officials say shows the impact of the the new task force. But, they say, the level remains wholly unacceptable.
 
'Mostly Joy Riding'
 Insurance companies find that in central and southern New Jersey only about one-third of stolen cars are recovered, suggesting they have been chopped up or shipped overseas for sale. But in northern New Jersey more than two-thirds are recovered, indicating that the prime intention is to drive them. The Newark police estimate that they recover about 78 percent of the city's stolen cars.
"In Newark, it's mostly joy riding," said Thomas J. Cleary, northeast manager for the National Insurance Crime Bureau, a group that monitors and studies car theft for a consortium of insurance companies. "It is not unique there for a young chap to get picked up 25 to 30 times for car theft."
Sergeant DeCastro, an old auto-theft hand, has seen the motivation change. "I was an undercover operative in a car sting four years ago," he said. "If you asked me then why they were stealing, it was to sell the cars to get money to buy drugs. That was the main reason. Now it's a street game. Who can steal the coolest car, the fastest car, the prettiest car and who can drive it the best."
 
The Perpetrators
Light Sentences, Repeat Offenders
 As with so many fads that entice the young, no one seems certain how this one began. "We wanted our own thing," explained Keekee, a 15-year-old thief who said Newark youths drifted into car stealing and stunt driving to stand apart from urban youths who expressed themselves through graffiti or other acts.
Certainly, the game has been fueled by the light penalties attached to the crime. Judicial overload and clogged prisons in New Jersey have meant that car thieves rarely serve much, if any, time behind bars. Probation seems to be the most common punishment, and juveniles are frequently released on their own recognizance the day they are arrested. Adult thieves often give fake names and ages to evade penalties.
What's more, because of the perils to bystanders, the police are restrained from chasing stolen cars at high speed unless they believe the drivers were involved in another, more serious crime
The police say there is little recognizable pattern to where car theft takes place. No area of Newark is immune, though incidents are scarcer in the East District. Many of the thefts in surrounding cities like Irvington, Elizabeth and East Orange, the police have found, are the handiwork of Newark thieves who venture out in bands and bring cars back in caravans to Newark. One reason for straying out of town is that thieves do not want to steal cars in neighborhoods where they are known. Any number of times, they have mistakenly stolen the cars of drug dealers from their area, only to have the dealers track them down and beat them up or shoot them.
There is a very definite pattern to where the cars are recovered. Most turn up in Newark's South and West districts, impoverished, sad areas of the city where most of the car thieves live and where they especially like to put on their driving exhibitions.
Nationwide, the most commonly stolen car is the Ford Mustang, though on the streets of Newark the car of choice is a Honda, especially an Accord, or its upscale sibling, the Acura. Thieves favor small, zippy cars because they handle well on the dense streets and are ideal for doughnuts. A black Honda with tinted windows is prized the most.
A $2 screwdriver or a "slim jim," a sliver of steel that slips between a car window and door, usually gets thieves past the door lock, or else they'll break a window. If a driver uses a locking bar like the Club to guard the steering wheel, the thieves will spray it with freon, freezing it, and then smash it with a hammer. To start the car, they'll crack the steering column with a flat-bladed screwdriver and insert the tool into the opening to start the car. On Hondas and other Japanese cars, they'll yank out the ignition switch and then stick a screwdriver into the housing and turn it. Hidden shut-off switches do deter many thieves. But if a thief really wants a car, he'll get a tow truck.
According to profiles put together by the joint task force, more than 65 percent of the offenders are aged 9 to 17. Few flirt with car theft once and then resist its scent. The Newark police keep a list of juvenile repeat offenders known as the target auto-theft offenders list, the equivalent of its roster of career adult criminals. To make the list a youth must be arrested at least five times. Dozens have been.
Sergeant Alston unfolded the rap sheet of one 11-year-old who has been on the list for two years. It contained 15 arrests for auto theft. The boy has been removed to foster care. Then the sergeant held up the sheet of a 14-year-old who had nine arrests. "Nothing has happened to him," he said. "He got a one-year suspended sentence and hasn't gone anywhere. That's crazy. And he's a prime-time player. What I'm showing you is how the home failed first and now the state failed."
 
The Victims
For Car Owners, A Losing Battle
 Bedeviled residents of Newark have been stumped over how to protect their cars.
For Loretta Hilton, seeing her car stolen has become a yearly ritual. In 1990, it happened at Thanksgiving when she was visiting a friend in East Orange. In 1991, it happened just before Christmas when she stopped in to see another friend in Newark. This year, it happened early, just three months ago, while the car was outside her house in the West District. The first two times, the car was recovered, badly dented. This time, it was not found at all.
"The last payment on the car was June," said Ms. Hilton, a 35-year-old medical technician. "So the car was finally mine. Except there was no car."
Leticia Nagbe, a 23-year-old computer operator who lives in Orange and drives to work in Newark, has had it worse: three thefts in two years. "It's depressing," she said. "These awful people have no regard for other people's feelings. I am so mad."
There are visible signs of the fury. Seething residents of the South and West districts, so often victimized, sometimes fling rocks as thieves race past. They occasionally shatter windows of stolen cars, adding to the damage toll for the victims.
Just the other week, a stolen car veered wildly down Avon Avenue and mowed down a 16-year-old girl, who subsequently underwent 10 hours of surgery. When the police arrived, inflamed residents of the area were rocking the car, trying to get at the passengers. Had the police not hustled the thieves away, they said, the residents might have killed them.
As the game stubbornly continues, its players keep devising new thrills. Thieves pile into cars and soar down the street with some of them trying to see how far they can droop out the window. Friends like to hurl bricks at the cars, or shove thick tree limbs in front of them as the thieves whiz by to see if they can avoid swerving out of control or flipping over.
"Another new thing is deliberately crashing them and then burning them up," said Amando Crespo, a security guard who patrols Pilgrim Baptist Village, a housing development in the West District. "It's crazy. These kids think they're immortal. They don't know. No one is immortal."

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND SOUND JOURNAL;
Beating the Traffic by Taking a Ride on the Waves

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
Tucked behind a tangle of highway ramps and storm fencing, a century-old ferry service here seems to be thriving, even as much of the rest of this city falls into disrepair.
Founded in 1883 by a group of businessmen, including P. T. Barnum, the Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company traverses Long Island Sound with loads of highway-weary travelers interested in cutting their travel time and experiencing a different way to get around. 
 "It's nice knowing that something like this exists," said Richard Mizdal, an artist from Remsenburg, L.I., who was returning from a visit to New England. "It's not only the efficiency factor, but it's kind of a romantic notion, of travel on the water."
Ferry service became more popular in several states during the 1980's amid concern over traffic congestion and declining air quality. In New Jersey, several companies sprang up to provide ferries between cities along the Hudson and points in Manhattan. New London, Conn., remains a ferry hub, with service to summer resorts like Block Island, Fishers Island and Orient Point, on Long Island's North Fork. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has proposed high-speed ferry routes between Shoreham, L.I., and New Haven, as well as routes linking Manhattan with towns along the Hudson River and other parts of the state.
On a pair of crossings last week, many of the parents aboard the Park City, one of two ferries operated by the Bridgeport company, seemed relieved to let their children out of their cars. Toddlers scampered around the broad, open decks. Older children leaned against the railings as Bridgeport's waterfront gave way to a flat, steel-gray expanse of the Sound.
Elsewhere, businessmen whispered into cellular phones, retirees relaxed as they headed for resorts on Long Island's South Shore. Others spent the trip absorbed in their newspapers or their laptop computers.
"We want to talk about the recession," said Patricia Churko of Stratford, Conn., who was traveling with two friends. "This is my trip this summer, instead of going to Cancun. This is my vacation. I've ended up on the Long Island ferry."
Several passengers said that were it not for the ferry, they would have little contact with Bridgeport. Some said they were grateful to the ferry for helping them avoid what they evidently regarded as a fate worse than Bridgeport: entering the maelstrom that they believe New York City to be.
"I hate to drive back into the New York area and all that if I can help it," said Jim Richardson of Westport, Conn., who was heading to Quogue, L.I., with his wife, Debby. Joe and Mary Stark, who grew up riding the Staten Island Ferry, were driving to Southampton from Goshen, N.Y. The ferry cut their travel time by an hour.
Their daughters, ages 4 and 2, ran past as they spoke. "Instead of having them in the car for four and a half hours, which is torture," Mrs. Stark said, "this is a nice break."
Within an hour, the jetties and sandy beaches of Port Jefferson came into view. In Port Jefferson, the ferry docks on a pier clearly intended for public pleasure. Seafood restaurants line it, pedestrians stroll up and down it, and seagulls wheel overhead. Bridgeport's pier, in contrast, has a lone snack bar and a basketball hoop, monopolized by ferry employees when they are between boats.
Originally the ferry service was meant to link the agricultural realm of Long Island with the industrial wonders of coastal Connecticut, "specifically Bridgeport," said Frederick A. Hall, the company's general manager. Bridgeport was also a popular destination for Long Islanders needing dental work, he added. The company grew quickly from one boat to two, where it has remained for most of its 109 years.
About 700,000 people ride the ferries every year, Mr. Hall said. Last year, 234,000 cars were carried as well. The price for a car and driver is $30 one way on weekends, and $24 in the middle of the week. Individuals pay $10 each way on weekends, which run from Friday to Monday in the ferry world, and $8 on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays. Round trips are available at a discount.
During the summer, the boats -- the Park City, which is Bridgeport's nickname, and the Grand Republic, which has nothing to do with either destination -- make 10 round trips a day, Mr. Hall said. Demand falls off after Columbus Day.
The ferry definitely has its fan club, and everyone seems to have a different reason.
"You know what I like to do," confided Guy Reuge, chef and owner of a restaurant called Mirabelle in St. James, L.I., who has taken the ferry several times as part of family vacations. "I take a big cigar usually. It has to be big enough to get me all the way there. By the time I arrive, I've finished it." Then it's back into the car, and on with the trip.

HEADLINE: Success of Canadian Exporter Is a Trade Issue

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Peerless Clothing Inc., a family-owned suit maker in Montreal, has done so well in shipping its men's wool suits to the United States that it has emerged as one of the final stumbling blocks in the lengthy negotiations for a free-trade agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
In the last three years, Peerless has tripled its sales, to $100 million (Canadian), and now provides 80 percent of all the Canadian men's wool suits shipped to the United States. Because of its growth and that of some other companies, the American textile industry has persuaded American negotiators to try to keep curbs on imported apparel. The Canadians have resisted, and the haggling continues as negotiations in Washington remained unresolved today. 
 Canada's International Trade Minister, Michael Wilson, standing up for Peerless and other companies in the small but vocal Canadian apparel industry, argues that Washington is clamping down unjustly on success.
 
Minuscule Market Share
 Jack Kivenko, president of the Canadian Apparel Manufacturers' Institute, complained, "As soon as we have any degree of success -- even though the amount of our exports is minuscule in the U.S. market -- the Americans are trying to stop us, which is not really fair."
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, has so far been unwilling to make an exception for Canada.
Imports by the United States of men's woolen suits from Canada rose ninefold, to 456,000 in the 12 months that ended May 31, from 49,000 in 1987. That growth was largely a result of the dismantlement of barriers under a free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada that went into effect on Jan. 1, 1989.
Peerless, whose 300,000-square-foot computerized plant employs 1,300 people in the north end of Montreal, saw the trade liberalization coming and capitalized on it. The 73-year-old company turns out 17,000 men's suits a week, as well as trousers and sport jackets.
Its chief executive and principal owner, Alvin Segal, a 58-year-old Montreal resident who calls himself a manufacturing specialist, said he had prepared for expansion by turning to a process known as European engineering to make what look like hand-tailored suits without the hand tailoring. Instead, pieces of fabric are carefully molded and fused to garments.
"When I saw what the Europeans were doing, I was fascinated, and began implementing it right here," he said in an interview on Friday. "The technology is widely available. I didn't do anything anyone else couldn't have done."
Such machine-made suits were developed in Europe after World War II, after a generation of tailors died in the Holocaust or fled the Continent, Mr. Segal said.
The process allows him to sell his suits to American retail outlets for as little as $130. The stores put on their own labels and mark up the suits to around $300.
Peerless has 2,000 retail accounts, most in the United States, and some in Puerto Rico and in Mexico.
Under the Canadian-American free trade agreement, Canadian manufacturers like Peerless can import spools of yarn from Europe and Asia and knit them into fabric for garments that are considered to be Canadian for trade purposes.
Such garments qualify for lower duties and eventually duty-free trade with the United States under the staged reduction of tariffs that is part of the United States-Canada pact. Peerless's suits pay a 15 percent duty, down from 25 percent in 1989.
But under the negotiations for the new North American Free Trade Agreement, the United States is insisting that suits or other garments made of foreign yarn come in under a special quota to get the preferential duty. Once that quota is filled, the suits would have to pay the full 25 percent tariff, the same as those from South Korea or Italy, for example.
In other words, the way the Canadians see it, Canadian companies that do not use American fabric to make garments would not be able to enjoy the freer trade benefits of the pact.
Asked his reaction, an American trade official said, "The Canadians are beefing because they are trying to get themselves a bigger quota." He declined to predict the outcome of the conflict.
 
Focus on Hills
 So far, Mrs. Hills has been unwilling to budge. Any eventual concession to the Canadians would depend on her judgment of the political as well as economic trade-offs.
The reason the United States has been so tough is that Canadian garment manufacturers like Peerless pay much lower import duties on foreign yarns and fabrics than their counterparts in the United States.
The powerful American textile lobby, which in recent years has been able to sway the votes of more than half the members of Congress, has kept duties on imported fabrics and yarns as high as 36 percent. Peerless and other Canadian companies pay only 8 percent on their European woolens and worsteds.
"It's the fabric that makes one garment different from another," Mr. Segal said. "We have access to world fabrics at world prices, and we don't want to give that up."

HEADLINE: Aldus to Cut Its Staff by 100

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The Aldus Corporation, one of many software makers plagued by falling revenue, is restructuring its United States operations and laying off 11 percent, or about 100, of its temporary and permanent staff.
The restructuring follows "economic and competitive pressures that continue to have a negative impact on our business," said Paul Brainerd, president. Last month, the company posted a second-quarter loss of $900,000 on revenue of $38.9 million. 
 "There's no evidence of any improvement yet in either the U.S. market or in Europe," said Robert Klieber, an analyst with Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis, referring to the company's products. "Cost-cutting can continue to help only if there's a boost to the top line."
Mr. Klieber said he expects the company to post net income of 46 cents a share on revenue of $165 million for 1992 and 80 cents on revenue of $180 million for 1993.
Aldus shares closed Friday at $13.25, down 50 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

HEADLINE: America Isn't Asia's Cop

 BODY:
The Soviet threat is ended. America has been able to scale down radically its troop strength in Europe. But in Asia, apart from the unplanned base closings in the Philippines, U.S. forces remain in place -- including 40,000 each in South Korea and and Japan.
Political and budgetary pressures will rightly tempt the next President to scale down these troop levels. A smaller U.S. military garrison makes good sense, provided Washington also works to build up a new system of regional collective security. Such a system would provide the best insurance against conflicts between Asian states as Japan raises its military profile in the region. 
 Worrisome conflicts are already taking shape. China and Korea are unhappy about rising Japanese defense budgets and a new law that permits Japanese military units to join U.N. peacekeeping operations. Today's Japan is not militaristic and lacks long-range weapons. But that doesn't reassure Asian victims of past Japanese aggression.
Seoul and Beijing will soon establish formal diplomatic ties. There is a danger that they might go on to fashion a military alliance that could isolate and provoke Japan.
North Korea's secretive nuclear program also threatens regional security. Unless South Korea can satisfy itself that Pyongyang isn't building a bomb, Seoul may reconsider its own renunciation of nuclear weapons. A Japan faced with four nuclear neighbors -- Russia, China and the two Koreas -- would undoubtedly feel pressure to go nuclear too.
Russia and Japan, meanwhile, remain locked in a territorial dispute left over from World War II. And China now rattles its neighbors by asserting sovereignty over islands claimed by Vietnam, Malaysia, the Philippines, Brunei and Taiwan.
These problems could be resolved through a new regional security organization that would include Japan, China and South Korea as well as Russia and the United States. As things now stand, aggrieved parties typically lobby for America's support. That could begin to put Washington in ticklish situations. But in a collective security arrangement, a natural forum for direct talks would be created. Washington would not feel compelled to take sides.
Members of Asean, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, also might want to participate. And diplomatic outcasts like Vietnam and Taiwan might eventually be brought in. A regional security organization might even become a modest force for democratization by subjecting each member's military forces to a healthy degree of outside accountability.
Even before the cold war ended, the mission of U.S. forces in the Pacific had shifted from containing Communism to keeping potential Asian rivals at arm's length from each other. There's no good reason for America to bear this regional security burden alone as Asian societies grow increasingly rich and powerful.
Moving from a U.S.-centered security system toward regional collective security won't be simple. But it could establish a more reliable basis for future regional peace.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A New Opening for Times Square

 BODY:
Times Square, magnet for millions, "crossroads of the world," has come to a crossroads of its own. The decision to suspend construction of four giant office towers as the core of a private-public redevelopment plan is a sensible bow to reality; the market for new mid-Manhattan skyscrapers is dead.
Planners will now want to rethink their grand design, and doers must move quickly to resuscitate the half-abandoned entertainment block of 42d Street. A stretch of theaters and small shops stands empty, its tenants evicted to make way for construction of the office towers. Boarded over with plywood and "Post No Bills" signs, two-thirds of the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues has the sad look of a deserted Main Street. 
 The block was tawdry before the evictions, dominated by vendors of porn, tacky knickknacks and XXX-rated movies. Their departure is good riddance. The crime rate fell when they left. But, now that new construction is on hold, it is urgent that the emptiness be refilled -- and with something better than was there before.
Final agreement on revised priorities is said to be near, and the new plan will then undergo extensive public review. It is expected to incorporate several major changes, all reasonable under the circumstances.
The private developers, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, will be released from an agreement to start building next year; they can wait until the market revives, or perhaps not build the towers at all. They will also be relieved of the immediate cost of renovating the sprawling Times Square subway interchange.
But they will reportedly assume new responsibility, to put serious money and effort into shoring up the block's retail activity and six old theaters right away. It is essential that they attract a variety of entertainment and retail businesses that can restore the zest suppressed by abandonment.
There is no reason to doubt the commitment of Prudential and Park Tower. Both are reliable, and both have a financial stake in the area's eventual prosperity. Equally certain, the block in question is prime territory for development. On average, some 8,000 people pass through every hour. Times Square itself remains a mecca for New Yorkers and visitors from every corner of planet Earth.
City and state agencies now have added burdens, too. At the Seventh Avenue end, the subway station still needs a complete overhaul. Where's the $91 million to pay for it? The Eighth Avenue end remains tawdry, because plans for that part of the block are still not firm. If that section remains as is, it can only be a drag on the end that's being improved.
The suspension of the major construction is a loss. Perhaps it's the fault of overambitious plans to begin with, or the delay caused by 47 lawsuits. The project may also have been undercut by city incentives that led to a glut of offices and hotels in the Times Square area. And surely the plan has been set back by the commercial real estate recession afflicting cities everywhere.
But the loss is also an opportunity -- for faster restoration of the street-level hurly-burly and empty theaters. This new opening challenges the creativity of private developers and public authorities alike. Times Square needs help.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Navy Resembles a Fraternity in Its Sexism;
New York Hearings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The impact of the Clarence Thomas hearing on public awareness about sexual harassment has indeed been dramatic, as shown in "Suffering in Silence No More: Fighting Sexual Harassment" (front page, July 13). 
 Millions of Americans recognized in Prof. Anita Hill's testimony a description of the kind of hostile environment in which they have been working. Now some of these victims are speaking out, and employers, including of New York State, are listening with renewed attentiveness.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has created a task force on sexual harassment, one of the first of its kind, to continue the public dialogue and to devise constructive approaches to preventing and redressing sexual harassment. The Governor appointed both men and women to this task force, understanding that both sexes must be involved in addressing the problem.
Members of the Governor's task force have been visiting communities around the state to hear suggestions from the public on how to stop sexual harassment. The task force has scheduled a public forum in Seneca Falls on Women's Equality Day, Aug. 29, and will be in New York City for three days of public hearings Sept. 22, 23 and 24.
We are also conducting roundtable discussions with people who have been sexually harassed, employers, therapists, lawyers and people of color, as well as lesbians and gay men.
As task force head, I have been moved by the courage of victims and their families in coming forward to describe their experiences. One woman in Albany spoke of a boss who, even after being brought up on disciplinary charges, continued to harass her. On Long Island we heard from a victim's husband, who told of the painful dilemma his wife faced in having to choose between staying in a job where she was sexually harassed or losing the income that would help provide a college education for their daughter. We have also heard instances of men being harassed by women and same-sex harassment.
We also have been impressed by the efforts of many employers to grapple with this difficult issue and work to find solutions.
The social and economic costs of sexual harassment are too high, both for the victims and for society. Prevention should be our goal. In New York City the task force can be reached through the State Division for Women offices at 2 World Trade Center, 57th floor.
 
JUDITH I. AVNER
Director, Division for Women
New York, July 23, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republican Platform;
G.O.P. Drafting Stand for Total Ban on Abortion

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Republicans began writing a party platform today that advocates a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion and embraces a variety of other conservative doctrines, including a repeal of the tax increases President Bush signed two years ago.
In contrast to the Democrats, who sought in the platform they adopted last month to round the edges on their sharpest liberal stances of the past, the Republicans seem determined to stress conservative principle over pragmatic drift toward the center. 
 While the platform will not be completed until later this week, the drafters indicated they would stick with the language on abortion used in the last two Republican platforms.
It declares that "the unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed." It does not provide for even the exceptions President Bush accepts: allowing abortions to end pregnancies that result from rape or incest.
The plank also supports appointment of judges who would overturn the constitutional right to abortion.
The Republicans who gathered here today in the downtown convention center, across town from the Astrodome where the Republican National Convention will be held next week, tried in their speeches to change the electoral tide that has been running against President Bush for the last month.
This morning, Richard N. Bond, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, kicked off the party's two weeks here with a rousing speech about "what a horror show a Clinton Presidency might be."
He suggested that Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado would become Secretary of Defense, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California would be Secretary of the Interior and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York would get the first nomination to the Supreme Court.
Ms. Schroeder's first recommendation, Mr. Bond asserted, would be "to stop referring to naval vessels as 'she.' "
Representative Bill McCollum of Florida, a co-chairman of the platform committee, declared, "Today is the first day of the re-election campaign of George Bush and Dan Quayle."
The chairman of the platform committee, Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, said the goal of the platform was to draw distinctions between Republicans and Democrats, and the document that was being drafted today did that on issues across the board: the economy, welfare, gun control, military spending and the environment, among others.
The sharpest difference, not surprisingly, involved abortion. The Democratic platform endorses a woman's right to choose abortion without exception and calls for government financing of abortions for poor women who cannot afford them otherwise.
 
Opponents in Control
 The Republicans' subcommittee on "individual rights, good homes and safe streets," which had jurisdiction over the abortion question, was stacked with abortion opponents, and they created a parliamentary situation that prevented the few delegates here in favor of abortion rights from amending the platform.
Two of those delegates, Bobbi Breske from Delaware and Mary Wiese from South Dakota, said in the subcommittee debate that Republicans from their states had expressed dissatisfaction with the hard line against abortion, especially in the cases of rape and incest, and that some were threatening to vote against the ticket over the issue.
"Are we just to put lives in jeopardy because a woman has been raped and she does not want to carry it?" asked Mrs. Breske, who works with Mary Kay Cosmetics and has long been active in Republican affairs in her state.
"The realities of life are sometimes very ugly," she added.
But Mrs. Breske and the handful of other supporters of abortion rights who attended the session were routed by the overwhelming majority of Republican platform writers who want to make abortion illegal.
 
'A Party of Principles'
 The subcommittee chairman, Mary Potter Summa, an assistant district attorney from North Carolina who is four and a half months' pregnant, declared, "What's in me is a human life that's kicking me and sitting on my bladder."
Texas newspapers are reporting that a large majority of Republicans, even in this conservative state, favor legal abortions in at least some circumstances, but Mrs. Summa said, "We are a party of principles and not a party of the whims of polls."
Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois made the case against allowing women who have been raped to have abortions. "The value of human life is transcendent," he asserted.
The subcommittee adopted the rigid language by a vote of 13 to 3.
Today, six subcommittees worked on various facets of the platform. Their work will go before the 107-member platform committee on Tuesday, and the abortion question will probably be raised again. But no one expects the outcome to be any different.
 
What Kind of Change?
 Before the drafting work began, the delegates gathered for what amounted to a pep rally and heard stem-winding speeches from Mr. Bond and other party leaders that did not praise President Bush so much as they hammered Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
In what sounded like a preview of the keynote address he will deliver at the convention next week, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas accused the Democratic Presidential candidate of supporting the largest tax and spending increases in the nation's history, steps that the Senator said would drive the country and countless businesses into bankruptcy.
"In a country that comes out for change, is this the change America wants?" Senator Gramm asked. "I think it is not."
One change the platform is pushing for is a repeal of the tax increases Mr. Bush signed as part of the 1990 budget deal. Among those were an increase in the tax rate on the wealthiest Americans to 31 percent from 28 percent and a higher annual Medicare tax on workers with incomes from about $55,000 to $125,000.
The whole budget agreement was a mistake, the subcommittee dealing with the economy declared. That conclusion goes somewhat beyond what Mr. Bush has said. He has maintained only that the agreement was a political mistake, not necessarily a substantive one.
A small group of backers of Patrick J. Buchanan, who ran against Mr. Bush in the early primaries this year, advocated such causes today as a wall across Southern California and the Rio Grande Valley to keep illegal Mexican immigrants out and the abolition of foreign aid. But such proposals are clearly going nowhere.
Mr. Buchanan is scheduled to address the convention next week, and his sister and campaign manager, Angela Buchanan, said her brother would put differences aside, support the President's re-election and "do nothing to harm the Republican Party between now and the election."
