HEADLINE: Justice Dept. Rebuffs Democrats On Special Prosecutor on Iraq Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The Bush Administration rebuffed House Democrats today and refused to seek the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate whether officials violated the law by trying to aid Iraq before the Persian Gulf war.
The decision may spare President Bush some political embarrassment in this year's campaign, but the Attorney General insisted that politics did not influence the decision. Democrats immediately attacked the decision as part of a politically motivated cover-up. 
 House Democrats requested an independent prosecutor in a letter to Attorney General William P. Barr on July 9. Mr. Barr responded today that there was no basis for a special prosecutor because the Democrats had not provided specific, credible information to suggest that high-ranking officials had committed any crimes.
 
'Stonewalling,' Democrat Says
 Mr. Barr said the Justice Department itself could investigate the actions of lower-level officials, including the alteration of Commerce Department documents relating to the approval of export licenses for Iraq.
The Democrats' request for a special prosecutor "fails to identify any particular person alleged to have committed a crime, or to describe any particular acts alleged to constitute a crime," Mr. Barr said.
Mr. Barr's decision appears to be final. The law on appointing special prosecutors says the Attorney General's decision "shall not be reviewable in any court."
Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said Mr. Barr's decision was "stonewalling, plain and simple."
 
'Extra Heavy Responsibility'
 Campaigning today in Philadelphia, Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential candidate, said he was "really troubled" by Mr. Barr's decision.
"It appears there is a lot of evidence there, and I understand the Attorney General thought there wasn't enough evidence," said Mr. Clinton. In the absence of a special prosecutor, he said, the Justice Department will have "an extra heavy responsibility to look into the apparent irregularities."
Mr. Bush has repeatedly asserted that the conduct of foreign affairs is his greatest strength, but Congressional investigators have challenged that contention with evidence suggesting that the Administration strengthened Iraq with economic aid and sophisticated technology before the gulf war. Administration officials say they were trying to moderate Iraq's behavior, and admit the effort failed.
In his combative response to House Democrats, Mr. Barr said, "The criteria for invoking the independent counsel statute are not present." He said that the Democrats had offered "vague and conclusory allegations" that were "wholly inadequate" to justify a request for a special prosecutor.
 
The Political Spin
 Mr. Barr warned the Democrats: "Repeated and unjustified attacks on the integrity of the department tear down the institution and undermine our ability to advance justice. As Attorney General, I believe strongly that we cannot allow the criminal process to be used as a political weapon or for partisan purposes."
But House Democrats said it was Mr. Barr who was playing politics. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, chairman of the Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs, said, "Mr. Barr is playing a dangerous political game in a desperate effort to protect the Bush Administration."
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said the Administration was "hiding in technicalities."
"The Attorney General is saying that you need to know the place, the time and the motive of the alleged crime," he said. "If you had that, you wouldn't need an independent counsel. It's like saying that the victim of a mugging has to have a videotape of the incident and the perpetrator in handcuffs before reporting the crime to the police."
The procedures for appointing a special prosecutor were established by the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, which was amended in 1983 and 1987. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia must appoint a special prosecutor if the Attorney General requests one.
Under the law, the Attorney General is supposed to consider only two questions: "the specificity of the information received and the credibility of the source."
Because Mr. Barr's decision cannot be challenged in court, Congress is likely to intensify its investigation. "The court of public opinion is open for business 24 hours a day, and that court will not be satisfied with the subterfuge concocted today," said Mr. Brooks, the Judiciary Committee chairman.
From 1986 to 1990, Iraq got more than $4 billion in loans and letters of credit from the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, and Congressional investigators say Iraq used some of the money to buy technology for weapons projects.
When a former executive of the bank pleaded guilty in June to charges of conspiracy and bank fraud, Federal District Judge Marvin H. Shoob, in Atlanta, said an independent prosecutor was needed to investigate the Justice Department's handling of the case.
Democratic members of Congress said there was evidence that Justice Department officials intervened to postpone indictments that could have embarrassed Iraq.
 
No Evidence, Barr Says
 But Mr. Barr said today that "there is not a shred of evidence that any department employee acted improperly" and that "there was no wrongdoing" by the department. Moreover, Mr. Barr said, Judge Shoob did not understand the case.
In the 1980's, the United States guaranteed several billion dollars of loans to Iraq. Such guarantees typically make it much easier and much less expensive for the borrower to raise the money.
Iraq was supposed to use the money to buy food grown on American farms; Congressional investigators say some was used to buy weapons and technology.
But Mr. Barr said today that even if Iraq had misused United States aid, "we have found no evidence that United States Government employees knowingly participated in or facilitated any such diversion."
The Attorney General acknowledged that the Agriculture Department continued to give aid to Iraq after seeing "possible evidence of irregularities." But he said the continued operation of the aid program was no crime.
 
Presses Justice Department
 Mr. Barr promised that the Justice Department would "continue to fully and fairly investigate" issues it was already reviewing. These include the alteration of Commerce Department records and apparent contradictions in Congressional testimony by Administration officials.
Mr. Barr said his decision was supported by other Justice Department officials, including two career prosecutors: the Deputy Attorney General, George J. Terwilliger 3d, and Michael Chertoff, the United States Attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Chertoff reviewed the department's handling of the case against Banca Nazionale del Lavoro.
In the latest in a series of speeches on American policy toward Iraq, Representative Gonzalez said today that the Administration knew Baghdad was using United States companies to buy military technology in 1989 and 1990.
"In part deliberately, in part through sheer neglect, the Bush Administration did little or nothing to stop Saddam Hussein's ambitious efforts," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: House Democrats have requested an independent prosecutor to try to determine if the Bush Administration violated the law by trying to aid Iraq before the gulf war. Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, center, said the Attorney General's refusal was "stonewalling, plain and simple." With Mr. Brooks were Representatives Charles E. Schumer of New York, left, and Charlie Rose of North Carolina. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A8)

HEADLINE: For Idle Young in Newark, Pride in a Theft Done Right

SERIES: Growing Up, Stealing Cars -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
For a demonstration, a 15-year-old boy, his frame as compact as a sparrow's, slid beneath the dashboard of a stranger's car. "This," he said in a boyish voice, "is how you get a car." The youth, known on the street as Monk, tugged back a plastic collar and displayed a tangle of wires, switches and pins that he had manipulated on so many other cars to start their engines and unlock their steering wheels.
If this had been another car -- a car that Monk wanted -- it would now be his, he said. But he was merely showing a visitor the ropes. And in doing so Monk offered a glimpse into the world of young car thieves. Nothing stops them: neither shrieking alarms nor locked bars on steering wheels nor even their consciences.
 
Black, Jobless and Poor
 "You can steal any car in the world if you know what to do," said Monk, a ninth grader who said he made it his business to know exactly what to do, especially when it came to his favorites: 5.0 Ford Mustangs and top-shelf Japanese imports, like Acura Legends and Vigors. 
 Throughout Newark's impoverished neighborhoods, mostly desperate places of vacant lots, overcrowded public housing projects, tumbledown homes and struggling inhabitants, there are scores of boys and girls like Monk, say the Newark police and Essex County prosecutors. Usually young, black, jobless and poor, they have helped make Newark the nation's top city for car thefts.
Some of Newark's young car thieves acknowledge that they strip off the most lucrative parts from cars they steal and sell them to drug dealers and unscrupulous auto shops. But many, like Monk, steal cars for the sheer thrill of it.
Local newspapers are often peppered with accounts of injuries and death resulting from accidents caused by youths in stolen cars. Many times, it is the car thief himself who is hurt or killed.
But the young thieves, who know full well the risks, shrug off such possibilities as something that happens to someone else.
"I drive, crash a couple of them, dump them and go get some more," said Monk, who is usually seen in baggy knee-length shorts, tattered T-shirts, sour sneakers and an eyeshade.
Shortly after 2 A.M. on a recent Saturday, teen-agers were playing "chase to kill" through an otherwise sleeping neighborhood. A Buick with Massachusetts license plates -- the driver said he had just stolen it -- sped off, its rear end fishtailing like a bass out of water. A Hyundai Sonata packed with four teen-agers raced to catch up.
But a miscalculation sent the Hyundai flying over the curb at a corner, creating a bath of sparks. After careering across the street, the car slammed against the curb, blowing out a front tire as smoke curled from under its hood and its windshield wipers started.
The teen-agers jumped out of the Hyundai and into the Buick, which had pulled alongside. In seconds, the Buick was gone.
Yelling, "everybody's going to drive tonight!" a 13-year-old boy called Sal-Dog ran to the Hyundai and drove it on the three good tires into a nearby school parking lot. Five minutes later, the Hyundai was a heap of smoking, dented sheet metal. Children ran from the parking lot with floor mats and a container of anti-freeze.
"It feels good," Sal-Dog said after his ride in the Hyundai. "You get this feeling like you are scared, like you feel high, like you're going to top over."
 
No Role Models And Little to Do
 Since 1986, Newark's car-theft rate has led other cities with populations of 50,000 or more. While the thefts have decreased here in the last two years, city officials and residents still wrestle with a reputation for a problem that remains at epidemic proportions.
The one thing Sal-Dog said he did not feel was remorse, excusing the epidemic by saying, "we take from other races."
Many of Newark's young people believe they are justified in stealing cars, explained Bernard James, a 26-year-old unemployed construction worker familiar with the lives of the youths, because the "rich thrive off the poor." And though the police say local black car owners are the major victims, in some of the city's harshest neighborhoods, rich is understood to mean white, suburban and able to afford an expensive car. Newark's car thieves are increasingly finding their prey in suburban towns, the police say.
Marie Sparks, mother of Demarko Sparks, an 18-year-old who was recently paroled after serving time for car theft, said she realized that stealing was wrong but understood the motivation. "This society is all about money," she said. "If you don't have any, you will do anything to get it. How can you blame them?
"How can we correct these kids when the ones like the mayors, police and politicians are doing all this dirty stuff?" she asked. "How can we expect these kids to do anything right?"
Many of the youths are for the most part raising themselves. They sleep by day and prowl by night far from the sight or guidance of parents. Many appear unkempt, malnourished and small for their ages. But almost every night they have the stamina to find the best examples of automotive science to make theirs for a night or two.
"I don't want a job, I just want to have fun," said Keekee, a 15-year-old eighth grader who says her greatest joy in life is stealing cars and riding them through her neighborhood.
Jackie Lawrence, president of the Newark chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, sees the roots of the problem as similar to the causes of drug abuse and other forms of juvenile crime. "What it has to do with is that our kids have nothing to do," she said. "There is so much energy within our young people today, and in Newark they don't have the proper outlets for all this energy."
Perhaps more disturbing, say police and city officials, is that there are hundreds of youngsters in Newark whose heroes spin the tires of stolen cars rather than lead classrooms, nations or even fast breaks on basketball courts.
Too many, say worried parents and youth counselors, want to be like Monk.
 
Struggle to Resist Strong Temptations
 Earlier this month, an 11-year-old boy who sat in a lawn chair in his yard to watch the car thieves driving their spoils said admiringly that when he got older he planned to start stealing cars, too.
He'd already picked out his first choice: a Mustang with a 5.0-liter engine, the most powerful of Ford's commercial line.
Bayyan Banks, who is 16, said he has watched a childhood friend and his friend's older brother grow up to be two of his neighborhood's most notorious car thieves. Resisting the allure of a stolen dream car has been difficult, he said.
"I couldn't do it because it would break my mother's heart," said the teen-ager, who plans to attend college and study automotive design next fall.
But when pressed, he confessed that there was another reason.
"When I was young I got in a car my friend stole," he said. "I couldn't really drive."
As he tried to drive the car down a narrow street near his home, he recalled, he panicked when he saw his friend's father driving toward him. "I didn't know enough to put the car in reverse, so I bumped into some cars then ran away.
"I was always terrified the police would come looking for me," he said. His mother, Carol Brooks, said she wanted to move her son and 14-year-old daughter out of the city, away from its influences. Mrs. Brooks said her first car was demolished in an accident involving a car thief being chased by the police.
"I told him, 'If I had a gun I would kill you,' " she recalled shouting as the thief was being arrested.
Although he refuses to steal cars, Mr. Banks has managed to retain the respect of his peers by making himself an expert on automotive technology. He studies popular car and consumer magazines and -- to maintain his part in conversations -- knows how to steal a car.
 
The Gathering Spot For Showing Off
 Almost every night, bands of teen-age thieves gather in several Newark locations for what youngsters call "car shows."
One of the most popular spots is along a two-lane stretch of Muhammad Ali Avenue between Bergen Street and Jelliff Avenue, just west of downtown, and the poorly lighted parking lot of nearby Harold Wilson School, a few blocks from where Mrs. Brooks and her family live.
Stolen cars from all over the region are brought here to be spun, raced and often banged and crashed to the delight of their drivers, fellow thieves and hangers-on along the sidewalks.
Imitating scenes in action films, the thieves make other people's cars howl and roar like wounded animals. High on their list are stunts called "figure eights" or "doughnuts," in which cars are made to spin leaving oval tire marks on the pavement, and "backward threes," three tight spins while driving in reverse.
Many also say they like to go "riding ghost," driving at night without headlights.
On a recent night, a shiny new red Honda Prelude rocketed down the slope of Muhammad Ali Avenue. At more than 60 miles an hour, the car -- filled with teen-agers, its stereo cassette deck thundering the latest "gangsta" rap, its air-conditioner blowing full gale -- almost separated from its wheels as it flew over a deep dip in the street.
As planned, the maneuver flung the car's passengers from their seats, teasing gravity and giving each an intoxicating moment that some said felt like weightlessness.
"It gets you 'suped,' " said Rahlude, a 13-year-old car thief, using the street slang for feeling super. Stealing late-model cars and playing "chase to kill" through his neighborhood "just makes you be happy," Rahlude said.
One night he was so happy, in fact, that he stole five cars in less than 12 hours.
 
Hiding Fear And Defying Police
 Jeffrey Fagan, a professor at Rutgers University's School of Criminal Justice, suggested that some of Newark's teen-age car thieves may be far from happy. "They are angry young men," he said, "and this behavior is a chance to get back at people making them angry. By and large, they can't own cars. These kids have channeled risk-taking and thrill-seeking into car theft."
Monk said that when he was arrested about a month ago for car theft his grandmother simply went to the city's juvenile authorities and took him home. "I got to go to court in a month," he said without concern.
Fear, or showing it, is anathema to car thieves whose reputations are based on daring and grace under pressure. To crash a car is humiliating, the teen-agers say. But when a young thief loses control of a car, as they often do, it is considered breaking the rules to show any emotion, even if a person is injured or killed.
"I never want to hurt anybody," said Easy E, an 18-year-old thief described by his peers as one of the best in the city. "It's the little boys who don't know what they're doing. That make it bad for everybody."
As he spoke, a Honda Accord whooshed past with a police cruiser in tight pursuit. Several thieves said in recent interviews that the Newark police still chase them despite a city policy prohibiting chases unless there is reason to believe that a stolen car has been involved in another, more serious crime.
If the police are reluctant to give chase, some young thieves say they try to provoke pursuit by ramming police cars. The cruisers are regarded as very slow, the thieves agree.
"I've done spins right in front of the cops," said Easy E, a charismatic high school senior who estimates that he has stolen about 200 cars in a three-year career. He says he enjoys taunting the police to chase him in road wars that risk arrest and jail time.
"It's a bad habit," he said. "But it feels good."

HEADLINE: Report to Congress Opposes Synthetic Hormone in Cows

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Congressional investigators said today that the Government should delay commercial approval of a genetically engineered hormone that increases milk production in cows until questions are resolved concerning its effects on people's health.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said it agreed with most scientific opinion that synthetic bovine growth hormone wais not harmful because humans did not absorb or use the animal protein. 
 But in a report issued today, the accounting office said cows treated with the hormone had a higher incidence of mastitis, an inflammation of the udder that often requires use of more antibiotics, which could be harmful if passed on at high levels to consumers through milk and meat.
"Concern exists now about whether antibiotic levels in milk are already too high from present antibiotic usage," the report said.
 
Most Substances Not Tested
 Referring to another report it issued last week, the accounting office said Federal and state inspectors routinely tested milk for only 4 of the 82 drugs used to treat dairy cows. "We cannot conclude at present that the nation's milk supply has not already been contaminated by antibiotics beyond acceptable levels," the report said.
Until the issue of indirect human safety risks is resolved, the investigators said, the Food and Drug Administration should stop allowing the sale of food products from research animals getting synthetic growth hormone.
Gerald B. Guest, director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Veterinary Medicine, said the Government was studying the issue of growth hormone-treated cows and whether they required more antibiotic treatment because of mastitis and other conditions.
"We have not seen the entire G.A.O. report and will review its recommendations when we do," Dr. Guest said in an interview, "but from what we've heard, it has not raised any new questions we have not considered before."
There is no indication the food products from treated animals are significantly different from those from normal cows, Dr. Guest said, and no immediate reason to keep the products off the market or require that they have special labeling, as recommended by the General Accounting Office.
 
Allowed Since 1985
 The Food and Drug Administration has approved the research use of synthetic growth hormone, also known as bovine somatotropin, made by four biotechnology companies. The hormone increases milk production in cows from 10 to 25 percent and is being tested in more than 100 herds around the country, industry spokesmen say.
Since 1985, the agency has allowed the sale of milk and beef products from cows treated with the drug, but does not require that those products be labeled as coming from animals treated with the synthetic version of the naturally occurring hormone.
Use of the synthetic cow hormone has been opposed for years by some consumer groups, who fear unknown health consequences of its use, and advocates of family farming, who say increased milk production could reduce milk prices and drive small dairy farms out of business.
Jeremy Rifkin of the Foundation on Economic Trends, an organization critical of genetic engineering, said that on the basis of the study, his group would file a formal petition with the F.D.A. calling for the agency to halt sales of food products from treated animals immediately.
But Richard D. Godown, president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, a trade association, disagreed with the major conclusions of the report, saying that current Government testing procedures were adequate.
Several members of Congress who requested the accounting office's report on the hormone said they were concerned that the F.D.A. had allowed marketing of food products from animals involved in research.
Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Government Operations Committee, called for an independent investigation of the potential risk of increased antibiotic levels in milk and beef because of the hormone use.
"I hope this report will cause an immediate stop in the marketing of food products" from bovine growth hormone treated animals, he said. Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan, said he was "profoundly disturbed by F.D.A.'s failure to adequately study the risk to consumers from antibiotic residues"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
To Republicans' Relief, Bush Hones Campaign

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
His speeches are getting sharper, more partisan, more laden with red-meat lines and tough-guy attitude. His surrogates are taking on Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee, with more gusto and fewer stumbles. President Bush finally seems to be entering what he calls the campaign mode.
For his fellow Republicans, it is not a moment too soon. Mr. Bush's campaign has been a series of missed opportunities to make the case for a second term, but he cannot afford to fumble the next two weeks. The Republican National Convention begins Monday, and the most recent spate of polls shows Mr. Clinton still holding on to a formidable lead of about 20 points. By contrast, four years ago the Bush campaign had cut Michael S. Dukakis's lead from 17 percentage points to 7 in the three weeks between the conventions. 
 Republicans know that 1992 is a year of great swings in the polls, but they are ready for the next swing now, please.
After a month of anxiety and outbursts of outright despair, they do see a few reasons for hope. Some believe that Mr. Bush is finally beginning to energize the Republican base with his portrait of Mr. Clinton as a man just itching to cut the military, raise taxes, and turn the health-care system into some Kafkaesque Department of Motor Vehicles and Medical Procedures.
On the organizational front, some senior Republicans expect an official announcement by the end of this week that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is finally returning to the White House to oversee the campaign. "You can't go through the convention with this kind of uncertainty, and it will give a lift to insiders at least," said one Republican strategist close to the Administration.
Moreover, the buildup to the convention this week will highlight Mr. Bush in the role he likes best, Commander in Chief and world leader. He was meeting with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel today, after holding forth on Bosnia and Herzegovina over the weekend. These are far better images from Kennebunkport than the cigarette-boat-and-golf-cart pictures that some Republicans have come to dread in these angry, recessionary times.
There are risks, of course, to all these world issues, most notably Bosnia, where Mr. Bush has come under criticism for not responding forcefully enough. Still, foreign policy expertise is a hard card for the Governor of Arkansas to match; when quizzed about his preparation to be Commander in Chief today on the CBS News program "This Morning," Mr. Clinton found himself discussing his experience deploying the Arkansas National Guard, which is not quite the same thing.
So much for the good news for Mr. Bush.
Barring some unexpected catastrophe, this election will revolve around domestic, not foreign policy. Mr. Bush's difficulty in articulating a powerful, persuasive domestic agenda for a second term has haunted him throughout this campaign. Ironically, that vulnerability was highlighted in his recent television commercials; one was devoted to Mr. Bush talking about the balanced-budget amendment and the other to a general expression of commitment to the principles of strong families, fiscal responsibility and the fight against crime.
At a time when polls show close to 80 percent of the American people believe that the nation has gotten off on the wrong track, when unemployment and the nation's fundamental economic competitiveness are painfully sensitive issues at the grass roots, the commercials seemed a tad unfocused. A few Republicans, speaking on condition that they not be identified, spoke yearningly of the heyday four years ago of Roger Ailes, the former Bush media consultant who has never been accused of lacking focus or edge.
Another danger for Mr. Bush: While energizing the Republican base is essential, it is also not enough, as Mr. Dukakis learned in 1988 when he rallied Democrats in the final two weeks of his campaign but still lost in a landslide. Presidential elections, by and large, are won or lost in the political center. Mr. Bush appears to be taking a gamble that he can shore up his conservative support without paying a price for it among the voters in the center.
To wit, the draft of the Republican platform released today, which is an unmistakably conservative document. It reasserts, for example, the party's support for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion, arguing, "We believe the unborn child has a fudndamental right to life which cannot be infringed."
Mr. Clinton, of course, has challenges and problems of his own. The Democrats have had the political winds at their back for the last four weeks, aided enormously by the withdrawal of Ross Perot, the success of the Democratic convention, the stumbles of the Bush campaign and a wave of bleak economic statistics. Now, however, Mr. Clinton will have to raise his game to a new level.
It is not simply the return of Mr. Baker, or the expected reorganization of the campaign, or the spotlight of the Republican convention and the almost inevitable bounce in the polls it will give Mr. Bush. It is simply this: For all Mr. Bush's difficulties, he is now entering "campaign mode," the time when he is ready, mentally, to fight, and becomes very, very dangerous.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Says G.O.P. Conflict on Economy Promises Higher Deficit

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton asserted today that President Bush had abdicated responsibility for the nation's economic troubles and that conflict between the President and his fellow Republicans promised larger Federal budget deficits.
"President Bush says the buck stops somewhere else, and you ought to be afraid of my opponents that might even be worse than me," the Democratic Presidential nominee said at an afternoon rally outside Independence Hall here. 
 "It would be funny if it weren't so sad," Mr. Clinton said, "a Government moving from crisis to crisis, having its best moment in a crisis or two, but never with any vision, never with any plan, never with any direction, never with any responsibility, never with any courage for the future."
 
Alert for Signs of Weakness
 A week before the Republican National Committee convenes in Houston, Mr. Clinton is seizing on any signs of weakness in his opposition.
Today's opening was provided by a memorandum sent to the President on Friday by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp and six Republican members of Congress urging Mr. Bush to include a call for tax cuts in the party platform.
Mr. Clinton said that such a move would drive the deficit higher and that voters should force Mr. Bush to say where he stood on the proposal. Mr. Clinton said such measures would "recreate the Reagan revolution" by eliminating the capital gains tax.
"They want another round of tax cuts for the wealthy," the Governor said. "They want to add $430 billion more to the deficit" over five years."
 
Shifting Spotlight
 Mr. Clinton has spent the last few days trying to force Mr. Bush into corners on both foreign and domestic policy matters. On Sunday, he marshaled Democratic leaders in Congress to chastise the White House on its stand on the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Today, the spotlight was on the flagging economy, where the Clinton camp would like to see it remain.
Responding to Republican attacks on Mr. Clinton's economic proposals, sent today in a three-page statement to reporters, Mr. Clinton's campaign released 10 pages of information and official statements.
The Republican statement read, "Clinton unabashedly proposes the largest tax increase in American history," and said the Democratic nominee's call for increased investment was a "code word for more Government spending."
"Clinton's bus tour isn't finished yet," Senator Phil Gramm of Texas said in the statement. "The next stop is deep in the heart of taxes."
George Stephanopoulos, the communications director for the Clinton campaign, called the Republican statement a "concerted, if pathetic, assault" and "exactly what you would expect from people who have no plan to get the economy moving again."
And Mr. Clinton, in a two-hour appearance with his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee on the CBS News program "This Morning," said criticism of his economic plan came from "people who don't believe investment leads to growth."
Those critics, he said, "are the same people who got us into this fix right now."
In what is becoming a trademark attack-and-response tactic for the Democrats' campaign, Mr. Clinton also used his speech here to anticipate new Republican criticism of the Clinton-Gore ticket.
"Now, building up to their convention in Houston, they're going to tell you every reason in the wide world why you ought to be afraid of Al Gore and Bill Clinton," the Governor said to thousands of people who attended the rally here. "Let me tell you something, in my little state, we've created almost as many private-sector jobs in the last three years as he has in the entire United States of America."
The Clinton organization has said that as Governor Mr. Clinton helped create 90,000 private jobs in Arkansas since Mr. Bush took office. The Bush Administration, it said, has been responsible for creating only 100,000 new private sector jobs nationally in that period.
Noting that he was speaking at the same site former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California used to begin his Presidential campaign earlier this year, Mr. Clinton strayed from his standard campaign speech to emphasize his plan for changing the way campaigns are financed.
Mr. Clinton has integrated talk of "reform" into his overall call for change and now says Mr. Bush is trying to convince Americans that they should be "afraid" of change.
"When the Republicans raise the old flag of fear, you tell them, 'No thanks. This time we're going to vote on our hopes,' " Mr. Clinton said today. "When they tell you Al Gore and Bill Clinton propose crazy ideas and we can make things worse, you tell them, 'No thanks, we're going to make things better.' When they sell you on a blame game, you say, 'Mr. Bush, you haven't even said how you stand on your party's own plans for economic growth.' "

The Economy
Drug companies would pay the Government application fees for drug approvals under an agreement being worked out in Congress. The F.D.A. would use the fees to hire 600 new examiners so it could cut approval times by half. [Page A1.]
The lawyer for Clark M. Clifford and Robert A. Altman, defendants in a multibillion dollar fraud involving B.C.C.I., accused the office of Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of trying to destroy the two men by freezing personal assets. [D2.] 
 New York City plans to help small and medium businesses by reducing the risks of banks that lend to them. [B1.]
 
Companies
McDonnell Douglas announced a cost-saving restructuring, separating its military and commercial operations. The company's stock rose $2.25, to $37.625. [D1.]
Barnes & Noble plans to go public by selling more than $100 million, or 36 percent, of its common stock to help finance an aggressive expansion of its Barnes & Noble and B. Dalton's stores. It will also issue $170 million in new debt. [D1.]
The retail industry showed signs of recovery. May Department Stores reported a gain of nearly 16 percent in operating income, and Woolworth said its net income jumped 57 percent. Dillard and TJX also posted increases. [D4.]
Sears, Roebuck named Arthur C. Martinez, a top executive at Saks Fifth Avenue, to head its troubled merchandising group. [D4.]
Procter & Gamble reported a 12 percent gain in net income, saying a gain from the sale of its Italian coffee business was offset by heavy spending for new products in Europe. [D4.]
Momenta International said it was negotiating a possible purchase agreement with an "offshore" company to avert bankruptcy. It introduced a pen-based computer last year. [D4.]
Jurors in a closely watched asbestos injury case decided that GAF, Keene and Pittsburgh Corning would have to pay punitive damages of up to two and a half times their share of compensatory damages. The case involves 8,549 Maryland workers. [D4.]
Polygram will buy 51 percent of Interscope's film unit in an effort to build a movie production and distribution business. [D15.]
 
Markets
The yield on the 30-year bond fell to to 7.36 percent, its lowest level in five and a half years. [D1.]
Stock prices were mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 5.04 points at 3,337.58, but declining issues outpaced advances by a 7-to-6 ratio on the Big Board. [D6.] Stocks were battered in both Japan and Europe. [D6.]
The dollar rose overseas but fell in New York. [D14.] Orange juice futures plunged on word of an early Brazilian harvest. [D14.]
 
International
American steelmakers can proceed with 72 legal complaints charging that foreign rivals receive government subsidies and sell steel at unfairly low prices, the International Trade Commission ruled, but it blocked 12 other complaints. [D3.]
The delay in the North American Free Trade Agreement reflects the huge number of details that must be settled in creating the world's largest and richest regional trading bloc. [D3.]

The weapons industry is going through radical change in trying to divide a smaller pie after turning out elaborate weaponry for four decades. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Barnes & Noble Plans $100 Million Stock Sale

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Barnes & Noble, the nation's second-largest bookseller, disclosed plans yesterday to sell more than $100 million in common stock to help finance an aggressive expansion of both its "super stores" and its mall outlets.
Barnes & Noble Inc., a private company, plans to sell 6.87 million shares, or about 36 percent of its stock, at about $15 a share, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It will also issue $170 million in new debt. 
 With 869 stores nationwide, Barnes & Noble operates booksellers under several names, including its own and B. Dalton. Second in size only to Waldenbooks, which is owned by the Kmart Corporation, Barnes & Noble has grown in recent years far beyond its flagship Manhattan store at 18th Street and Fifth Avenue.
 
A Financial Opportunity
 Mitchell Clipper, Barnes & Noble's chief financial officer, said the stock and debt plan would allow the bookstore chain to take advantage of low interest rates and high stock prices to finance expansion.
"There's an opportunity here," Mr. Clipper said . "We want to take advantage of it."
Under the recapitalization, the company will issue 5.5 million shares of stock in the United States and Canada, and an additional 1.37 million overseas. A further 6.06 million shares will be exchanged for existing preferred stock and subordinated debt, and 3.75 million shares will be sold to Leonard Riggio, the company's chairman, and to Vendex International, a Dutch retailer.
The company plans to use the proceeds from the $170 million in new debt to retire more than $130 million in B. Dalton notes and to pay more than $19 million in unpaid dividends and interest.
Mr. Riggio and Vendex are currently 50-50 owners of the company's privately controlled stock, and the recapitalization will reduce their holdings to 32 percent of the common stock each.
Mr. Riggio bought Barnes & Noble in 1971 and is given credit for pioneering discount bookselling on a large scale. In 1986, when he had 35 stores in the New York City area, he acquired B. Dalton, which was the nation's second-largest chain, for about $300 million.
In the following years, Barnes & Noble also acquired Doubleday Book Shops and Scribner's Bookstores.
Recently, book sales at Barnes & Noble have been growing faster than profits. Mr. Clipper attributed that to the overhead costs involved in opening new stores.
The company's revenues increased from $880 million in 1990 to $920 million in 1991, he said. But for the 52-week-period that ended on Feb. 2, Barnes & Noble recorded a loss of $371,000. In the quarter that ended May 2, the loss ballooned to $9.4 million.
"It's up-front costs, the costs involved in opening a lot of new stores," Mr. Clipper said. "You get it back at the end of the year."
At present, the company operates 68 super stores, which average 15,000 square feet each and carry 100,000 titles, compared with 3,000 square feet and 10,000 titles in most of its 770 mall stores. It also operates a mail-order business and 31 other retail stores.
The common stock offering will be made through Morgan Stanley & Company; Dillon, Read & Company; Paine Webber Inc., and S. G. Warburg Securities.

HEADLINE: Car Buyers Turn Back to Detroit

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Suzanne Welsh, a clerical worker from Buena Park, Calif., had no intention of trading in her 1989 Toyota Camry, but her brother-in-law's new Saturn started her thinking.
"I've had three Japanese cars in a row, and I started to feel real guilty," she said. 
 Ms. Welsh recently decided to buy a Saturn, built in Spring Hill, Tenn., by the General Motors Corporation.
Two years ago, the Saturn was not on the market. This year, nearly 7 percent of all small cars sold in the United States are Saturns.
Chalk up a victory for the much-maligned American auto industry. After years of affection for Japanese and European brands, many hard-core import buyers are switching to American makes. That is helping the Big Three to reverse years of declining profits, and more recently steep losses, and putting foreign rivals somewhat on the defensive. In the recent quarter, the Detroit auto makers all reported vastly improved financial results.
 
Younger Buyers

 Among those turning to American brands are younger buyers, many of whom may never before have owned a car from the Big Three.
In the 1980's, many younger, well educated, affluent people were taken with imports like the BMW, the Volvo and the new Japanese luxury lines: the Acura from Honda, the Infiniti from Nissan and the Lexus from Toyota. But there now seems to be a growing recognition that some models built by American companies, like the Saturn and the Ford Explorer, a large sport utility vehicle, offer quality that is close to comparable Japanese and European models at prices that are significantly lower.
"Facts about quality and value have led to some powerful rethinking of domestics versus imports," said Madelyn Hochstein, president of DYG Inc., a research firm in Elmsford, N.Y.
And Richard Lepley, senior vice president of sales and marketing for the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation in Cypress, Calif., said of the Big Three, "They're making better cars, no question about it."
 
 
Sunroof Patriots
 What is more, buying from Detroit is perceived as patriotic, a bulwark for the nation against a flood of foreign cars.
Consider Carol Miller, 40, a teacher from Canton, Mich., and a new fan of Ford. "I have done nothing but put down Ford in the past because of two bad cars I had in 1981 and 1982," she said. "We started feeling guilty for owning a 1991 Nissan Stanza because family members worked for the auto companies. I bought a Ford Escort, which I love because I get 40 miles to the gallon."
Buying American brands does not necessarily guarantee that jobs will be kept in this country. Some Escorts, for example, are made in Mexico, and many of Chrysler's mini-vans come from Canada.
Besides the Saturn and Explorer, other models enjoying new popularity include the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the Cadillac Seville STS. Vehicles like these from the Big Three are drawing buyers away from Japanese-made rivals like the Acura Integra, the Isuzu Trooper, the Nissan Maxima and the Lexus LS400, all made in Japan.
Eighty percent of Saturn buyers said they would not have considered another General Motors car, the company reports, and 50 percent had not planned to buy an American make.
Detroit is heartened that years of cost-cutting and improving productivity finally seem to be paying off. During the first half of 1992, Ford, G.M. and Chrysler together grabbed a 71.9 percent share of the 6.5 million cars and trucks sold in the United States, an increase of 1.7 percentage points from a year earlier.
That was the first time since 1988 that American auto makers' market share increased as Japan's share dipped. And those fractional gains have meant the difference between a profit and a loss.
This year, the Ford Taurus could surpass the Honda Accord as the biggest seller in America, the first time in three years a car built by the Big Three would hold the top spot. Taurus appeals to buyers with families -- baby boomers with children.
Honda, in fact, recently decided for the second time in a year to trim car production at its two plants in Ohio.
 
 
Wide Range of Prices
 The buyers turning to American brands seem to be from many income groups, judging from the price ranges of the popular brands, from the $10,000 Saturn to the Seville STS, which can cost $45,000 or more.
Yet Mr. Lepley of Mitsubishi contends that the recent wave of purchases is by less affluent consumers, who are traditionally more loyal to domestic brands than the average buyer. "They tend to hold onto their cars longer, and we're now in a part of the automotive cycle when many of them are trading," he said.
If he is right, sustaining the trend could be tricky. What is more, Detroit's popular models are more than matched by its laggards. While G.M. and Ford are already making all the Saturns and Explorers they can without opening new assembly lines, some Big Three models are badly trailing in important market segments.
It is unclear whether Japanese rivals will counterattack. American auto makers expect them to up the ante with new models and more cost-cutting. Japanese car makers could also increase their sales immediately by selling to buyers for rental fleets or offering cash rebates -- practices they have resisted.
One catalyst for this turnabout has been Detroit's argument that spending money on American cars will help fortify employment and national prosperity. That argument is not new, but it comes as consumers have less reason to be fearful that they will be stuck with a lemon.
"We're seeing not just a buy-America attitude, but an attitude that says let's give American products a chance," said John Middlebrook, general manager of G.M.'s Pontiac division. "We're getting a shot at people we haven't seen for years."
Buy-American fervor peaked in January during President Bush's trade mission to Japan. Big Three executives charged that Japan's trade imbalance had contributed to the recession, though many economists argue that American auto makers have themselves to blame for losing customers to Japanese franchises.
 "I know buy-America is working because of the number of people who come in and say, 'I like your buy-America advertising; the flags got us thinking about American cars," said Doug Alverson, a salesman at Young Pontiac-Cadillac-Saab in Escandido, Calif.
Japanese auto makers are working to neutralize the national origin of cars as a factor in consumers' decisions about what to buy. They take pains to point out that they build cars in United States plants. And they have been publicizing more aggressively their role as employers, parts buyers and contributors to American education, art and charity. Honda and Toyota have each produced advertising featuring workers at their plants in Ohio and Kentucky.
 
 
Imports Suffer in California
 Japanese companies contend that their drop in market share may be no more than a temporary pause caused by the uneven economic recovery. Honda executives, for instance, say sales of their cars have been disproportionately depressed by economic weakness in California, a stronghold for Honda and other import lines.
Yet the American car's revitalization is notable in California, the front line of the Big Three's campaign to win back customers.
 In San Diego County, for example, registrations of Pontiacs rose 87 percent in the first three months of the year, while registrations of Hondas and Toyotas declined. Behind the rise: advertising bought collectively by Pontiac dealers compared the Pontiac Grand Am SE with the Honda Accord LX and Toyota Camry LE, which are both slightly larger. The ads also emphasized price, noting that when comparably equipped, the Grand Am costs $14,832, compared with $17,230 for the Accord and $18,488 for the Camry.
"Imports have gone up in price twice as fast as domestics," said Ronald Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter, who studies pricing trends. His research showed that the average imported vehicle sold during the first quarter cost $19,411, compared with $16,666 for the average domestic. Since last year, the average import rose $1,734 in price, while the average domestic increased $822.
Japanese auto makers have been forced to raise prices for several reasons. The dollar's weakness against the yen has made products from Japan more expensive for Americans. The collapse of stock prices in Tokyo and the decline in Japanese real estate values has hurt auto sales in Japan, forcing that nation's auto makers to raise prices overseas to bring in more revenue.
Finally, pressure resulting from protectionist sentiment in Washington has led Japan to reduce its "voluntary" car exports to 1.65 million, from 2.3 million. Fewer exports may prompt the Japanese to increase production at American plants, but in the short term may limit the supply of some models, forcing prices up.
 Though Asian brands still dominate the top ranks of the influential J. D. Power & Associates annual survey of owners about auto quality, domestic brands have been earning much higher marks. The average number of reported problems for all brands, foreign and domestic, has fallen consistently for the last four years to 125 per 100 new cars, from 177 per 100 new cars.
"Quality differences are minimal any more," said Joel Pitcoff, a Ford research specialist. Therefore, "fewer people go directly to the import store without considering domestic alternatives."
He added, "The problem all along was, we weren't getting people to consider our products."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Offers Loan Plan For Businesses

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New York City yesterday announced a plan to help small and medium-sized businesses by reducing the risks faced by banks that make loans to them.
The program represents a sharp change in the way the city has supported small business, which is considered vital to producing jobs. 
 In recent years, the city has maintained a fund of $10 million to make loans directly to such businesses. But under the new plan, it would dedicate half that fund to insuring bank loans, partly covering any losses the banks may have and presumably creating incentives for them to lend far more.
 
Support for Small Business
 The plan, announced by Mayor David N. Dinkins and the city's highest ranking economic development officials at City Hall, underscores the influence of Barry Sullivan, the retired bank chairman who was appointed Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development earlier this year. Mr. Sullivan has made city support for small business a priority.
Until recently, the city has geared most of its incentive efforts, ranging from energy subsidies to tax abatements, toward large corporations.
The new program will try to persuade banks "to open their doors, and their wallets, to more small business," said Mayor Dinkins, who described the program a "true public-private effort."
Under the plan, the city said its $5 million will be used to match contributions made by borrowers and the banks themselves in setting up a Small Business Reserve Fund, that would, in effect, guarantee at least 10 percent of the loans.
For instance, on a $100,000 loan, the lender and the borrower would each be asked to put $2,500 aside in the fund. The city would then match the $5,000 total. If the loan was not repaid, the $10,000 in the reserve fund would go to the bank.
Over time banks are expected to build up their contributions to the fund. They would then be allowed to use any surplus to recover up to the full amount of some delinquent loans.
Ultimately, city officials said, the fund could stimulate as much as $100 million in loans to small and medium- sized businesses.
So far, no banks have been selected to participate, but the city said several, including Chemical Bank, Apple Bank, Citibank and Chase Manhattan have expressed interest.
"Bankers are extremely enthusiastic about this idea," said Carol Parry, manager-director for community development at Chemical Bank. If it succeeds, she added, the program would "create a level of comfort among banks in making loans that in the past have been considered too risky."
Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said the city would seek 10 banks to participate in the program, and would make its selections based upon how aggressive the lenders promise to be in working with small businesses.
 
Select Banks by Oct. 1
 He said the city would select the banks by Oct. 1, and hoped lending would begin under the new program by Jan. 1.
For banks in the program, the reserve fund would represent a cushion, and limit their losses in lending to the kinds of small and mid-sized businesses that have in the past had high rates of failure, and therefore been considered credit risks.
If the program succeeds in prompting a large enough volume of new loans, participating banks will have set aside enough money in the reserve fund that they can recoup all of their losses on occasional loans that sour, officials said.
The program is patterned after a somewhat similar one in Michigan, where that state's Department of Commerce began building the Michigan Strategic Fund in 1987. In an interview yesterday, Mark Morante, the director of the Michigan program, said 80 banks were now participating, and $25 million in financing had been extended to small businesses.
"We consider it a great success," said Mr. Morante, adding that only 5 percent of the money loaned out by banks in the Michigan program had been lost through defaults, and the bank losses were fully covered with money available in the Strategic Fund.
But he added that one shortfall of the Michigan program was that participating banks had in some cases held to conservative lending policies, and turned down applications by promising small companies, even though their losses were limited.
"The key issue is whether banks can adopt a new and more aggressive philosophy of risk management," he said.
If it succeeds, the New York City program could rival the Small Business Administration in financing for small and medium-sized businesses. The Federal agency, which underwrote tens of millions of dollars in New York City loans last year, guarantees banks that it will compensate them for up to 85 percent of loans that they make to qualifying small businesses when those businesses default.
City officials and bankers said the city's program would offer advantages over the system employed by the Small Business Administration. One is that nonprofit organizations, which do not qualify for financing by the Federal agency, would qualify in the city's program.
Another is that the city's program would require less red tape than the Federal Government. Indeed, Mr. Sullivan said yesterday that the program was designed to give banks as much freedom as possible to control their lending, but would give them a financial nudge to take more risks.
"We are letting the experts make the loans," he said. Nonetheless, if the program succeeds, "we are going to make it a bit easier."
Although the city has traditionally deemed businesses with under 100 employees or less than $10 million in annual sales to be "small" -- thereby qualifying for consideration in small business lending -- it said it would let the banks define what they consider a small or medium-sized business. One catch for businesses that hope to apply for financing under the new program is that their borrowing costs are almost certain to be higher than for companies that qualify for more conventional bank loans. That is because of their contributions to the reserve fund, and those of the banks.
As is customary in banking, experts said the borrowers would pay their own costs as well as those incurred by lenders. Although few expect borrowers to make up-front cash payments for their loans, the reserve fund costs will be financed, requiring them to take out larger loans.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yield on 30-Year U.S. Bond At Lowest Level in 5 1/2 Years

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday to its lowest level in five and a half years, and now investors and dealers are waiting to see if this week's three big Treasury auctions will knock this rally in bond prices off the track.
But if that does not happen, long-term interest rates are moving into a new zone, a level not seen for decades. Some analysts predict that rates could fall to 7 percent by the end of the year, the lowest they have been since the early 1970's. 
 "The generation that is investing now has to get used to it," said Lawrence C. Waldorf, the portfolio manager at First Investors Management Company.
Pat Rothstein, managing director at Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., said, "The only bearish thing I can say about the market is that I can't think of anything bearish."
In secondary trading of Treasury securities, the yield on the bond due in 2021 fell to 7.36 percent, the lowest level since early January in 1987. The previous low had been the 7.38 percent hit in January of this year. Since July, the yield on the long bond is down four-tenths of a percentage point.
The market is being driven higher by several factors, including the slow growth of the economy, the belief that short-term rates will not turn up for some time, and the good data on inflation, which continues to remain low.
In addition, a lot of investors are selling mortgage-backed securities because of the fear of losses from early prepayments of existing mortgages. Now that long-term rates have fallen so sharply, homeowners are refinancing their mortgages. The cash from these sales is being plowed back into the longer end of the Treasury market, traders said.
The unemployment data for July, released Friday, added fuel to the rally that began in July, when the June employment data indicated that the economy might even be in for another dip. The July data confirms there is some growth but so sluggish that investors are more confidently shedding the two usual worries of a recovery: rising inflation and rising short-term interest rates.
The fall of long-term rates would be of some relief to the Federal Reserve Board, whose sharp cuts in short-term rates have yet to enliven the economy in any convincing way. The chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, has complained that the high level of long rates is inhibiting the recovery.
The rally yesterday was across the board. In the auction for three- and six-month bills, the average discount rates fell sharply after rising for two weeks. The 3.13 percent discount rate for the three-month bill was the lowest since Feb. 14, 1992. The 3.19 percent on the six-month bill was the lowest since July 1, 1963.
 
Something Perplexing
 Mr. Rothstein said a rally just before the three big Treasury auctions was a bit perplexing. He said the dealers would have liked the market to fall a little bit because that gives them more flexibility in bidding in the auction. But he added: "I think if the market stays strong all through the refunding something else will have to knock the market back. But I don't know what will do it."
On Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the Treasury will auction $36 billion in 3- and 10-year notes, and 30-year bonds. Some dealers are worried that this huge new supply of Treasury securities could weigh down a market that is already very heady.
"You will need some continued good news to continue this," one trader said. He argued that there could a sharp correction downward in the market after the auctions. But others were less worried, especially about the three-year auction today.
Several traders said they expected the three-year auction to go well because banks have been buying a lot of three-year notes recently. The banks are not finding a lot of loans to make and the yield on three-year notes of around 4.5 percent is a lot better than on the average money market fund, which is around 3 percent.
These traders said that this demand has left a lot of the dealers with few or no three-year notes, and that they will want to replenish their stocks.
In the pre-auction, or when-issued, market yesterday, the new three-year note was trading at a yield of 4.66 percent, down from 4.71 percent on Friday.
In the 10-year, auction, which is Wednesday, and the 30-year auction on Thursday, the outlook is not as clear. One reason is the inflation data due on Wednesday and Thursday. If the actual numbers for the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index are much higher than consensus forecasts, investors could suddenly be less interested in these longer-term securities.
A trader who said he expected the inflation data to be positive and the auctions to go well did say there could be a brief period of indigestion after the auction when the prices fall and yields rise. But then the market should resume its rally, he said.
In the pre-auction market, the new 30-year bond was offered at a yield of 7.32 percent, down from 7.36 percent on Friday. In the secondary market, the current bond due in 2011, was offered at 107 5/8, up 13/32 to yield 7.36 percent, compared with 7.39 percent on Friday.
The 10-year note was traded at 6.48 percent, down from 6.54 percent on Friday. While there is no price in the pre-auction market, a decline in yield means that the security is rising in value.
Traders said that yesterday's rally began overnight in Tokyo and continued in the morning trading in New York and then the market was quiet for the rest of the day. A lot of the buying, one trader said, was by investors and institutions that had not joined in the buying on Friday and, therefore, were in short supply of Treasury securities and worried about missing a rally.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Close Mixed in a Lazy Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday in one of the year's laziest sessions. Traders found few insights on the economy and kept a close eye on the bond market.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks, which traded mostly lower throughout the day, moved ahead in the final minutes to close up 5.40 points at 3,337.58. That small gain came after the Dow lost 61.60 points last week. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advancers 6 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was extremely light, with 142.5 million shares trading hands -- the second slowest session of the year. The quietest session of 1992 was on March 20, when volume came to 134.17 million. On Friday, 190.6 million shares changed hands.
 
Bond Prices Soar on Jobs Data
 No major economic reports were released during the session to drive trading in either direction. On the corporate front, none of the day's developments seemed to affect the overall market.
Stock analysts instead were examining developments in the bond market following last week's strong rally, said Steven Van Brunt, assistant vice president for equity trading at Nikko Securities Co. International.
Bond prices soared and yields fell after release of the July employment report, which showed the jobless rate fell slightly to 7.7 percent but also indicated that the economy grew little over all.
A strong bond market makes stock analysts nervous because they believe investors may decide to shift their cash out of stocks and into bonds. Late in the day, the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 3/8 point while its yield fell to 7.36 percent.
Deepening troubles in the Japanese stock market had little effect on the United States markets, analysts said.
 
Navistar Down, McDonnell Up
 Navistar was among the session's most actively traded issues, down 1/8 at 2 1/8. The Chicago truck maker has angered union members with plans to cut health insurance benefits, and workers said they planned to picket a meeting of management today.
McDonnell Douglas gained 2 1/4, to 37 5/8, after it announced a broad corporate restructuring. The St. Louis company said it planned to consolidate its six military contracting units into two, seek a partner or buyer for its helicopter company, and close a plant in Columbus, Ohio.
The most active Big Board issues were Texas Utilities, up 1/4 at 42 3/4, and Nationsbank, down 1/2 at 45 1/4.
Technology issues faced another mixed session.
Storage Technology sank 6 1/8, or 18 percent, to 27 1/4. The computer memory maker said last week that it was delaying introduction of a new product.
Hewlett-Packard fared better, up 1 5/8 at 60 1/2. Yesterday's buying followed Friday's plunge -- 12 5/8, to 58 7/8 -- when the computer maker said third-quarter earnings would fall below analysts' expectations.
In other technology issues, I.B.M. was up 1 3/8, to 88 1/2; Kyocera, fell 1 1/2, to 54 1/4, and Matsushita, was off 1 1/2 to 93 1/2.
Among widely held issues, Coca-Cola gained 1/2, to 43 1/8; Citicorp dropped 3/4, to 18 7/8, and General Motors rose 7/8, to 37 7/8.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Procter & Gamble Earnings Rose 12% in Latest Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that fiscal fourth-quarter net income increased 12 percent, saying that a gain from the sale of its Italian coffee business was offset by heavy spending for new products in Europe.
For the quarter ended June 30, the consumer-products company earned $339 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $304 million, or 41 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales advanced 6.6 percent, to $7.17 billion from $6.72 billion. 
 "It was weaker than expected," said Diane L. Mustain, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Indeed, earnings were about a penny below analysts' consensus estimate of 47 cents a share.
Shares of P.& G. eased 62.5 cents, to $49.25, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Analyst: U.S. Lines 'Subpar'
 Ms. Mustain noted that without the one-time $61 million gain on the sale of the coffee business, earnings would have lagged behind expectations.
But Joseph Kozloff, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the underlying quality of Procter & Gamble's earnings was a little stronger than the numbers indicated. He said that because of the windfall from the sale of the coffee business, the company spent heavily to introduce Always feminine-protection pads in Europe and some laundry detergents.
"They are implying they are managing their earnings stream," Mr. Kozloff said.
Still, Mr. Kozloff called the fourth-quarter performance in the United States "subpar." He said the weak economy hurt the company's shipments, which he calculated declined 2 percent. "Everybody is having a tough time in the United States," he said.
He said P.&G.'s overall volume grew 4 percent, with international shipments rising 12 percent.
For fiscal 1992, P.& G.'s profits grew 5.6 percent, to $1.87 billion, or $2.62 a share, from $1.77 billion, or $2.46 a share, in fiscal 1991. Sales climbed 8.6 percent, to $29.36 billion from $27.03 billion.
Procter and Gamble's chairman and chief executive, Edwin L. Artzt, said, "This was a year of solid growth." After a slow start, the company's earnings grew an average of 10 percent over the last three quarters, he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Are Mixed In Absence of Trading News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other major currencies yesterday, rising overseas and then falling in New York in the absence of any news to move the market.
Gold prices were also mixed. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $350 an ounce, off $1, after gold had risen 10 cents, to $350.40 an ounce, on the New York Commodity Exchange. Analysts said there was little news to affect the market. 
 Charles Cossentino, a vice president for foreign exchange at the Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank, said the dollar fell in thin trading as investors cautiously watched the Federal Reserve for possible intervention on the dollar's behalf.
The Fed entered the market at least three times on Friday, buying dollars in an attempt to bolster the sagging currency.
Stephen Flanagan, vice president at the Mitsubishi Bank, said the market saw "a steady stream of mark buying and dollar selling that will continue unless the Federal Reserve intervenes again."
Traders were marking time in anticipation of fresh news on the economy. The Government's producer price index is to be released tomorrow and retail sales figures for July are due out Thursday.
The financial markets are waiting to see if the new figures indicate any strength in the economy. If the nation appears on its way to recovery, the Fed will be under less pressure to nudge interest rates lower. The dollar, like all currencies, draws support from higher rates.
The dollar rose to 127.90 yen in New York yesterday from late Friday's 127.45. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 127.92 yen, down .03 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 128.05 yen.
The British pound gained ground against the dollar in New York, rising to $1.9315 from late Friday's $1.9295. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.9268 from $1.9290.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.4630 German marks, down from 1.4680; 1.3130 Swiss francs, down from 1.3150.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Building Stocks Wither in Tokyo

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WITH just about everything else failing, the Japanese Government is now pinning its hopes on the construction industry to winch the ailing economy and stock market out of their deepening ruts. The idea is to pour tens of billions of dollars into public works, like roads, sewage plants and bridges, on the theory that the employment and orders from construction companies will give the economy a sorely needed lift.
For a while, that had made various construction-related shares the darlings of the stock market. But in a sign of the depth of the market's malaise, even that sector is now looking worn out. Investors seem to find every piece of news just another excuse to run for the exits. 
 It is also a sign, some analysts say, that the market is not just out of steam, but out of ideas. None of the old tricks, like finding "theme stocks," seem to be working.
As of the end of last week, construction-industry stocks had fallen about 38 percent over the last 52 weeks, compared with a 34.6 percent decline for the overall market in the same period, according to John Baldwin, an analyst here with Jardine Fleming Securities.
But over the last 26 weeks, construction stocks have dropped 36 percent, while the market has fallen 27.4 percent. And over the last 13 weeks, construction stocks have tumbled 26.5 percent, while the market has lost 14 percent.
"If anything, these stocks have held up longer than I would have expected," said Hugh Conaway, an analyst who follows the Japanese construction industry at Baring Securities here. "These stocks may be near bottom, but they're not ready to be bought yet, not for another six months."
The Japanese Government's budget for the current fiscal year had already been fattened with a heavy load of public-works spending, in part to satisfy American trade negotiators. The hope was that with some stimulus to demand at home, Japanese exporters would be more inclined to sell their products domestically, thus moderating Japan's huge trade surplus.
Then, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa had announced at the end of March that his Government would be front-loading this year's public-works spending by signing about 75 percent of the contracts in the first half, giving the economy a little extra jolt. The market continued to slump.
So two weeks ago, the Government said it was preparing a supplementary budget, to be formally announced in September, that would increase public-works spending by as much as $55 billion.
The market's response? Stock prices on Monday fell to their lowest levels since March 1986, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues temporarily cracking through the 15,000 level.
As Peter Sanborn, a construction industry analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities, noted, the decline in the construction stocks may be in defiance of Government plans, but it is not irrational. In a recent report, he wrote that investors were responding to the trend in Japanese public-works spending, which typically soars at first, only to drop off sharply once the economy recovers.
Profits decline with the loss of Government contracts. Investors, he said, are just getting out in front of an expected lowering of Government public-works spending in coming years, especially when the economy begins to perk up.
"There is a real danger that interest in public-works stocks will shift abruptly with mounting confidence in an economic turnaround," Mr. Sanborn wrote.
The economic signs these days augur ill, but most analysts expect an upturn sometime next year. And that has provided investors yet another excuse to shed the so-called counter-cyclical stocks that were supposed to hold up when everything else looked gloomy.
Shares in Kajima, for instance, a leading construction company, have fallen 12.6 percent since July 1, to 750 yen on Monday. Shimizu, another big construction concern, has tumbled 10.6 percent since July 1, to 805 yen.
Nippon Hodo, Japan's largest road builder, has seen its shares plummet 28.7 percent in the same period, to 1,790 yen on Monday.
Even Obayashi Road, another top road builder whose shares Mr. Sanborn recommends, has seen its stock price tumble more than 14 percent over the last six weeks, to 1,840 yen on Monday.
Mr. Conaway of Baring Securities attributed much of the misery in the construction sector to the fact that private orders have collapsed because of a plunge in corporate investment.
While Government contracts once made up half of the industry's orders, they now make up only about 30 percent. This shift is a result of the private construction boom over the last six years, he said. As a result, investors are looking at the promise of tens of billions of dollars more in Government public-works spending not as a boon, but as the minimum necessary to keep the industry from suffering an even deeper recession.
"The problem now is that if we don't get 6 or 7 trillion yen in extra public-works spending this year, you'll see a real drop," Mr. Conaway said. "That's the minimum we need just to keep the sector going really."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Stop at a Flatter Tax?

 BODY:
Seven leading Republican conservatives, led by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, are pushing President Bush to adopt a bold plan to slash taxes. In a memo they warn: "We can't keep promising the American people that patience will lead to prosperity. We must show them that we have a set of principles and a plan to dramatically expand economic growth, job creation and entrepreneurial capitalism."
To that end, the group proposes a "flatter, lower, simpler" tax code. Exciting rhetoric. But shopworn specifics. The seven would have been better off going all the way to Jerry Brown's flat tax proposal. The California Democrat's plan, though flawed, was at least bold. 
 The Republicans would lower marginal tax rates by 3 percentage points. That's hardly revolutionary, coming only a few years after Congress, prodded by Mr. Kemp, cut the top tax rate by more than 20 points. The memo signers also propose raising the personal exemption to $6,000, which alone wouldn't spur entrepreneurs or anyone else.
The memo becomes slightly more venturesome when it proposes to eliminate capital gains taxes on long-term investments and to insulate capital gains taxes, and some corporate deductions, against inflation. But the plan, illogically, stops short of applying the same correction to inflated deductions that investors are allowed for borrowing costs. Nor does the memo analyze costs. Under this Alice-in-Wonderland scenario, Congress would declare tax holidays without raising anyone else's tax or gutting Federal spending.
The plan's piecemeal tactics don't measure up to its lofty objectives. Imagine, for example, a tax code that would reward saving and investment, penalize consumption and protect the poor. A tax code that would integrate corporate and personal taxes to eliminate double taxation of investment income. A tax code that would wipe out nearly every deduction and exemption except those targeted for the poor. A tax code that would apply a single rate across the board.
Sound familiar? If the Republicans wanted boldness, all they had to do was adapt Mr. Brown's plan, correcting its glaring but remediable errors. That could produce a plan that's truly pro-growth. This memo is, by comparison, mere tinkering.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial
