HEADLINE: U.S. Accused of Easing Pursuit of S.& L. Cases

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Government lawyers told a Senate panel today that Federal attempts to sue and recover money from former officials of defunct savings and loan associations had been mismanaged and relaxed in recent months. They suggested that political influence played a role in weakened Government efforts.
A lawyer with the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency responsible for cleaning up collapsed savings and loan institutions, said the agency dropped plans to sue officials of an institution around the time one of them visited with President Bush. The lawyer, Jacqueline P. Taylor, criticized the decision to resolve the matter out of court rather than to file a lawsuit as "an inappropriate settlement because of political reasons." 
 The panel, the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, also heard Ms. Taylor, two other agency lawyers and a top official of the General Accounting Office, a Congressional investigative body, tell about organizational disruptions in the Resolution Trust program to recover money from those who helped cause the collapse of hundreds of savings and loan associations.
Any reduction in recoveries by the Government from accused savings and loan wrongdoers would increase the scandal's total cost to taxpayers, now estimated at more than $200 billion.
 
An Official's Defense
 Albert V. Casey, the president of the Resolution Trust, defended his agency's efforts, including a recent organizational restructuring. He repeated his commitment that the corporation would "vigorously and effectively pursue its claims against those whose wrongdoing caused losses to the American public in connection with the widespread failures in the savings and loan industry."
Mr. Casey did not comment on the testimony of Ms. Taylor or the other attorneys, but promised the committee a reply later this month. He also acknowledged that the reorganization of the legal program involved some mistakes but denied that the mistakes had been caused by any desire to prevent aggressive investigations.
At the hearing, the committee made public a Resolution Trust personnel policy implemented earlier this year that in effect set up special hiring preferences for well-connected attorneys seeking jobs at the corporation.
At today's hearing Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, criticized that policy, saying it suggested improper political influence. Mr. Casey, who responded that he would "take it out of effect" immediately, said that today's hearing was the first time the policy had been brought to his attention.
In pursuing those responsible for savings and loan failures, Mr. Casey said, the agency must find wrongdoing as well as determine that it is economically efficient to bring a case. About one third of all failures lead to cases, he said. He added that recent changes in the legal program were part of an effort to streamline the Resolution Trust as it moved toward completion of its business next year.
But the lawyers, supported by the Senate committee's chairman, Donald W. Riegle, a Michigan Democrat, said the most experienced lawyers were being replaced or punished, allowing potential defendants off the hook. Two other agency attorneys who today told the panel there had been mismanagement in the legal program, Bruce Pederson and Bradley Smolkin, were recently reassigned and demoted from their positions as managers.
The three lawyers also criticized a draft memorandum prepared last month as part of a Bush Administration review of proposed Government guidelines for suing officers and directors of banks and savings and loans. The guidelines, the lawyers said, would make it harder to sue directors who were not full-time employees of an institution.
Mr. Casey, in a letter earlier this month to Senator Riegel that was released at today's hearing, said he had expressed concerns to other regulators that "issuing guidelines would not be advisable, because some defendants might attempt to use such a statement for defensive purposes."
The lawyers told the committee that the question of who is sued is a sensitive issue because a number of prominent people served on the boards of savings and loan associations that failed.
A pending case in Arizona has already prompted charges of political influence. It involves a failed Phoenix savings institution, one of whose former directors is the Governor of Arizona, Fife Symington, a Republican, who is contesting charges of negligence.
According to Government records, other prominent former directors of defunct institutions include political fund-raisers; two Cabinet members, Edward Madigan, the Secretary of Agriculture and Edward J. Derwinski, the Veteran Affairs Secretary, and Neil Bush, the President's son.
 
Bush Meeting in Salt Lake City
 Ms. Taylor, until recently a section chief based in Denver, would not identify the case that was being settled coincidental with the meeting with President Bush.
But other officials, who asked not to be identified, said the institution was Deseret Federal Savings and Loan, based in Salt Lake City before it failed and was taken over by the Government in 1989. Some of Deseret's directors, officials said, had close ties to the Mormon Church, whose leaders met with President Bush last month in Salt Lake City.
A longtime outside director of the savings and loan, Howard W. Hunter, is the president of the Council of the Twelve Apostles, a high post in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints -- the church's formal name. Don LeFevre, a Mormon Church spokesman, said Mr. Hunter was one of the church officials who met with Mr. Bush but that savings and loan litigation was not discussed during the session. Asked about a possible lawsuit, Mr. LeFevre said Mr. Hunter would "see what happens when and if a lawsuit is filed."
 
Negotiations Over Deseret
 In her testimony, Ms. Taylor said agency officials dropped plans to file a lawsuit around the time of the visit with President Bush and were in the process of settling the case. Stephen Katsanos, an agency spokesman, said tonight that settlement discussions were under way over Deseret Federal, but he declined to discuss the matter further.
An associate of Mr. Hunter's, who insisted on not being identified, said he was unaware of any political influence being brought to bear on the case and added that Mr. Hunter had gone out of his way not to involve the church in the private negotiations.
In a written statement to the committee, Ms. Taylor mentioned political pressures not to pursue outside directors aggressively, violations of corporate policy and negotiations involving settlements for only small amounts of money, but she did not identify the cases at issue.

HEADLINE: China Report Sees Prison as One Big, Happy Jail

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The Government sought today to rebut Western criticisms by issuing a major report on conditions in Chinese prisons. But it painted such a glowing portrait of prison life that skeptics are unlikely to be convinced.
The white paper, "Criminal Reform in China," is part of a broad effort by the authorities to counter allegations of torture, hunger and slave labor in what critics call China's "gulag." The report includes numerous statistics, but its tone is so far removed from what former prisoners have said that it is unclear how reliable the figures are. 
 "After the founding of the People's Republic, the people's government established a new kind of socialist prison, where the prisoners are regarded as human beings, where their dignity is respected, their personal safety is insured and they receive fully humane treatment," the report declared.
It contrasted these conditions with prisons before the 1949 revolution. In those days, it said, Americans and Chinese agents together "savagely tortured and secretly murdered revolutionaries."
China's huge prison network is one of the country's great mysteries. There is little comprehensive information and foreigners are allowed to visit only model institutions, like Beijing No. 1 Prison. In such visits, some prisoners try so hard to please the authorities that they insist to reporters that they do not want to leave when their sentences expire.
In fact, former prisoners interviewed privately have almost unanimously reported that conditions are brutal, with beatings and other torture a way of life. Almost all have said that food is awful and insufficient, and that some favorite felons known as "cell bosses" are allowed to abuse others in any way they want.
Prison conditions have become an issue in Chinese-American relations, both because of United States concerns about human rights violations of political prisoners and because of evidence that products made by Chinese prisoners are being illegally exported to the United States.
 
Prison Labor
 The report issued today said that 90 percent of the prison population participates in labor, while the rest are excused because they are old, disabled or otherwise unfit to work. But it said the total value of prison goods in 1990 was about $500 million, less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the nation's total economic output.
"Some news reports are very distorted and turn black into white," said Zhao Shaohua, an official of the State Council Information Office, which edited the 26-page white paper. "We want to use this report so that the world can understand our legal work."
The State Council issued a similar white paper, on human rights, a year ago. Most diplomats regard such materials as important less in the arguments they make than in the implication that such issues are now open for discussion and that China will debate and defend its human rights record.
The human rights report at least acknowledged lapses in some areas, while the report on prisons today moved from one glowing high note to the next.
One of the few indications that anything goes wrong is the statement that in 1990 and 1991 a total of 24 wardens and guards were themselves imprisoned for beating up detainees.
In another public relations gesture, a Chinese-backed magazine in Hong Kong recently published photos of prominent dissidents smiling in their prison cells.
 
Photos of Political Prisoner
 The most important among them were two photos of Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known political prisoner, who is now serving the 14th year of a 15-year prison sentence.
The photos of Mr. Wei were the first to emerge of him since his trial, and they show him looking relaxed, cheerful and apparently healthy.
One photo shows him smiling, displaying his teeth, apparently to counter reports in the West that a poor diet caused his teeth to fall out. It is impossible to tell from the photo if his teeth are real.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

NEW YORK CITY
 
WELFARE ROLLS KEEP CLIMBING
In the most telling sign of the tremendous human damage the city's economic woes have caused, the number of New Yorkers on welfare broke the one million mark last month for the first time since the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's. Most of the newcomers are unskilled workers who have had trouble competing for jobs in the recession, many economists and state officials said. A1.
 
FLAWS FOUND IN BRIDGE INSPECTIONS 
 New York City bridge inspectors have grossly overstated the amount of time they spend checking the city's smaller bridges to determine whether they are safe, an 18-month investigation by the City Council and the City Comptroller shows. The investigators blamed the Dinkins administration for failing to adequately supervise the city's bridge inspectors in determining whether they do their jobs. But they would not say who specifically was at fault or whether the bridges were unsafe as a result. B3.
 
ON EDGE OVER RAPES IN QUEENS
All along the streets of Laurelton, Queens, nervous women are changing their habits and taking precautions as they live in fear of a man who the police say has raped five women over the last year. B3.

HEADLINE: Using Art as Creative Teaching Force

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
The art lesson in a recent workshop was no ordinary one: the students were teachers. They were asked to empty their purses and pockets and, on a white sheet of paper, create a face using as few of the items as possible. .
One face was simply a pair of sunglasses. Another was single earring representing a mouth. A third was a profile created by a necklace forming a forehead, a nose and a chin. 
 "This shows you that art can be anything," said Donald Olsen, a band and orchestra teacher at Eastchester High School in Eastchester, N.Y., and one of 30 teachers participating in the workshop at the Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education. "It gives you a different way of looking at things."
It was also an example of a teaching concept known as esthetic education, which aims not only to promote a broader understanding of the arts but to encourage teachers to think differently and more creatively in everything they do. Another aim is to foster the recognition that the arts are a positive experience to which all people should be exposed.
 
Promoting Art for 17 Years
 The institute, the education arm of the Lincoln Center for Performing Arts, has been promoting esthetic education since it was founded 17 years ago. The program includes the workshop for teachers, and it takes plays, concerts and dance performances to students during the academic year or brings the students to Lincoln Center to see the performances.
The teacher education component is something virtually no other program has. Schools from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut pay $2,500 to $5,000 to participate.
Practitioners say esthetic education, championed early in this century by the educator and philosopher John Dewey, produces ripple effects far beyond expanding understanding of the arts.
Teachers say esthetic education training can accomplish three other goals: it helps them integrate the arts into courses like history, literature and even mathematics and science; it helps insure that even in times of recession the arts are not entirely eliminated through budget cuts, and it helps a child's self-esteem, because in the arts there is no single "correct" approach.
 
Beyond 'Assembly Lines'
 "Most of our schools are G.M. assembly lines," said Michael Moore, the director of Arts Unlimited in Bowling Green, Ohio, a program modeled after the one at the Lincoln Center Institute. "They do the same thing over and over. This is one of the reasons our schools are in trouble.
"Esthetic education is a lot messier. Esthetic education keeps asking, 'What if?' and 'Why not?' Esthetic education says there isn't one right answer."
For these reasons, the concept is also sometimes difficult for many teachers to grasp, accustomed as they are to the structured atmosphere of a public school. But teachers exposed to esthetic education at the Lincoln Center Institute workshops say the experience helped break down traditional thought processes and encouraged them to think more expansively.
One participant, Eddie Maldonado, for instance, a special education teacher at Salk Middle School in Old Bridge, N.J., said that when she now teaches history, she introduces the music of the era, and in her literature class the paintings of the period are discussed.
For science and math teachers, the application of the arts is more of a stretch. But several teachers said that art, in fact, could help them make the hard-core disciplines more accessible to students.
In another workshop exercise, teachers carved four potatoes into various shapes and sizes. From the exercise, Francine Kaalund, who teaches science to students in grades 6 through 9 at Middle School 158 in Bayside, Queens, had an idea to let her students supplement textbook lessons in the development of the frog by carving potatoes to show its growth from tadpole to adult.
Some educators say there is little research data to support the notion that the arts can help in the instruction of subjects like math and science. "The evidence that a good arts program can improve performance in non-arts areas is thin," said Howard Gardner, a Harvard University psychologist.
Educators and some policy makers lament that the arts are still regarded as an enrichment rather than a staple. Others argue that at a time when many schools are having trouble paying for and maintaining the basics, the arts should be viewed as enrichment.
"I don't see it as a budget trade off," said Ernest L. Boyer, the president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching in Princeton, N.J., who was recently named chairman of the Lincoln Center Institute's Board of Directors.
Mr. Boyer said incorporating the arts into literature and history, for example, requires only a teacher who can do so. "The arts have been pushed to the edges, as a frill, and considered something we can come back to when everything else is covered," he said. "It's been one of the real tragedies in the American education philosophy."

HEADLINE: Cutback in Military Spending: No Help for Ailing Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Not since the 1950's has the United States recovered from recession while military spending was falling sharply. But now that the cold war is over, America is struggling to do just that, and finding it difficult.
The precipitous drop in military spending in the last 18 months has eroded an important pillar of the economy, and many economists say that is a big reason that the United States is now having such trouble pulling out of recession. 
 While critics of military spending have long argued that the money and manpower could be better employed in the civilian sector, virtually no one questions that military spending has served as a powerful source of economic demand.
"There has not been a time when a rise in defense spending would mean more for the economy than now," said Alicia Munnell, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. "We are growing so slowly that defense spending can make the difference between a rising unemployment rate and a falling one."
The military budget authorization -- $286.7 billion in the current fiscal year, adjusted for inflation -- has been falling at more than 5 percent a year since 1990, notwithstanding the fighting in Kuwait. That is twice as steep as the rate of decline in the late 1980's.
But among all categories of military spending, the greatest damage to the economy has come from the cutback in procurement spending: orders placed with factories. It has been falling by more than 12 percent a year since 1990. And under President Bush's budget proposal now before Congress, the sum will drop another 13 percent in fiscal 1993. Procurement has a multiplier effect, creating jobs not only at military contractors but also at the companies that make the consumer goods the well-paid military workers buy.
DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting service, estimates that this lower level of military spending "probably cuts one-quarter of a percentage point off economic growth," said David Wyss, DRI's chief economist. "That is a considerable drag in a nearly stagnant economy growing at less than 1.5 percent a year."
Nor has the drain ended. Continued cutbacks by military contractors sliced 17,000 jobs in July, the biggest single-month decline in military contractor employment since the recession began in July 1990. Certain areas, like Southern California, are being hit especially hard. And industry executives suggest considerable shrinkage is still to come.
For four decades, military spending has accounted for an average of more than 7 percent of the nation's annual output of goods and services, seldom falling below 5 percent even during earlier cutbacks. Today that level has shrunk to just about 5.5 percent of the gross domestic product, and most projections see it sinking below 4 percent by 1997.
"The impact is bigger than you can see by just looking at the numbers," said Herbert Stein, a senior economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
Two other big cutbacks in military spending have occurred since the cold war began in 1950, after the Korean War and after Vietnam. But neither hit the economy with as much force as the current reduction in military spending.
Soaring consumer demand, very much absent today, helped to offset the military cutback in the early 1950's. "It was only after the Korean War that Americans finally decided that we would not go back to the Great Depression, and they let go and spent," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist.
The continuing Government outlays for Lyndon Johnson's Great Society programs -- economic stimulus also absent today -- helped to counteract the Vietnam military cutback, which began in 1968. Even so, both cutbacks contributed to brief recessions, in 1957-1958 and in 1970.
This time, military spending actually peaked as far back as the fiscal year 1985, and has been falling ever since. But much of the damage to the economy -- and particularly to jobs -- did not hit until more recently. As long as the cold war held out the promise of renewed weapons making, military contractors waited out the lean years -- as they did in the 1950's and 1960's -- keeping their operations largely intact. But with the abrupt dissolution of the Soviet Union, that promise is gone.
Now leading military companies like General Dynamics, Hughes Aircraft, Raytheon and General Electric are shrinking their operations in anticipation of permanently lower sales, and their actions will ripple through the economy as workers lose jobs.
"We don't see the traditional rebound that has characterized downturns in defense spending in the past, and we are preparing ourselves on that basis," said James Cunnane, a senior vice president at General Dynamics, which makes warplanes, armored vehicles and submarines.
In just 19 months, General Dynamics has eliminated 17,000 jobs, shrinking its work force by nearly 20 percent. And there have been similar rapid layoffs across the industry, as military contractors increasingly find themselves behaving as any other company forced to compete for shrinking business would.
"There used to be more contracts and the revenue base was bigger so you could support more costs, but those days are gone," said Sheldon Rutstein, chief financial officer at Raytheon, maker of the Patriot Missile and other military hardware. Raytheon, which held employment in its military operations above 75,000 through 1990, has now reduced its work force to 68,200.
"We are well aware that our competitors are taking similar steps," Mr. Rutstein said, "so we have to be one step better to be in a position to pull in the next contract."
 
Employment
Timing of Layoffs Couldn't Be Worse
 Nowhere is the effect of the more vigorous cutbacks in the military supply industry more evident than in the Labor Department's monthly employment statistics.
Until the summer of 1990, employment at military contractors -- the hundreds of companies that receive 50 percent or more of their revenues from sales to the military -- hardly fell. The job rolls at these companies, which reached a high of 1.44 million in 1987, declined by only 33,000 in the following three years.
"For a long time, people in the industry thought they would get well, that orders would rise, but the orders clearly were not coming," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group.
When the Berlin wall fell and the Soviet Union collapsed, the reductions began in earnest. Beginning in the middle of 1990, employment at military contractors plunged by more than 100,000 a year, falling to 1.19 million last month. That decline -- of some 225,000 people -- represents 15 percent of the 1.47 million jobs that have disappeared during the current recession, which began in July 1990.
"The timing for such steps could not have been worse," said John E. Bregger, an economist at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Just when we need a boost from defense, we get a negative."
Many jobs are being lost in California and the Northeast, but hundreds of communities elsewhere are also affected as the contractors slice orders to their suppliers. General Electric's Aerospace division, for example, is shrinking its network of about 2,000 suppliers by 50 percent -- using the best supplier of, say, wire harnesses to sell to all of G.E.'s 13 aerospace plants, instead of having each plant buy from a different company.
Compounding the problem, military workers earn among the highest hourly wages in the nation, usually well above the national average of $10.58 an hour. When their jobs disappear, consumer spending, on which a recovery depends, suffers more than if a lower-paid retail store clerk or office worker is laid off.
What's more, the armed forces have shed 160,000 people since 1990, and now stand at just over two million men and women. That is only 1.6 percent of the total labor force -- the lowest percentage since World War II. The cutback has been particularly painful for high school graduates, especially minorities, for whom the armed services have been an important source of jobs. Blacks account for 20.6 percent of the men and women in the military.
 
Remedies
Conversion Proves To Be Difficult
 Despite the bounty of military spending, critics like Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate in economic science, and Albert T. Sommers, senior economist at the Conference Board, have argued that the same money used to develop civilian technologies could have made the United States more competitive with other nations, not less competitive. The same dollars invested in rapid transit or housing or fiber-optic networks, they say, might have created more jobs and more national wealth than the investment in weaponry.
"It is crazy that we should need to have defense lead the way in public spending," said Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But the question now is whether, as military spending shrinks, any other source of spending or investment will take its place. The cold war persuaded Americans to support big Government outlays for weapons, even running up big budget deficits in the process. But now that the Soviet Union has disappeared as an enemy, there appears to be little national resolve to divert such huge sums into other public spending -- even spending that is thought to lay the foundation for a stronger economy and greater productivity later.
The Bush Administration and the military contractors themselves are trying various remedies. Some $7 billion in Federal money has been earmarked to promote conversion to civilian production, through grants for job training and communities dependent on military contractors. In St. Louis, for instance, McDonnell-Douglas has laid off 10,000 workers in the last 18 months.
But conversion is difficult in a recession, when existing manufacturers of consumer goods or machinery cannot sell what they already produce. Even small companies like Essex Industries in St. Louis, which has switched from making breathing devices for pilots to oxygen equipment for patients, do not make an immediate contribution to the economy. Employment at Essex has shrunk from 500 to 400 and raises are scarce for workers whose average pay is $12 an hour. "We were in a position to grant a 4 percent raise in February, and we hope we can grant another in the future, but only if the company performs well enough," said Eugene Corn, a vice president. "To put it simplistically, there is a dry period between the time you develop a product and the time you can sell it, and we are in that valley now."
Rather than convert, the leading military contractors are turning to exports for relief. Raytheon, for example, hopes that by 1996, it can export 40 percent of its radars, missiles and tactical weapons, up from 20 percent today.
But with the end of the cold war, there is a lot of competition abroad. The former Soviet Union is also trying to sell its military hardware, as the FMC Corporation's Ground Systems division in San Jose, Calif., discovered. The company lined up a sale of armored personnel carriers to the United Arab Emirates, only to learn that the Emirates decided to buy used equipment from Russia instead.

HEADLINE: Proposal To Double Park Area On the Shore

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration announced a long-range plan for New York City's waterfront yesterday that would eventually double the area for parks, esplanades and walkways while preventing gargantuan developments that wall off the shoreline.
The ambitious proposals foresee an esplanade that would virtually encircle Manhattan. Waterside pathways would also be built along the shore in Long Island City, Queens; next to the Harlem River in the Bronx, and rimming most of Brooklyn's south shore and Staten Island's north shore. 
 The heart of the administration's plan is a proposal to revamp the zoning laws to force developers to build smaller, lower buildings and provide the public access to the shore.
The zoning changes would forbid using underwater land when figuring the permissible size of a building. It would also require builders to let streets continue through to the water so that the rivers and harbors are not blocked from view. Developers would be required to leave a fifth of the land on which they build for park space.
"We're trying to change building that seals off the waterfront from the rest of the city and creates a wall," said Rosina K. Abramson, the executive director of the City Planning Department.
Anticipated for years, the plan knits together dozens of unconnected designs by public and private groups into a cohesive and unified vision, public officials and environmentalists said. The weighty document marks the first time since New York enacted its initial zoning law in 1916 that the city will have special requirements for waterfront developments to include open space.
 
Hearings in the Fall
 Every facet of the plan will take months or years to complete and must eventually be approved by the City Council. This fall, the City Planning Commission will hold hearings on the plan and make changes. The Council is expected to take up the zoning changes next spring.
The plan was immediately praised by neighborhood groups, politicians and environmentalists, who have long argued that the city could reap economic benefits from more recreational and commercial amenities on its waterways. Such development has spurred growth in cities such as Baltimore, Boston, Toronto, Seattle and San Francisco.
"It really portrays a vision for the use of the waterfront in Manhattan and the rest of the city that is right on target," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "City Hall has moved the waterfront to the forefront."
But developers questioned the wisdom of the proposed zoning changes. Building on the water is expensive, they said, since it often requires new sewers, roads and pilings. By reducing the size of projects and the number of apartments with water views, they said, the city could end up making most new projects unprofitable.
"If you are going to overly restrict development from a design and a density point of view, our question is, 'Will there be viable opportunities along the waterfront?' " said Michael Slattery, senior vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "Collectively these regulations may be a discouragement for development."
The plan recommends hundreds of projects, including these:
*In Manhattan, the plan envisions a 270-acre park with esplanades and public piers on the West Side from Battery Park City to 59th Street. It would also construct dozens of esplanades to close gaps at various points, including the riverfront between Donald Trump's proposed Riverside South development and 72d Street and gaps in lower Manhattan at Pier A, the Whitehall Ferry Terminal, the Battery Maritime Building and north of the South Street Seaport.
*In the Bronx, the plan proposes a new park at the Hunts Point Marine Transfer Station Site, once the Sanitation Department shuts down its operation there. It would also build a new esplanade along the Bronx River from West 165th Street to 225th Street that would be connected to the Harlem Beach park over one of the bridges in the area. In addition, it recommends a series of esplanades, boat launches and fishing piers in Soundview, Ferry Point and Pugsley Creek Parks in the eastern Bronx.
*In Brooklyn, the city proposes developing the six piers in Brooklyn Heights in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge to allow the public greater access. It also proposes linking the Shore Parkway bike path to Coney Island.
*On Staten Island, the plan recommends completing the North Shore Esplanade that would run from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to the Ferry Terminal and then along the northern shore to Snug Harbor. It also recommends creating a new beach at Cedar Grove Avenue on the southern shore.
*In Queens, the administration has proposed redeveloping most of the Long Island City waterfront to increase public access and link existing parks. It also would limit public access to the natural areas around Jamaica Bay.
The plan proposes establishing nature preserves along about a third of the city's shoreline, including Jamaica Bay, the Harbor Herons Complex on the eastern shore of Staten Island, and parts of Long Island Sound and the upper East River.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Central Banks' Intervention Helps to Prop Up the Dollar

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Bank coordinated a dollar-buying spree yesterday with a dozen European central banks to keep the dollar from drifting any closer to its all-time low against the German mark. But the action lifted the dollar only slightly.
The Fed's intervention, its third in three weeks, was apparently aimed at keeping the dollar from going down so far that it bred panic in currency and stock markets. The buying was also intended, traders said, to prevent the dollar from hitting a record low that could be politically embarassing to President Bush during an election year.
The dollar closed at 1.4669 German marks, up from Monday's close at 1.4630 marks, and a cut above the all-time low of 1.4475, set on Feb. 11, 1991. The Fed began buying when the dollar fell to 1.4620, traders said, and waded into the market repeatedly during the day. 
 The dollar rose to 128.00 Japanese yen in late New York trading from Monday's 127.90. In Tokyo overnight, before trading began in Europe, the dollar closed at 127.91 yen, down 0.01 yen from Monday's close. In afternoon trading in London, the dollar was quoted at 128.05 yen.
Chris Bourdain, manager of foreign exchange sales at Credit Suisse New York, said the Fed and other central banks wanted to assure traders that they would set a floor to the dollar's price and they wanted to demonstrate a coordinated policy.
"But that glosses over the very big differences in interest rate policy," he said. "Europe is anti-inflation, and the U.S. is pro-growth, and that's about as opposite as you can get."
The dollar's sharp drop in recent months has followed a yawning discrepancy between short-term interest rates in the United States and Germany: the former are at their lowest point in 30 years; the latter at their highest in 50 years. A higher payoff in interest rates lures investors from the United States to Germany, and from dollars to marks.
As usual, Fed officials declined comment. A spokesman for the Bundesbank, which participated in the buying, said that the action was taken at the initiative of the Fed, Reuters reported.
The Fed and the Bank of Canada bought dollars last Friday, traders said, but yesterday's concert of central bank buying was the first since July 20, when the dollar fell to 1.4473 marks and then lifted to 1.4937 marks.
Despite yesterday's mixed results, foreign exchange traders said they expected the Fed to re-enter the market again, and as often as necessary to keep the dollar from falling sharply. One trader estimated that the Fed bought between $600 million and $800 million in dollars yesterday.
"They are most concerned about confidence in the dollar," said a foreign exchange manager, citing both the economic and political concerns of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. "The last thing Brady needs is a record low."

HEADLINE: Increase in Labor Costs Is Slowest in 17 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
American labor costs, held back by the weak economy, have risen this year at the slowest pace in 17 years, while productivity posted a healthy gain in the spring, the Government said Tuesday.
The Labor Department said that unit labor costs for nonfarm businesses inched up at an annual rate of three-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June quarter, following a barely perceptible rate of advance of one-tenth of 1 percent from January through March. 
 As for productivity, defined as output per hour of work, it posted a third consecutive healthy gain of 2.3 percent, annualized, in the spring. That followed rates of 2.5 percent in last year's fourth quarter and a giant 3.8 percent advance from January through March, the best productivity showing in five years.
 
Increases in Productivity
 For the second quarter, the productivity increase was led by a big 4.7 percent rate of advance in manufacturing, reflecting strong gains in production of durable goods, which are long-lasting items like cars.
Economists were encouraged by both the pickup in productivity gains and the extremely low increases in unit labor costs, saying the figures should translate into better profits for American companies and continued good news on inflation.
The gains, however, are a direct reflection of the stagnant economy, which has caused widespread layoffs, driven unemployment up to a current level of 7.7 percent and put severe downward pressure on wages.
"Four years of a moribund economy have played a large role in breaking the back of inflation," said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. "We have set the stage for the lowest rates of inflation in 30 years."
Mr. Sinai said that instead of consumer prices rising at an annual rate of 4 percent to 5 percent, he was looking for the underlying rate of inflation to be between 2 percent and 3 percent.
"We have had a full year of markedly lower rises in unit labor costs and that historically has signaled a sea change in the underlying rate of inflation," he said. "A beneficial side effect of this dismal economy should be lower rates of inflation for a long, long time."
The Government was scheduled to report on Wednesday the performance of wholesale prices in July followed by the consumer price report on Thursday. Analysts were looking for small increases in both reports of around two-tenths or three-tenths of a percent.
Economists were also encouraged by the gains in productivity this year although they cautioned that much of this strength could be related to the fact that productivity normally increases in the early stages of an economic recovery as businesses are cautious about hiring back laid-off workers and instead get more output from a reduced work force.
For all of last year, productivity barely budged, rising just one-tenth of 1 percent as both output and employment plunged.
Productivity growth averaged just above 1 percent in both the 1970's and the 1980's, far worse than the 2.5 percent annual gains posted from 1947 to 1967.
Economists said that until the United States finds a way to reverse the long-term slide in productivity, American standards of living will continue under severe downward pressure.
David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill Inc. of Lexington, Mass., said he was hopeful that the United States would be able to post better gains in productivity in the 1990's than it did in the last decade because the labor force will be older and more experienced.
But he said significant improvement in United States productivity would not come until government and private investment levels increased substantially.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential candidate, has made investment a central part of his economic program and the Bush Administration is also searching for ways to bolster long-term investment.
"We are still suffering from a lack of investment that got worse in the 1980's," Mr. Wyss said. "It is hard to get productivity growth without investment."

HEADLINE: 7 Black Hospitals Struggle to Find A Modern Role

BYLINE: By MARIA ODUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Not long after the turn of the century, the nation had about 200 hospitals built primarily to serve blacks. For black health-care professionals, they were meccas. For black patients, they were welcome alternatives to being treated in neglected corners of segregated hospitals.
Today, long after the tight fist of lawful segregation loosened its grip, only seven historically black hospitals remain, and health-care experts say some of them have only a faint pulse. While historically black colleges, newspapers and other businesses found their niches in the post-segregation era, black hospitals seem to have had trouble redefining their role. 
 "Black hospitals are in very dire straits right now," said Dr. Vanessa Gamble, an assistant professor of the history of medicine and preventive medicine at the University of Wisconsin Medical School. "For most of them, I don't think the future is very bright."
The hospitals serve large numbers of patients who are poor and underinsured. They include Howard University Hospital in Washington; Norfolk Community Hospital, Richmond Community Hospital and Newport News General Hospital in Virginia; Southeast Specialty Hospital in Greensboro, N.C.; Meharry/Hubbard Hospital in Nashville, and Riverside General in Houston. In some cases, 50 percent of emergency-room patients cannot pay for services.
That financial drain was a leading factor in the hospitals' decline, some health experts say. But others blame desegregation for the decline because the end of segregation fostered an exodus of blacks to white-run businesses, as blacks exercised their right of choice, rather than bringing whites to black-run institutions.
A group called the Coalition to Save the Black Hospital plans to ask the Federal Department of Health and Human Services for financial assistance. The group is made up of representatives of black health-care organizations, other black health-care professionals and the administrators of eight historically black hospitals, including one that recently closed, and four hospitals that became predominantly controlled by blacks after shifts in population.
 
Request for $500 Million
 The coalition's chairman, Dr. Bernard Bridges, said the hospitals needed about $500 million, an amount "comparable to the cost of a Stealth bomber," over five years to pay for replacing equipment, hiring new staff members, expanding facilities and paying off debts.
"We want to be able to demonstrate to H.H.S. that if they are serious about treating poor, disabled and elderly people, then we have a core population that is situated in proximity to these hospitals that can get services there with sensitivity and dignity," said Dr. Bridges, a medical consultant for the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. He added that the coalition had begun negotiating with H.H.S. but had not submitted a final proposal.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in an interview that Federal funds for private, black-run hospitals would be possible "if there are special situations" in which individual hospitals may need "short-term support for a special problem or to launch a special program."
Citing studies that show blacks receive less medical care than whites and have a higher infant-mortality rate, health-care experts and civil rights leaders say there is still a need for black hospitals, many of which have a small percentage of white patients. "These hospitals continue to serve a very vital purpose in the black community," said the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, president of the S.C.L.C. "Adequate and affordable health care continues to move farther and farther away from those who need it most."
Historically, the hospitals were important community resources, said Dr. James A. Goodman Sr., president of the Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta. "They provided mentoring opportunities and were an economic force in the community," he said. "The role has diminished because of marketplace forces."
The first black-run hospital was Provident Hospital in Chicago, founded in 1891 by Dr. Daniel Hale Williams, who performed one of the first successful open-heart surgeries there in 1893. By 1920 there were about 200 of them, but about 56 black hospitals closed between 1961 and 1988, and 15 were either merged or consolidated with other hospitals or changed into institutions no longer controlled by blacks.
Reflecting on the time he worked for Provident Hospital, from 1984 to 1986, Craig May, now a senior public-information officer for the American Medical Association, said: "There was a sense of pride that I felt, a kind of swelling inside of me, when I saw all these black men and women wearing stethoscopes around their necks or carrying test tubes. We used to let black kids have tours to let them know that the medical profession is one where they could excel."
He said that on weekends, the hospital treated a succession of patients after assaults, drug overdoses or alcohol-related accidents. "And a lot of people would come because it was cold outside and they didn't have anywhere else to go," he said. "They'd say their stomach hurt or their head hurt, just to have a place to sleep. Everybody knew Provident was not going to ask if you could pay for your service. The hospital viewed its mission as caring for black people, and to its dying day, it stayed true to its mission."
Provident Hospital closed in September 1987, in the face of climbing debt and a decline in patients.
Dr. David Satcher, president of Meharry Medical College in Nashville, which is affiliated with Meharry/ Hubbard Hospital, described a special role for that hospital and Howard University Hospital. "Howard and Meharry provide leadership in African-American health care and are on the forefront of researching diseases that affect African-Americans, like sickle cell and cancer," he said.
Meharry/Hubbard Hospital appears to be likely to merge with a white-dominated public hospital, Metropolitan Nashville General Hospital, a measure that challenges Meharry/ Hubbard's status as a black hospital. The Nashville Metropolitan City Council will take a final vote on the merger proposal on Tuesday. Under the agreement, the city's hospital will eventually move its services to Meharry/Hubbard Hospital, which it will lease for 30 years. The merger is intended to help the city avoid having to rebuild or completely renovate its antiquated hospital and would allow the city to free Meharry from the financial drain created by serving so many people who cannot pay.
The largest historically black hospital is Howard University Hospital, which is 140 years old and has 479 beds. It lost $38 million in the last three years and was only able to pull itself out of the red after taking measures like laying off 218 employees last year, said Kevin Lofton, the hospital's administrator. Other black hospitals, like Newport News General Hospital, have had to seek bankruptcy protection.
Despite their financial problems, black hospitals perform a service by training black physicians, officials of the hospitals say.
"When you get into specialty categories like neurosurgery, ophthalmology and plastic surgery, then a large number of blacks are trained at black schools," Mr. Lofton said. "It is still difficult for black physicians to get into training programs in these high-specialty areas."
To shore up their financial base, black hospitals are trying to woo the black middle class with everything from friendlier faces to community outreach programs.
"The remaining institutions really must find a common thread that would tie them together in some way that will let them find a niche and that would let them develop a special, viable approach to helping the black community," said Nathaniel Wesley Jr., director of planning at Howard University Hospital, who has been doing research on black hospitals for 15 years. "We can't be all things to all people. We need to find out what our remaining institutions need to do best and then strike out and do that."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Living Desk

LENGTH: 1447 words

HEADLINE: Fixed-Price Lessons, At $19.92 a Customer

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
SAN DOMENICO, an elegant Italian restaurant on Central Park South with leather chairs and ocher walls, is often sparsely populated at lunch time. But this month, San Domenico is packed. So, too, is the Gotham Bar and Grill, Le Perigord, the Sign of the Dove and other restaurants with reputations for good food but images of being too expensive or too forbidding for most New Yorkers.
It took a bargain to bring restaurant madness back to New York. 
 Since the Democratic National Convention was held here in mid-July, about 50 restaurants have been offering a three-course lunch for $19.92, not including tax or tip. While that is hardly a cheap lunch, it is less than the restaurants otherwise charge for three courses. The promotion has attracted so many people to the restaurants that some owners, already committed to continuing the bargain until Labor Day, are thinking of prolonging it into the fall. Many hope a similar promotion will be organized next summer.
The surge has brought an energy to the business that is reminiscent of the mid-1980's, when going to restaurants rather than the theater or opera became the definition of an exciting time out. "I had somebody walk in who said they had gone to every restaurant that was doing this," said Anne Rosenzweig, the chef and co-owner of Arcadia, at 21 East 62nd Street. "It's become a New York thing to do."
Although profits are lower on the $19.92 lunches, owners said that the sight of bustling restaurants, and the possibility of drawing new customers, has been beneficial. "We have to concentrate on getting the restaurant busy, on creating a sense of excitement about going out again," said Tony May, the owner of San Domenico, where the promotion has more than doubled weekday lunch business, from about 30 a day to 70. "Of course, I don't make money on it. But right now, I am losing money anyway. We want to get people in the restaurant."
The promotion was originally organized by Tim Zagat, the restaurant-guide publisher, and Joseph Baum, the restaurateur, as a nice extra for delegates and New Yorkers during the convention. They did not expect that some of the 100 or so restaurants that originally participated would suddenly get thousands of calls a day.
"The reaction surprised all of us," Mr. Zagat said. Although the passion for a bargain has subsided, it has not stopped. Diners who had been looking for the best deal on a grilled chicken in a takeout shop are roaming from top restaurant to top restaurant, trying their $19.92 specials.
These lunchers are like an army of reviewers, rating restaurants on whether they offer too little choice, or too small portions. Esther Frankel, who ate lunch last week at the Sign of the Dove, at 1110 Third Avenue at East 65th Street, with Nina Shulman, her daughter, said there was not much crab in her pasta. "And the coffee wasn't hot," she said. "We sent it back."
A critical approach is not surprising in a demanding populace that can find the downside in anything, from a drop in subway crime to falling housing prices. Some of the complaints have been legitimate. Some restaurants have reduced portions; some have offered the cheapest dishes from their menus. Restaurant owners, too, have had plenty to say, off the record, about those who do not deliver the goods. But there has also been a lot of praise, and much goodwill created by certain restaurants.
Maureen Quinn, who was eating lunch last week at Le Perigord on East 52nd Street with two friends from work, Addy Zeni and Barbara Levy, praised the formal French restaurant, usually a haunt for United Nations diplomats. "They don't make you feel like you're less because you're only paying $19.92," she said.
She and her friends have been to Le Perigord twice to sample the bargain lunch, which for the entree includes a choice of veal in a light mustard sauce, boneless quail with shredded vegetables, or salmon in a white wine, tomato and herb sauce. (They were also offered on the usual lunch menu, which costs $29 for three courses but offers many more choices.) Without publicity on the promotion, "we would never have come here," Ms. Zeni said. "We had a perception that it was too much money."
Restaurant owners like the promotion because it draws customers without devaluing image, mainly because prestigious restaurants have joined in. A single restaurant, cutting prices, would not necessarily have benefited.
"If I would go out on my own, I would look as if I were discounting the restaurant," said George Briguet, the owner of Le Perigord, where weekday lunch business has increased to 150 diners a day from 40.
About a dozen restaurant owners who were interviewed said that they make little money on the $19.92 lunches because food costs take up a larger-than-usual portion of the price ultimately charged. Many restaurant owners aim to cover their food costs with 25 percent of the total bill, knowing they will profit because the balance of the price will be more than enough to cover costs for labor, rent, fuel, flowers and the like. In the bargain lunches, food costs often are as high as 40 percent of the check, leaving less to cover other expenses.
To keep food costs down, some chefs are trying new techniques. David Bouley, the chef and owner of Bouley, at 165 Duane Street, has already sold out the $19.92 lunch, which he is offering weekdays through August, using all organic ingredients and promoting the farms that provide them. He uses expensive ingredients like chanterelles on his regular menus, but the lower-priced menus rely more on things like celery. Using those ingredients but still meeting his usual standards, he said, requires cooking with "more love and effort."
Does the lower-priced lunch mean that restaurants could emerge from their doldrums if they simply lowered prices? The owners are trying to figure that out. Generally, they said that they make so little on the lunches that they need large volume to compensate, and that they are not sure the volume would continue if the lower prices were to become permanent.
Some restaurants stopped the promotion after the first week. "We were afraid we were going to alienate a lot of our regular guests who were finding it difficult to get reservations for lunch," said Danny Meyer, the owner of the Union Square Cafeat 21 East 16th Street, which was deluged with calls during the promotion.
The lower prices have prompted some to get out of the office and eat well. A group of editors from Dell Puzzle Magazine, after a lunch at the Sign of the Dove, said they would not have eaten there at regular prices. "We would have gotten a pizza," Stacey Peltz said.
William Barr, who was meeting friends from Florida at the Dove, said that they would have eaten there anyway, but that the price was an extra incentive. "With the economy the way it is, you look for things like this," said Mr. Barr, a retired banker.
To some extent, owners risk providing food at less profit to customers who would have eaten out anyway. When Randy Hynote decided to organize a business lunch last week at the Gotham Bar and Grill at 12 East 12th Street, he did not know it was offering the special. "I came here because it's excellent food," he said.
Sometimes, the bargain does not mean a lower check. Romita Shetty said she ate the special lunch at TriBeCa Grill and ended up with a higher-than-usual tab, because ordinarily she would not order three courses.
Indeed, belief in the bargain may be more important for some people than the actual saving of money. Some restaurants said the average check was only a dollar or two below the nonbargain average. Henny Santo, a co-owner of Sign of the Dove, said the restaurant usually has a lower-priced menu in its cafe, where a two-course lunch costs less than $19.92. But because of the promotion, which has forced a temporary suspension of the cafe lunch menu, business has grown substantially.
The pricier a restaurant, the more its business has tended to grow with the promotion. Gotham, which usually serves 70 people at weekday lunches, is serving 110. Le Madri, at 168 West 18th Street, which used to serve 70, is seating 150. Coco Pazzo, at 23 East 74th Street, which had served 35 to 50, is now serving 100. Montrachet, which used to serve 35 to 50 at lunch on Friday, the only day it opens for lunch, now does more than 140.
By the end of the month, the restaurants will figure out exactly what they have made in profits and whether they will continue the promotion. "We think we're making a little money, but we don't know," said Jerry Kretchmer, an owner of Gotham Bar and Grill. "Most important, it put a smile on everybody's face."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The $19.92 lunch has increased business at Le Perigord. (Lee Romero/The New York Times) (C10)

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Break Up the Unifieds? It's Now History

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The athletes of what is almost certainly the last Unified Team have returned after a triumphal Olympics, with their future no more certain than that of their varied homelands.
The supremacy of the Unified Team in Barcelona had a bittersweet feeling to many, as the last hollow victory of an intensive sports system and the totalitarian empire that spawned and funded such excellence. The huge governmental investment in socialist sport stemmed not from any love of athletic competition, but from the Cold War, and now it is gone. 
This was the first team from the former empire to train and perform with minimal government money, and the sudden commercialization that made the airline flights to Barcelona possible will not be enough to preserve the foundations of such superb performances: the local coaches and clubs, the centralized institutes of physical sport and science, the expensive central training centers for gymnasts, wrestlers and so many other specialist athletes.
For instance, Smirnoff, the American vodka company, which spent so much Western cash to sponsor the team, and whose repetitive advertisements on Russian television put so many local teeth on edge, is unlikely to support these teams in non-Olympic years. And except for large states like Russia and Ukraine, it is extremely doubtful that the other republics, like Kazakhstan or Kyrgyzstan, will spend much tax money on keeping up their superb, inherited sports facilities, or that Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan, where so many of the good weight lifters and wrestlers seem to come from, will worry much about them in the midst of ethnic warfare and economic chaos.
 
Going for Money
 Vitaly Shcherbo, the extraordinary Belarussian gymnast who won a record six gold medals in Barcelona and wore an old Soviet emblem on his jersey, summed up the new, commercial "one for one and all for one" spirit when he spoke of his plans in the West: "I'll go for the most money," he said. "We all will."
It is not that too many of the citizens of the former Soviet Union would blame him in the current economic climate, but it is yet one more measure of how empty the socialist ideal has become, and how confused people are about their patriotism, both topics for some sadness and irony here.
Commentators on the lengthy and much-watched Olympics television broadcasts had their favorites, speaking of "nashi komanda," or "our team," even when the Unified basketball team was playing Lithuania. One said, with some irony: "I wish our weight lifter will win. I want so much to hear the Moldovan national anthem."
Today's Sovetskaya Rossiya, under the headline, "Olympians of the Former U.S.S.R. Leave Undefeated," asked why the Unified Team was "the best" in Barcelona. "How could it happen that the athletes of the Unified Team, representing countries which are experiencing such political storms and economic difficulties, managed to perform better than the teams of the prosperous West?"
 
'The System Survived'
 The answer, the paper suggested, was not that the team found sponsors and solved its financial problems, or that there was some "new splash of patriotism." What really counted was that "in sports, counter to many other aspects of life, the system survived." This time, at least.
Pravda, the longtime organ of the Communist Party and now a mouthpiece for the conservative reaction here, had an extraordinary headline today: "The Cause of the New U.S.S.R. Combined Team Is Alive and Victorious." It was extraordinary because, after all, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is dead, however much mourned by Pravda, and this was not the U.S.S.R. Combined Team at all, since the Baltics are long gone. It was not even the Commonwealth of Independent States Team, since Georgia and Azerbaijan have not joined the Commonwealth but participated in the Unified Team.
Pravda went on to use the Unified Team's success as "a good example" for Commonwealth politicians. The athletes "really turned their team into a commonwealth without borders and differences, and proved that the cause of the U.S.S.R. Combined Team lives on victoriously," a hackneyed phrase normally used in olden days about the "cause" of the Communist Party.
 
Rivalries and Problems
 Beyond the obvious reservation that the people of Ukraine and the other independent states want to keep their new borders and even accentuate their differences, the team had its own rivalries and problems, though more among the sports bosses of the various states than among the athletes themselves.
Even before the Games began, Vitaly Smirnov, president of the Unified Team's Olympic committee, complained bitterly about nationalist politics interfering with the selection of team athletes, with some Ukrainian rhythmic gymnasts (one of whom won the gold) being chosen ahead of a Russian woman. In Barcelona, he finally said: "To the very last, let us be polite to each other."
Smirnov, before the Games, predicted flatly that the Unified Team would win 43 gold medals and win the medals table. In fact, the athletes of this great, dying institution of superb athletics and totalitarian politics won 45.
 
Celebration Becomes Disaster
 MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (AP) One spectator was killed and nine seriously injured when scaffolding collapsed during a welcoming ceremony for Estonia's Olympic team in its capital, Tallinn, according to reports from ITAR-Tass and Eta news agencies.
Dozens of people had climbed the scaffolding around a four-story building under renovation. They were seeking a good vantage point from which to cheer the return of the Olympic athletes from Barcelona.
Most of those injured in the accident Monday night were teen-agers.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Hampshire In Refunding

 BODY:
New Hampshire is tentatively offering $100.9 million of turnpike system revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. Proceeds will be used to refund bonds sold when interest rates were higher. 
 The maximum yield for the financing is about 6.206 percent for a 5.75 percent bond due in 2020 and offered at a price of 94. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 3.75 percent for an issue due in 1994 to 4.7 percent in 1997, 5.5 percent in 2002 and 6 percent in 2007.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 448 words

HEADLINE: Back on Track

 BODY:
Good for President Bush and Israel's new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin. Their cordial meeting in Kennebunkport opens the way to quick approval of $10 billion in U.S. loan guarantees for Israel and to real bargaining at regional peace talks, to resume on Aug. 24 in Washington. Every bit as important, civility has supplanted sour contention in an old, valued alliance.
The new mood was as evident as the smile on George Bush's face, and in his hospitable embrace of the plain-spoken hero of Israel's great victory in the 1967 war. 
 The President angered many American Jews last fall by refusing to approve the loan guarantees while Israel persisted in widespread expansion of Jewish settlements in disputed Arab territories. But in a June election fought on peace issues, Israelis punished the pro-settlement Likud Government and turned to Mr. Rabin's Labor party. Thus Washington and Jerusalem are on parallel tracks heading into a sixth round of Arab-Israeli peace talks.
Confirming the new mood was a welcome decision by Mr. Rabin's Government to seek the repeal of a law prohibiting people under its jurisdiction from making contact with the Palestine Liberation Organization. So objectionable is this vague law that even former Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir drew back from imposing criminal penalties on West Bank Palestinians who met openly with the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat.
Lifting that ban is the kind of conciliatory gesture long urged by Palestinians. So is the curtailment of new settlements by the Rabin Government. This means that the Arab side can no longer dwell interminably on Israeli inflexibility. The burden is now on Arabs to come up with serious, achievable proposals, beginning with interim autonomy arrangements for the West Bank and Gaza.
While parallel, American and Israeli purposes are not identical. There's plenty of room for differences about, say, "security" settlements, which Mr. Rabin strongly favors. But on two huge matters there is agreement: Israel's new Government accepts the idea of making genuine compromises for real peace, and it gives priority to investing in jobs and houses for Jewish immigrants from Russia and Ethiopia.
That has also been Mr. Bush's hope, for which he has been unfairly attacked. It was, after all, the Bush Administration that airlifted Jews from Ethiopia and changed U.S. immigration policies to encourage Soviet Jews to go directly to Israel. And Washington also orchestrated the successful campaign to rescind the detestable Zionism-is-racism resolution at the United Nations.
In all this, good politics and human decency have gone together; Mr. Bush has earned the right to take a bow.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Vice President;
Quayle Attacks Bar Association for Honoring Hill

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 11

 BODY:
A year after declaring war on the country's civil justice system, Vice President Dan Quayle renewed his assault on the American Bar Association today by criticizing the group for honoring Anita F. Hill, the Oklahoma law professor who accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment.
Mr. Quayle also used two public appearances here to assert that the Democrats remained beholden to special interests, specifically contending that Gov. Bill Clinton was "in the pocket" of the country's trial lawyers. As exhibit A in his case, Mr. Quayle, who is himself a lawyer, pointed to Hillary Clinton's speech on Sunday at the American Bar Association convention in nearby San Francisco, where Professor Hill was given an award. 
 "Most Americans, black and white, male and female, young and old, believed Clarence Thomas and not Anita Hill," Mr. Quayle said in a speech to the California chapter of the Christian Coalition. "That doesn't matter to the A.B.A. To them she is a heroine, because she led the attack against a man who happened to be conservative and black -- a combination that makes liberals fly into a rage.
"And who did they choose to present this award to liberalism's heroine for the 1990's? None other than her fellow lawyer, Mrs. Hillary Clinton," he added. Hisses swept through the hotel meeting room at the mention of Mrs. Clinton.
 
Kind Words for Hill
 "Well, it is very clear that the American bar leadership is just one more special interest group of the Democratic Party," Mr. Quayle continued. "We now know why Bill Clinton can never support legal reform."
Mr. Quayle was inaccurate in saying that Mrs. Clinton presented the award to Professor Hill. The wife of the Democratic Presidential nominee merely spoke at the luncheon, where the bar association presented six women with its Women Lawyers of Achievement Award.
But Mrs. Clinton, who is the immediate past chairwoman of association's commission on women, did have kind words for the professor. She said in her speech that Ms. Hill "transformed consciousness and changed history with her courageous testimony" about Judge Thomas during the hearings on his nomination to be a Supreme Court Justice.
Professor Hill was chosen for the award by the 12-member Commission on Women in the Profession. The award recognizes women lawyers who contribute to career opportunities for other women lawyers.
Ms. Hill was honored for her "impact on American society in general and on women lawyers in particular." A statement issued by the association when the award was presented did not take a position on whether Ms. Hill's accusations were true, but lauded her for speaking "eloquently and persuasively on behalf of millions of women who have been harassed in the workplace."
 
Revisiting an Old Issue
 A year ago, when the American Bar Association met in Atlanta, Mr. Quayle gave one of the most memorable speeches of his Vice Presidency, calling for significant changes in the civil litigation system. His proposals formed the foundation of a new policy direction for the Bush Administration.
In revisiting the issue today, Mr. Quayle made his fight with the bar association purely political, and he used Professor Hill and Mrs. Clinton as the vehicles for his attack.
"Obviously, if Hillary Clinton wants to be associated with Anita Hill, that's fine, that's her choice," Mr. Quayle said at a news conference after his speech. "But what it does show is that the Clinton Presidential campaign is clearly in the pocket of the American Bar Association leadership."
The Clinton campaign quickly responded to Mr. Quayle's comments.
"Everyone says stupid things sometimes, but Dan Quayle just does it more of the time than most," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director. "The President has no economic plan. All he can do is send Dan Quayle out to be his attack puppy."
In recent weeks, Mr. Quayle has asserted that the Democratic ticket of Mr. Clinton and Senator Al Gore would not be able to deliver the changes they promise because of ties to special interest groups like the National Education Association. Republicans have used that portrayal of the Democrats in past campaigns.
He also used self-deprecation to raise doubts about the Democrats' political views. "During that Democratic convention you probably heard it said 100 times that Bill Clinton and Al Gore are moderate," he said. "Ladies and gentlemen, if they're moderates, I'm a world champion speller."
Mr. Quayle turned down an invitation to speak to the bar association on Monday, even though he was close by, saying timing and conditions for a speech could not be worked out. But he derided the association's leadership from a distance not only for honoring Ms. Hill and opposing his proposals for overhauls, but also for failing to support a recent crime-fighting plan by Attorney General William P. Barr.
Last month, Mr. Barr issued a report calling on states to combat violent crimes with a variety of tough measures. The association's president, Talbot D'Alemberte, wrote to President Bush that the recommendations "ignore the broad societal context for violent crime."
In a statement today, Mr. D'Alemberte said "there seems to be a fundamental difference" between the association and the Bush Administration.
"The Vice President believes that the business of our justice system is business," he said. "We believe the business of our justice system is justice and we believe that justice should be available not just to the rich but to all Americans, and see nothing in the Vice President's proposals to accomplish that end."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Dan Quayle greeting young residents of a housing development in Sacramento, Calif., yesterday. (Associated Press)
