HEADLINE: U.S. Knew of Possible Survivors In Indochina, Reagan Aides Say

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Three top Reagan Administration officials responsible for tracking the cases of United States servicemen missing in Vietnam said today that the Government had known for nearly 20 years that some American prisoners of war may have been alive in Indochina when troops were withdrawn in 1973.
But in testimony to the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs the three officials expressed doubts that any prisoners remained alive in captivity now.
 
U.S. Lost Its Chance
 The officials, part of an Administration that sought to focus new attention on the issue in the 1980's, testified that they had always assumed that there were American prisoners of war alive in Indochina in 1973. They also charged that the United States lost its best chance of finding out what happened to all unaccounted-for Americans by not pressing the issue forcefully in the years immediately after its withdrawal from Indochina. 
 "In the period when the trail was hot, when there should have been a full-court press, the effort was less, not more," Lieut. Gen. Leonard H. Perroots, head of the Defense Intelligence Agency from 1985 to 1988, told the committee. He was referring to the Administrations of Richard M. Nixon, Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter.
The others who testified today were Richard T. Childress, a staff member on President Reagan's National Security Council, and Richard Armitage, a former Assistant Defense Secretary.
But officials of previous Administrations insist they did all they could to ascertain the status of American servicemen missing in Vietnam in the early 1970's, and they deny they were negligent in any way. [Page A6.]
In recent weeks, in many hours of testimony and through the declassification of more than a million Pentagon and White House documents now making their way into the public domain, the Senate committee has been developing a fuller account of the Government's handling of the missing servicemen.
But the picture still remains incomplete, and there is contradictory evidence. Despite the contradictions, what is gradually emerging, in the view of many members of the committee, are new details on nearly two decades of United States and Vietnamese actions and contacts giving greater credence to the claims of the families of missing Americans.
The United States lists 2,266 Americans as unaccounted for from the Vietnam War. About half of these are known to have died, but their remains have not been recovered. Of the rest, 130 to 135 fall into the category of prisoners who may have been alive in captivity in 1973, according to Defense Department officials and investigations by the Senate committee drawing on information about these servicemen's last known whereabouts.
It is this group that has become the focus of a new investigation into the issue of the missing. The status of the others is unknown, and they are listed as missing in action.
Over the years, many officials have suggested that there were American servicemen unaccounted for in Indochina, many of them pilots shot down during the war. But the statements today represented an unusual public confirmation at a time when the issue has re-emerged.
The issue of the missing has now been split effectively into two questions: how many people where unaccounted for in 1973, when American troops came home, and how many of this number might be living Americans who survived in captivity after that.
Several officials involved in accounting in the Nixon years have testified that while they knew prisoners had not returned as expected, they assumed virtually all had died at some point in captivity, although Vietnamese, Laotian and Cambodian officials never explained why they were not returned. Other officials disagree, saying that they believed prisoners did survive, though only one, Robert Garwood, a Marine, later came home.
 
Allusion to Vietnam Offer
 Mr. Childress raised the possibility in testimony today that Americans may have survived into the 1980's when he alluded to an offer said to have been made by Vietnam through a third country for the release of Americans in return for development aid. Mr. Childress said that the offer was "followed back to Vietnam" in the mid-1980's, but that there were no prisoners.
The committee chairman, Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, cut off further discussion of Mr. Childress's assertions and said the panel would hear the details in closed session.
This was the second report the committee had received of purported approaches by Vietnam in the 1980's through intermediary countries, suggesting the exchange of prisoners for money or pledges of aid.
A former State Department official close to the issue said in an interview today that offers like these have been appearing since the 1960's. All of them have been proved fraudulent, he said.
 
Hanoi Says All Returned
 Vietnam has always insisted it returned all prisoners in 1973. It has returned several hundred sets of remains since then.
In a summing up of recent testimony on Government actions on the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue and the private interventions of Ross Perot, who made several trips to Indochina in search of information on the missing, Senator Kerry said that "there is really no mystery about where this cry of conspiracy comes from."
"This issue that has haunted America for 20 years has not haunted it falsely," he said, after General Perroots, Mr. Childress and Mr. Armitage, who now heads the relief program for the ex-Soviet republics, all said that there had been no full accounting for servicemen in 1973 and that there has still been no full accounting today.
In a key exchange, Senator Kerry said, "So if it's true that we do not have a full accounting as we sit here today in 1992, it has to be equally as true that we did not have a full accounting in 1973 when we left Vietnam; is that true?" All three officials agreed.
They added that they had been saying this for years, in meetings and speeches to family groups. They welcomed the declassification of documents, saying that secrecy had only contributed to allegations of cover-ups from the P.O.W.-M.I.A. lobby and accusations from others that the issue of the missing was a political campaign without foundation in fact.
Henry A. Kissinger, who was President Nixon's national security adviser in 1973, said Tuesday on the ABC News program "Nightline" that he had never been satisfied with Vietnam's accounting for the missing, although President Nixon announced on March 29 of that year that all prisoners were home. In "Years of Upheaval," his memoirs covering that period, Mr. Kissinger wrote of taking 80 names of missing Americans to Indochina in the the summer of 1973 to ask officials to account for them.
In several months of testimony and extensive investigation, the Senate Select Committee has produced a list of 133 names of people who were reliably reported to be in captivity in Vietnam or Laos in 1973, but who did not come home in prisoner exchanges.
The Defense Department has a similar list of 135 "discrepancy cases," where there is enough information about the last known location of apparently live Americans to suggest that Hanoi knows what happened to them.
"Vietnam can easily account for hundreds of Americans," Mr. Childress, who made a number of trips to Hanoi in the 1980's, told the committee today. He added that he believed there were "elements in the politburo" who had decided not to cooperate more.
Mr. Armitage, a fluent Vietnamese speaker who spent four years in South Vietnam during the war and also led delegations to Hanoi, said that to make headway on the resolution of cases believed to be soluble, "the Governments of Vietnam and Laos, and what passes for the Government of Cambodia, will have to open up and give us full access to their records."
Unanswered questions about the missing are the chief reason Washington has not normalized relations with Vietnam or lifted an economic embargo against Hanoi.
The three Reagan Administration officials said they had no hard evidence that Americans remained alive in Indochina now, but all added that they believed it was possible. They said some servicemen might have stayed behind of their own volition and could account for some if not all of the live sightings of people identified as Americans in recent years.
"I don't think there's an organized, institutionalized effort to hold a lot of people," said General Perroots.
Mr. Armitage said: "There are Americans in Indochina. I don't know the circumstances. They may be living freely."
The officials said there had been no conspiracy by the Government to cover up evidence of living Americans. But General Perroots said there were times when the Government should have worked harder to resolve the question of the missing.
The Reagan Administration years were critical to the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue because the White House gave considerable encouragement to family groups and other lobbyists who sought to give the problem a high political profile.
Critics of the policy say that the Reagan Administration raised false hopes, while actually doing little to solve the problem.
As the committee's work has clarified some questions, it has also produced new conflicting accounts. On Tuesday, for example, Mr. Perot and McMurtrie Godley, a former United States Ambassador to Laos, presented diametrically opposed accounts of a briefing for Mr. Perot at the United States Embassy in Vientiane in 1970. Both were under oath. Today in closed session, the Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Laos at the time was reported to have supported the Ambassador's recollections.
Though Mr. Armitage and Mr. Perot both say they believe that prisoners remained in Indochina when the United States withdrew its troops, they have disagreed over whether Americans are still in captivity. Mr. Perot, who takes the position that many Americans are still prisoners, has waged a campaign to discredit Mr. Armitage and his handling of the issue during the Reagan years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "In the period when the trail was hot, when there should have been a full-court press, the effort was less, not more," said Lieut. Gen. Leonard H. Perroots, former head of the Defense Intelligence Agency, of the Government's failure to act on finding out what happened to all Americans unaccounted for. He appeared before a Senate committee. (George Tames for The New York Times) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: The Trade Accord;
ECONOMIC ACCORD REACHED BY U.S., MEXICO AND CANADA TO LOWER TRADE BARRIERS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The United States, Canada and Mexico today formally announced a comprehensive plan for free trade across North America and portrayed it as an opportunity for greater economic growth for all three nations.
The agreement was greeted enthusiastically by business groups generally, although some American executives complained about last-minute concessions by American negotiators. 
 But American labor unions, which have long opposed opening the Southern border, continued to contend that the accord would send jobs to Mexico.
President Bush said the agreement -- which is subject to legislative approval in all three countries -- protects America's place in the world by creating jobs and economic growth.
 
Challenge for the U.S.
 "The cold war is over," he said at a news conference today. "The principal challenge now facing the United States is to compete in a rapidly changing, expanding global marketplace."
The key elements of the free trade agreement are these:
*Eliminating customs duties on tens of thousands of products.
*Setting up obstacles to prevent Asian and European companies from bypassing American tariffs by shipping goods through Mexico.
*Opening Mexico's banking, insurance and securities industries.
*Creating panels to resolve commercial environmental disputes.
 
Enlarging the Markets
 The accord is meant to give consumers of all three nations a wider variety of goods at lower prices and to make American industry more competitive by enlarging its markets. It is also intended to enrich the Mexican economy and to give greater access to Mexican markets to Canada while protecting its 1988 free trade agreement with the United States.
Mexico saw the agreement as a symbolic stride in its march away from decades of protectionism and poverty. It has prepared an elaborate lobbying campaign in the United States to work for its passage. [Page D4.]
In Canada, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney began his campaign to sell closer North American ties to a skeptical Canadian public. [Page D5.]
The accord, reached after 14 months of negotiation, will create a regional trading bloc of 370 million people producing $6 trillion worth of goods and services each year, more than the European Community. The success of the 12-nation European Community in lowering customs duties and stimulating regional trade partly inspired the negotiations that led to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The agreement immediately became an issue in the United States Presidential and Congressional campaigns. Minutes after the President's news conference, one of his campaign officials criticized Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential candidate, for disparaging the agreement in recent weeks.
"He waffles and wiggles all over on a North American Free Trade Agreement -- he's in the pocket of labor," said Torie Clarke, the campaign's chief spokeswoman.
Mr. Clinton said today that he would review how the agreement affected labor and environmental standards before taking a position.
"We do need a new agreement with Mexico; we need to do that," he said while leaving a meeting of the American Federation of Teachers in Detroit. "I want to see whether this meets those standards or whether there's some suggestions we ought to make for other things that need to be done either within or outside the agreement."
 
Review by Lawyers
 Administration officials said today that lawyers were still going over the accord and that they would not be able to release a full text for several weeks. This logistical difficulty meant that Administration officials were able to announce American gains from the agreement without allowing opponents to pore over the document for clauses that would hurt specific industries.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, said late Tuesday that the Finance Committee, which he heads, would hold hearings on the agreement this fall. Republicans and Democrats expect the hearings to produce a bruising debate over the nation's economic future in the middle of an election campaign.
Congress is expected to approve the agreement next year if President Bush is re-elected, but only after a lengthy legislative battle. If Mr. Clinton is elected, the battle could be longer if he adds his own provisions, but approval is still considered likely.
The legislation putting the agreement's provisions into law is likely to include new programs to retrain workers who lose their jobs because of imports, as well as new programs to clean up environmental hazards and build highways and bridges along the border with Mexico.
The Administration has not said how it proposes to pay for these programs. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat and House majority leader, has proposed a tax on cross-border transactions, but the Administration opposes the idea as likely to inhibit trade.
Mr. Clinton has not said whether he would try to reopen the negotiations if he won the election. But he has suggested that the agreement should do more to protect American workers and the environment.
 
Endorsements From Business
 Many business executives and their lobbyists were quick to endorse the accord today. M. Peter McPherson, the Bank of America's executive vice president for Latin America and Canada, welcomed the agreement as allowing American banks to begin competing in Mexico after decades of restrictions. "This gives us the authority to open new banks in Mexico that can borrow pesos and lend pesos," he said.
Kay R. Whitmore, the chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company, said, "It could unleash a surge of trading activity with Mexico, already our third-largest trading partner and fastest-growing export market."
John F. Akers, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, said the pact "holds great promise for the development and growth" of North America.
 
Complaints on Autos
 But Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said the plan made it too easy for Japanese and European competitors to bypass American customs duties by manufacturing cars and trucks in Mexico.
And oilfield equipment makers like the LTV Corporation were dismayed that American negotiators allowed Mexico's giant state-owned oil and electricity monopolies to move slowly in buying more from American and Canadian companies.
Labor unions contended that the agreement could encourage American businesses to move factories and jobs to Mexico. Thomas R. Donohue, the secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., told a news conference this morning that the accord would lead more American companies to set up factories in northern Mexico to take advantage of low wages there.
"There are 600,000 jobs along the Mexican border that used to be U.S.-based jobs," Mr. Donohue said.
 
A Long Wait for Benefits
 The benefits of the agreement will not become apparent to consumers for years. Under an existing American program, nearly half of all imports from Mexico enter duty-free, and this will barely change when the agreement goes into effect, most likely on Jan. 1, 1994. The main exception lies in apparel, for which tariffs will be eliminated immediately on a few garments -- like T-shirts -- that are scarcely produced in the United States and are currently imported from East Asia.
The highly protected textile and apparel industries were divided on the agreement. Some companies condemned it as leading to more low-wage competition while others praised it as an alternative to a worldwide reduction in protection for these industries under the auspices of the Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Roger Milliken, the chairman of Milliken & Company, a large textile producer based in Spartanburg, S.C., criticized the agreement for "seeking to make us more competitive by forcing the shift of the higher-paying jobs of American workers to other countries where wages, and therefore costs, are far less."
The Mexican products facing the highest American tariffs are agricultural commodities, and the tariffs on them will fall very slowly. Farm goods account for all but 3 of the 14 products put into the category for slowest removal of American tariffs, with duties not disappearing entirely for 15 years. Many of these duties now approach 100 percent.
 
More in the Supermarket
 Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said American consumers would have more choices in supermarkets as the tariffs fell. "It means that if you want to get a cantaloupe a couple of months later than you can get one down at your Safeway this morning, that will be an opportunity afforded to you," she said.
The American tariff on cantaloupes, which averaged 43.4 percent last year, will be among the few duties eliminated over 15 years because of lobbying by American producers.
The biggest surprise today concerned rules for determining which cars and light trucks would qualify for duty-free treatment under the agreement. Mexico and Canada wanted to require that only 50 percent of the value of a car be produced in North America, to encourage Japanese and European companies to set up factories in those countries to supply the United States market.
The United States sought a requirement of 70 percent, but settled for a gradual increase over eight years, to 62.5 percent from 50 percent. Julius Katz, a deputy United States trade representative, said that the figure was acceptable because it came with stringent rules for counting which parts are made in North America.
The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association nonetheless criticized the same provision of the agreement for being too restrictive.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, with the delegates from Mexico and Canada, Dr. Jaime Serra Puche, right, and Michael H. Wilson, after announcing a free trade agreement yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A1)
 
Chart: "Provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement"
 The free trade agreement negotioated by the United States, Canada and Mexico will bind their economies together in a regional trading bloc with more people and more economic output than the European Community. Here are the accord's principle provisions:
 
Advertising
 Each country's laws and regulations will treat all advertising agencies in North America equally. Mexico will allow American and Canadian companies to do business without setting up local offices and hiring local staff.
 
Agriculture
 Duties on all farm products will be phased out, some quickly, some over 15 years.
 
Autos
 Over 10 years, Mexico's complicated system for requiring a rough balance in the import and export of cars and car parts will be phased out. So will tariffs on cars and trucks. But at least half the value of a car, rising to 62.5 percent over eight years, must be built in North America for it to qualify for duty-free treatment.
 
Banking
 U.S. and Canadian banks will immediately be allowed to acquire Mexican banks accounting for as much as 8 percent of the industry's capital. All limits on bank ownership will be removed by Jan. 1, 2000.
 
Disputes
 Special judges will be empaneled to resolve disagreements on matters like fishing rights, government subsidies, environmental regulations and other trade laws.
 
Energy
 Mexico will pay performance bonuses to successful oil exploration companies, but will still bar foreign ownership of oilfields.
 
Environment
 Dispute panels on most environmental issues will have precedence over international panels. Suggestions by environmentalists for a tax on trade to pay for cleanup along the Mexican border were not incorporated in the agreement.
 
Food Safety
 Countries will be allowed to challenge each others' safety standards if they can prove that the standaards discriminate against a country's products.
 
Government Contracts
 Mexico's many state-owned enterprises and Government agencies currently reserve virtually all their contracts for Mexican companies. The pact will limit this reserve to half the contracts at first, falling to 30 percent over 8 years, and zero after 10 years.
 
Insurance
 U.S. and Canadian companies will be allowed to take over insurance companies in which they already hold minority stakes. All limits will be removed on Jan. 1, 2000.
 
Jobs
 The agreement makes no provisions for job assurance, ignoring demands from some labor unions and Congressional Democrats for changes in Mexican minimum wage and worker safety laws. The Bush Administration is crafting a separate program to help workers who lose their jobs because of the pact.
 
Securities Firms
 U.S. and Canadian firms will be able to buy companies accounting for as much as 10 percent of the Mexican industry's capital. All limits will be removed on Jan, 1, 2000.
 
Tariffs
 Customs duties on nearly 10,000 products will be elimated, either immediately or in stages over as long as 15 years.
 
Temporary Work Visas
 Corporate executives and some professionals from all three countries will be able to live and work anywhere in North America with fewer bureaucratic formalities. The rules are narrowly written to prevent large-scale immigration to the United States from Mexico.
 
Textiles
 Garments will qualify for duty-free treatment only in the yarn is made, the cloth is woven, and all cutting and sewing are done in North America. Canada has won a partial exemption from the rule.
 
Trucking
 U.S., Mexican and Canadian trucking companies will be allowed to do business on cross-border routes that are now forbidden.

Carla A. Hills
 United States trade representative, age 58.
 Member of the Cabinet in charge of trade policy, in office since 1989. Previously a partner in Weil, Gotshal & Manges law firm. Chairwoman of Urban Institute, 1983-88. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Ford Administration.
 
Jaime Serra Puche
 Mexico's Secretary of Commerce and Industrial Promotion, age 41.
 Appointed 1988. Oversaw deregulation of the transport and packaging industries. Reduced controls on foreign investment. Economic consultant to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's transition team. Ph.D. in economics from Yale.
 
Michael H. Wilson
 Canada's Minister for International Trade and Minister of Industry, Science and Technology, age 54.
 Appointed to both positions in 1991. Finance Minister, 1984-1991. Member of Parliament from Toronto since 1979. Executive vice president, Dominion Securities, 1973-79.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis;
As Simple as Life Itself

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Republican Party has staked out "family values" as a principal theme this year, a way of reconnecting with voters who are no longer enamored of the Republicans' handling of the economy.
But the issue is not as simple as party strategists might have expected. It is playing out in the political debate, and in the culture at large, in complicated and unpredictable ways. And the Democrats, who watched Republicans run away with the politics of values in the 1980's, are determined not to let it happen again. 
 President Bush ran into the dangerous intersection of the personal and the political in an NBC interview broadcast Tuesday night. The staunchly anti-abortion President was presented with a hypothetical test of his "family values": a pregnant granddaughter who came to him and insisted on having an abortion.
Some who watched Mr. Bush's response, in which he said he would try to dissuade her but would ultimately "stand by my child," saw a loving paterfamilias with strong political principles but also a heart.
Others, however, saw a man committed to outlawing abortion for other men's daughters and granddaughters but not willing to foreclose it for his own. Advocates of abortion rights heard Mr. Bush's statement that in the end it would be the woman's decision ("Well, whose else's -- who else's -- could it be?") and replied, exactly so.
James Carville, a top strategist for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential nominee, asserted: "I think when voters read that they think: 'Well, of course if George Bush's granddaughter needed an abortion, she could get it. But what about me?' "
Perhaps. No one quite knows how voters will react to hypothetical situations that cut so close to home, that test both their ideals of what family life should be and their messier realities. They are sharply divided on whether Washington should even be in the business of "upholding traditional family values," according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll in June; 52 percent said it should, 41 percent said it should not.
Sam Popkin, a professor at the University of California at San Diego, who is advising the Clinton campaign, argues that most Americans fall into the "ambivalent middle" on these issues. They want abortion to be legal, he says, but they do not want it presented as as a "good." (Thus Mr. Clinton's assertion, "I am not pro-abortion; I am pro-choice.")
 
The Two-Parent Ideal
 They feel two-parent families are the ideal, but "recognize life doesn't always work out that way." They felt some empathy for Murphy Brown, the television character who recently became an unwed mother and drew Vice President Dan Quayle's fire.
The Republicans counter that the Democrats are only using middle-of-the-road oratory to mask a hard left agenda. That was the message coming today from Richard N. Bond, chairman of the Republican National Committee. As the Republicans prepared for their Aug. 17-20 convention in Houston, Mr. Bond assailed Hillary Clinton, a lawyer who has long worked and written on children's legal issues, as someone who "has likened marriage and the family to slavery."
At the same time, the Republicans were working on a draft of their platform that extols "the fine example of family values and family virtue as lived by the President and the First Lady." And the Republicans were preparing for an unusual address to the convention Wednesday night by Barbara Bush -- on the subject of family values, of course.
 
Of Hearth and Home
 Mrs. Bush, whose poll ratings far exceed her husband's, has become an icon of traditional wife and motherhood, and Republicans clearly see her as an enormous asset, a kind of super-endorsement of her husband's emotional and home life. They also like the contrast with Mrs. Clinton, a partner in a major Little Rock law firm who spent weeks last spring trying to recover from an offhand, dismissive remark in defense of her legal career: "I suppose I could have stayed home and baked cookies and had teas."
Will attacks on Mrs. Clinton highlight her vulnerabilities, or offend voters' sense of another family value -- that a candidate's spouse ought to be out of the line of fire? Mr. Clinton seemed to be appealing to that sense today, asserting, "For them to try to take her life and career and twist it around, it's sort of sad."
The principal risk for the Republican leaders over the next 10 days, however, is that they extol "family values" in a way that pleases their party's right flank, but leaves the middle unmoved. The convention features a lineup of staunch conservatives like the Rev. Pat Robertson, who will speak on family night, and the party's platform is taking a tough line on such social issues as abortion.
Still, Mr. Bush himself may be reaching for the "ambivalent middle."
The Republican platform writers were putting the party on record this week against laws that recognize same-sex marriage and attempts to "include sexual preference as a protected minority receiving preferential status." But Mr. Bush was taking a more personal and conciliatory line with Stone Phillips, the reporter for NBC News, Tuesday night, in response to another hypothetical occurrence: a grandchild who came home and informed him that he or she was gay.
"I would love that child," he said. Mr. Bush went on to say that he would hope that the child would not advocate that life style, or propose that "same-sex marriage is a normal way of life." But he reiterated, "I would love that person."
He was picking his way carefully through the minefield between the personal and the political.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Convention City;
In No Mood to Party, Houston Awaits the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The official poster for the Republican National Convention features a rodeo cowboy atop a huge bull with the Houston skyline in the background. A safe choice? Not in a city that has struggled with its identity for a decade and now, grappling with a series of setbacks, is in a grumpy mood as it prepares to host the President and his party.
The poster caused a tiff over whether the Wild West image was the right one for a major city of the 1990's that is trying to lift its flat economy by promoting itself as a sophisticated international business center. 
 Like much of the nation, Houston has been vexed by a stubborn recession, but the downturn struck here just as the city was beginning to recover from the devastating collapse of oil prices in the 1980's. Now large-scale layoffs by major employers regularly make headlines. The Houstonian Hotel, President Bush's nominal Texas residence, is in bankruptcy.
After several startling murders last year, the city dumped a 10-year incumbent mayor, Kathryn J. Whitmire, in favor of Bob Lanier, a businessman who campaigned almost exclusively on a promise to put more police on the streets.
Even the weather has been demanding: record-setting rainfalls have caused extensive flooding since winter.
"The Republican convention is coming to Houston at a time of greater pessimism than at any time in the city's recent history, including the depths of the oil bust," said Stephen L. Klineberg, a professor of sociology at Rice University, "and that's bound to color not only how the convention is received but also how the city votes in November."
There are few signs that the general public is getting excited about the convention. Certainly there is little of the stir that accompanied the July 1990 Economic Summit here, an event that turned into a civic celebration of the city's emergence from the oil bust.
"Folks are so distracted with their own concerns that what appears to be a very predictable convention is virtually irrelevant," said John Mixon, a law professor at the University of Houston. "I plan simply to avoid the traffic."
Long known for the overriding optimism of its wildcatting spirit, Houston is grappling with anxieties that began with short-term economic problems and extended into a general uneasiness about the future.
 
Identity Problem
 "Before it cratered, the petroleum industry drove this city, defined it, for such a long time that it'll be years before something else comes along to take its place as the thing that makes Houston unique," said Michel Halbouty, 83 years old and the city's senior independent oilman.
"Getting hit by a recession right when we were climbing out of a hole has undoubtedly diminished Houston's can-do spirit," Mr. Halbouty said. "It's by no means gone, but it has been challenged."
Arguments over what image to project are almost inevitable in a city uncertain about its prospects. "There's lots of talk about the poster because plenty of Houstonians think the cowboy thing can be overplayed when we really need to be promoting ourselves as a sophisticated, international city," said Dancie Perugini Ware, a prominent public relations executive.
The poster hubbub was elevated to the level of public debate last Sunday when the lead editorial in The Houston Chronicle derided "all the cringing" over the poster, and argued, "We aren't cowboys, but to say we have not inherited a strong Texas tradition is nonsense."
 
Charting a City's Mood
 In what may be the most extensive tracking of any city's moods, Mr. Klineberg has conducted a public opinion survey in the Houston metropolitan area every year since 1982, through boom and bust, recovery and recession. This year's Houston Area Survey produced a statement of profound apprehension about an unpredictable future.
The surveys have involved samples of 412 to 679 people and have a margin of sampling error of four percentage points.
In March 1982, just before a series of oil price cuts sent Houston into a tailspin, 76 percent of the respondents to the survey rated job opportunities as excellent or good. By 1987, with the city in the depths of the oil market collapse, 87 percent said the opportunities were fair or poor. In 1990, with the recovery well under way, opinions were almost evenly split between optimists and pessimists. But evidence of gloom returning showed up in the survey taken last February, when 65 percent said job opportunities were fair or poor and only 29 percent judged them favorable.
"Coming back from disaster, Houston had one of the fastest-growing economies in the country from 1989 through most of 1991," said Ray Perryman, an economic consultant and forecaster based in Waco, Tex. "But along the way the Houston economy became a lot more like the national economy, and so it became vulnerable to national recessions."
The oil industry, especially the exploration and production sectors, never completely rebounded from the bust. Domestic drilling is now at a 30-year low. Instead, Houston has developed new industries, especially in health care and high technology, and has expanded production of chemicals and plastics. Energy accounted for more than 60 percent of the Houston economy during the boom, but its share is now less than 30 percent, Mr. Perryman said.
Houston, which in 1989 added 97,000 jobs to its economy, will add 4,000 jobs this year, Mr. Perryman predicted.
"Houston is experiencing a flat economy, not the severe downturns you see on both coasts, and in many ways it is well positioned to come out of the recession stronger than other cities," he said. "I don't hear the optimism that was quite striking a couple of years ago. There were high expectations that the bad times were past and a new era of growth had begun. Now people are disappointed."

HEADLINE: Selling Jets to Saudis a Tough Issue for Bush

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
President Bush is facing a decision to sell advanced F-15 fighter planes to Saudi Arabia, an issue fraught with election-year politics as well as sensitive foreign policy considerations.
The question of whether to proceed with the $5 billion sale of 72 of the warplanes has been percolating for months. But it was brought to the fore on Tuesday after Senator Christopher (Kit) Bond, a Missouri Republican, urged Mr. Bush during a White House meeting to move quickly on the sale. 
 Congressional supporters of the sale quickly spread the word that Mr. Bush had responded that the sale was under serious consideration. Administration officials said later, however, that no decision had been made.
What is clear is that proponents of the sale believe that the coming Presidential election, as well as the Administration's decision to grant loan guarantees to the Israelis, make this the moment to move. Defense companies, union officials and Congressional proponents of the sale have mounted a major lobbying effort.
Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel announced on Tuesday that they had agreed on a long-delayed package of $10 billion in loan guarantees to help the Israelis resettle immigrants from the former Soviet Union.
Administration officials said today that in their discussions in Maine on Monday, Mr. Rabin persuaded Mr. Bush that "he had set new priorities of national interests that shift the settlement policy significantly."
Mr. Rabin also met today with Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee. Mr. Clinton told Mr. Rabin that he supported the agreement on loan guarantees to Israel and he stressed that his election would not mean that the continuity of the relationship between the two countries would be harmed.
"I conveyed to the Prime Minister my intense desire not to let the partisan difficulties of the election here in the United States to in any way impede the peace process," Mr. Clinton said after the meeting.
Under the agreement worked out with Israel on the loan guarantees, the United States can deduct whatever money Israel spends on settlements from that year's guarantees. Officials said Mr. Bush and Mr. Rabin agreed that this "deductibility" would not begin until after the first year.
They also agreed that the "deductibility" would not apply to certain kinds of construction, which are to be defined in a side agreement between the two governments and could include settlements that Israel can demonstrate are needed for its security, settlements in East Jerusalem, and things like roads that can be used by both Arabs and Jews.
The roots of the debate over the possible sale of new F-15 aircraft to Saudi Arabia go back to early this year when Saudi Arabia formally asked to buy 48 F-15E and 24 F-15H planes.
The F-15E is an advanced air-to-ground attack configuration of the F-15, which the Air Force used during the gulf war. The F-15H is a two-seat version of the air-to-air version of the fighter.
If the Administration decides that the sale should be made, it could involve the sale of a somewhat less capable versions of the aircraft to try to mollify critics.
McDonnell Douglas, the Missouri-based defense company that builds the F-15, has been eager to see the sale go through. The company has no new orders for F-15's and unless foreign sales are made it will have to shut its production line. Already, 1,000 of its workers have been laid off as the production of F-15 fighters has decreased and as the sale of commercial airliners has declined, company officials say.
McDonnell Douglas officials assert that subcontractors will be hit harder. Company officials claim that 20,000 aerospace jobs could be lost by next year, if the Administration does not approve the F-15 sale this summer. Richard Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who serves as House majority leader, and 25 other lawmakers sent Mr. Bush an letter on Aug. 5 urging the President to proceed expeditiously with the sale to avert "thousands of lay-offs" and warning that the Saudis may buy British Tornadoes if the United States refuses to sell F-15's.
In recent weeks, it appeared as if the Administration would wait until after the election to approve the sale, which McDonnell Douglas insists would come too late to avert some lay-offs. But proponents of the sale have seen the Administration's decision to approve loan guarantees to Israel as an opportunity to seek a quick White House endorsement of the sale.
The loan guarantees, proponents insist, will insulate the Bush Administration from criticism from pro-Israel lawmakers, if the White House proceeds with the sale. And the election-year focus on the economy, they say, will raise the political cost of not approving the sale.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The U.S., Canada and Mexico formally announced a free trade pact that will create a market of 370 million people producing $6 trillion worth of goods and services each year -- surpassing the European Community. Leaders portrayed it as an opportunity for greater economic growth for all three nations, and business generally cheered it -- with some exceptions. [Page A1.]
Mexico celebrated the pact as transporting it from poverty and protectionism into life as a developed land. [D4.] 
 Canadian business welcomed the pact, but Prime Minister Brian Mulroney faces a tough task in selling it to the public with both labor and the political opposition fighting it. [D5.]
 
The Economy
Scientific research by American business is stagnating, the National Science Board said. It recommended tough steps, including Government action, to compete internationally. [D1.]
Inflation remained on a short leash last month, Labor Department figures showed. Prices received by producers for finished goods rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, as energy prices fell for the first time in six months, and food prices held steady. [D1.]
Two Government lawyers said they were in a twilight zone professionally as a result of Senate testimony Tuesday. Jacqueline P. Taylor and Bruce Pederson questioned the Federal commitment to recover money from officials of failed savings institutions. [D1.]
The Senate rejected a cut in capital gains taxes sponsored by Republicans, as it quit for three weeks without completing action on enterprise zone legislation prompted by the Los Angeles riots. [D2.]
With chemical spills and blizzards more likely menaces than nuclear attacks, the F.C.C. is on the verge of overhauling the nation's Emergency Broadcast System. [D2.]
 
Companies
The House voted to curb the ability of American and United to dominate the airline industry through their computerized reservations systems, which are used by travel agents. [D6.]
Warren E. Buffett has raised his Wells Fargo stake to 10.75 percent, from 9.7 percent, filings with the S.E.C. show. [D6.]
G.E. plans to test market a credit card and may try to gain a foothold in the fiercely competitive credit card business by offering consumers discounts on G.E. appliances. [D12.]
Datek Securities has been suspended for 90 days by the N.A.S.D. The Staten Island market maker was accused of having abused the Small Order Execution System. The firm laid off 50 people, leaving only a skeleton staff. [D8.]
 
Markets
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 10.27 points to end at 3,320.83 as a late decline in bond prices put pressure on stocks. Big Board losers narrowly outpaced gainers 911 to 788. [D8.]
The bond market took a breather after its two-day rally, and the yield on the long bond was unchanged at 7.31 percent. [D15.]
Precious metal futures plunged on fear of renewed recession raised by persistent weakness in raw materials prices. Gold fell $8.70 to $338.60 a troy ounce. [D16.] The dollar was mixed. [D16.]

HEADLINE: Saving a Silver Screen in Jersey City

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 7

 BODY:
In 1939 moviegoers sat mesmerized before the 50-foot screen at the Loew's Jersey theater as Atlanta burned nightly in "Gone With the Wind." In 1967, thousands lined up beneath the theater's glittering marquee for tickets to "Dr. Zhivago."
Today a new generation of viewers gathered in the lobby of the now-closed Loew's Jersey movie palace, where a $4 million fund-raising effort is under way to save the 63-year-old theater. The city hopes a first-run "big screen" theater and performing arts center will open here in 1994. 
 "This is going to become, we expect, one of the better-known major entertainment venues in the metropolitan area," said Colin Egan, a member of the recently formed board of the Jersey City Center for the Performing Arts. "This is the ultimate in the entertainment experience. There's nothing like it anymore in this area. The building itself is a marketing tool."
 
A Mere Glimmer
 Seated just beyond the usually boarded front doors, visitors to a limited schedule of exhibition showings caught a mere glimmer of the Loew's majesty. Beyond its gilded promenade-ringed lobby, the theater itself sits in baroque splendor, with a universe of plaster cherubs and gold-leaf foliage climbing 90 feet to the chandeliers in its domed ceiling.
In 1973, Loew's was divided with unadorned sheetrock into three viewing rooms, which operated until 1986. Filthy, unlighted and uncarpeted, the cavernous auditorium sits neglected, suspended in time like a cathedral in a war zone.
The Loew's is one of three "movie palaces" standing within sight of one another on Jersey City's Journal Square, symbols of an era of glamour and bustle in a city that once came alive at night. Today, only Loew's stands a chance of returning to its former glory: the Stanley theater now belongs to the Jehovah's Witnesses and the State was gutted and modernized before it closed several years ago.
Despite its obvious need for restoration, the 3,300-seat Loew's is well preserved.
"It's probably the finest surviving movie palace not only in the state but in the whole New York-New Jersey area," said Bob Furmanek, an archivist involved in the restoration.
Saving the Loew's actually is as much an economic crusade as it is a nostalgic one. In 1986 Hartz Mountain Industries, a major local developer, bought the theater, which it planned to tear down as part of a full-scale redevelopment of Journal Square. The plan included condemning neighboring properties, which touched off opposition from merchants.
Theater activists joined the fight against Hartz and ultimately were successful when the changing economy stalled new building. In 1988, Hartz agreed to give up the theater in exchange for substantial tax abatements if $4 million could be raised for its restoration by December 1992.
Jersey City pledged $1 million to the project and is expected to offer an additional $2 million at its Aug. 19 council meeting. A state historic preservation grant provided another $1 million.
While many in the city agreed that the Loew's should be saved as a landmark, some questioned whether the troubled city should be in the business of bailing out such a speculative project.
"It's such a tricky thing, revitalizing an area that has turned into a strip of junk stores," said Sebastian D'Elia, an aide to Acting Mayor Joseph Rakowski. "I think this could be a step in the right direction. It's a good thing, but definitely not the only thing we need."
 
Business Isn't Enough
 Theater proponents say business development alone will not revitalize the blighted local economy. They say entertainment and night life are critical now, just as they were in 1929 when Loew's was built and Journal Square was a commercial and transportation hub.
"The thought of saving Journal Square by tearing down this and putting up an office complex just isn't going to work," said Mr. Egan of the arts center board. "It's not enough. We have to re-evaluate what it takes to revive an area and if everyone who comes here only stays from 9 to 5, that won't do it."
Mr. Egan, a public relations consultant and historian who has become a full-time volunteer for the theater project, said the loss of the Loew's would leave a deep scar on Journal Square, as well as on the psyche of Jersey City.
"You could never do this again today," he said. "The guys who did this got paid cents an hour for their work. They did not reap monetary rewards for their labor."
"If you destroy all of this, take it away," he said, "then it's as if they never lived at all."

HEADLINE: THE TRADE ACCORD;
An Outsider Nation at Last Arrived, Mexico Is Embracing the Agreement

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Mexico celebrated its negotiation of a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada today as a great symbolic stride in its march from decades of protectionism and poverty to a future in the developed world.
Then, Government officials turned to what they described as the larger challenge of selling the agreement to a divided and skeptical nation. They meant the United States. 
 Although freer trade promises more drastic changes for Mexico than for either of its new partners, wide public support for the accord and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's overwhelming political control make its approval a formality here. Only the Mexican Senate will vote on the treaty, and members of Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party hold 61 of its 64 seats.
North of the border, however, Mexican officials foresee intense political struggle that may turn on their ability to convey the image of a poor neighbor transformed: a country brimming with economic opportunities and environmental concern, and determined to leave behind its corrupt and authoritarian past.
 
Lobbying on a Huge Scale
 And though no one expects this to be an easy sell, the Salinas administration and its many lobbyists in Washington have fashioned what appears likely to be one of the most elaborate efforts at political persuasion ever undertaken in America by a foreign country.
"There is going to be a very big campaign in the United States," said a Mexican official who, like several others, would discuss the effort only on the condition that he not be identified. "We have the plans, the strategies, the tactics. We have only been waiting for the product."
Long before trade negotiations ended, Mexican officials said they were already breaking down the draft agreement in terms of the business opportunities it might offer to each American state and Congressional district. The constituents of American lawmakers who sit on committees involved in trade legislation will get more attention from Mexican diplomats and delegations; those of incumbents expected to lose their seats in November will get less.
Already, callers to the Mexican Embassy in Washington can ask for 76 academic studies forecasting the effects of the treaty on jobs, wages, trade, immigration and the environment in the three countries.
American businessmen who have worked in Mexico have been enlisted to tell their success stories. Tours of the United States are being set up for Mexican politicians, entrepreneurs and union leaders in the modern (and English-speaking) mold. Mexican-American business groups are being wooed, and Mexican Jews are being recruited to lobby Jewish groups in the United States.
The scale of the effort reflects what the Government sees as its enormous potential gain.
 
Jobs and Growth
 Other variables being equal, Mexican economic officials calculate that the flow of foreign investment into the country with a North American Free Trade Agreement would increase economic growth by at least 1 percent a year.
Some trade experts believe the pact would create more than a million Mexican jobs by the end of the decade, while narrowing the gap between what workers are paid in this country and the eight or nine times as much they can earn in Canada or the United States. Over a decade or two -- but not initially -- the rise in wages is expected to stem the migration of Mexican laborers north.
Opinion surveys and interviews suggest that only a small minority of Mexicans understand any more about free trade than its most general promises. Yet at 6:30 this morning, Mr. Salinas was triumphantly waving a thick copy of the agreement before television audiences. His message was actually less about treaty provisions and tariff barriers than about national catharsis.
"We Mexicans have demonstrated that we can do things well and assure our position in the world," he said. "We have shown with deeds that we achieve what we set out to do.
"Two years ago, when we began promoting the treaty with the United States and Canada, some considered it an impossible aim," the President went on. "Now, having concluded the negotiation of the treaty, restored growth and lowered inflation, we are showing that we achieve our goals and that renews our self-confidence. That is why Mexico is respected abroad and seen as a nation united, determined to progress and to have a great role in the next century."
 
Critical Voices
 Some other Mexicans were less exuberant.
"As far as I'm concerned, the treaty is just going to hurt us," said Victor Pacheco, a 28-year-old carpenter who was dismissed two years ago by the state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex.
"The Government goes around other countries saying we live in peace and everything is great, but we here are not the only ones with problems," said Mr. Pacheco, who camped out with scores of other former Pemex workers in Mexico City's central plaza, protesting their dismissal as part of the huge enterprise's push to become more efficient. "Many factories are on strike and many factories have closed," he said. "Our industry is being dismantled because of the treaty."
The appearance of consensus remains an important political value in Mexico, and several officials said that people like Mr. Pacheco would not be ignored. Answering complaints that Mexican negotiators had made most of the big concessions in reaching the treaty, officials have begun to describe heroic efforts to keep the country's oil resources from greedy foreign hands, to protect Mexican farmers, and to lower tariffs more quickly abroad than at home.
"There is going to be a very big barrage of information here," said an aide to the President. "We want the information to be out there because it is the principal antidote to any partisan account of the treaty."
The official noted that even most of the political parties and business groups that have criticized aspects of the trade agreement, or its negotiation, had not opposed an agreement outright. Reflecting the perception of many of the critics, another official said, "their voices are louder in Washington than they are here."
In the United States, however, Mexican critics of the accord may have to struggle to be heard over their Government.
The Mexican Trade and Foreign Ministries -- since their successful push last year for approval in the United States of the "fast track" legislation that authorizes the Bush Administration to negotiate an agreement that Congress cannot amend -- have built one of the biggest and most expensive teams of lobbyists, consultants and public relations agents of any foreign mission in Washington. Among them are Charls E. Walker Associates Inc.; Burson-Marsteller; Charles Black Associates, and Joseph O'Neal, a former aide to Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas.
Capitol Hill has become an inevitable stop for visiting Mexican officials, and free trade speeches by Mexican consular officials are commonplace in states that have previously had little to do with Mexico.
But despite this groundwork, an official said, "what remains is much more important than what we have finished."
"We are going to be launching a strategy of being in almost the entire United States, meeting with the editorial boards of local newspapers, meeting with business chambers and talking other people," the official continued. "The intensity of our campaign will be much greater than it was with the 'fast track.' "
Mexican aides say the effort will be somewhat easier because they will be able to cite the specific advantages of a completed treaty. The imagery of a new Mexico, with a booming economy and reliable, American-educated leaders, will remain central to the pitch, these officials said. But several American lobbyists and Congressional aides said the selling of Mexico was also likely to be easier because Congressional concerns had narrowed since the fast-track debate.
Then, American critics attacked the trade agreement using issues ranging from the loss of jobs to Mexico's respect for human rights, its political system, its drug-enforcement programs and the possibility that freer trade would make it a haven for industries fleeing American environmental regulation.
"Over the past year, everything but the labor issue and the environmental issue have fallen by the wayside," said B. Timothy Bennett, a trade lobbyist for Mexico's main business chamber. He argued that while some of those issues might reappear in Washington debate next year, the Mexican Government's success would depend less on how well it lobbied than on what new environmental safeguards it imposed.
As in Canada and the United States, environmentalists and other critics of the agreement lodged new complaints today in response to the news of the agreement.
"In the United States Congress and the Canadian Parliament, there is going to be a real discussion," said Ricardo Valero, a Mexican Congressman and the foreign affairs secretary of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party. "Here we've already discounted that. Of the three countries, Mexico is the only one that has a real fast track."

HEADLINE: Police Detail Why Gunmen Came to Club

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
The gunmen whose botched robbery at the Corona Social Club in Queens left two men dead and one critically wounded were trying to steal money from two illegal gambling machines, the police said yesterday.
Officers were still searching last night for as many as two other suspects who might have slipped away from the club at 101-17 43d Avenue in the uproar that followed a wild shootout between two of the gunmen and police officers. 
 "The club contained Joker Poker, illegal gambling machines," Sgt. Nick Vreeland said. The two gambling machines, which can hold thousands of dollars in cash, contained only $70 total, said another police spokesman, Lieut. Raymond O'Donnell.
The gambling machines have been a major source of income for organized crime in recent years, police officials have said.
The robbery went awry, witnesses and the police said, when the gunmen, lying in wait to rob the man expected to come to empty the machines, were instead surprised by a cleaning crew that entered the drab, unmarked two-story building in the heavily Hispanic neighborhood.
 
Shots and More ShotsTwo Now Charged
 "They rolled up the gates and opened the door and they were confronted by as many as five males inside the club," Lieutenant O'Donnell said.
One of the members of the cleaning crew, who Lieutenant O'Donnell said were people "affiliated with the club," escaped and flagged down a police car. The police soon entered a building adjoining the social club and went to the club's basement while the rest of the cleaning crew and the gunmen were inside.
"As the officers were coming up the stairs, there were two shots fired on the stairs of the social club," Lieutenant O'Donnell said. "The officers retreated, slammed the door at the bottom of the stairs and called for assistance."
Police said some of the suspects fled to the club's roof, firing at least four shots from there toward 43d Avenue. Two of the suspects left the roof and broke into the basement apartment of a Pakistani immigrant, Saeed Ahmad, taking him hostage and then shooting him to death as the police tried to stop them, Lieutenant O'Donnell said.
One of the gunmen, Raphael Mendez, 21 years old, of Jackson Heights, Queens, was killed in the resulting shootout with officers. Another, Victor Rodriquez, 26, of Richmond Hill, Queens, was critically wounded, the police said.
A third suspect, Joseph Vidal, 23, of Jackson Heights, was arrested Tuesday night. Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Vidal were charged with second-degree murder, burglary, robbery and criminal weapons possession, Sergeant Vreeland said.
The police removed the two illegal coin-operated electronic gambling machines from the social club yesterday.
Despite the presence of the machines, the police said the club was legal and they had received only one complaint against it in the three years it had been open. Last year, neighbors told officers that they believed drugs were being sold inside. The police said they investigated but found nothing.
After the police barricades were taken down in front of the club yesterday afternoon, Jochy Alvarez, 44, an unemployed truck driver who had walked inside and poured himself a shot of Remy Martin cognac, said, "It was a nice place, believe me."
"For the area," said Mr. Alvarez, who described himself as a frequent patron, "this is one of the places where you don't see people doing drugs, because there are no kids here."
Those in the know would ring a bell and enter a foyer where they could be watched through a long window, Mr. Alvarez said. They would be frisked for weapons, he said, and let into a dark, spartan room, with a pool table at its center, illuminated by red, green and blue lights.
Farther back in a black-painted room, three red bar stools stood in front of a small bar, which had a bottle of vodka, the bottle of Remy and club soda and beer. Down a rickety staircase, in a white basement, cartons of Heineken stood stacked to the ceiling. Two gaming tables were next to the beer.
Mr. Alvarez said 40 to 60 people would gather at the club at night to play pool and drink beer, a mixed crowd of Dominicans, Ecuadorans, Colombians and Puerto Ricans who live in the neighborhood. "It's one of the few clubs in Queens that was all right," he said. "They searched you. If they found you with weapons they wouldn't let you in."
Maximo Bentre, 33, who said he once worked as a security man in the club, said there had never been problems there. "Nothing ever happened," said Mr. Bentre, a slender man in a black shirt who now acts at a bouncer at a nearby club.
 
No Praise From Neighbors
 But some neighbors described the club as one of the hidden drinking and gambling joints and houses of prostitution that had changed what had once been a quiet residential neighborhood.
"This used to be a nice neighborhood. It's got to the point you can't walk on the streets anymore," said Jose Grullon, 35, a maintenance worker from nearby Jackson Heights. "Every time they open up one of these places, it's trouble for the neighborhood," he said. "I'd love to move, but I can't afford to move. I pay $400 for a nice apartment."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Panel Asks More For Science

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A Federal panel said yesterday that scientific research by American business was in a perilous state of stagnation and recommended tough steps to strengthen industry against foreign rivals, including a series of actions by the Federal Government.
While many experts have issued such calls to action, this one is unusual for its breadth and authority. Its author, the National Science Board, is the policy-making arm of the National Science Foundation, a Federal agency that supports general science research in the United States and is responsible for monitoring the nation's overall scientific health. 
 Without saying so explicitly, the panel's report seems to repudiate the laissez-faire approach of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, which disdained Government involvement in industry research in favor of reliance on market forces. Lately the Bush Administration has softened its stance on this issue, and Gov. Bill Clinton has strongly backed new Federal policies to increase industrial innovation.
The National Science Board in its report, released yesterday in Washington, detailed American declines in research spending by business and setbacks in high-technology markets and called for a plan in which Government would play a leading role in riding to industry's rescue.
 
Art of Fostering Innovation
 Among the proposed Federal steps were increasing the money for industrial research; changing tax, fiscal and monetary policies to promote scientific investment, and creating Federal education programs to train future corporate leaders in the art of fostering innovation.
The report "paints a grim picture," Dr. Roland W. Schmitt, the president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in Troy, N.Y., and co-chairman of the report panel, said in a statement, adding that stronger Federal leadership was needed. "Implementation of a national technology policy, establishing a rationale and guidelines for Federal action, should receive the highest priority," he said.
The situation was especially dangerous, he said at a news conference, because the erosion of America's industrial edge was steady rather than precipitous, leading to insufficient alarm being given to the issues and markets at stake.
"We're waving a warning flag," he said. "There's an emerging risk" that the United States is losing its inventive and competitive edge, threatening a series of significant losses and setbacks.
The report, "The Competitive Strength of U.S. Industrial Science and Technology: Strategic Issues," was done by the National Science Board's five-member committee on industrial support for research and development. Besides Dr. Schmitt, a former head of corporate research for General Electric, the committee's co-chairmen are Dr. Arden L. Bement Jr., director of science and technology at TRW Inc., a leading high-technology company engaged in civilian and military work.
Reaction to the report was swift and appeared to be overwhelmingly positive. Daniel F. Burton, executive vice president of the Council on Competitiveness, a private-sector group, said the report was important because it came from a nonpolitical arm of the Federal Government.
Charles F. Larson, executive director of the Industrial Research Institute, a trade group based in Washington, praised the report and said it codified an emerging consensus. "Whoever is in the White House is eventually going to see the light and realize that industry and government have to work together on this as a team," he said.
 
From Teflon to Transistors
 Traditionally, America's main source of innovation and technological leadership has been scientific research by private industry. People in corporate research invented nylon, Teflon, the transistor, the computer chip, fiber optics and instant color film. But now industry faces rising competition from abroad. In 1991, top honors in the award of sheer numbers of United States patents went to three Japanese companies: Toshiba, Mitsubishi and Hitachi.
In its report, the National Science Board panel, echoing past alarms, found that American spending on industrial research and development had stagnated in the 1980's and early 1990's, even as foreign rivals increased their investments.
In the last three years, it said, six competitors -- Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Sweden and Britain -- significantly increased their support of civilian research so that it cumulatively rose from being 25 percent larger than similar work in the United States to being 34 percent greater.
The report noted that American spending on industrial research slowed from an annual average growth of 7.5 percent in constant dollars from 1980 to 1985, to only four-tenths of 1 percent from 1985 to 1991.
 
At Risk of Decline
 As a result, it said, many American industries were at risk of decline, including computers, factory automation, motor vehicles, metals and electronics.
The report, citing a survey of 139 leading high-technology companies, said the main cause of the financial pullback was not Federal policy, technology management or the changing global economy. It was, the report found, general management practices and external financial pressures.
Corporate laboratories, it said, were under severe financial stress and were being forced to shift to shorter-term research for existing markets. It found that the mountain of corporate debt accumulated during the takeovers, mergers and acquisitions in the 1980's had squeezed research to some extent, but that the top financial pressure was the "growing dominance of institutional investors in equity markets and their demand for short-term returns on their investments."
It added that many top corporate managers lacked the skills and insights to tie technology into business strategy. In summary, the report said the United States "spends too few dollars" on industrial research and makes poor use of the ones it does.
It called for a tax credit for research and development to be made permanent and a moratorium on a Treasury regulation that induces American corporations to move research overseas.
Perhaps most important, it called for a sharp reversal of priorities in the overall Federal research budget, shifting the focus from the military to the commercial. Currently, some 60 percent of the $70 billion or so Washington is spending this year on science research goes to the Defense Department and other agencies engaged in military research.
Industry research sponsored by the Federal Government should be a team effort with business that focuses on generic, precompetitive technologies that have a broad range of commercial applications, the report said.
In a recommendation likely to provoke controversy, the report also called for Federal efforts to improve how industry performs its own research. For instance, it called on the National Science Foundation, the Government's main sponsor of general scientific research and education programs, to consider broadening its mission to include "the education of future corporate leaders of both high-technology and traditional industries."
Copies of the report can be obtained from the National Science Board, 1800 G Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20550.
