HEADLINE: Amid the Gentility of the East End, A Town Confronts Domestic Abuse

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
For a moment, Martha E. seems far from the cushioned chair and calm office where she speaks. In her eyes, it is 1990, and her husband is shouting at her, his anger building. Suddenly, he strikes.
Pregnant, she closes herself like a shell over the baby, protecting it from the kicks that rack her from skull to knees. Afterward, she picks herself up and limps out with the couple's 2-year-old son. 
 They stumble half a mile in the rain to a friend's house, casualties of domestic battles not commonly associated with this wealthy resort. Though wife beating seems improbable amid the beachfront mansions of the scions and stars who live here, it is serious enough that East Hampton has taken the highly unusual step of financing a private shelter for battered women, one of only three shelters for all of Long Island.
"Sometimes I think it's harder for people who have money," said Martha. "It's humiliating, because nobody expects it. When I tell people about what happened to me, they're surprised. And I can't understand why."
This is the tale of Martha's journey through a menacing marriage punctuated with episodes of domestic abuse, a form of violence that claims a new victim every 15 seconds and that was responsible for the deaths of three out of four women killed in America last year, according to the State Office for the Prevention of Domestic Violence.
It is also the story of a town's decision to help women escape abusive homes, and of police officers, judges, voters and volunteers who are building and furnishing a shelter in this summer resort, a pocket of Long Island's deepest poverty and grandest wealth.
 
Filling Hidden Needs
 The Rev. Frederick Schulz had no illusions about domestic violence sidestepping either the residents of the East End's fine mansions, its farmers or its workers. As minister of the First Presbyterian Church, he was getting calls to see bruised wives and children more and more often throughout the 1980's.
When it was his turn to organize an evening at the Rotary Club, he invited Mary Bromley, a psychotherapist the Police Department had hired to help victims of rape and domestic abuse. Her work had convinced her that domestic abuse was a major social problem on the East End. She suggested the Rotarians contribute the money they had raised at their Sunday morning pancake breakfasts to build a shelter for battered women.
"We don't really need that, do we?" club members asked Mr. Schulz.
"You should see the steady stream that's coming into my office," Mr. Schulz replied.
Around the same time, Patrick G. Halpin took over as Suffolk County Executive, and began a tough new policy favoring the arrest of men who beat their wives. Mary Bromley and Mr. Schulz went to some members of the East Hampton Town Council, police and judges, opening talks on the problems of battered women.
"At first, people don't believe this can be the case out in the Hamptons," Mr. Schulz says. "But all you have to do is look at the statistics. And then people begin to think, and they realize they all know somebody who is a victim, or who they think is a victim."
The East End itself -- where Long Island narrows to a slender strip of land ending at Montauk Point -- seems to feed the isolation common to abusive homes. "We've been told that the farther you go east, the higher the incidence of alcoholism and domestic abuse," Mr. Schulz says.
Obsession Turned Violent
When Martha met her husband, she was a 21-year-old waitress who was new to New York from California. Her husband was 19 years older, the owner of several restaurants. He was forceful, charming and seductive. He was also a heavy drinker.
"We'd have a fun life style," Martha says now. "We'd go to restaurants, do things, go out a lot, and spend a lot of money."
The older man was obsessed with her, wanting to know where she was at all times, what she was doing, who she was seeing. His personality seemed to crowd the space between them, eclipsing Martha's own will at times.
On some level, his certainty may have reassured the young woman starting out in a strange and daunting city. And his mercurial temper was not foreign to her. Martha's father had the same overbearing, explosive ways.
She remembers now the first time her husband hit her. They had been together less than a year, when she stayed out late with a girlfriend.
When she returned home, her husband said nothing, but she could sense anger crouching like a mugger inside him. Then she accidentally knocked over a can of soda he was drinking, and he pounced.
Without being asked, Martha answers the obvious: Why did she stay?
"It's typical," she says in embarrassment, "but I thought when I had our first child it would somehow change things, that he would calm down." She now realizes that it was during her three pregnancies, when she was at her most vulnerable, that the violence was the most intense.
 
More Monitoring of Abuse
 In 1987, the Retreat was a couple of women with great connections and a modest plan: they would educate judges, police officers, social workers and women themselves about domestic violence. They would also find a network of people willing to welcome battered women in an emergency and, eventually, build a cottage to shelter them.
At their urging, Police Chief Tom Scott began training officers to recognize abuse and arrest batterers, and began sending the Retreat daily copies of all abuse complaints so the group could offer to help the victims. The number of abuse complaints from women shot up from 119 last year to 300 in the first seven months of 1992 -- a good sign, Captain Sarris said, of the growing awareness among women.
At Criminal Court, Judge James R. Ketcham wrote orders of protection for women who had been abused, abandoning the traditional reluctance among judges to throw a man out of his own house.
The town council paid for investigators to prepare independent reports on cases of abuse, so that courts would not rely exclusively on the statements of husbands and wives to determine whether it was safe for a man to return home. When children acted strangely in school, teachers began asking questions.
But building a shelter would require land and money, neither of which the Retreat had. Enter Tony Bullock, the East Hampton Town Supervisor.
At 34, with a shock of sandy blond hair, Mr. Bullock has the kind of prep school confidence that allows him to wear jeans to work and get away with it. He also had a sense that he could finesse a few legal technicalities to help the Retreat build a shelter.
He gave the Retreat town-owned land, liberally interpreting statutes defining "public purpose." East Hampton voters approved a $650,000 bond to finance construction of an 18-bed shelter. The Retreat will pay the bond's costs over 30 years, and then have the option to buy the building.
"Frankly, we're probably two steps on the wrong side of the law," Mr. Bullock acknowledged. "But if anyone wants to call us on this, we'd be surprised."
 
Accepting the Abhorrent
 Martha suspected her marriage was not normal, but her husband disagreed. After all, the turmoil had marked every relationship he had ever had with women, he said. Their friends tolerated the abuse; on a plane once, they told her to "loosen up" after watching Martha's husband give her a black eye in the airport.
"People didn't ask that much," she said. "They don't want to know, so they don't see."
But gradually, even as she denied she was abused, a part of Martha sought the means to survive: she took a job, and with the money went to see a therapist, who turned out to be Mary Bromley.
Martha stopped therapy, however, because she could not handle Dr. Bromley's open declarations that she was being abused.
And then her husband hit Martha for the last time. He knocked her down in the bathtub and held a bathroom scale over her head. "This is the time he kills me," Martha thought. "I'm dead."
By the time he backed off, Martha had broken free, and made the final decision to leave.
"I can't live my life wondering when is the next time I'm going to be afraid that I'm going to be killed," she decided. "It had gotten to the point where I knew I couldn't go home to face that anymore."
Now, Martha looks at a chart the Retreat uses that breaks abusive relations into components, terrible in their precision: isolation, intimidation, threats, using children, sexual, economic and emotional abuse.
"I didn't understand that this was a pattern," Martha said, the glint of revelation in her eyes. "He did all of this to me."
Sherry Wolfe, a former battered wife who chairs the Retreat's board of directors, said that without a place to go women will inevitably return to a dangerous home. "That's why it's so important to be there," she said.
Martha feels certain she would not have had the strength to leave without the Retreat's help. It was here she found the first glimmers of compassion and reassurance. "When I was totally devastated, they would pick me up and help me," she said.
"It's hard for somebody else to understand how tough it is to pull yourself out of it when somebody is totally overwhelming of your whole life," she said. "I really had to start everything from scratch. That was terrifying -- not just the fear of physical violence, but starting your whole life over."
Last week, a truck visited the East End's wealthy homes and businesses, collecting furniture, pictures and appliances that people here had donated. With the opening of the Retreat's new shelter, there will be 52 beds for battered women on Long Island, population 3 million. Last year, 12,433 battered women and children were turned away from shelters in New York State for lack of space.
But what surprises Ms. Wolfe, Tony Bullock, Mr. Schulz and others in this community is not how difficult it was to find solutions for battered women, but how simple, once they'd tapped the common will.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE ACCOUNT;
Mulroney's Task: Selling Trade Pact to Canadians

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney today opened his campaign to sell closer North American trade ties to a skeptical Canadian public. Business leaders generally endorsed the free trade pact just concluded by the North American partners, while the political opposition, including organized labor, tried to tear it to pieces.
An indication of the likely intensity of the coming storm was an exchange between Mr. Mulroney and Bob Rae, Premier of Ontario and a member of the Socialist-leaning New Democratic Party that opposes the Prime Minister's Progressive Conservatives. 
 Alluding to American Presidential politics, Mr. Rae charged that the pact had "everything to do with the Republican convention next week and nothing to do with the interests of the Canadian economy or Canadian workers."
Mr. Mulroney dismissed the Rae remark as "beneath requiring any comment" and went on to laud the accord as a "significant achievement for Canada" that would "create new wealth for citizens of all three nations." He said Canada had achieved its main objectives, which were to gain greater access to the Mexican market and protect its 1988 free trade agreement with the United States.
 
Canada's Motives
 Ottawa had entered the three-way talks late and defensively, after Washington and Mexico had already begun negotiating. The Canadians feared that market opportunities hard won in their 1988 pact with Washington could be undercut.
In welcoming the accord, many business people pointed to budding relationships between Canadian and Mexican enterprises. One illustration: SHL Systemhouse Inc. of Ottawa, which has just won a $500 million contract from the Mexican Government to provide computer communications systems to support more efficient Mexican tax collection.
"The Mexicans are very interested in Canada and seem somewhat less intimidated by Canadians than Americans," noted Tim Page, senior vice president of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce in Ottawa. The 170,000-member chamber has an increasingly active affiliate in Mexico.
Among other likely winners are Northern Telecom Canada Ltd. of Toronto, which could benefit from the huge telecommunciations investments expected to be made by Mexico; Bombardier Inc. of Montreal, which could get business in urban transportation systems, and the Royal Bank of Canada and other big Canadian banks through expanded financial service demand from Mexico.
 
Mexico's Surplus Is Eroding
 Canadian-Mexican trade is relatively modest -- only $3 billion in two-way business last year, compared with $200 billion worth of Canadian-United States trade. And thanks to exports of cars and fruits and vegetables to Canada, Mexico enjoyed a huge surplus of $2 billion.
But this year that surplus is being whittled down. Canada's exports to Mexico in the first five months of 1992 more than doubled, with automotive parts scoring the biggest gain. Imports from Mexico were up only 12 percent.
Reaction in the business community was not universally positive. Daniel Schwanen, senior policy analyst at the C. D. How Institute, a Toronto-based policy research group, said that in general the agreement would "put more of a squeeze on the labor-intensive and relatively low-wage sectors in Canada." But, he added, "All of high technology should gain."
Canadian furniture makers, for their part, are worried about more competition from both Mexico and the United States.
"U.S. manufacturers and retailers will be drawn to Mexico to access a pool of cheap labor, thus cheaper product," said George Sinclair, executive vice president of the Ontario Furniture Manufacturers Association.
Apparel makers won small increases in quotas for shipments to the United States, but one executive, Alvin Segal, owner of Peerless Clothing Inc. of Montreal, which exports wool suits, said he detected "no joy in the industry."
"The question," Mr. Segal said, "is how we survive against lower wages from Mexico."
 
A Broadside From Labor
 Organized labor, in the form of the 2.3-million-member Canadian Labor Congress, fired a broadside, calling the pact part of an economic agenda that is destroying jobs and the country.
"The federal Government is showing nothing but contempt for Canadians," said Bob White, president of the powerful labor group, which he said was "gearing for an ambitious action plan, involving coalitions of Canadians from all walks of life" to torpedo the agreement.
Mr. Mulroney said today that he would seek ratification as soon as possible. But in view of the degree of opposition, he is unlikely to railroad the enabling legislation through the House of Commons. Instead, there will probably be a debate lasting several months. Most analysts think the earliest that the pact will be voted on will be next winter.
 
A Likely Campaign Issue
 Like President Bush, Mr. Mulroney is expected to use positive features of the trade agreement in his own bid for relection. The Canadian leader, who will probably seek a third term, must call elections by the fall of 1993. Many analysts expect a spring election.
Opponents of free trade, still smarting from Mr. Mulroney's victory in the 1988 election, in which free trade was also the major issue, plan to hammer away at potential job losses under a North American pact.
The New Democrats like Mr. Rae and the party leader Audrey McLaughlin have promised to abrogate the deal if they come to power in the next election.
Meanwhile, Jean Chretien, the leader of the Liberal Party, which among the three parties currently has the highest backing in the polls, said he wanted to study the terms before deciding whether Canada should sign on.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "What Happens Next"
 
After top officials from the United States, Mexico and Canada initial the free trade agreement in the next few weeks, it still faces formal approval in all three countries.
 
UNITED STATES
 
The pact cannot be signed until 90 days after it has been initialed and submitted to Congress, during which time formal legislation is drafted to turn the pact into law. Congress then has 90 working days to approve it by a majority vote of each house. Congress may not reverse any provisions, though it may supplement them with various programs, like those to retrain workers.
 
PROSPECTS: Expected to pass no matter who is the next President. But if Bill Clinton is elected President, he might want to reopen negotiations to put his own stamp on the accord, and that could cause problems.
 
CANADA
 
Parliament is expected to vote this year, though the process for turning trade pacts into law may be affected by continuing revisions in Canada's Constitution.
 
PROSPECTS: Likely to pass so long as Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative Party maintains its hold. But general elections, possibly as early as next spring, could put its passage in question.
 
MEXICO
 
Approval requires only a majority vote of the Senate, which could take place ina scheduled session this winter or next spring, or in an extraordinary session.
 
PROSPECTS: Approval almost certain, as the President's party holds 61 of the 64 Senate seats.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Slight Easing in Treasury Prices

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market took a breather yesterday. After two days of a strong rally right into the teeth of the Treasury's big August auctions, prices eased slightly across the board and some yields rose.
The 10-year auction saw adequate demand, although some dealers were apparently spooked by some last-minute rumors of aggressive bidding. 
 But the average yield of 6.49 percent for the new note was the lowest since the 10-year note was first offered in May 1976. And the decline in the price of the 30-year bond, which was down nearly 3/8 of a point early in the day, narrowed in later trading, leaving the yield at 7.31 percent -- the five-and-a-half-year low reached on Tuesday.
And although some other yields rose yesterday, there were several reports that gave additional support to one of the main factors aiding the market -- declining inflation.
The Producer Price Index for July rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, after a two-tenths of 1 percent increase in June. For the year through July, the index is up just 1.8 percent. And the core inflation rate, which excludes food and energy, was up just two-tenths of 1 percent.
In another anti-inflation signal, gold dropped sharply. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the October futures contract was down $8.90, to $340.10 an ounce. And the Commodity Research Bureau index dropped further below the 200 level to 198.38, its lowest close since 1986.
 
Downward Price Pressure Seen
 Traders said there would be some downward pressure on prices today, because traders would be trying to raise yields before the final leg of this week's auction -- the 30-year bond. But referring to the economic data released yesterday, one trader said, "After that, then the economic data will tell the story."
Many traders think the market is ahead of itself and ready for a correction. But they also say that the data reflecting slow economic growth and low inflation is still basically good. At worst, this means the Treasury rally could stall. But unless there is some unexpected bad news, traders do not think that yields are going to rise sharply any time soon.
In the secondary market, the bond due in 2021 was offered at 1085/32 , down 3/32 to yield 7.31 percent, the same as the day before. In the pre-auction, or when-issued, market, where trading occurs ahead of the sale of the new 30-year bond, the yield was 7.26 percent, up from 7.25 percent Tuesday.
The new three-year note, which was auctioned Tuesday, was offered yesterday in late trading in the secondary market at 9913/16 , down 3/32 to yield 4.69 percent, which was the average for the auction. But that was above the close of 4.66 percent in the when-issued market on Tuesday.
The coupon on the new 10-year note is 6.375 percent. The average yield of 6.49 percent was flanked by a high yield of 6.50 percent and a low of 6.47 percent. The bid cover, which is the ratio of the $11 billion in notes auctioned to the total bid, was 2.28 -- below the average for the last 12 auctions.
Even though the auction did not meet overwhelming demand, there were indications, one trader said, that by later in the afternoon a lot of the securities had been sold by the dealers. One sign was the yield in the pre-auction market falling from the 4.69 percent just after the auction to 4.67 percent. The yield decline means the demand for the 10-year note was up.
 
Some Traders Guessed Wrong
 Going into the auction of the 10-year notes, traders and dealers had said they expected decent demand. The talk just before the 1 P.M. deadline for bids was of yields of 6.48 to 6.49 percent, which is where the yield was for the new 10-year note in the when-issued market.
Right after the deadline -- but before the results were announced -- the yield in the when-issued market began to decline, signaling that there might have been more demand than they expected. Some dealers apparently decided that their bids in the 6.48 percent and 6.49 range would not be aggressive enough and apparently went buying in the pre-auction market, pushing the yield lower. About a half-hour after the bid deadline, the yield had dropped to 6.46 percent.
But when the bids were announced, the average was 6.49 percent. The highest yield was 6.50 percent. This meant that the dealers who had been worried about not bidding at a low enough yield had been wrong -- a mistake that resulted in some immediate selling.

HEADLINE: G.E. to Issue Credit Cards, Possibly Tied to Discounts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The General Electric Company is planning to move into the fiercely competitive credit card business and may try to entice consumers with discounts on G.E. appliances.
The company's financial subsidiary, the GE Capital Corporation, plans to begin test marketing the card later this year, a spokesman, Anthony Zehnder, said today from General Electric's headquarters in Fairfield, Conn. 
 Mr. Zehnder said G.E. was considering trying to attract new card holders by offering them discounts on G.E. appliances for using the card.
 
A Crowded Market
 Analysts said G.E. would have to offer such incentives and devise an innovative marketing plan or it would have a tough time attracting customers in a saturated market.
"It's really tough now for any new player to come in," said Robert B. McKinley of the RAM Research Corporation, which tracks credit card rates. "They are going to have to stand on their heads for people to notice."
The card would also put G.E. in direct competition with banks and other nonbank credit card issuers. The General Motors Corporation is said to be planning a credit card that would provide discounts on its cars, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is already a major issuer of credit cards.
 
Choices for Consumers
 "I think it's bad news for traditional big banks that have gotten away with high interest rates and fees," said Elgie Holstein, president of Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group in Herndon, Va. "It gives consumers more choices."
GE Capital has the potential to become one of the top credit card issuers if it taps the 40 million card holders in credit card portfolios it manages for American retailers. But the company said it had no plans to do that.
"We have no intention of converting our private-label clients," Mr. Zehnder said. "These will be all new card holders."
He said the card would be tested in local markets but declined to name them.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$1.2 Billion Bond Offering Is Priced by New York City

 BODY:
Amid an active week for municipal bond issues, New York City made yesterday's biggest deal, pricing $1.2 billion of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
The proceeds from the bonds, which are backed by the full faith and credit of the city, will be used to refund earlier issues that carry higher interest rates. Among the new bonds that were tentatively offered, the maximum yield was 6.60 percent for a 6 1/4 percent debt security due in 2021. The rest of the serial bond issue was priced to yield from 3 percent in 1993 to 5.3 percent in 1997, 6.2 percent in 2002, 5.9 percent in 2007 and 6.60 percent in 2010 through 2020, the underwriters said. 
 The general obligation issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, with the exception of the bonds due in 2007 through 2009, which are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and rated triple-A by Moody's, S.& P. and Fitch Investors Service.

HEADLINE: Senate Opposes a Cut In Capital Gains Taxes

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Senate rejected an effort by Republicans to cut capital gains taxes today, as it quit for three weeks without completing action on enterprise zone legislation that was originally proposed in response to the rioting in Los Angeles four months ago.
The Senate vote was not unexpected, and it appeared to reflect strong Democratic opposition to even a narrower capital gains cut that would provide the tax benefit to businesses investing in selected inner-city neighborhoods, impoverished rural communities and Indian reservations. 
 The amendment provoked a sometimes vehement debate. Republicans argued that the capital gains cut was needed to spur the economy, while Democrats said it would do little more than spur larger budget deficits.
As the Senate slogged through scores of amendments to a wide-ranging $31 billion tax bill with provisions applying to crack babies, retirees and purchasers of expensive jewelry in addition to 125 enterprise zones, Democratic leaders saw no choice but to drop their plans to pass the legislation before the August recess began tonight.
 
Action on I.R.A.'s
 The Senate approved by voice vote a compromise on individual retirement accounts, expanding them to all but the wealthiest citizens by limiting deductibility for deposits to individuals earning under $80,000 and couples earning under $120,000. The amendment also reinstates a first-time home buyer tax credit worth $2,500 over two years, a provision that had been taken out of the legislation on Tuesday.
Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon and a proponent of the home-buyer tax credit, said the provision would generate up to 125,000 new housing starts and 400,000 home sales.
By a vote of 80 to 14, the Senate rejected an amendment offered by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, that would have reordered the legislation to cut $2.7 billion in tax benefits offered to corporations and directing those savings to an expansion of the Job Corps program, community policing and repairs of public housing and schools.
"This bill started as a response to the crisis in our inner cities," Mr. Bradley said in the debate on his amendment. "But instead of squarely facing the cycle of despair that we have created in our inner cities, this bill has become the engine for the extenders, passive losses, minimum tax relief and the President's marginal proposals to kick-start the economy."
 
House Legislation
 The House has already passed somewhat similar tax legislation, which would establish 25 enterprise zones in inner cities and 25 more in rural areas. The House version includes modest capital gains benefits for businesses that invest in impoverished neighborhoods for at least five years.
Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, introduced an amendment that would have reduced the corporation and individual capital gains rates to a maximum of 15 percent and prevented capital gains taxes from being paid on gains because of inflation. He said his measure was necessary "if we are truly serious about getting America moving again."
Opposing the measure, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said: "A vote for this amendment is a vote to increase the budget deficit by more than $47 billion. Let's be realistic."
The amendment was defeated on a parliamentary motion by a vote of 57 to 37.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rise 0.1% As Inflation Stays in Check

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Prices received by American producers for finished goods rose a skimpy one-tenth of 1 percent in July, as the economy's weak recovery kept a tight rein on inflation, Labor Department figures showed today.
The price of energy fell for the first time in six months, and peaches and other fresh fruits slid by the biggest amount in more than two decades to help food prices remain steady. 
 Nor was there anything disturbing at earlier stages of processing where there had been some hefty price increases in preceding months. The Labor Department found that prices for both intermediate goods and crude goods were unchanged in July.
 
Low Inflation Estimate
 "There is very little inflation pressure," said Ben K. Han, an economist for Philadelphia-based Corestates Financial Corporation. He said that his bank had now pared its estimate of 1992 inflation to below 3 percent, and that it saw the possibility of the inflation rate approaching 2 percent in a year from now.
Although it was not unexpected, the latest evidence of subdued inflation raised hopes in some quarters that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates yet again in support of the sluggish economy. The Fed's main policy-making body, which is to meet next Tuesday to set a monetary course for the following seven weeks, will also have figures on consumer prices for July by then. They are scheduled to be released Thursday.
Among the voices urging further easing of monetary policy was Charles Schultze, a Brookings Institution economist and former Government official, who appeared today before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. Dr. Schultze said the Fed should ease rates, calling 3 percent inflation "perfectly livable." He noted that short-term interest rates had yet to turn negative when adjusted for inflation; typically that occurs during business downturns.
 
Down From Prior Months
 The one-tenth of 1 percent rise in prices of finished goods last month followed advances averaging three-tenths of 1 percent for May and June and brought the rise for the latest 12 months down to 1.7 percent.
When food and energy are excluded, however, this so-called core rate of producer inflation rose two-tenths of 1 percent for July after slipping one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
Unlike the Consumer Price Index, the producer indexes do not include services or imported goods.
The price of passenger cars climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, possibly reflecting temporary plant shutdowns that kept inventories in check, while tobacco products fell much less than in June. Prices of soaps and detergents rose substantially.
On the other hand, gasoline and home heating oil turned down after a sharp June rise, and increases for fresh vegetables, fish, beef, veal and milk products were offset by lower prices for fruit, poultry, shellfish, fats and oils, pork and roasted coffee.
Among the huge swings in fruits and vegetables were plunges of 44.5 percent for peaches, 41.2 percent for strawberries and 32.6 percent for melons. But prices of vegetables rose 19.7 percent, the most since February, as increases for potatoes and carrots approached 80 percent.
Prices were unchanged for intermediate goods, like bolts of cloth. Prices turned down for energy and food, while nondurable products used in manufacturing, like chemicals, rose less than in June.
Materials for durable manufacturing rose six-tenths of 1 percent, however, with increases accelerating for primary copper, copper and brass mill shapes, cold rolled steel sheets and hardwood lumber. Lead prices, which had been flat, jumped sharply.
But prices turned down for plywood, zinc and semifinished steel mill products, and hot rolled steel sheet and strip fell faster than in June.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Mixed Amid Mood of Uncertainty

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against most major currencies yesterday despite heavy buying a day earlier by central banks hoping to bolster the sagging dollar.
Figures released yesterday on wholesale inflation had little effect on the dollar, said Mike Faust, senior currency strategist with MMS International. 
 The Labor Department reported a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent for July in the Producer Price Index, which measures inflationary pressures before they reach the consumer. The figure was in line with expectations.
Although Tuesday's intervention by 14 central banks braked the dollar's rapid decline, it drifted lower on some markets. The coordinated effort failed to stir any interest in buying or holding dollars, traders said.
It was the second time in less than a week that central banks entered the market to support the tumbling currency. Traders yesterday were "trying to get a handle on the levels at which the central banks would enter the market again," Mr. Faust said.
 
Deterrences to Buyers
 Intervention was the only factor supporting the dollar, he said. Low interest rates and fears that the Federal Reserve might ease again, as well as the sluggish economy and the uncertain political situation ahead of the Presidential election, were unsettling potential dollar-buyers, Mr. Faust said.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, thereby decreasing the need for dollars.
Mr. Faust said those factors have meant the intervention in the dollar's favor is having less effect than it might. "Intervention is more successful when the underlying fundamentals are working in favor of the dollar," Mr. Faust said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.87 yen, down 0.04 from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.75 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 127.30 yen, down from 128 yen late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9285, from $1.9225 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.9305, up from $1.9275 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines 10.27 After Bonds Weaken

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Wall Street's blue-chip stocks ended weaker yesterday, pressured by a late decline in bonds that followed an $11 billion auction of new 10-year Treasury notes.
The Dow Jones industrial average shed 10.27 points to end at 3,320.83. Decliners narrowly outpaced gainers 933 to 757 on the New York Stock Exchange, while volume rose to 177 million shares from 173.9 million on Tuesday. 
 Few factors seemed to sway investors. The market showed scant reaction to the morning announcement of the North American Free Trade Agreement involving the United States, Canada and Mexico.
 "A lot of players are missing here," said Ron Doran of C. L. King & Associates. "We're in the middle of the summer doldrums."
 The Treasury's 30-year benchmark bond lost 5/32 of a point, or $1.56 for every $1,000 face amount, to end at a price of 108 after rebounding from its lows.
The rises of one-tenth of 1 percent in the July Producer Price Index and two-tenths of 1 percent, excluding food and energy, were within estimates.
"Inflation seems to be very much under control," a trader said.
Steve Poling, an executive vice president at Fortis Advisers, said: "The market is shrugging everything off these days. Interest rates seem to be the only glue keeping things together."
The long-anticipated free trade pact was viewed as a positive sign for the stock market. But analysts said they saw little immediate reaction from Wall Street.
"It's a minor plus," said Hersh Cohen, president at Shearson Asset Management.
But, noting that there were few factors behind trading, he said: "It's just a dawdling day in August. We're completely beholden to the bond market."
 Mr. Doran said while stocks may be stuck in a range for the near term, "long term, I think there's still a good buying opportunity," adding, "the downside is limited."
Among individual issues, the Limited and the Gap were heavily traded. Paine Webber cut its rating on Limited and Merrill Lynch lowered estimates on both companies. The Limited eased1/4, to 19 7/8, while the Gap lost 7/8, to 31 1/2.
Shares of Applied Materials added 3 1/4, to 25 1/4 after reporting strong third-quarter results.
Parametric jumped 3, to 42 1/4, after it received the largest contract in its history. It will provide Caterpillar with at least 2,000 work stations using its software.
Parametric said it expected at least $10 million from the contract within the next four quarters.
Gold stocks were pounded because of plunging gold prices and waning inflation. Newmont Gold slipped 2 7/8, to 40 7/8; Pegasus Gold eased 1 1/8, to 14 5/8, and Newmont Mining fell 3 3/4, to 44 3/4.
Shares of Dataram slumped 6 7/8, to 7 7/8, after it reported lower first-quarter profit margins, reflecting its price cuts in the computer work station market.
The Nasdaq market index slipped 0.75, to 570.85, while the Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks lost 1.12, to 417.78.
The American Stock Exchange index eased by 1.62 points, to 386.46. The N.Y.S.E. composite index of all listed common stocks was off 0.62, at 229.99. The average price per share lost 9 cents.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Metals Prices Drop Sharply Over Fears About Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The prices of precious metal futures plunged yesterday as persistent weakness in the prices of raw materials raised renewed fears that the economy was again slipping into recession.
On the other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures were lower, cotton futures rose, oil futures advanced and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
 Platinum led the collapse in metals. Platinum for delivery in October dropped $13.40, to $354.30 an ounce, on the Mercantile Exchange in New York. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August fell $8.70, to $338.60 an ounce; September silver tumbled 12 cents, to $3.775 an ounce.
Analysts said the stage was set for the selloff on Tuesday, when the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 agricultural and industrial commodities fell below 200 for the first time in six years. Weak commodities prices indicate a lack of demand for raw materials by manufacturers, which bodes ill for the economy.
Precious metals reacted because a slowing economy means less industrial demand for platinum and silver and low inflation means less investment demand for precious metals, which are historically viewed as a hedge against rising prices.
"The whole atmosphere of the commodities has shifted from one of modest optimism into one of economic malaise, slow growth, low inflation -- the kind of psychology that existed in 1991," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist for Merrill Lynch Futures.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber, said the falling Japanese stock market was adding to fears of global economic weakness.
Grain and soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade ahead of a Government crop report that, as expected, predicted near-record corn production and a huge soybean crop.
In the report after the close of trading, the Agriculture Department estimated 1992 corn production at 8.76 billion bushels compared with last year's harvest of 7.47 billion bushels and the record of 8.88 billion set in 1985.
 
Energy Mostly Higher
 Oil futures ended modestly higher, retaining some of the gains posted early in the session on rumors, denied by the Pentagon, that Iraqi troops were massing near the Kuwait border.
Light crude oil for September delivery rose 17 cents, to $21.08 a barrel; September heating oil rose 0.32 cent, to 57.87 cents a gallon; September unleaded gasoline rose 0.80 cent, to 60.63 cents a gallon, and September natural gas fell 1.1 cents, to $1.911 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Take a Slight Downturn

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds took a slight downturn in the latest week after appearing to stablize the week before, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
The seven-day compounded and simple average yields for tax-exempt funds were both down 4 basis points, to 2.18 percent and 2.16 percent, respectively. With the 30-day average compound and simple yields at 2.17 percent and 2.19 percent, respectively, both averages were down a basis point from last week's computation. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 IBC/Donoghue's said assets of tax-exempt money funds showed a $2 billion outflow, leaving $96.7 billion in the funds. Analysts said the outflow of cash from the funds, much of it coming from the early refunding of many tax-exempt issues, had begun to move back out of the money market funds and into new issues now being generated from a heavy calender of tax-exempt borrowings.
 
Longer Maturities Popular
 Investors are also moving from the money market funds into the longer maturities of municipal bond funds.
Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, expects the pattern to continue as long as the yield curve remains fairly steep and longer maturities continue to offer higher yields.
The average number of days remaining until maturity of tax-exempt securities held in fund portfolios fell by a day, to 63, still a long time, according to analysts. A good percentage of portfolio managers remain confident that interest rates will not sudddenly back up on them.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-free yield is 3.02 percent, while the equivalent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.15 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market funds, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson in Milwaukee, ran its streak to two months as the fund with the best return, 2.96 percent, or 3 basis points lighter than last week.
Yields in taxable money market funds also fell, as assets rose by $3.9 billion, to $500.7 billion. Of the total, institutional assets rose $2.5 billion, to $179.8 billion, with retail accounting for the rest of the increase as assets gained $1.4 billion, to $320.9 billion.
Mr. Frank noted that these funds gained cash as yields fell, explaining that money market yields plunged last week and that may have led investors to go back into money market funds, since yield movement usually lags the market.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market funds was 3.13 percent, down 2 basis points, while the simple yield fell 3 basis points, to 3.08 percent. Over a 30-day period, the compounded and simple average yields were both down 4 basis points, to 3.19 percent and 3.14 percent, respectively.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios for the week was unchanged at 64.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, had the best return among general purpose funds for the second consecutive week, posting a return of 3.92 percent.
By comparison, the average yield of a bank money market account was 3.04 percent for the week.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Clinton's Luck . . . Or His Albatross?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"YOU can help by putting a nice, positive interpretation on the fact that there are 200,000 more jobs created," President Bush told reporters assembled last Friday to hear the White House's spin on the July employment figures.
But economists seem more inclined to view the small decline in joblessness, to 7.7 percent, as just the puddle at the bottom of a nearly empty glass. Many are hunkering down for a long, dry season in the labor market -- one in which the growth in national output is barely sufficient to absorb the natural growth in the work force. 
 That, of course, is wretched news for Mr. Bush, who seems fated to face the voters with the unemployment monkey firmly attached to his back. But slow recovery could also prove to be a political trap for a victorious Bill Clinton, who would enter office with a big jobs problem and few weapons to fight it.
As President Bush reminds Americans, the recession is over. Why, then, are so many still feeling the pain? Why is unemployment close to the levels endured at this stage of recovery from the far more ferocious recession of 1981-82?
Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, looks to the late 1980's for the answer. While the recent recession was relatively shallow -- output fell less than 2 percent -- the upturn has been achingly gradual.
And the whole cycle came on the heels of wo years of economic wobble. As a result, output is hardly greater today than it was in the last months of Ronald Reagan's reign.
Mr. Gordon notes that in the postwar decades the economy has had to grow at about 2 1/2 percent annually to stay ahead of the employment curve -- 1 percent to absorb the growing numbers of workers, the rest to offset long-term gains in labor productivity. Thus by historical benchmarks, joblessness might have been expected to be approaching double digits by 1992. "The real mystery," Mr. Gordon concluded, "is why unemployment isn't even higher."
But now Mr. Bush's chickens are apparently coming home to roost. While the White House is predicting a full percentage point decline in unemployment by the end of 1993, Walter Cadette, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, is among those who are far less sanguine.
Mr. Cadette invokes Okun's Law, the economists' rule of thumb that in the short run it takes an extra two percentage points' worth of growth to reduce unemployment by 1 percent. Factoring in the expected additions to the work force, plus ongoing productivity improvements driven by technology, the Morgan Guaranty economist figures that the economy will have to grow at a 4.5 percent rate simply to drive unemployment below 7 percent by the end of 1993. And hardly anybody -- not even the current resident of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue -- is forecasting a growth rate above 4 percent.
When it rains, it pours. While unemployment will presumably return someday to the tolerable 5 percent rate last enjoyed in 1990, the work generated in the recovery may not be all that job seekers have in mind.
James Medoff, an economist at Harvard, points out that compared with previous recessions relatively few jobs lost during the 1990-92 downturn were temporary layoffs. Just one unemployed worker in six (compared to two of five in recessions past) can reasonably expect to return to the same employer. And new hires are very unlikely to earn as much as they took home from their previous jobs.
Mr. Medoff notes, moreover, that since the 1970's, employers have become far less willing to provide fringe benefits to new employees. In 1979, 23 percent of new jobs included health benefits; a decade later, the figure had fallen to 15 percent. Over the same period, new hires with pension coverage fell from 43 percent to 38.
With hindsight, it is obvious that Mr. Bush's economists overdosed on happy pills. They expected a brief recession, a soft landing from the speculative boom of the Reagan years.
Instead, they got a crisis in slow motion that has left millions who believed it was morning in America either out of work or in fear of losing the jobs that support their middle-class living standards.
Candidate Clinton's luck, however, could prove to be President Clinton's daunting challenge. If the next President is inclined to put the recession behind him by giving the economy a quick fiscal kick, he will have plenty of support from the left-center. "Hang the deficit," Mr. Gordon said. "Full speed ahead on spending with a long-term growth payoff."
But there is no guarantee that traditional fiscal policy would work. The spectacle of a Democratic President and Congress undoing the deficit-reduction agreement could spook investors, driving up long-term capital costs. And it could lead to a run on the dollar, forcing the Federal Reserve to shore up confidence with higher short-term interest rates.
This policy web, tangled by a decade of what-me-worry economics, could prove very difficult to unweave.

HEADLINE: Don't Be Fooled: These Objects Are Useful

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
SIMPLE baskets woven from the wild grasses of the Savannah River, asymmetrical salad bowls made of celadon porcelain, and Isamu Noguchi-inspired tables made of plywood are some of the 200 or so objects in "More Than One: Contemporary Studio Production" at the American Craft Museum. The exhibit, which includes works by 21 artists, opens today at the museum, 40 West 53d Street in Manhattan, and runs through Nov. 8.
"Studio production means that more than one object is produced, and that the artist has either hands-on contact with the object from start to finish, or complete supervision or approval of the final object," said John Perreault, the museum's senior curator. "Artists make multiples both from economic necessity and from an idealistic ideology that it's important to make beautiful handmade objects for everyday use that ordinary people can afford." 
 Objects by 11 of the 21 artists in the exhibit are sold in the museum's shop; these small home accessories range in price from $38 for a porcelain plate by Marek Cecula to $425 for a porcelain teapot by Dorothy Hafner.
Chris Lehrecke of Brooklyn makes curvy tables, which he admits are inspired by Noguchi, out of simple materials like plywood.
"I began making these shapes from solid pieces of wood, and I thought it would be interesting to accomplish the same thing with more industrial materials like plywood and fiberboard, to make something beautiful out of something ordinary," Mr. Lehrecke said. For an egg-shaped table, he cuts 97 thin strips of fiberboard, lays them side by side, molds and laminates them to form the surface of the table and then sands them to a satin finish. The steel base is minimal.
Another minimalist working in wood laminate is Skip Abelson of Manhattan, whose bentwood chairs feature two kinds of wood. One chair might have a seat and underside of maple, while the rest is cherry. A slit runs a few inches down the back of the chair.
"The crack is to relieve the tension," Mr. Abelson said, "and it's kind of sexy."
James Makins, a Manhattan artist, makes goblets, bowls and plates of palest porcelain. "I wanted to work with a clay body that would allow me to edit everything down to the essence of the material," he said. "I was also attracted to porcelain for its incredible sensuality."
Mary Jackson of Charleston, S.C., has reworked the basket. Using grasses from the low country near Charleston, she weaves the fibers into contemporary designs based on traditional African patterns.
For all the artistry of these crafts, the objects are intended to be used. "As opposed to art that hangs on the wall and doesn't do anything," Mr. Perreault said, "these objects are art that you can sit on, eat off or wear."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Coffee cup and saucer, in celadon porcelain, by James Makins. (Joshua Schreier)

HEADLINE: Getting More Camp for Less Money

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE

 BODY:
DESPITE a straitened economy, children all over the country went to summer camp this year. But to pay for it, many families had to be more resourceful than they had been in the past.
Some parents sent their children to less-expensive camps run by schools or nonprofit groups, or to camps offering financial assistance and gradual-payment plans. Some even worked at camps their children attended, in exchange for reduced fees. 
 Paula Pacicco of Morris Plains, N.J., sent her 5-year-old daughter, Danielle, to a day camp run by the Morristown-Beard School in Morristown, N.J., for six weeks this summer. The cost, $640, was lower than at many other camps because the buildings of the private school for children 11 to 18 were used and because some of the school's older students and alumni were hired as counselors and supervisors.
"The camp's administrators are not interested in making a million dollars," Mrs. Pacicco said. "They want to keep their students' parents happy by giving the kids supervised employment, showing them how to be responsible. Meanwhile, families like mine benefit."
Other camps have low fees because they are financed by a parent's employer, the college a parent attended or a group a parent belongs to. Camps sponsored by organizations like the Y.M.C.A., Boy Scouts or Girl Scouts and those that are affiliated with a religious group or owned by a municipality are also in demand because they often offer financial assistance and subsidize part of a camper's fee, said Gary W. Abell, a spokesman for the American Camping Association, a nonprofit educational association that represents 5,000 day and resident camps nationwide. Fees at such camps, he said, range from $15 to $55 a day. By contrast, independently owned camps range from $35 to $80 a day.
"More families are seeking inexpensive camps, especially parents who work and need all-day child care when school is out," said John G. Snowden, vice president for camps and conference services for the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York. "We've also seen an increase in the number of families needing assistance to attend our camps, especially middle-income families."
Still other parents sought arrangements the whole family could enjoy, like Deerkill Day Camp in Suffern, N.Y., whose recreational facilities are open to campers' families on weekends. "For the price of joining a beach club in Westchester, you can send your kids to day camp during the week and the whole family to a kind of country club on weekends," said Robert I. Rhodes, an owner of Deerkill.
The camp's fees vary with the length of stay, from $2,620 for eight weeks to $1,375 for August only, Mr. Rhodes said. On weekends, the pool, tennis courts and indoor basketball court can be used by families.
Mr. Abell said parents pursued "all sorts of options, like day camp, which is very popular now and being offered by all sorts of agencies and religious institutions, instead of the more expensive resident camps."
To make camp affordable and keep enrollment high, camp owners "are more accommodating of parents than ever before," he added, "offering shorter sessions, for example, or allowing parents to extend their children's stay" as circumstances allow.
Jim Eagan, director of the Morristown-Beard Day Camp, said the camp instituted a payment plan "partly as a response to the economy." Parents, he explained, pay $160 the first week of camp, and $100 a week until the entire bill is paid. "About 30 to 40 percent of our parents are on the plan," he said, "and we have between 100 and 150 kids ages 4 to 12 in any one week."
At some camps, a number of parents worked as counselors in exchange for some salary and lower camp fees. "I thought, what could I do, in what way could I make a difference?" said Terry Kalayjian, a graphic designer. "My answer was to teach swimming" at Trinity Day Camp in Manhattan.
The arrangement, Ms. Kalayjian said, offered surprising benefits. "It's a way to spend unpressured time with Lara and Sevan," she said, referring to her daughters, who are 10 and 7. "And it connects me to when I went to camp, which was a very positive experience. "More important, it teaches my kids to see Mom in a different light: being resourceful, using different skills. And it tells them that we all have hidden resources on which we can draw."
Those hidden resources are in high demand, said Dr. Arthur I. Pober, an education consultant. "Camp puts a dent in almost every family budget," Dr. Pober said. "After all, many parents consider camp an experience that their children can ill afford to miss, but it is often one for which they cannot readily afford to pay. So this year, the scramble was on to get more camp for less."
He described how some city parents send their children on long bus rides to day camps in the country "so that they can have a sleep-away camp experience without the sleep-away camp expense." Or, he said, they opt for "short but sweet" camp stays -- say, two weeks at a tennis, math or chess camp.
Many parents say such abbreviated camp sessions force them to rediscover local amenities, like the beach or municipal pool.
"In the process, they are rediscovering the joys of not having kids programmed all the time," Mrs. Pacicco said. "You know, there is something to be said for letting kids goof around in the morning, while parents do errands. Then in the afternoon, you can pack them up and go for a swim."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Danielle Pacicco, 5 years old, and Alison Alberga, a counselor, in the pool at the day camp run by the Morristown-Beard School in Morristown, N.J. (Kim Garnick/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
MATHEMATICS may be the most anxiety-provoking subject taught. For many adults, especially those who avoided math in school, facing a column of numbers, a graph or a set of fractions still makes the palms sweat and the heart race. And they, like the children now grappling with math, probably learned their fear from parents or elementary-school teachers who felt incompetent, too.
"Math anxiety is not genetic, but it's highly contagious," said Elisabeth Ruedy, a math teacher at the Trinity School in Manhattan who wrote "Where Do I Put the Decimal Point?" (Henry Holt, $19.95). "I have never found a toddler who didn't love numbers. It gives them a feeling of power. The problems arise when they start kindergarten." 
 Elementary and preschool teachers usually receive far less training in how to teach mathematics than how to teach reading and writing. In fact, many selected their profession partly because they felt uncomfortable with advanced math and science. They are more likely to view mathematical ability as something they cannot expect from all children -- a strikingly different attitude than the one they hold toward such subjects as reading.
The misconception that basic mathematical ability is innate often leads children and their parents to respond more passively to mathematics than to other subjects, waiting to discover whether they have a natural talent for it. There is less incentive to work hard at it because it feels out of their control. This leads some children and teachers to interpret initial difficulty understanding something as an inability to master it.
"Mathematical ability, at normal levels, is no more innate than any other form of general intelligence," said Sheila Tobias, the author of "Succeed With Math: Every Student's Guide to Conquering Math Anxiety" (College Board, $12.95). "Confidence, risk-taking and feeling in control are important in doing well in math or any other subject."
The issue of math anxiety is significant for both children and parents. Comfort with and competence at mathematics are increasingly important for success in adulthood. Avoiding math courses severely restricts the fields a student can study and the jobs a new graduate can find.
Although it is sometimes assumed that girls are more anxious about math than boys, and that students who do poorly in the subject are more anxious than those who do well, research has shown that's not the case. Many students who do well in math are still anxious, attributing their success to luck instead of knowledge and effort.
"I get very concerned about the stereotyping of girls as not being able to do math," said Dr. Susan F. Chipman, a psychologist in the Office of Naval Research in Arlington, Va., who has studied math anxiety. "Even though there are minor differences in confidence, we can't really say that math anxiety is a female problem."
As with most fears, avoiding mathematics doesn't get rid of the anxiety, and may even make it worse. The feeling of failure becomes part of the person's self-concept well into adulthood, often despite evidence to the contrary.
"Women will tell me that they shop for a family of five and figure out the bill in their heads, or they'll deal with fractions when they bake, but they'll claim that they can't handle mathematics," said Dr. Irene Deitch, an associate professor of psychology at the College of Staten Island who conducts workshops on math anxiety. "They don't see the connection with their everyday lives."
When pressed, many adults can date their fear to a time when they were absent from school because of an illness or a family move. Others say it followed a crisis: a death in the family, perhaps, or their parents' divorce. Often they missed understanding a critical concept, and everything that followed and built on that concept made no sense.
Teachers of math-anxiety courses for adults routinely describe students who are managers, even bankers. Many feel overwhelmed when faced with increasing responsibility involving things like budgets or financial projections. The students report having the same feelings of doubt and shame that they had decades ago in the classroom.
Ms. Ruedy said that, time and again, adults in her class hid their hands under the desk when she asked them to do a problem out loud. "It seems that some of the nuns in old parochial schools would rap them on the knuckles when they didn't know the answer," she said. "A lot of my adult students remember being hit at home or at school when they didn't do well in math. That's 100 percent counterproductive."
 
How a Parent Can Add, Not Subtract
CHILDREN look to their parents for cues as to how they should respond when they're frustrated by a math problem. The parent's attitude is often much more important than the ability to "crunch numbers."
A parent who pauses to ponder the question, draws a diagram or two to clarify it, approximates the answer and then does the calculations will help the children more than one who instantly gives the solution. While it takes longer, the first approach teaches persistence and other skills that can be applied to any math problem.
If your child is anxious about mathematics, there are some things you can do:
Pay attention to your own feelings about mathematics.
Are you anxious? Do you treat your child's math homework differently than other subjects? Children sense your attitudes, and quickly learn whether they are expected to succeed or fail.
"Learn the mathematics your child is learning," advised Sheila Tobias, who has written books on math anxiety. "Demonstrate your own confidence, problem solving and willingness to take risks."
And don't try to tutor your own child if you're anxious about the subject yourself. "Get someone who's comfortable with math," said Elisabeth Ruedy, a math teacher in Manhattan who works with children and adults. "It has to be somebody whose stomach isn't in a tight knot."
Relate the mathematics the child is learning to the real world.
All too often, the math problems children are asked to solve in school seem irrelevant. Have you ever really needed to know how far apart two trains are an hour and a half after they leave the station? When was the last time you wanted to know how many rods there were in the perimeter of a field?
"Show your child how mathematics is embedded in the stories in the newspaper," Ms. Tobias said. "Rates of inflation, sports records, reading graphs."
Remember that success is critical.
Children who are frustrated tend to avoid math. "Any success you can give your child is great," Ms. Ruedy said. "If you insist on using a workbook, buy one that's too easy instead of too hard for your child."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
San Francisco Turns To a Top Sports Agent

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12

 BODY:
In America's sports pages, Leigh Steinberg is considered among the most influential and successful player agents in the country. So what is he doing trying to keep the Giants in San Francisco?
It is like this, Steinberg said today: If the Giants take flight for Florida next season, San Francisco will lose one of its civic treasures. And his 6-year-old son, Jonathan, will lose his favorite baseball team. 
 Steinberg is suddenly the central figure in attempts to find a group of investors willing to purchase the Giants from Bob Lurie and prevent their move to the Sundome in St. Petersburg, Fla. Without a buyer, it is likely that National and American league owners will approve the sale of the club, perhaps next month.
 
Deserving of Franchise
 "I don't think I'd feel very good watching the team leave without fighting vociferously to save it," Steinberg said by phone from New York. "The litmus test is finding out how sincere the interest is in keeping the Giants in the area. Tampa-St. Pete is gorgeous, and they deserve a franchise, just not ours."
The decision Tuesday of potential investor H. Irving Grousbeck to pull out of a bid for the team undeniably set back hopes, but Steinberg said he is continuing to pursue other investors. He met with one today in New York, who will step forward within a week to make an offer. Steinberg would not identify the person.
Grousbeck projected losses of up to $10 million annually starting in 1994, but Steinberg said it was possible to increase revenues in several ways.
He said one method would be for the fans to make a bigger commitment to the team -- a broader fan base that would, he said, increase season tickets by 15,000 a year, giving the team an average attendance of about 35,000 per game and more than 2.8 million a year. He has also said that a new stadium would help attendance.
 
Request From the Mayor
 Steinberg said he was pulled into the search for a buyer by Mayor Frank Jordan of San Francisco. He said that Jordan, whom he has known for some time, called him after Jordan was elected to office in June and asked if Steinberg would help identify and contact possible investors.
Steinberg said that of the 40 people he initially reached, 20 had some interest and 10 were seriously interested. But with four weeks left before owners convene for meetings in St. Louis -- and with the Giants' owner, Bob Lurie, having already accepted an offer of a reported $111 million from a Tampa group -- even Steinberg conceded, "The amount of time is possibly too short, and the amount of money is a large one."
He is trying, though. But why?
Steinberg, 43 years old, said he would not be a part of any ownership group and that he will not receive a finder's fee for locating a buyer. But because he lives part-time in Berkeley, across the San Francisco Bay, he has an interest in the economic vitality and health of the area.
"It would be devastating to have a business like the Giants desert the city," he said. "The symbolism would send a very discouraging message to people who are trying to get California out of the recession."
He also said that his son was vividly distressed after learning that the Giants might leave.
 
Insists on Community Service
 "There's something magical about the connection of baseball and kids," Steinberg said. "The Bay Area wouldn't understand what it lost until it lost it."
Steinberg represents some 100 professional athletes, including about 70 football players, among them Warren Moon, Troy Aikman and Jets quarterback Browning Nagle. He is known for accepting only clients who give back to their communities -- some, for instance, have provided scholarships to their former universities -- and said that his interest in keeping the Giants is similar.
"I don't know how I'd answer the question, 'Why did we let the Giants get away?' " he said.
 
Marlin Owner Raises Money
 FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The chairman of the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, Wayne Huizenga, sold 1.5 million shares of his stock in the company to help pay for his Florida Marlins, Blockbuster announced today.
The shares amounted to about 9 percent of his Blockbuster holdings. He still holds about 14.7 million shares, according to a company statement. Officials did not provide further details of the stock sale.
During Blockbuster's annual meeting last year, Huizenga said he would probably sell two million shares to help pay for the Marlins, which cost an estimated $135 million.
The National League team is to begin play next season.
The video rental company has approximately 18.5 million shares outstanding. It closed today up 12 1/2 cents to $12.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
UNITED AIRLINES IS OFFERING AROUND-THE-WORLD FLIGHTS

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
United Airlines is offering around-the-world flights that will link its Atlantic and Pacific networks with new service through New Delhi, beginning Feb. 10. Some analysts dismissed the plan as a marketing ploy based on an outdated image of the romanticism of air travel. "What's the point?" asked James C. Halstead, a securities analyst at Hoare Govett. "The last time we really saw this was Pan Am as they expanded their network. It's now irrelevant." Passengers will pay $2,241 for economy seats and $4,159 for first class if they leave from the United States, a United spokesman said. He said the prices would probably fall later. Passengers leaving from London pay more, from $2,944 to $7,033.

HEADLINE: For America's Common Wealth

 BODY:
Millions will save a few cents every time they buy orange juice, a few dollars on shirts and sweaters and a few hundred dollars on automobiles because of the North American Free Trade Agreement concluded in Washington yesterday. All told, if Congress approves, consumers will save billions. But none of the savings will come labeled "Courtesy of the Trade Agreement" and few consumers will know to be grateful.
On the other side of the ledger, however, the losers, though few, will be highly visible -- and vocal. Some factories in the textile, glass and automobile industries will shut down, throwing workers onto unemployment lines. 
 They'll surely express angry opposition when the agreement arrives in Congress for approval. It comes as no surprise that Senator Donald Riegle and Representative David Bonior, both from auto-dependent Michigan, are already leading protectionist opposition.
The danger is that Congress will bend to the will of these few visible losers, in the process trashing the common wealth, the huge cumulative gains for everyone else.
The better way to proceed -- the way President Bush has promised -- is to embrace the agreement, embrace the benefits of free trade but also help dislocated workers. Now it's squarely up to Congress to do both: protect the many winners and the few losers alike.
The agreement would link the U.S., Mexico and Canada in a $6 trillion trading bloc, the world's largest. It would gradually eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers. The agreement would open Mexico's markets to U.S. exports of banking and investment services, petrochemicals, transportation and telecommunications equipment, insurance and other goods and services now blocked by Mexican tariffs or quotas. Mr. Bush delivered on his promise to build in safeguards for U.S. environmental and health standards.
Because U.S. tariffs are already low, the agreement would do more to increase U.S. exports to Mexico than vice versa. By one estimate, the agreement would create about 300,000 jobs in U.S. export industries, while eliminating about 100,000 in industries displaced by imports.
But such numbers can be misleading. The trade agreement won't affect the total number of jobs in the U.S., only their allocation. There will be more in banking and petrochemicals, fewer in textiles and glass. That means production will take place where it's cheapest, with the savings passed along to North American consumers.
Dislocated workers, many in low-paid occupations, will meanwhile need relocation assistance, retraining allowances, tuition assistance and guaranteed medical insurance. The next question is who pays, and the best answer would be for Congress to do so out of general revenues. But if that's politically impossible, Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, has come up with a useful alternative: a tax on Mexican-U.S. trade.
At first glance, it might seem contradictory to tax trade in order to free trade, especially given Mr. Gephardt's reputation as a protectionist. If the cross-border tax is kept small and temporary, however, his idea makes sense. Asking traders to pay some of the costs of the trade agreement is a tolerable price for Congressional approval.
The trick will be to keep a good idea from being turned into a protectionist weapon. The minority of losers deserves protection from harm, but not at the expense of the common wealth.

HEADLINE: Health Care Market Has Failed Consumers;
Oregon Plan Misfires

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Bold Medical Plan, Derailed" (editorial, Aug. 6) shows woeful misunderstanding of the issues involved in Secretary of Health and Human Services Louis Sullivan's rejection of Oregon's misdirected attempt to ration health care. There are more reasons than the few you attempt to rebut to reject this basic change in the state's Medicaid program.
Oregon lawmakers like me who opposed the rationing plan have been frustrated by the news media's inability to look behind the scheme's fashionable attractiveness and to examine the fundamental issues it presents. The Oregon plan ignores, and perhaps exacerbates, the most pressing necessity for health care reform in America: cost control and reduction. Instead of restricting the profits of care providers, the Oregon proposal allows payments to increase by 30 percent. 
 The Oregon plan is an attempt by the medical establishment to avoid what you call "real comprehensive medical reform." Do you seriously think a proposal supported by every medical professional group and association could constitute real reform? Economic self-interest is at the heart of this controversy.
The American medical establishment is desperate to find an alternative to the Canadian model, which has become, despite its faults, the most attractive solution to the problems of our own unworkable system. Why? Under the Canadian approach the incomes of physicians will go down. Under the Oregon plan the incomes of providers increase. In Canada medical expenditures are limited by real cost controls; the Oregon approach places the entire burden of reform on needy patients.
 
TOM MASON
State Representative, 11th Dist., Ore.
Portland, Ore., Aug. 6, 1992
