HEADLINE: Two Regulators Say Testimony Led to Demotions

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Two Government lawyers who raised questions about the Federal commitment to recover money from officials of failed savings and loans said today that their efforts had placed them in a professional twilight zone.
Jacqueline P. Taylor and Bruce Pederson had harshly criticized their employer, the Resolution Trust Corporation, in a Senate hearing on Tuesday, lamenting what they regarded as the political influence that is weakening their agency's efforts to recover money from wrongdoers in the savings and loan industry. 
 "I'm a licensed attorney practicing for eight years in Colorado and practicing for seven years in Minnesota; this is all in jeopardy," Ms. Taylor said today in an interview at her lawyer's office, a short distance from the Senate hearing room where she testified on Tuesday. She has been demoted and reassigned from her position in Denver overseeing Resolution Trust cases against former savings and loan officials.
Mr. Pederson, a manager in the Denver office, said he had also been demoted.
 
Pledge of No Reprisals
 Albert V. Casey, the president of Resolution Trust, assured Senators on Tuesday that there would be no reprisals against the lawyers for their testimony, in which they talked of political pressures not to pursue certain cases aggressively.
Appearing more relaxed than she did on Tuesday, but still frustrated, Ms. Taylor said: "For me personally, it's been hurtful. Is it worth it? If it stops the damage."
Ms. Taylor and Mr. Pederson filed a class-action grievance with Resolution Trust in what they called an attempt to restore the independence and effectiveness of the unit where they worked.
They said they were motivated in part by the recent death of another lawyer in the Denver office who also aggressively pursued cases against former savings and loan officials and was under tremendous pressure.
Mr. Pederson said part of the reason he came forward to criticize his own agency was purely emotional. "A former colleague died recently of a heart attack at 36; it has an effect on you," he said.
The unit where they worked is called professional liability. This once obscure legal and regulatory backwater has increasingly taken on political coloration, the two lawyers say, as the unit's staff and policies are diluted.
 
Change in Guidelines Weighed
 Mr. Casey insists in public statements that the corporation intends to pursue vigorously any and all wrongdoers. But more quietly, as part of the Bush Administration's election year deregulatory efforts, top Administration and White House officials have been involved in discussions over whether the Government should change its guidelines for suing former officers and directors of failed banks and savings and loans, according to documents and officials.
A recent draft guideline circulating among Federal agencies would make it harder to sue some directors, the lawyers say. Even if that guideline is not adopted, they said they detected a subtle relaxation of the standard in practice.
The people who stand to gain from softer guidelines are the thousands of former directors of failed savings and loans and banks. Some of them are politically influential, including two Cabinet members -- Edward R. Madigan, the Secretary of Agriculture, and Edward J. Derwinski, the Veterans Affairs Secretary. Others are prominent citizens and many have never been accused of wrongdoing before. They often complain that they are simply innocent victims of a bad economy and should not be sued by the Federal Government.
In her testimony, Ms. Taylor said the agency recently dropped plans to sue officials of an unnamed institution around the time one of the officials visited with President Bush. She criticized the decision to resolve the case out of court as "an inappropriate settlement because of political reasons."
Officials who asked not to be identified said the institution at issue was Deseret Federal Savings and Loan, based in Salt Lake City, before it was taken over by the Government in 1989. A longtime outside director of the savings and loan, Howard W. Hunter, is a senior Mormon Church official, and was one of a number of church officials who met with President Bush last month in Salt Lake City.
A church spokesman, Don LeFevre, said the savings and loan litigation was not discussed at the meeting.
Ms. Taylor said she had tried to be careful and balanced in deciding whom to sue. She worked mainly for private financial institutions before joining Resolution Trust last year.
"There were many times we received exculpatory information that certain targets had not done anything negligent and we dropped them" as potential defendants, she said.
Mr. Pederson, in contrast to Ms. Taylor, has spent much of his legal career in the Federal Government, including a stint at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's professional liability unit.
Because the Government insures savings and loan deposits it must pay for the cost of bailing out failed institutions. The less money the Government recovers from wrongdoers the more taxpayers have to contribute to the cost of the rescue, now estimated at more than $300 billion.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 14, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A headline and a picture caption in Business Day yesterday about Government lawyers who raised questions about the recovery of money from savings and loan officials misstated the sequence of events. The lawyers were demoted before their Senate testimony, not after it.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
BAKER LEAVING STATE DEPT. TO HEAD WHITE HOUSE STAFF AND GUIDE BUSH'S CAMPAIGN

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
President Bush today appointed Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to run the White House and direct his campaign, and both men vowed to salvage the President's re-election by putting domestic issues at the top of their agenda.
In a surprisingly direct admission that the Administration had dwelled on foreign affairs at the expense of economic and social concerns, Mr. Baker declared that from now on, "President Bush targets America." 
 With the appointment of his closest friend as chief of staff and senior counselor, the President gutted the top ranks of the State Department and swept through the upper echelon of the White House.
 
Seeking Another Mandate
 "We must insure that the United States is unquestionably safe and strong at home and abroad," Mr. Bush said in a White House appearance. "And I also want his counsel and assistance as I seek a mandate from the American people to put this program into action."
Mr. Baker resigned as Secretary of State effective Aug. 23, after the Republican National Convention, but he clearly left the door open to resume the job if Mr. Bush wins in November. Deputy Secretary Lawrence S. Eagleburger will serve as Acting Secretary.
By replacing Samuel K. Skinner as chief of staff and taking on the new counselor's title, Mr. Baker assumes what Mr. Skinner described today as "unprecedented" power: combining control of the White House, the campaign and foreign policy into one office.
Another senior official said, "It's the closest thing we've had to a deputy President in modern history."
 
Holding the Reins
 Mr. Baker has always run the State Department with the help of a small inner circle. A senior department official said today that Mr. Baker would use his contacts and his broad responsibilities as chief of staff to remain involved in foreign policy.
Pushing aside Mr. Skinner and significantly reducing the influence of his campaign manager, Robert M. Teeter, Mr. Bush moved Mr. Baker and his circle of close aides into jobs that the White House made clear will be directed as much at winning Mr. Bush a second term as at running the executive branch.
Mr. Teeter "will continue to run the campaign under the direction of the President and the chief of staff," said Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.
"The campaign leadership and Secretary Baker have had long experiences with working together." he added, explaining a move that sent a wave of relief through White House and campaign officials but drew immediate fire from Democrats.
They accused Mr. Bush of sacrificing national security to political ambition at a time when the Middle East peace talks have not concluded and the Balkan war threatens the "new world order" Mr. Bush has tried to establish.
Mr. Fitzwater countered: "We want the best team we can get. We want the best players here, and we've got them and we're moving forward."
 
Stand on Ethics Reassessed
 Mr. Fitzwater said the political activities of Mr. Baker and his principal aides would not violate a 1991 directive by C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, forbidding campaign work by the White House staff. The memo noted that Federal law made it illegal to use White House money or equipment for campaign purposes and that "certain restrictions" were imposed on political work, even by Mr. Bush's senior appointees.
Mr. Fitzwater said the counsel, who was designated by President Bush as his ethics policeman, had now reviewed his earlier position with the help of Justice Department lawyers and decided that these appointments did not violate it.
Mr. Gray and Justice Department officials said today that previous White House chiefs of staff, including Mr. Skinner, had played important campaign roles. The chief of staff position is not covered by the Hatch Act, the Federal law barring Government workers from political activities.
Mr. Bush was described by aides as relieved but a bit vexed, perhaps because a campaign that he had expected to be a virtual coronation had deteriorated to the point where he had to turn once again to Mr. Baker, who rescued his campaign in 1988.
During a day of announcements, news conferences and speeches, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker signalled a new turn in the President's efforts to bolster his dismal poll ratings. He and Mr. Baker acknowledged that Mr. Bush's domestic policies had disappointed many Americans, but said he had been consumed by pressing world affairs.
"I recognize that many Americans today are anxious, many have genuine concerns and others have doubts," Mr. Bush said at the White House. "But over the past four years Americans have accomplished results that once seemed beyond possibility."
 
'No Apologies for That'
 His words were amplified by Mr. Baker in a speech at the State Department. "Some will ask why President Bush spent so much time on foreign policy during his first term, and here is my reply," Mr. Baker said.
"The President saw a chance to take on the two central problems of our age -- the struggle for freedom and the threat of nuclear war -- and he seized it," Mr. Baker said. "No apologies for that. It's time now to turn to new challenges."
The Democrats wasted no time attacking the President over the shift. Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee, said in California that he worried that the move would hurt the Middle East peace process and make the Republican campaign "cleverly negative" instead of "clumsily negative."
"He's one of the best politicians, deal makers and political handlers they've got," the Arkansas Governor said of Mr. Baker.
Mr. Clinton also sought to brush aside the new argument that Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker were trying to make. "I think this argument that we had to take care of the world in our first term, and now we'll get around to America if you'll give us another term, I don't think the American people are going to find that too persuasive," he said.
 
Gore Sees a 'Panic'
 His running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, called the move "a sign of extraordinary political panic to take a sitting Secretary of State out of the Mideast talks and the other negotiations that are under way to concentrate purely on political activities."
Democratic reaction from Capitol Hill was negative. "Jim Baker was doing such an excellent job as Secretary of State that I believe this move is a mistake and not in the national interest," said Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
White House aides gritted their teeth against the criticism. "I am sure that Secretary Baker is pleased and proud of this newfound respect that he's getting from Democrats," Mr. Fitzwater said. "Eat your heart out, folks."
In replacing Mr. Skinner, the President gave the former Transportation Secretary a consolation prize: naming him "general chairman" of the Republican National Committee, which was been largely an honorary post.
 
Recruiting the Old Team
 Mr. Baker, meanwhile, essentially reassembled the team that helped him run Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign, removing them from the powerful State Department posts in which they have helped Mr. Baker run foreign policy in a tight circle based on personal loyalties and longstanding relationships.
Bringing those aides with him was apparently part of the deal that Mr. Baker struck with Mr. Bush, beginning with a conversation the two men had on a fishing trip to Wyoming last month.
Margaret D. Tutwiler, Mr. Baker's close aide and spokeswoman, will become White House communications chief. Mr. Fitzwater, who held that job briefly, returns -- "happily" as he put it -- to his spokesman's role.
Robert B. Zoellick, Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs, will become deputy chief of staff; Dennis B. Ross, the State Department director of policy planning, will take on that same post -- a new one -- at the White House; and Janet Mullins, who was Mr. Baker's Congressional liaison, will be the White House political director and campaign liaison.
 
Some Familiar Faces
 There was widespread speculation that Mr. Baker would bring back Republican strategists who had been excluded from the campaign by Mr. Teeter, including Roger Ailes, Mr. Bush's 1988 advertising consultant; Kenneth Duberstein, who was Mr. Reagan's last chief of staff; and perhaps even Edward J. Rollins, who briefly worked for the Ross Perot campaign.
Clayton K. Yeutter, the White House domestic policy coordinator, is expected to leave the Bush Administration and return to his private life in Illinois.
Mr. Skinner's deputy, W. Henson Moore, will be put in charge of White House relations with state and local governments.
In an interview, Mr. Skinner, whom Mr. Bush praised lavishly, put the best face on his removal, saying he had gone to Mr. Bush two or three months ago and suggested that Mr. Baker needed to be brought back. "We knew we were in a fight for our life," Mr. Skinner said.
Mr. Baker was White House chief of staff in 1984, during Ronald Reagan's re-election campaign, and ran campaigns for Mr. Bush in 1980 and again in 1988, when he came in to help revive the Vice President's fortunes as he trailed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis after the Democratic National Convention.
 
Even More Powerful
 But Mr. Baker in 1984 did not have undisputed sway over either the White House, where other powerful figures challenged his authority, or over the campaign.
Today, campaign and White House aides talked happily about a new phase in the campaign. But for the two men at the top, it may in some ways be a return to an old one.
In 1989, when Mr. Bush took office, he had to deflate Mr. Baker after suggestions that Mr. Baker's deputies did little to quash talk that the new Secretary of State was a deputy president.
No sooner had Mr. Bush announced today's move than the talk started again, and Mr. Fitzwater found himself having to stress reassure the press corps that Mr. Bush, not Mr. Baker, was in charge.
"He's been chief of staff before, and he knows the position," Mr. Fitzwater said.
"The President maintains all of the policy prerogatives that he always has. There's no change."

Both men have vowed to salvage the President's re-election campaign. At left was Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A14)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: Friend in a Time of Need

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
James A. Baker 3d is a formidable political operator, and he should have no trouble in imposing order upon the disarray that he inherits as impresario of President Bush's re-election campaign. He has Mr. Bush's ear, and he tells him what he thinks in an uninhibited, fraternal way. His new role will do wonders for Republican morale in the days ahead.
But Mr. Baker is subject to the same limitations as all campaign managers. A shrewd tactician can give an edge to a candidate, but at the Presidential level he cannot do the candidate's job, nor can he often change the direction the political winds blow. 
 James A. Farley in the 1930's and Lawrence F. O'Brien in the 1960's were considered master manipulators, but their candidates, Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy, were their own biggest electoral assets. Farley, O'Brien and Svengali together could not have elected Adlai E. Stevenson or Barry Goldwater or Michael S. Dukakis.
 
Baker's Strategy
 It is Mr. Bush, not Mr. Baker, who must be the medium for whatever message the new chief of staff may come up with; it is he who must make the speeches, he who must debate Mr. Clinton and he who will be pictured in the television advertising. What message and what means of delivering it will convert the President from a symbol of what has gone wrong to a symbol for its cure?
Mr. Baker will give it a good try. He provided a clue to his strategy when he said in his farewell remarks at the State Department that Mr. Bush had been obliged to concentrate on foreign policy in his first term because of a momentous series of upheavals in the world, but was now ready to turn to the domestic concerns -- jobs, schools, health care -- that preoccupy Americans.
But Mr. Bush has been trying to sell that line since the New Hampshire primary this year, when he traveled to that economically squeezed state and told voters tired of foreign policy speeches, "Message: we care."
Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, a leader among his party's conservatives, was as happy as any other Republican to hear that Mr. Baker was taking over. He warned, though, that "there's no magic bullet, no miracle to be worked" in the campaign.
It will be harder this time than it was in 1988, when Mr. Baker stepped in to rescue Mr. Bush at the nadir of another Presidential campaign. Then Mr. Bush, however indifferent a campaigner he had proved, was the heir-apparent to an immensely popular President, the economy was booming and he had a clean slate on which to write his pledges and portray his virtues. Now he is an unpopular incumbent, well known to the voters, burdened with a limp economy.
It may be harder even than in 1976, when Mr. Baker almost piloted Gerald R. Ford to victory over Jimmy Carter, despite Mr. Ford's pardon of his disgraced predecessor, Richard M. Nixon.
 
Setting Goals
 Defining the task is simple enough. Almost all senior politicians in both parties agree that the President's biggest problem -- bigger than his broken promise not to raise taxes, bigger than the recession -- has been his failure to articulate a series of goals for the United States in the decades ahead and the means of achieving them. As a Senator who sees Mr. Bush regularly put it, "He hasn't yet, at this late date, given the country a reason for voting him a second term, and if he can't do that, then he will not be re-elected."
It is widely believed that Mr. Carter failed to provide the voters with a picture of what his second term might be like, and he was denied one.
Mr. Baker's main job is developing such a message, setting priorities, and finding a way for Mr. Bush to sell them to a dubious electorate. Yet Mr. Baker has never been any more expert in the conception of sweeping themes than the President himself. He is the Republicans' supreme pragmatist, ever suspicious of ideology.
There is also the inherent contradiction that faces the incumbents in a year when even they concede the national craving for change. Mr. Bush said this morning of Mr. Baker, "He knows about change, how to distinguish wise moves from foolish ones." Mr. Baker sought to portray the first Bush term as showing how to master change.
Mickey Kantor, a member of Mr. Clinton's inner circle, put the point with partisan acerbity. Mr. Baker will be very hard put, he said, to "give the President a vision transplant."
Mr. Baker is not to take over his new job until after the Republican National Convention, which opens on Monday in Houston, but he will have to go to work sooner than that.
His first task is to banish defeatism, and he made a start on that in his State Department talk. The critics said the United States could not put together and sustain a coalition in the Persian Gulf war, and it did, he reminded his co-workers. They said this country could not produce meaningful Middle East peace talks, and it did.
The message was plain: Despite the polls, despite the quiet desperation in Republican ranks, despite voters' confusion about what the Administration stands for, George Bush and Jim Baker, the dynamic duo, together again, will once more silence the skeptics and put Bill Clinton and Al Gore to rout.
In the three weeks since the Democratic convention, Mr. Bush has been unable to make a significant dent in the Democrats' lead. By past standards, he should have cut it in half, at least, by this stage. Now the goal is to do so by Labor Day, which is three weeks away, and that may prove to be impossible unless the convention and Mr. Bush's speech next Thursday are big hits.
But then, Mr. Bush would not have proposed the switch, and Mr. Baker would not have agreed to make it, unless things were pretty desperate. The Secretary of State is only very reluctantly moving back to precisely the job he held before moving to the Treasury and then on to the State Department, and he is not helping his own prospects of running for President in four years.
 
What About the Balkans?
 Furthermore, the President has opened himself to criticism on several grounds. A European ambassador said today that the President, by nearly cleaning out the upper echelons of the State Department, "makes it look as if he puts a higher priority on his own survival than on any world problem -- Somalia, Bosnia, the Middle East peace talks, the Iraq crisis, you name it."
Mr. Bush's old friend and counsel, C. Boyden Gray, had only recently issued a memorandum arguing that, from an ethical point of view, campaign tasks should not be undertaken by members of the White House staff, which of course is exactly what Mr. Baker plans to do. So the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, had to go through a lot of contortions about the essentially inseparable nature of policy and politics to cope with that embarrassment.
Finally, from a purely political perspective, Mr. Bush looks like a weak leader, a candidate who can find only one man with whom he is truly comfortable and upon whom he can rely for advice and support in extremis. That puts Mr. Baker in a strikingly powerful position. Washington was talking of him today as a Deputy President, and some voters may find that an excessive role for someone nobody voted for.
None of that will matter if Mr. Baker can turn the campaign around, of course, and many things could happen between now and November that would make his job easier, like a major crisis abroad or some deeply damaging new revelation about Mr. Clinton's past. But at the moment this looks as if it may be one of those years, like 1912, 1932 and 1952, when the tide runs so strongly against the "ins" that it is difficult for the most accomplished campaign strategists to divert it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Chrysler asked Alan Greenspan for help on its $6.8 billion loan package. The company asked the Fed chairman to intercede with Germany's central bank on its behalf, because a few banks in the 152-member worldwide consortium, including a German institution, are refusing to renew their loans. The company and analysts view the loan package as vital to its revitalization. [Page D1.]
Kirk Kerkorian's apprehensions about Chrylser management were quelled. Two top executives and an outside director of the anto maker held a peace conference with the investor, who owns 9.9 percent of the company's stock. [D4.] 
 G.M. raised its prices on 1993 models by 1.6 percent on average, less than Ford and Chrysler. Some prices were lowered. [D4.]
Equitable Companies lost $17.6 million from continuing operations in the second quarter, considerably lower than its $212.6 million loss a year earlier. It went public in July. [D3.]
P. A. Bergner & Company is outraged. The troubled retail chain thought it had a deal with Arthur C. Martinez, whom Sears, Roebuck hired away from Saks Fifth Avenue. [D3.]
Triton Energy announced the resignations of two top officers, William Lee, chief executive, and David Gore, president. [D3.]
 
Markets
The bond market experienced a sharp selloff, following a report that seemed to indicate that the White House was more interested in stimulating the economy than in reducing the deficit. The yield on the long bond jumped above 7.41 percent. [D1.]
Gold prices plunged to a six-year low -- $334.10 an ounce on the Comex, down $4.50, as investors and speculators began selling because of low inflation numbers. [D1.] The dollar fell against most major currencies. [D13.]
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.56 to close at 3,313.27, as stock prices responded to the drop in bond prices. [D6.]
Three commodity exchanges agreed to stay in New York, preserving 9,000 jobs and $50 million in tax revenues. The three exchanges -- the Coffee, Sugar, and Cocoa Exchange; the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange -- had considered moving to New Jersey. [B1.]
 
The Economy
The Congressional Budget Office called the economy tepid, torpid and anemic, saying it was on "the verge of a sustained recovery," but would not grow enough to reduce unemployment significantly before Election Day in November. The report offers little solace to President Bush. [D1.]
Economic statistics offered little hope of recovery. Even though retail sales climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in July, and consumer inflation scarcely grew, workers' buying power fell. [D4.]
Vehicle sales rose 11.4 percent in early August. Sales of domestically built trucks soared 32.2 percent in response to new buyer incentives, but passenger car sales slid 1 percent. [D4.]
Workers increasingly are operating outside the corporate fold. Some are thriving; some are struggling. [A1.]
 
International
Japan was nervous about the North American free trade pact, fearing its own export-driven economy would suffer. [D6.]
Bankers fear Brazil's foreign debt accord could fall apart because President Fernando Collor de Mello, trying to avoid impeachment, has begun a political spending campaign. [A3.]
 
Today's Columns
Mortgage bankers are trying to sell their stock, taking advantage of a price boom borne of low interest rates and refinancings by mortgage holders. Market Place. [D6.]
Advertisers show little interest in the Republican convention. Indeed, the networks earned dismal ratings for their coverage of the Democratic convention last month, and less drama is expected from the G.O.P. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Latest Economic Data Show More Listlessness

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
In a flurry of mixed but essentially uninspiring economic statistics, the Government reported today that retail sales climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in July while workers' buying power fell, even though consumer inflation was very modest.
Another report showed that first-time claims for unemployment insurance dropped 66,000 in the week that ended on Aug. 1, reversing an increase in the preceding week related to a temporary companywide shutdown by the General Motors Corporation. 
 Today's figures, which included a rise in the Consumer Price Index of just one-tenth of 1 percent, might have been regarded more favorably if not for a downward revision in June's retail sales that transformed an advance of five-tenths of 1 percent into a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent.
Retail sales, which account for about a third of economic activity, were thus considered something of a disappointment, and analysts said they still did not see any significant pickup in an economy so sluggish that five straight quarters of growth have yet to convince many Americans that the recession is over.
"It just doesn't have any verve, vim or get-up-and-go," Paul W. Boltz of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore said of the economy.
The Commerce Department's initial tally, based on a small sample of its retail respondents, showed July sales at $159.5 billion, up five-tenths of 1 percent for the month and 3 percent above the level of July 1991.
Although the figures are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences, price changes are ignored. With consumer inflation at 3.2 percent the last 12 months, this means the volume of goods moving across retail counters the last year has been almost unchanged.
Sales of nondurable goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, with increases posted for nearly all categories. Receipts were up 2.3 percent for department stores and others selling general merchandise, while the gains were nine-tenths of 1 percent for restaurants and bars, eight-tenths of 1 percent for apparel and accessory stores, two-tenths of 1 percent for gasoline stations and one-tenth of 1 percent for food stores.
The only decline was at drug and proprietary stores, which slumped two-tenths of 1 percent.
All big categories of durable goods contributed to an overall advance of four-tenths of 1 percent. Stores selling furniture, home furnishings and equipment did best, posting a 1.3 percent gain; automotive dealers eked out a one-tenth of 1 percent increase.
Most analysts remained unimpressed. "There is nothing in these figures that suggests the economy is even close to emerging from the slow growth pattern," said Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers.
 
Prices Remain Stable
 The report by the Labor Department that the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in July was seen as reflecting a weak economy as well as providing reassurance that inflation remained firmly under control.
Of the seven principal groups, only transportation and medical care -- both of which rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month -- had sizable increases. And even the rising cost of medical care has moderated of late; it was up at an annual rate of 6.1 percent over the latest three months, compared with 7.8 percent for the quarter that ended in April.
The cost of housing slowed to a one-tenth of 1 percent advance last month from four-tenths of 1 percent in June, while food prices declined slightly with the aid of a 3.6 percent drop for fresh fruit.
Airline fares, which had dropped nearly 10 percent in the preceding two months, rose 3.2 percent in July. The so-called core inflation rate, with food and energy excluded, was up two-tenths of 1 percent in July, the third straight month at this pace.
For the five metropolitan areas for which July data were published today, there were increases of three-tenths of 1 percent for New York and Los Angeles, lesser increases for San Francisco and Chicago and a one-tenth of 1 percent decline for Philadelphia.
The one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers pushed it to 140.5, meaning that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 base period now costs $14.05.
Services, which account for 55 percent of the index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month while commodities, accounting for 45 percent, rose one-tenth of 1 percent, less than in May or June.
The companion Consumer Price Index covering urban wage earners and clerical workers rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, to 138.4.
The Labor Department also calculated today that real average weekly earnings fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July, reflecting hourly earnings and weekly hours worked that were both unchanged as prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
The decline of 66,000 in initial jobless claims, the biggest in 13 years, put the total at 403,000 for the week ended Aug. 1, returning it to near the 400,000 level of July 18.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
ESCOBAR INDICTED IN BROOKLYN
Pablo Escobar, who is said to run the Medellin cocaine cartel, and the man described as the cartel's top assassin, Dandeny Munoz-Mosquera, were indicted in Brooklyn on Federal charges of blowing up an Avianca airliner in 1989, killing all 110 people on the plane. When Mr. Munoz-Mosquera was arrested in Queens last year, Federal agents were unable to charge him with anything more serious than making false statements about his identity although they said they believed that he had murdered many people in Colombia. B3.
 
A DEADLINE LOOMS FOR DAILY NEWS
With a deadline looming from the bankruptcy court, the issue of which prospective buyer will be able to acquire The Daily News will probably be settled soon. Then again, maybe not. B3. 

STRANDS OF EVIDENCE PRESENTED
Prosecutors in the case against Alejandro Henriquez presented their strongest pieces of evidence to a Bronx jury: hair and fiber samples they say link the defendant to all three young victims he is accused of strangling to death. B2.
 
WOODY ALLEN SUES FOR CUSTODY
Woody Allen, the prolific film maker who once confessed, "I like to spend my time with work and only a limited time with kids," filed suit against his longtime companion, Mia Farrow, for custody of their three children. B3.
 
REGION
 
A LOT OF PEOPLE, A FEW POLICE
While a special state commission examines the disturbances that erupted June 14 along the boardwalk in Belmar, N.J., the man leading the investigation said he was surprised that trouble had not occurred elsewhere where small police departments have to deal with big crowds. B4.
 
OPENING UP THE PORT AUTHORITY
Amid widespread allegations of excessive spending, and under pressure from lawmakers in Trenton and Albany, the commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted to end a decades-old procedure of using executive sessions to conduct business outside the public eye. B4.
 
WATER USE ON THE RISE
Despite year-round conservation measures, water use in Nassau County is on the rise, raising new concerns about the potential contamination of the county's underground water supply in the coming decades, Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli said. He called for a tightening of state restrictions on water pumping in the 51 water districts in the county, even if it means further limits on water use. B4.
 
A HOLE IN THE NEW JERSEY BUDGET
Saying that New Jersey is "paying the price for the static national economy," Treasurer Samuel F. Crane announced that the state finished the latest budget year $37.6 million in the hole, largely because it collected less sales tax than expected. The gap represents about three-tenths of 1 percent of the $11.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that ended June 30. B5.
 
SUING TO SAVE THEIR JOBS
The state's largest public employee union filed a lawsuit in state court to block the layoffs of 1,200 of its members. The defendants are Governor Florio, Personnel Commissioner Anthony J. Cimino and Treasurer Samuel F. Crane. B5.
 
Our Towns by Kirk Johnson B4

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Four Who Will Help Baker Run the White House and a Campaign

 BODY:

Janet Mullins
Assistant to the President for Political Affairs
Was Assistant Secretary of State for Legislative Affairs . . . Known for her political insights with a strong desire to keep her life as private as possible . . . 43 years old . . . Popular on Capitol Hill . . . Was director of Congressional affairs for the Bush Presidential transition team . . . Executive Director of Fund for America's Future, Vice President Bush's political action committee . . . National Field Director for Mr. Bush's 1988 primary campaign . . . Chief of staff for Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, from 1985 to 1987 . . . Legislative Director and Chief of Staff for Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, from 1979 to 1982 . . . Was Special Assistant to the Kentucky Deputy Secretary of Commerce.
 
Margaret Tutwiler
Assistant to the President for Communications
Was Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs and the department's spokeswoman . . . Known for her political savvy and ability to deal with the press . . . Instant access to Mr. Baker, who relies on her political judgment . . . Was top deputy to Mr. Baker when he led the 1988 Bush-Quayle campaign . . . Was Mr. Baker's Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs at the Treasury Department . . . 42 years old . . . Served in the Reagan White House as Deputy Assistant to the President for political affairs . . . Was public affairs representative for National Association of Manufacturers in Alabama and Mississippi before joining George Bush's 1980 campaign . . . Hobbies include gardening and collecting Persian carpets.
 
Dennis B. Ross
Assistant to the President for Policy Planning
Was Director of policy planning at the State Department . . . specialist in Middle Eastern affairs, but also played major role in setting policy toward the former Soviet Union . . . Coordinated with Moscow policies toward Iraq leading up to the Persian Gulf war . . . Regarded as hard-working, private, nonpartisan and moderate . . . A major architect of the Middle East peace talks since then . . . National security adviser on the 1988 Bush-Quayle campaign and transition team . . . 43 years old . . . Handled Middle Eastern affairs as staff member on the National Security Council from 1986 to 1988 . . . Former deputy director of the Pentagon office that compared Soviet and American military abilities . . . Hobbies include golf and basketball.
 
Robert B. Zoellick
Assistant to the President and Deputy Chief of Staff
Was Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs . . . Specialist in economics, trade and international environmental policy . . . Known as a humorless technocrat with a talent for organization . . . Along with Dennis B. Ross, a member of James A. Baker 3d's policy-making advisers . . . Counselor and executive secretary in Treasury Department in 1988 . . . In 1985, special assistant to Deputy Secretary of Treasury Richard G. Darman, who said "he can do more first-class work in 24 hours than 12 ordinary people could do in 24 hours" . . . 39 years old . . . Staff assistant in the Justice Department's Criminal Division in early 80's . . . Hobbies include military history and long-distance running.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Clinton's Speech on Foreign Policy Leadership

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech today by Gov. Bill Clinton to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council.
The world remains a place of peril. While the Soviet Union is gone, a President must still be ready to defy and to defeat those who threaten us. Whatever else we expect of our Presidents, we still need a resolute leader who will wield America's might, and marshal all our resources and the resources of our allies to defend our most fundamental interests. 
 And yet today there are new tests of leadership as well. The first is to grasp how the world we live in has changed. The second is to assert a new vision for our role in this dynamic world. The third is to summon all of our strength, our economic power, our values, and, when necessary, our military might in the service of our new vision.
I do not believe that Mr. Bush has met these tests. Despite his clear effectiveness in organizing the allies against Iraq's aggression. Too often this Administration has held on to old assumptions and old policies, trying to prop up yesterday's status quo, failing to confront our new challenges.
I have agreed with President Bush on a number of foreign policy issues, but I do not believe he has a complete vision of this new era. In a world of change, security flows from initiative, not from inertia.
Next week, the Republicans will gather in Houston to nominate Mr. Bush and to praise his record. Will they paint a partisan portrait of the past? Or render a vision of the future that we Americans can build together?
 
Credit for Communism's Fall
 In their campaign, the Republicans have already tried to claim sole credit for the victory of freedom, in the United States, and in the cold war. And they suggest that in their second term they will finally bring to domestic policy the same energy and expertise marked by foreign policy in their first term.
This argument misreads both history and current events. The notion that the Republicans won the cold war alone reminds me of the rooster who took credit for the dawn.
The truth is that from Truman to Kennedy to Carter, Democrats as well as Republican Presidents have held firm against the expansion of communism. From Richard Russell to Scoop Jackson to Sam Nunn and Les Aspin, Democratic leaders in Congress have helped build the finest defense forces in the history of the world.
More important, we must never forget that in the end, communism rotted from the inside out, with heroes both famous and unknown leading the way.
Even more flawed is the Republican claim that just as they changed the world in their first term they can now change America in their second, or fourth.
We must understand that foreign and domestic policy are now two sides of the same coin. If we're not strong at home, we cannot be strong abroad. And if we can't compete in the global economy, we will surely pay for it here at home.
The same President who refused to make changes, as American wages fell from 1st to 13th in the world, as our productivity lagged badly behind other nations, was slow to recognize changes in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
The same Administration that has so far done nothing for 10 million Americans unemployed, and more than two-thirds of our work force whose wages are now lower in real terms than they were 10 years ago, stood by as courageous Chinese students were attacked by tanks in Tienanmen Square.
A preference for the established order over constructive change gives an enormous advantage in the world in which we live to the high-wage, high-investment, high-growth nations, in Europe and Asia, with which we must inevitably compete for the futures of every man and woman, every boy and girl, in the United States of America.
Global change is inexorable, and can work to our advantage or to our disadvantage, depending on what we do.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The currency of national strength in this new era will be denominated not only in ships and tanks and planes, but in diplomas and patents and paychecks. My first foreign policy priority will be to restore America's economic vitality.
I have laid out a strategy to raise our people's skill levels, boost productivity, spur innovation and investment, reduce the national debt and make us the world's strongest trading partner.
I will elevate economics in foreign policy, create an economic security council similar to the National Security Council and change the culture in the State Department so that economics is no longer a poor cousin to old school diplomacy.
In a Clinton-Gore administration, Presidential leadership will mean mobilizing our country for the global economic competition that is the hallmark of this new age. It will mean securing commitments from American business and American labor to take on new cooperative responsibilities.
For there can be no growth without increased productivity in the private sector. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	Imagine where we would be today in California if before the big defense cuts started in 1988 we had a plan to reinvest every dollar of those defense cuts in retraining the work force, in giving companies time to retool, in reinvesting in new technologies like high speed rail, recycling, waste reduction, new systems of transportation and communication, all of which are consistent with a new approach to energy and the environment.
It would have made a big difference in California, and you wouldn't be in the fix you're in today if we'd had that plan then. It is not too late, but we must begin to pursue that course.
The second imperative of Presidential leadership in this new era is to reinforce the powerful global movement toward democracy and market economies. Our strategic interest and our moral values are both rooted in this goal.
As we helped democracy expand, we make ourselves and our allies safer. Democracies rarely go to war with each other, or traffick in terrorism. They make more reliable partners in trade and diplomacy.
Growing market economies expand individual opportunity and social tolerance.
Yet Mr. Bush has been oddly reluctant to commit America's prestige to the side of the people inspired by America's own example. When democratic reformers sought to break up the Soviet empire, this Administration at first snubbed Boris Yeltsin, sided with the crumbling Soviet center and failed to lead the call for aid to Russia until the President was pushed into it by Richard Nixon and others.
When 50 million Ukrainians sought emancipation from the dying Communist empire, this Administration withheld moral support, and instead, in Kiev itself, the President publicly chided Ukraine's voices of independence for seeking, I quote, a suicidal nationalism.
When China cracked down on pro-democracy demonstrators, exported advanced weapons to radical regimes, and suppressed Tibet, this Administration and this President failed to stand up for our values. Instead he sent secret emissaries to China signaling that we would do business as usual with those who murdered freedom in Tienanmen Square.
And when it was clear to all that Yugoslavia was inexorably breaking apart, Mr. Bush and his secretary of state gave short shrift to the yearnings of those seeking freedom, in Slovenia, Croatia, and Bosnia; and ignored the warning signs that Milosevic was emerging as one of Europe's bloodiest tyrants.
 
Standing for Democracy
 From the Baltics to Beijing, from Sarajevo to South Africa, time after time this President has sided with the status quo against democratic change, with familiar tyrants rather than those who would overthrow them, and with the old geography of repression rather than a new map of freedom. . . .
My administration will stand up for democracy. We will offer international assistance to emerging fragile democracies in the former Soviet Union, and Eastern Europe, and create a democracy core to help them develop free institutions.
We will keep the pressure on South Africa until the day of true democracy has dawned. 

 	 	 		. ..	 	We can never forget this essential fact: power is the basis for successful diplomacy. And military power has always been fundamental in international relationships. So a President must provide the American people with a clear explanation of our enduring security interests, and a new estimate of the threats we are likely to face in the post cold war era.
So far, in my judgment, this Administration has failed to supply that rationale; failed to give a clear strategy for a new national security; and that is fueling isolationism here at home from both the left and the right.
Today there are two wrong-headed and dangerous approaches to adjusting our defenses for this new era. One is the administration. It talks of strategic change, but basically, simply shrinks the existing cold war force structure.
Continuation of this policy runs the risk of weakening the two elements that were absolutely critical to our victory in the Gulf: our superbly trained and motivated personnel and our world class weapons technology.
At the same time, there are those, some in my party, who see defense cuts as largely a piggybank to fund domestic wish lists. With our defense structures and missions as a mere afterthought rather than a starting premise.
This policy would also weaken our technological superiority, and the quality and morale of our superb personnel.
Leadership demands more than a cold war minus or domestic spending plus approach to the defense of this nation.
A President must identify the new threats to our security, define military missions to meet those threats, adapt the forces to carry out the missions, and back up the forces with the training, technology and intelligence necessary to prevail.
We must start with a fresh assessment of the new dangers that could threaten our interests and potentially require the use of force, including the risk of new threats from former Soviet republics should democracy fail, especially before all the nuclear weapons had been dismantled.
The spread of weapons of mass destruction, historic tensions in various regions, especially the Korean peninsula and the Middle East. And the related risks of terrorist attacks. And the growing intensity of ethnic, fundamentalist, and separatist violence, as we have seen in Yugoslavia and elsewhere, that can spill across borders and engulf other nations.
The mission of containing an expansionist Soviet Union has disappeared, but an enduring mission remains. To maintain nuclear deterrence even as we reduce nuclear arsenals. To reassure our friends and allies and discourage potential adversaries. To pursue our interests when possible through strengthened institutions of collective security. To preserve freedom on the high seas and protect our global economic interest.
And to provide the superior technology and forces that are the ultimate guarantor of liberty. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	 My administration will make security and savings compatible. It will reduce forces, but maintain a credible presence in Europe and Asia. We will stand up for our interests, but we will share burdens, where possible, through multilateral efforts to secure the peace, such as NATO, and a new voluntary U.N. rapid deployment force.
In Bosnia, Somalia, Cambodia, and other torn areas of the world, multilateral action holds promise as never before, and the U.N. deserves full and appropriate contributions from all the major powers.
It is time for our friends to bear more of the burden.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Says Bush Failed Leaderships Tests Abroad

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton challenged George Bush today in the area the President boasts as his greatest strength, the conduct of foreign policy, and pronounced the White House approach "flawed" because it ignored domestic economic problems.
Mr. Clinton, who has more often stressed his agreement with the President on the handling of policy matters in the Middle East and Eastern Europe, abandoned that approach today to try to prove that the Governor of a small state can handle international concerns. 
 "Whatever else we expect of our President, we still need a resolute leader who will wield America's might and marshal all our resources and the resources of our allies to defend our most fundamental interests," Mr. Clinton said in a speech to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council.
"And yet today there are new tests of leadership as well," he said. "The first is to grasp how the world we live in has changed. The second is to assert a new vision for our role in this dynamic world. The third is to summon all of our strengths, our economic power, our values and, when necessary, our military might in the service of our new vision.
"I do not believe Mr. Bush has met these tests."
 
More Aggressive Approach
 The Democratic nominee has stepped onto foreign policy turf before, delivering speeches at Georgetown University in December and to the Foreign Policy Association in New York last spring. Both were intended to demonstrate that he had firm opinions on international issues.
But as the Bush Administration has challenged Mr. Clinton in recent weeks by suggesting that he could not be trusted to handle such serious matters and would be "reckless" in formulating American policy, Mr. Clinton has grown more aggressive as well.
The Arkansas Governor said his plans to revive the nation's economy would be his "first foreign policy priority." He also said his administration would offer foreign aid to emerging democracies, support the peace process in the Middle East, support the creation of a Radio Free Asia and act in concert with other nations to support democratic forces throughout the world.
"We will make the United States the catalyst for a collective stand against aggression, the action I have urged for some time in response to Serbian aggression in Bosnia, one with which the Bush Administration now agrees after the President's press secretary first called it reckless."
Mr. Clinton supports increased financing of some new military technology, including the C-17 aircraft, the V-22 Osprey aircraft, which takes off like a helicopter and flies like a conventional plane, and the Seawolf submarine. He also said the United States should be prepared to make increased use of National Guard and Reserve forces "so that our use of force will be considered with utmost seriousness, maintained affordably and supported broadly at home."
He said shifting the emphasis to more mobile forces would result in military budget savings of about $60 billion more than President Bush has proposed over the next five years.
"My administration will make security and savings compatible," Mr. Clinton said. He said he would accomplish this in part by forcing other American allies to share more of the burden for maintaining peacekeeping forces in Europe and elsewhere.
"In Bosnia, Somalia, Cambodia and other torn areas of the world, multilateral action holds promise as never before, and the U.N. deserves full and appropriate contributions from all the major powers," he said. "It is time for our friends to bear more of the burden."
In his remarks today, he stressed the link between a robust American economy and strength abroad, saying that "foreign and domestic policy are now two sides of the same coin."
Mr. Bush, he said, "abdicated leadership" on global environmental issues at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in June, has tried to "prop up yesterday's status quo," and has allowed a debt-laden economy to become his Administration's "most glaring foreign policy failure."
"In a world of change, security flows from initiative, not from inertia," Mr. Clinton said. His remarks seemed designed to be a pointed response to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's assertion today that the Bush Administration has scored impressive foreign policy victories.
"The notion that the Republicans won the cold war reminds me of the rooster who took credit for the dawn," Mr. Clinton said.
"We must never forget that in the end, communism rotted from the inside out, with heroes both famous and unknown leading the way," he said.
Mr. Clinton particularly criticized the White House as being slow to come to the aid of democracy protesters in China, tardy in recognizing the impending changes in the former Soviet Union and negligent in supporting human rights elsewhere.
"From the Baltics to Beijing, from Sarajevo to South Africa, time after time, this President has sided with the status quo instead of democratic change, with familiar tyrants rather than those who would overthrow them, and with the old geography of repression rather than a new map of freedom," Mr. Clinton said.
In every discussion he has held about foreign policy, Mr. Clinton has been asked how he would be able to handle international concerns when his experience has been largely domestic and political. Today was no exception.
He said that he would not relish the prospect of sending citizens into combat, "but neither do I flinch from it." He stressed his support -- although it was late in coming -- for President Bush's decision to use force in Kuwait. And he stated categorically that his administration would punish American companies that sold nuclear technology to "outlaw states like Iraq."
Before he delivered today's speech, Mr. Clinton told reporters: "The issue on foreign policy is, How much do you understand about the world? What are your values? What is your judgment? Do you have the personal strength to make the right decisions? The two great wars we fought in this century were led by presidents who came to the White House from the governorships."
The tougher talk about his own resolve and experience reflected a new direction for Mr. Clinton as he seeks to capitalize on the combined strengths that he has said he and Senator Al Gore, his running mate, bring to foreign policy.

HEADLINE: Rabin Hailed by Jewish Officials, Relieved Over Improved Relations

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Fresh from securing President Bush's support for $10 billion in United States loan guarantees, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel received a warm reception in Manhattan yesterday from officials of American Jewish groups, many of whom expressed relief that several years of cool relations between the Bush Administration and Israel had come to an end.
Mr. Rabin, in his first major meeting with officials of American Jewish groups since he led the Labor Party to an election victory in June, pledged a "new order of national security policies" in Israel that focused on jobs and education. He outlined his Government's program to the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, an umbrella group of 50 national Jewish organizations. 
 Speaking at the Plaza Hotel, Mr. Rabin said that only in a revived economy could Israel successfully absorb the 400,000 Jews who have come to Israel from the former Soviet Union over the last few years.
"This is what is important to Israel, more than three settlements or 10,000 units in the territories," he said to applause from the American Jewish officials and referring to his decision to freeze construction of new settlements in the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Mr. Rabin also attended a fund-raising dinner with prominent Jewish philanthropists, among them Leslie Wexner, the president and chairman of The Limited Inc., and Charles R. Bronfman, co-chairman of the Seagram Company.
As a sign of the mood that one figure described as "controlled euphoria," officials of the United Jewish Appeal said they raised $67.3 million at the dinner, making it the most successful fund-raising event in their history. They said the money would be used to help Israel resettle Jews from the former Soviet Union.
Joel D. Tauber, the national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, said donors were encouraged both by Mr. Rabin's plans to emphasize Israel's economic redevelopment and by the repaired relationship with Mr. Bush.
"We're Americans and we're all pleased that our country is cooperating with Israel," he said. "It just makes you feel better."
Several people who attended the meeting predicted that the agreement on loan guarantees would help Mr. Bush recover some of the Jewish support that he had lost when he blocked the loan quarantees more than a year ago. The United States had insisted Israel halt building settlements in the occupied territories as a condition to receiving the loan guarantees, a condition former Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had refused to meet.
"I think both Mr. Rabin and Mr. Bush had a domestic need to repair the relationship and especially to put the loan guarantee controversy behind them and they have suceeded in that," said Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
But others said that the accord came too late and feelings were too bitter for Mr. Bush to gain significant Jewish support in the November election.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Platform;
Party Takes More Conservative Stance Than Bush

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Republicans today adopted a party platform embracing a degree of social and religious conservatism that at times goes beyond the stands taken by President Bush.
The most obvious example is support for a Constitutional amendment that would outlaw abortion. Although Mr. Bush would permit legal abortions when pregnancies were the result of rape or incest, the platform calls for prohibiting such exceptions. 
 The platform also repudiates the tax increases Mr. Bush signed two years ago. And it calls for building a fence along the Mexican border to keep out illegal aliens, a step that offends many Mexicans, just when Mr. Bush is trying to expand trade with Mexico.
After approving the platform today, the delegates tried to reach out to the people who disagree with some of the conservative planks, particularly those who advocate a right to abortion. The resolution, offered by Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, an ardent foe of abortion and the dominant voice on the platform committee, states:
"We respect the honest differences of opinion of those Republicans who debate our positions on important issues and look forward to working with them toward Republican victories in November. Most importantly, we invite all Americans to join our party, to support our candidate and consider our platform, which represents the views of mainstream Americans."
While the conservatives clearly controlled the reins here this week, a few Republicans said they feared that the party was risking victory in the election by being so rigid. Richard M. Rosenbaum, the national committeeman from New York, said in an interview that he was "deeply troubled" because he thought some of the conservative planks would cost Mr. Bush votes in New York and elsewhere.
During the four days of drafting, some proposals were rejected on the ground that they ran counter to Mr. Bush's policies. Such was the case when the delegates defeated an attempt today to have the platform oppose favorable trade status for China.
 
Conservatives on Top
 But the defeats for the conservatives were few and far between.
In the area of education, for example, the platform opposes birth-control counseling and the distribution of condoms in schools, and it advocates voluntary prayer and the recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in classrooms. The document supports access to school property for Bible clubs, home schooling and Government tuition subsidies for students in private and parochial schools.
On other issues, the platform opposes same-sex marriages and adoptions by same-sex couples, and it favors the ban on homosexuals in the military. It supports a law making the deliberate spread of the AIDS virus a crime, and it states explicitly that the use of condoms and needle exchanges do not prevent AIDS.
For a political document, the Republican platform has an unusually strong religious content. It states the party's belief in the Judeo-Christian tradition and declares that "faith in God" along with "hard work, service to others and limited Government" made the nation prosperous. The third paragraph after the preamble has a quotation from the Book of Proverbs: "Train up a child in the way he should go and when he is old he will not depart from it."
The preamble has this passage: "In choosing hope over fear, Americans raised a beacon, reminding the world that we are a shining city on a hill; the last best hope for man on earth."
A few female delegates tried to delete the phrase after the semicolon or to change the word "man" to "humankind." They got little support. But there was signficant support for several delegates who thought the same phrase should be eliminated because it suggested that Jesus Christ was not the last best hope. In the end, the entire passage was retained.
The economic section advocates a wide variety of tax cuts favored by President Bush, like a tax credit for first-time home buyers and a reduction in the capital-gains tax. But it also goes beyond any tax break proposed by the Bush Administration by calling for an eventual increase in the personal exemption, the deduction a taxpayer can take for each family member, to about $5,000, more than twice what it is now.

HEADLINE: Slow Growth Foreseen By Congressional Office

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office said today that the United States economy was on "the verge of a sustained recovery," but would not grow enough to reduce unemployment significantly before Election Day in November.
The agency's forecast for economic growth over the next 18 months was summed up in three adjectives: tepid, torpid and anemic. 
 The report offers little solace or encouragement to President Bush as he faces an election campaign in which economic conditions are expected to be the most important issue.
 
2.5% Growth Predicted for 1992
 The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the economy will grow 2.5 percent from the final quarter of 1991 to the final quarter of 1992. "Such anemic growth will not permit a rapid drop in unemployment," the report said.
In July, 9.8 million Americans -- 7.7 percent of the work force -- were jobless.
"Although many new jobs will be created as economic growth picks up, this recovery is also expected to see an unusually large number of job losses," the Congressional Budget Office said, because of cuts in military spending and layoffs by large corporations trying to reduce costs and increase productivity.
The budget office said that the military cutbacks would, by 1995, eliminate more than 800,000 jobs in the armed forces and companies that do military-related work for the Government. In 1991, six million people were working in such jobs, about half in the Government and half in private industry.
The forecast by the Congressional Budget Office is less optimistic than that of the Bush Administration, which sees economic growth of 2.7 percent in 1992. The economy grew only three-tenths of 1 percent in 1991. The budget office forecast is generally in line with projections by private economists.
The budget office sketches an exceedingly grim picture as it scans the coming decade, from 1992 to 2002. Based on current trends and policies, it said, the Federal budget deficit will soar to $514 billion, from $314 billion, its revised estimate for the current year. The figure for this year is up from $269 billion last year and is a record, but it is well below the $352 billion projected by the budget office in January.
Federal spending for Medicare and Medicaid, the health programs for the elderly and the poor, will triple, to $605 billion from the current $198 billion, it estimated.
The Federal debt, which represents the accumulated total of all Federal borrowing, will more than double, to $6.5 trillion in the year 2002, from the current $3 trillion, the budget office said, forcing the Government to double the amount it pays in interest on the debt, to $410 billion in 2002, from the current $200 billion.
By 2002, the report says, the Federal debt will be equivalent to 66 percent of the gross domestic product, the highest such proportion since 1951, when the Government still owed huge amounts from World War II. The Government's current debt is equivalent to 51 percent of the gross domestic product, the total output of goods and services.
The Congressional Budget Office said the pace of economic growth projected for 1992 and 1993 was "only half the rate that normally occurs in the first two years of an economic recovery."
The decline in this year's deficit forecast results mainly from a delay by Congress in approving money needed to bail out savings and loan associations and to protect depositors. Once approval is given, spending of that money will increase the Federal budget deficit in the future, the report said.
The economy has been so sluggish in the last year that it "hardly seems like a recovery," the report said. Moreover, it said, the recovery is not progressing under its own power, but has been sustained in recent months by the repeated lowering of interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
The report estimates that the jobless rate will average 7.5 percent this year. In January, the Congressional Budget Office and the Bush Administration predicted that the jobless rate for this year would be 6.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Japan Reacts Cautiously to North American Trade Accord

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Japan reacted cautiously and nervously today to the new agreement to spur free trade in North America, fearing that the accord could hurt its export-driven economy and leave it the only major economic power not part of a trading bloc.
Some Japanese officials said the North American Free Trade Agreement, if it turns out to be exclusionary, could cause Japan to reconsider the idea of an Asian trading region, something the nation has opposed. "There will be more intense discussion about the idea of Asian integration," said a Foreign Ministry official involved in economic matters. 
 The United States has been opposed to an Asian trading bloc, fearful that it would be excluded from the world's fastest-growing economic region. Malaysia has made a proposal for a trading bloc that would exclude the United States and be led by Japan.
 
Preference for Free Trade
 So far, Japan has sided with the United States in opposing the Asian bloc, saying it prefers free trade worldwide. Indeed, any gains to the United States from the opening of the Mexican market by the North American trade agreement could be more than offset if it ends up provoking measures that close off the Asian market.
Japan, which has a lot to lose if other nations protect their markets from imports, has been worried about both the North American Free Trade Agreement and plans for an economically unified European Community. And while Japan has often been accused by other nations of being an unfair trader, it has recently become more vocal in criticizing what it sees as the unfair trade practices of other nations.
Officially, Japan said today that it "in principle welcomes" the conclusion of the North American agreement, which would gradually eliminate tariffs and barriers to trade among the United States, Canada and Mexico.
But it said it would seek assurances that the agreement would not act as a barrier to Japan in the North American market and that it would conform to the worldwide trading principles known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
"Looking at the agreement, there seem to be certain elements negative to third countries, including Japan," Yasuo Tanabe, director of North American trade policy planning for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said in an interview today.
Foremost among them, he said, was a provision that would gradually raise the percentage of North American content that would be required in a car for it to be moved from one North American nation to another without duties. The new rule would be 62.5 percent compared to 50 percent under the existing United States-Canada trading agreement.
 
Japanese Plants in Canada
 Three Japanese companies now have plants in Canada that export to the United States without paying tariffs -- Toyota, Honda and a joint venture of Suzuki and the General Motors Corporation. The United States has charged that the Honda cars do not meet the 50 percent requirement, although that dispute is now apparently being settled in Honda's favor, Mr. Tanabe said.
