HEADLINE: Fewer Ties Are Bonding Workers to Corporations

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Robert Hempstead and Lawrence Gundrum represent two sides of the new economy, where fewer and fewer people work full time for big companies. They are part of the growing ranks of American workers who operate outside the corporate fold that had been the ideal of work life throughout the postwar years. Some are thriving; some are struggling.
The 48-year-old Mr. Hempstead of Los Gatos, Calif., is an expert in the intricacies of disk drives, the storage boxes in computers that hold vast amounts of data. After 11 years at I.B.M., he worked for a few Silicon Valley start-up ventures before setting himself up in 1989 as a one-man contractor available to companies for special projects. 
 Since then, the work has come to Mr. Hempstead. He has never lifted a phone or sent out a resume to hunt for a job. He makes up to $200,000 a year. "I'm free to do what I want and work for people I like," he said. "I love this."
Mr. Gundrum, a 49-year-old from Rowley, Mass., has not fared as well. A senior engineer and project manager at the General Electric Company's aerospace operations in Massachusetts, he was laid off at the end of 1988 in one of the company's many rounds of job cuts. At first, the electrical engineer, who also has an M.B.A. degree, was able to get good jobs with smaller firms.
But the moribund New England economy and the decline in the aerospace industry led him to switch fields, after three stints on unemployment that ate up his life savings of $60,000. Mr. Gundrum is now a loan officer for a Boston bank who gets no salary but a commission on each mortgage loan he lands.
 
'Humbling Experience'
 This year, he expects to make less than a third of the $80,000 a year he made in his best years. He is hopeful about his new career, optimistic that his income will rise considerably in time, but he admitted, "The past few years have been a devastating, humbling experience."
Mr. Hempstead and Mr. Gundrum live a continent apart in starkly contrasting circumstances and work in different industries, but they are both part of the fast-changing relationship between corporate America and the nation's workers.
Straining to become more nimble and entrepreneurial, big companies are paring down to a smaller, core work force, while increasingly farming out all sorts of Fewer Ties Are Bonding
Workers to Companies
tasks once handled in-house like corporate travel, payroll, even product design. The workers supplying these services go by various labels -- contingent workers, contractors, consultants, freelancers, temporaries -- and the satellite firms that employ some of them are said to be in the "outsourcing" industry.
 
The Companies
Headquarters Staff Will Be Shrinking
 An economy with slimmed-down companies that buy most services from outside suppliers could be more flexible and competitive. But economists warn there is also the danger that the losers, like Mr. Gundrum, may far outnumber the winners, like Mr. Hempstead.
"The worry is that this will tend to create a dual economy in America," said Michael Piore, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Some people will do very well, but many more could end up without medical care, training opportunities or job security."
The phenomenon is difficult to measure precisely, but the trend is evident. The total employment at the Fortune 500 companies fell by 2 million, to 12 million, from 1985 to the end of last year. Workplace Trends, a bimonthly newsletter, reports that the number of people who lost jobs in cutbacks jumped from 110,000 in 1989 to 550,000 -- or more than 2,000 every workday -- last year among American companies that publicly reported staff reductions.
For the first seven months of this year, Workplace Trends says, permanent staff cuts are running 2.3 percent ahead of last year's pace.
Experts insist that few of these jobs will return when the economy improves because most companies are changing the way they operate rather than merely reacting to the recession. "There's a revolution going on in corporate America: companies getting lean, faster moving and more flexible," said William Morin, chief executive of Drake Beam Morin Inc., which finds jobs for laid-off managers and professionals. "It's never going to be the same again."
The idea of farming out work to others is certainly not new. But what is happening now takes it much further. Companies are looking closely at virtually everything they do and applying the market test: can it be done at least as well and cheaper by an outside supplier?
So things like legal work, data processing, travel, accounting, marketing research, product design, warehouses and cafeterias are being contracted out to individuals or specialist firms that provide a certain service to a handful of larger companies. What remains within the walls of a big company is, in managerial parlance, its core -- its essential skills handled by full-time employees.
In the future, that core may be surprisingly small. The current model of a big glass-and-steel corporate headquarters on landscaped grounds, directing a worldwide army of tens or hundreds of thousands may soon be a thing of the past. The corporation of the future, says Charles Handy of the London Business School, will be a core of a couple hundred people overseeing lots of related businesses, from factories to laboratories, that can range from wholly owned subsidiaries to independent subcontractors.
 
The Employees
Many Will Become Contract Workers
 Most workers, some experts predict, will have tailored employment contracts, and portable pension funds, roving from company to company to suit the needs of businesses and their own preferences. "We'll have extraordinarily sophisticated employer-worker relationships, so that almost everyone will be a contract worker," said William Davidson, a professor at the University of Southern California business school.
The process, they say, will move well beyond big companies, and to some degree it already has. Today's service subcontractors often pay outsiders to do chores for the same reasons that big companies do: to curb costs and keep their in-house experts focused on their specialties.
Wendy Liebmann, a former Revlon marketing executive, founded a New York marketing research consulting firm in 1986. Since then, the client list has grown to include Revlon, Colgate Palmolive, Conde Nast and others, but the firm still operates with a core of three professionals. Tasks like field research are farmed out to others. "We believe in hiring outside specialists just as our clients hire us as specialists," Ms. Liebmann said.
Analysts predict that temporary-help companies are poised for strong growth, once the economy recovers, because companies will hire crews of outsiders instead of adding permanent people.
And Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary-help company, expects to see further growth in its business of supplying clients with teams of people to handle entire service functions. Today, about 20 percent of its $1.5 billion-a-year business comes from managed services, meaning Manpower comes into a company with people and runs services like mailrooms, copy centers or telephone-marketing operations. Two years ago, contract services accounted for only 8 percent of the business, estimates Mitchell Fromstein, the company's president. John Poland, vice president for managed services, said his customers "are pushing us in this direction as fast as we can go."
In Cary, N.C., the Knowledge Systems Corporation is a high-tech subcontractor. The 35-person company is a specialist in an advanced computer software method known as object-oriented technology, which allows programs to be written in modules that can be linked together in different combinations. Its clients include Hewlett-Packard, Texas Instruments and I.B.M., and its employees are typically rented out as consultants or team leaders to product development groups in the big companies.
"Ours is a niche business with highly talented people in a specific domain," explained Reed Phillips, chief executive of Knowledge Systems.
John Mason, a 36-year-old computer scientist for Knowledge Systems, has just finished a two-year assignment as a player-coach working with a development team at a nearby I.B.M. programming lab. "Because I know the technology, I can speed up their work by pointing out shortcuts and how to avoid problems," he said.
Yet I.B.M. is a supplier of contract services as well as a buyer. A services subsidiary, Integrated Systems Solutions Corporation, runs much of the data processing under contract for companies like Eastman Kodak, United Technologies, Continental Bank and Supermarkets General.
In the first half of this year, I.B.M.'s revenue from services, including Integrated Systems, jumped 42 percent. "This kind of outsourcing is a real growth business," said Lane Jorgensen, manager for market support and planning.
 
The Bottom Line
A Boom for Some; A Bust for Others
 The people who work outside the big-company fold as contractors, consultants and freelancers are as varied as the work they do. Some speak with disdain of full-time employment with a large company as "going captive," while others hope to use contract work as a bridge to a permanent job. Contract workers, especially skilled engineers, can often make better money in the open market. They also prefer to sidestep big-company politics, often like to travel, and say that moving from project to project gives them a steady diet of technological challenges.
A 45-year-old engineer, Terry Arthur is a established contract worker. His expertise is in designing aerospace parts to withstand the stress of supersonic flight. Over the years, he has crossed the country working on the C5-A cargo plane, the Lockheed L-1011 passenger jet and Grumman's F-14 fighter, among others. Today, he is working on modifications to the Gulfstream G-4 executive jet in Savannah, Ga., under contract from Butler International Inc., a temporary-help concern that supplies engineers and technical workers.
He makes over $100,000 a year, working 50-hour weeks, leading a design team of 31 people. Through Butler, he has good medical and dental coverage, for which he pays $520 a month. His wife, Chris, and his 17-year-old son, Joseph, live in Marietta, Ga., a four-hour drive he makes on weekends. His 20-year-old daughter, Katie, attends Auburn University.
"I take a risk as a contract worker, and my family took a risk," he said. "But it's allowed me to work on a lot of new projects, and that's the exciting part of engineering."
The risk proved to be greater for Norman Johnson Sr., an electrical engineer who started as a contract worker in 1980, at age 50, after a series of regular jobs at big companies, including Raytheon and I.B.M. He admits that the shift to contract work was not entirely voluntary. "Most big companies won't hire people in the sciences at that age," he said. "Their attitude is that your skills are outdated."
For years, Mr. Norman did well, earning nearly $100,000 annually in his best years. The contract work also gave him free time to work on a passion and possible second career, as a clown. But when the economy soured, the parts-testing contract job he had disappeared at the end of 1990, when Pitney Bowes shut down the operation to which he was assigned. He could not find work elsewhere, his income plummeted, he was forced to sell his three-bedroom house in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and filed for personal bankruptcy last year.

HEADLINE: It's the 90's, Counselor: 'Superfluous' Fees Denied

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
"Even a Michelangelo should not charge Sistine Chapel rates for painting a farmer's barn," Judge Joseph Weis of the United States Court of Appeals for the 3rd Circuit in Philadelphia wrote a decade ago. Now, another Federal Judge, Gene Carter of Portland, Me., has gone one step further: when 47 lawyers from 16 law firms apply a bit of superfluous trim to barn freshly painted by others, they should not receive a dime.
Judge Carter's decision flowed from one of the last great hostile takeovers of the 1980's, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's 1989 acquisition of a smaller pulp and paper manufacturer, the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation. And his blistering 61-page ruling, with Judge Weis's Michelangelo remark on the cover, signaled the end, for these plaintiffs' lawyers at least, of an era in which money flowed freely and giant fees were forked over with few questions asked. 
 The unfortunate 47 -- from 16 different law firms, largely in New York but also from Philadelphia and Chicago -- represented some Great Northern shareholders who sued company management for resisting the takeover attempt. After the $6 billion deal was struck in February 1990, the lawyers submitted a $2 million bill to Georgia-Pacific, charging $641.85 for each of the 3,121.25 hours that they said they had worked on the case.
 
Raising the Price per Share
 To justify their fee, the lawyers contended that their efforts had helped persuade Georgia-Pacific to increase its offer from $3.18 billion to the $3.74 billion it eventually paid, or from $58 to $63 per share. They had initially demanded $10 million. And with Georgia-Pacific agreeing to pay, the fix appeared to be in, subject to the judge's approval.
But as things turned out, they made their request in the wrong case at the wrong time in the wrong place before the wrong judge. On July 30 Judge Carter, egged on by a "friend of the court" brief from the State of Maine, stepped in and not only denied them the fees but lambasted them as well.
For all their apparent activity, Judge Carter ruled, the lawyers for the shareholders did little more than piggyback on the work already being done by Shearman & Sterling, counsel for Georgia-Pacific. Though the shareholders' interests and those of Georgia-Pacific clearly differed -- the former sought sale at the highest possible price, the latter at the lowest -- both pushed for a deal. And to Judge Carter, it was Shearman & Sterling that was doing all the heavy lifting, while the shareholders' counsel went along for the ride.
"The vast amounts of time and expense" the shareholders' lawyers had had generated in the case, he wrote, were "both frivolous and parasitic."
Judge Carter peppered his opinion with words like "superfluous," "duplicative," "excessive," "egregious," "exorbitant" and "extravagant." Moreover, he acerbically reviewed the lawyers' working, reading, faxing, phoning and even their eating habits -- all of which, he maintained, made their unproductive efforts still more costly.
 
Return to Frugality
 "This case is, in a way, a fin-de-siecle event," said Stuart J. Baskin of Shearman & Sterling. "These lawyers were forced to defend an 80's-era fee in a region where 90's-era frugality has been a way of life since the 1690's.
Stephen D. Oestreich of Wolf, Popper, Ross, Wolf & Jones of New York, who led the plaintiffs' lawyers group, called the ruling "just dead wrong" and said charges that he and his colleagues ran up bills on make-work were "unwarranted." He contended that Judge Carter had not understood the case, that he had misperceived their role and that he had applied a double standard in which corporations could hire lawyers to their hearts' delight while shareholders had to economize mercilessly.
But John C. Coffee, a securities law expert at Columbia Law School, said Judge Carter had simply called attention to a truism in corporate takeovers: that shareholders' lawyers routinely exaggerated their contributions, and that companies involved in acquisitions, eager to avoid nuisance suits, routinely pay them to go away.
"This court just rebelled at the notion of lawyers claiming they were the cause of something that was clearly driven by other market factors," he said. "When you have a law firm with all the resources of Shearman & Sterling, the plaintiffs' lawyers are at best a fifth wheel and probably a free rider."
 
'No Coercion, No Duress'
 The best indication that the shareholders' lawyers had helped, Mr. Oestreich said, was that Georgia-Pacific had agreed to pay them. "There was no coercion, no duress," he said. Appearing before Judge Carter, however, Mr. Baskin of Shearman & Sterling described the lawyers' role more diplomatically. "They were trying to be helpful and trying to assist," he said.
Great Northern's lawyer, Bernard J. Nussbaum of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz of New York was still more cryptic, calling the shareholder litigation "a factor" in Great Northern's handling of the case.
In addition to Wolf, Popper, the firms affected include Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Specthrie & Lerach; Kaufman, Malchman, Kaufmann & Kirby; Stull, Stull & Brody; and the offices of Curtis V. Trinko and Joseph H. Weiss, all of New York; Kahn, Robinson, Curley & Clayton and the law office of Frederic F. Brace Jr., both in Chicago; and Berger & Montague of Philadelphia.
Even if the lawyers had affected the outcome of the case, Judge Carter wrote, they did not deserve anything close to what they were asking. He accused them of documenting their charges inadequately, padding their bills, racking up hours to produce documents that were already available from other cases, duplicating one another's efforts, charging rates for work that was performed by partners but that could easily have been assigned to secretaries, and billing to attend depositions where their presence was unnecessary and they sat mute.
He noted that lawyers from Berger & Montague in Philadelphia, for instance, attended five depositions in New York without asking a single question. He further noted that the lawyers collectively billed $8,583.11 for reading newspaper coverage of the takeover. He pointed out, too, that Steven Schulman, a lawyer at Milberg, Weiss, submitted bills for four meals in a single day.
"He may have worked up an enormous appetite recording the vast numbers of hours that he billed in this litigation, but the Court will not allow his meals to be subsidized," Judge Carter wrote. Mr. Schulman did not return a phone call seeking comment.
The visiting lawyers, particularly Mr. Oestreich of New York, clearly aroused Judge Carter's dander. He seemed especially annoyed by claims that the out-of-towners had expertise that local lawyers lacked.
"Despite Mr. Oestreich's fulsome testimony in praise of the highly refined legal acumen of himself and his confreres and his condescending assessment of the local bar," the judge wrote, "there is no showing in the record of such luminous skills in pursuit of the shareholders' interest."
 
Efficiency Questioned
 In fact, Judge Carter wrote, the very length of time the outside lawyers poured into one particular motion -- 20 lawyers from 11 firms spent 900 hours -- "casts grave doubt on the proposition that Mr. Oestreich and company from outside the district are, in fact, the superior lions of specialized art and proficiency that he has proclaimed them to be."
Mr. Oestrich said he could think of nothing he had said or done in Maine to have aroused Judge Carter's ire. "We held the lawyers in Maine in the highest esteem," he said. He added his group had not yet decided whether to appeal Judge Carter's decision.
Many of the examples the judge cited were culled from the lengthy "friend of the court" brief that the state of Maine filed in the case. As a frequent defendant in civil rights and constitutional cases in which lawyers' fees are assessed, the state had a vital interest in how courts access legal fees, said Peter J. Brann, the assistant attorney general who wrote the brief.
"The lawyers in this case treated themselves like the national touring company of the Broadway show, 'Anything Goes.' ," Mr. Brann said. "But these costs are all passed on, and eventually someone, whether it's shareholders or consumers, has to pay the piper."
"Up to now it's been easier for people to look the other way," Mr. Brann said. "Maybe the 80's are finally over."

Stephen D. Oestreich, who led a group of lawyers representing Great Northern shareholders in favor of the takeover, called the ruling "just dead wrong." (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Drops to a 6-Year Low

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Gold prices plunged yesterday to their lowest level in six years, provoked by a spiral of selling by investors and speculators worried that this month's low inflation figures spell the end of a recent rally in gold.
The price of gold for delivery this month dropped $4.50 an ounce yesterday, to $334.10 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. In the last three days, August gold on the exchange has dropped $16.30 an ounce, or 5 percent. In London, gold slumped $9.50 an ounce yesterday, to $337.30. 
 The sudden drop wiped out weeks of incremental advances, which many traders and analysts had heralded as the long-awaited comeback in the gold market after years of moribund trading.
Yesterday's New York close was the lowest since Jan. 1986, when gold bottomed at $326.30, according to Daphne Bloore of the World Gold Council, an association of gold-producing companies.
This week's fall came as speculators, betting heavily on a rising gold price, were surprised by a convergence of economic factors that were minor when viewed independently but scared traders into selling.
"It was like a snowball effect," said Warren Myers, vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. "Commodity funds were liquidating their positions, and fear began feeding on itself."
Oddly, one of the factors that initiated the selling panic was a rise in gold prices in Australia, which kicked off a flurry of sales by major Australian gold producers. At the same time, a trio of economic indicators in the United States signaled that inflation was remaining low. Gold is a favored hedge against inflation.
When platinum prices suddenly dropped, the selling panic was on. Managers of large commodity funds, many of whom had accumulated large gold positions as the price rose in recent months, became afraid of further price drops and began selling. Speculators in heavily traded gold futures contracts joined the retreat.
"There has been a lot of hype recently about how well the fundamentals were doing," said Raymond Schenk, head of precious metals trading at Credit Suisse. "But when people realized that the bullish sentiment was exaggerated, it started a whole chain reaction of selling. Everybody is suddenly running for the exits."
Mr. Schenk explained that many gold traders plan to sell once the price falls to a specific level; this week's fall accelerated after the price of gold fell below $342 an ounce on Wednesday. Now that gold is under $335, Mr. Schenk said, it could fall even more precipitously.
But most precious metals analysts agree that an eventual and gradual rebound is likely because many of the speculators who sold gold short in anticipation of its fall will eventually have to buy into the market.
Mr. Myers of Merrill Lynch also noted that once the price of gold falls much below $350 an ounce, it becomes unprofitable for many gold producers to keep mining operations at full capacity. In South Africa, which produces more than 20 percent of the world's gold, producers are likely to cut production, which will nudge prices upward again as supplies are affected, he said.
"Although the momentum is distinctly downside, I think we're near the bottom," he said.
At the same time, he warned that prices were unlikely to rebound fast, unless some extraordinary event, like civil strife in South Africa, affected the world's gold output unexpectedly.

Pork Bellies Up
 (By The Associated Press) -- Pork belly futures leaped the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday on speculation about future sales of subsidized American pork to the former Soviet Union.
Corn and soybeans rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade on forecasts of lower production.
Oil prices rose slightly on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude oil for September delivery rose 26 cents, to $21.34 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Baker Plans Active Foreign Policy Role From the White House

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Although he is resigning as Secretary of State and moving to the White House, James A. Baker 3d and his aides plan to continue playing an active role in shaping American foreign policy from their new perch, particularly on the Middle East.
A senior official, briefing reporters immediately after Mr. Baker's farewell speech to State Department employees, said, "The fact that we are going to the White House does not mean that we are in any way precluded from being actively involved to the extent that we have time to be or want to be." 
 As a result, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who will move from Deputy Secretary to Acting Secretary, seems likely to serve as a caretaker, a role underscored today by the clear message from the White House that the door is open for Mr. Baker to return to the State Department, if Mr. Bush is re-elected. To the extent that Mr. Eagleburger is allowed to leave his own imprint in the last months of the Administration, it is not seen as likely to differ much from Mr. Baker's, since he comes from the same pragmatic school of American foreign policy as the other senior Bush advisers.
Although Mr. Baker is stepping down as Secretary at a time when there is no overriding foreign policy crisis facing the United States, there are several significant opportunities and regional problems that demand immediate attention, as well as a growing need to define a new framework for American foreign policy at a time when the old Cold War framework has disappeared.
 
Several Cases Unresolved
 Apparently in an effort to fend off criticism that he is walking away from American foreign policy at a time when Bosnia is aflame, when the situation in Haiti is unresolved and when the Arab-Israeli peace talks seem finally ripe for some progress, Mr. Baker is letting it be known that he and his principal foreign policy adviser, Dennis B. Ross, plan to continue influencing foreign affairs from the White House.
The mixing of foreign policy and campaign politics implicit in Mr. Baker's new role would not be new in Washington, although this may be a particularly visible case. The connection between foreign policy and domestic politics is often most acute during Presidential campaigns.
President Nixon's 1972 re-election effort, for instance, was clearly enhanced by his trip to China that year, the first by an American President. And President Carter's 1980 re-election campaign was badly wounded by decisions that he made on the Iran hostage crisis and the failed American rescue mission.
As a man steeped in politics, Mr. Baker has worked under the widespread assumption in Washington that politics and diplomacy were inseparable during his stewardship at the State Department. He reinforced that impression early in his tenure when he took a partisan shot at the Democrats from the State Department podium. But after being roundly criticized for that, he tended to keep his public distance from campaign politics and insisted that his recommendations and actions as Secretary of State were not distorted by political considerations.
 
His Farewell Speech
 But between now and the election, Mr. Baker, and the Administration, will be hard-pressed to sustain the view that campaign politics will not strongly influence Administration foreign policy. That was evident today in Mr. Baker's farewell speech at the State Department, which began as a review of what had been accomplished by the department in the last three and a half tumultuous years, and ended in a highly partisan re-election appeal for the President. Although Mr. Baker was given a standing ovation by the Department employees, many agreed with one official's assessment that "he should have stopped after the first 10 minutes."
Another question raised by the Baker appointment is how the lines of authority and communication on foreign policy will work now. Only hours after a senior State Department official said Mr. Baker and his aides would be keeping a hand in foreign affairs, particularly on the Middle East, a senior White House official briefing reporters said Mr. Baker would have no policymaking role on the Middle East and would only be an adviser.
Senior State Department officials speak of Mr. Eagleburger, as "managing" the department, but seem to suggest that the big decisions will be made by the President and Mr. Baker from the White House. The senior State Department official told reporters that Mr. Baker intended to remain "actively involved" in foreign policy, noting that the White House Chief of Staff job "has very very broad responsibilities." He said Mr. Baker, either personally or through Mr. Ross, would step in "as the need arises," and reminded reporters that Mr. Baker "will be next door."
 
How to Replace Traveling
 When the senior State Department official was challenged as to how Mr. Baker, who made 15 trips to the Middle East to get the Arab-Israeli peace talks to the point they are now at, intends to still play a role in those negotiations, he said, "Who says the parties can't come to the White House?"
Such comments, besides being intended to deflect criticism about Mr. Baker's abandoning diplomacy for politics, also seem intended to put at ease allies abroad who have longstanding working relationships with Mr. Baker and are now worried about a sudden shift in his absence.
This is particularly true of the Arab leaders -- Saudis, Egyptians, Syrians and Palestinians -- who appreciated what they felt was Mr. Baker's even-handed approach to the Middle East problems, who have been expressing anxiety about his departure and who view Mr. Eagleburger as overly sympathetic to the Israelis.
Mr. Eagleburger is not in the best of physical health. He showed up at the State Department today with his left arm in a sling, because of some medical tests, a cane by his side and an inhaler for his asthma in his hand.
When asked what happened with his arm, the ever-jovial Mr. Eagleburger simply responded, "You should have seen the other guy."
 
A Small Inner Circle
 Mr. Baker always ran the State Department through a small inner circle of advisers, whom he placed as a layer on top of the traditional foreign policy apparatus, and used them as the team with whom he focused his strategies for dealing with everything from arms control to the Middle East. They were Mr. Ross, the Policy Planning Director; Margaret D. Tutwiler, his spokeswoman; Robert Zoellick, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, and Janet Mullins, Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs. Mr. Eagleburger managed the day-to-day operations of the department.
Mr. Eagleburger may be best known for a prophetic speech he gave just as the Berlin Wall was wall crumbling in which he warned that while it was good that the cold war was over, ironically it one day may be missed because of all of the ethnic animosities in Europe that were artificially suppressed by the weight of Soviet occupation. A former Ambassador to Belgrade, Mr. Eagleburger also played a major role in shaping American foreign policy toward the Yugoslav problem, and admits that he in some ways misjudged the venom and intentions of the Serbs.
Mr. Baker's tenure as Secretary of State may well be remembered for the problems he solved and the problems he ignored. He and Mr. Bush were far ahead of the other allies in pushing for, and helping to structure, German unification. His knitting together of the coalition to fight the Persian Gulf war has been hailed as a highly skillful act of diplomacy. He negotiated both conventional and nuclear arms control treaties with Moscow that were praised even by the Democrats as very advantageous deals for the United States. And maybe most creatively, Mr. Baker managed to cajole, press and persuade Israel and all of its Arab neighbors to sit down together for face-to-face negotiations.
 
Deficiencies Listed
 But at the same time, he maintained a Reagan Administration policy of building up Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, long after the Iran-Iraq war had ended; he never challenged Mr. Bush's failed policy of constructive engagement with China's dictatorial leaders; he virtually ignored United States-Japan relations and was not even on Mr. Bush's disastrous trip to Tokyo last year; he was very slow in dealing with the crisis in Bosnia, and he has done little to really shape a post-cold war framework for American foreign policy.
"I think you have to give him immense credit for presiding over the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war," said Michael R. Beschloss, an historian of American foreign policy. The initiative came from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Beschloss added, but it was Mr. Baker's skill and his close relationship with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze that helped Washington exploit these opportunities, and helped the Soviets make some unpalatable concessions.
On the down side, Mr. Beschloss said, historians will probably focus on the fact that Mr. Baker ran the department with such a small group that he often could not deal with more than one issue at a time. For instance, he said, while focused on the collapse of the Soviet Union, they may have ignored or sent some very wrong signals to President Hussein, and they had little time or energy to think about a future vision of American foreign policy at this very confusing moment.
"Bottom line, though," Mr. Beschloss concluded, "I think historians will look back and say the most important thing that occurred during these years was the end of the cold war, and they will say that Baker helped it happen faster, more smoothly and on terms more favorable to the United States."

HEADLINE: Brazil Chief's Free Spending Imperils Debt Accord

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Trying to avoid impeachment, President Fernando Collor de Mello has begun a political spending campaign that bankers fear could unhinge an accord on Brazil's foreign debt.
A congressional panel that is investigating corruption charges is expected to issue a report in two weeks recommending Mr. Collor's impeachment. With the Chamber of Deputies likely to vote on impeachment in September, members of the President's Cabinet quoted Mr. Collor as vowing in closed meetings last week to spend billions of dollars on projects intended to guarantee the loyalty of 168 legislators needed to defeat the motion. 
 Bankers here are apprehensive about the effects a surge in public-works spending could have on the deal to reschedule Brazil's $44 billion debt to commercial banks, which calls for a tightening of inflation.
"If Collor has to buy his presidency, inflation goes out the window," the representative here of a foreign bank that negotiated the deal said on Tuesday.
 
Spending Lists Drawn Up
 He said there was a good chance that the deal, which was agreed upon in principle on July 9, would not go through because Brazil would be unable to meet the conditions set by the International Monetary Fund.
Last week, the President released $2 billion in new spending on social projects and farm credits, and ministers drew up spending lists totaling almost $5 billion, press reports here said.
Brazil is the developing world's largest debtor. In addition to the $44 billion it owes commercial banks, it has $72 billion of debt to foreign governments and other lenders.
Brazil and the International Monetary Fund, which partly guarantees the rescheduling agreement, have agreed on a monthly inflation goal of 2 percent by December. Inflation is currently running at 22 percent a month. With the surge in spending, economists predict a December inflation rate of 30 to 40 percent.
On Wednesday, an economic team flew to Washington with the latest numbers: Brazil's nominal deficit in the second quarter of 1992 exceeded an I.M.F. target by 30 percent, or $7 billion.
"The market is skeptical of this accord ever being implemented," Alden Brewster, president of Tisbury Capital Inc., a New York-based trader in third world debt, said on Tuesday.
 
Minister Is 'Resisting'
 Mr. Brewster said the price of Brazilian debt fell on the secondary market after the debt accord, in contrast to the responses to other Latin American debt deals. Reflecting market uncertainty, the price of Brazilian debt fell from 39 percent of face value in mid-June to 30 percent today.
But two negotiators of the accord retained their optimism this week.
"As far as the debt agreement goes we are moving ahead and we expect to start negotiation on the term sheet with the Brazilian side on Monday," said William R. Rhodes, a Citicorp vice chairman who supervises Latin American debt negotiations.
Mr. Rhodes said he had been assured by Brazil's leading economic officials last week that they "will stick to economic reform program and will not be deviated by political pressures."
Brazil's Economy Minister, Marcilio Marques Moreira, said in an interview this week that negotiations on the final details of the accord were progressing and that he was "resisting" pressure for increased Government spending.
But spending pressure mounts daily.
During two months of congressional testimony that ended on Wednesday, a picture emerged of Mr. Collor's turning a blind eye to an influence-peddling ring that paid millions of dollars worth of bills run up by the President's personal household. Mr. Collor's former campaign manager was said to have extorted millions of dollars in bribes and skimmed millions more through fixed bidding practices.
Today, the congressional panel voted to request the preventive detention of the ring's reputed leader, Paulo Cesar Farias, Mr. Collor's former campaign treasurer. and the freezing of his assets. Panel members said that in an 18-month period ending last April Rosane Collor de Mello, the President's wife, received $506,700 in checks drawn on accounts controlled by Mr. Farias.
The panel's report is due Aug. 26 and congressional leaders say that motions to impeach will be inevitable in September. To block impeachment proceeedings, the President needs favorable votes from 168 legislators in the 503-member Chamber of Deputies, or one-third.
To win this support, Mr. Collor, head of a small conservative party, entered into an alliance last week with the Liberal Front Party, a right-wing party strong in Brazil's impoverished northeast, where it has long been a political tradition to trade votes for public works projects.
 
Collor 'Underworld' Noted
 Last week, Jose Goldemberg, a respected former dean of Sao Paulo University, resigned as Education Minister, citing "an underworld" in the Collor administration. His replacement, Eraldo Tinoco, a Liberal Front member from the northeast, immediately announced that his "door will be permanently open to politicians."
Also last week, another Liberal Front member, Ricardo Fiuza, the Social Action Minister, broke with any austerity policies and asked members of Congress to send written requests for development projects to his ministry "as soon as possible."
This week, Isto E, a Sao Paulo newsweekly, predicted that President Collor would try to funnel $5 billion in development money to projects controlled by important members of Congress between now and Nov. 15, the end of a two-round mayoral voting process.
"The President is throwing everything that he has got to make sure that impeachment does not go through," said Amaury de Souza, a Sao Paulo political scientist.
 
Tax Receipts Are Down
 The problem is to find the money.
Tax receipts fell by 16 percent in the first half of this year, but the Government has promised not to print cash or to float bonds. Deep divisions in Congress appear to rule out approval of new laws to increase tax collection.
The Liberal Front president, Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, a northeastern state Governor, emerged last week as Brazil's de facto Prime Minister. Mr. Magalhaes all but demanded the resignation of Mr. Moreira, the Economy Minister, a former banker and Ambassador to the United States who is widely credited with restoring local and international business confidence in the Collor Government.
Mr. Magalhaes said of Mr. Moreira: "This talk that Marcilio is well known overseas is nonsense. The Varig manager in New York is better known than he is." Varig is Brazil's largest international airline.
In contrast, an American banker in New York said, "As long as Marcilio can keep his job and run economic policy, people in Washington will be eager to bend over backward."
 
Opposition Plans Rallies
 Mr. Moreira said on Tuesday: "It's not the moment for the captain of the economic team to leave. The country needs tranquillity."
With the Liberal Front committed to guaranteeing the survival of Mr. Collor for the second half of his term opposition politicians plan to organize rallies in September demanding his resignation.
"Presidents don't leave their palaces in handcuffs -- they leave before," said Ibsen Pinheiro, an opposition congressman who is president of the Chamber of Deputies.

HEADLINE: 3 Exchanges Agree to Stay, and New York City to Pay Half

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
At least three of the city's five commodities exchanges will stay in New York under an agreement announced yesterday to build a new trading headquarters in lower Manhattan. The agreement, announced by the exchanges, the city and the state, is intended to preserve 9,000 jobs and $50 million in tax revenues and calls on the city and state to finance half the cost of the new center.
The three exchanges -- the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the New York Cotton Exchange and the Commodity Exchange -- said the new trading center would cost about $150 million and would be considerably smaller than the center that was initially planned to house all five commodities exchanges, which had threatened last year to move to New Jersey. 
 The New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest of the five exchanges, withdrew from a plan to build a joint headquarters with the four other exchanges in January, citing unresolved differences over the scope of the project. It is looking for other space in Manhattan. The last and smallest of the five exchanges, the New York Futures Exchange, has not formally signed the agreement announced yesterday, but city and state officials said that they expected that it would.
Many city and state officials had all but given up on the project when the Mercantile Exchange pulled out. The agreement announced yesterday represented a last-ditch effort by the city and state to save the project by providing half the financing for the new commodities center, an usually high percentage of financing.
The New York State Urban Development Corporation will invest $27 million in the project and the city will provide a $26 million grant and $22 million in capital construction money. The remaining $75 million will come from private financing arranged by the exchanges.
 
Cuomo Calls News 'Exciting'
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo praised the agreement yesterday, saying in a statement: "The decision by the commodities exchanges to establish a new headquarters in New York City comes at a crucial time for the state and nation. With almost 2 million New Yorkers and 17 million people nationwide either unemployed or underemployed, this project is a rare bit of exciting economic news."
The new commodities headquarters will be built on a city-owned lot at Murray Street between West and Greenwich Streets, four blocks north of the World Trade Center, where the exchanges are currently situated.
The seven-story building will accommodate the trading, support and administrative staffs of the three exchanges. It will have a 51,000-square-foot trading floor with more than twice the size of the exchanges' current trading space. The building was originally proposed as a 47-story tower with two trading floors.
Planning for the new center began more than a year and a half ago when the five exchanges announced that they were unhappy with their cramped trading floor in the World Trade Center and would relocate to northern New Jersey, taking about $100 million in tax revenues and 11,700 jobs with them.
The five exchanges, which serve as marketplaces for trading futures and options contracts, have a history of squabbling. The Mercantile Exchange, which has about 3,500 employees and accounts for about half the $100 million in city and state tax revenues from the commodities industry, has said that a major reason it withdrew from the joint project was the inability of the exchanges to agree on a new joint system for computer tracking of trades, which was expected to save the exchanges $8 million a year. Telephone calls to officials of the Mercantile Exchange were not returned yesterday.
Barry Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said yesterday that the agreement insured that the scaled-back project would go forward, but he added that some minor details had yet to be agreed on. "I am just delighted that we have reached an effective deal that will keep vital jobs in our city." he said. "And we are hopeful, very hopeful that we can reach a deal with the other two exchanges as well."
 
City Plans to Recoup
 Carl Weisbrod, president of the City Economic Development Corporation, said that the city would provide the project with $22 million in capital construction money that has already been included in the city's budget. The city plans to recoup that money through a combination of higher rental fees at the new center and payments from the commodity exchanges in lieu of taxes.
The project, which was approved by the New York City Council and the New York City Planning Commission in March, also requires the approval of the Mayor and the State Urban Development Corporation; both have indicated their support. Construction of the project is expected to begin in the spring of 1993 and to be completed by the end of 1994.
Alan Hanson, a spokesman for the Commodity Exchange, said that officials of the three exchanges and state and city officials had worked hard in the past month to streamline the building so that it would be affordable while meeting the exchanges' needs.
One remaining barrier to the project is opposition from nearby residents, who have been pressing the developers for park space to be included in the plan, and have filed a lawsuit to block the project.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond and Gold Markets Jolted

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Word of James A. Baker's imminent return to the White House to help President Bush's flagging re-election campaign played an unexpected role yesterday in a sharp selloff of the bond market.
Traders said remarks by Mr. Baker, as reported by a news agency early in the afternoon, helped send the market reeling, just as it was digesting the auction of $10 billion in new 30-year bonds, the third tier of the Treasury's big quarterly sale this week. Some traders interpreted the remarks to mean that a new Bush Administration would be more interested in stimulating the economy than in reducing the Federal deficit. 
 Until the selloff, the 30-year bond auction had gone well, maybe even a little better than the auctions of 3- and 10-year notes this week. Like the others, yesterday's auction set a record, with the average yield of 7.29 percent being the lowest since 30-year bonds were first regularly auctioned in February 1977.
 
Giving Up a Week's Gains
 In late trading in the secondary market, the bond due in 2021 was off almost 1 1/4 points and the yield had jumped back to over 7.41 percent, giving up all the gains of the last week that took the yield to a 5 1/2-year low. The yield on Wednesday was 7.31 percent.
In the when-issued market before the auction for the new 30-year bond, the yield was 7.36 percent, up from 7.26 percent the day before. The 10-year note auctioned on Wednesday was also off sharply, falling 5/8 of a point, to yield 6.56 percent, compared with 6.47 percent the day before.
Some traders attributed the entire selloff to the report of Mr. Baker's remarks as he resigned as Secretary of State to become Mr. Bush's Chief of Staff. But other traders said different forces, including profit-taking and the current lofty level of the market, set off the decline. They said Mr. Baker's remarks as reported added to the sharpness of the fall.
"This is the kind of knee-jerk reaction we get because a lot of the market was overbought." said Matthew Alexy, a government trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation, explaining that a correction should be expected. All that was needed was something to set it off.
"But the Baker stuff did have something to do with it," he added.
 
Forces Behind the Rally
 Mr. Alexy was quick to point out that even with the decline in price of the long bond and the resulting jump in the yield, the market had lost only what it gained in the last week. And he said the forces that had been propelling the rally -- continued slow economic growth and declining inflation -- were still in place.
In fact, economic data released yesterday before the auction just seemed to reinforce this view. The Consumer Price Index was up just one-tenth of 1 percent in July and retail sales gained only five-tenths of 1 percent last month. And although initial claims for unemployment compensation dropped 66,000, the largest fall since 1979, the fall was just to 403,000, which has been the recent level of claimants.
In a short article carried on the Dow Jones News Service, Mr. Baker was reported to have said lower tax rates should be a key to President Bush's re-election campaign.
Although there were no direct quotes confirming this sentiment, several traders said investors seemed to conclude that a new Bush Administration would put less emphasis on cutting spending and lowering the record Federal deficit.
 
'Negative for the Market'
 "The balanced budget would take a back seat on the Administration agenda to lower taxes," said Greg Erardi, head government securities trader at Salomon Brothers in New York, giving his interpretation of the report.
"If this turns out to be true this would be quite a negative for the market," he added. An effort to simulate economic growth with tax cuts would worry investors because faster growth could rekindle inflation and lead to a rise in short-term interest rates. And adding to the Government deficit in the process would just multiply the impact.
According to the text of his speech, Mr. Baker said, "We should build on the fundamentals of lower taxes, limits on Government spending, greater competition, less economic regulation and more open trade that can unleash tremendous private initiative and growth."
Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush clearly hope that the former Secretary of State and Secretary of the Treasury can bring some political stability back to the Bush campaign. But even if his comments were not well interpreted by investors, traders said yesterday that he brought political risk back into the bond market, especially if the tone of his comments as reported was true.
 
Reason for Sluggishness
 "The additional political uncertainty of a Presidential election year is something that the market has not been noticing for some time," a government securities trader.
A rise in bond yields is clearly something neither Mr. Baker or Mr. Bush would like. High long-term interest rates are one of the reasons that the economic recovery is so sluggish. And the weak economy is a reason why Mr. Bush's re-election outlook is cloudy and one of the reasons he brought his longtime friend, Mr. Baker, back to the White House.
Several traders said that going into the auction, dealers had thought the yields bid would be 7.29 percent, 7.30 percent or even 7.31 percent. After the bidding deadline of 1 P.M., prices for the new bond began to decline, with yields rising. This apparently encouraged some dealers, who thought their bids of 7.30 percent would win, to sell off bonds in the when-issued markets to secure their expected profits on the bonds they would win in the auction.
But the average and high yields in the auction were both 7.29 percent, meaning that some dealers who had sold bonds before the results were not going to get them in the auction if they bid 7.30 percent. Now they had to scramble to cover the sales they had already made.
 
Market Feeds on Itself
 This buying sent the market prices higher and yields lower. Then, some investors decided to take profits and the yield began to rise again and the entire market began to fall sharply.
As the decline of prices and the rising of yields was continuing, Mr. Baker's comments were reported and the market dropped even further. "The market began to feed on itself," one trader said.
The coupon on the new 30-year bond is 7.25 percent, the lowest coupon since the May 1986 auction.

HEADLINE: Truck Sales Up 32.2% in Early August as Car Sales Slid 1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built trucks soared 32.2 percent in early August in response to new buyer incentives, but passenger car sales, reflecting the uncertain economy, slid 1 percent, according to figures released today by the auto makers. Combined, vehicle sales rose 11.4 percent.
The Ford Motor Company reported a 34.3 increase in truck sales from a year earlier, while the General Motors Corporation said it had a 23.5 percent gain. The Chrysler Corporation's truck sales rose 34.3 percent, according to an estimate. 
 Despite the 11.4 percent increase in total vehicle sales for the 10 major domestic auto makers from Aug. 1 to 10, the projected annual rate for new- car sales slipped to 5.8 million in the period, the lowest since early May.
The Government said today that consumer purchasing power had fallen in July for the second straight month, leaving Americans with less money for new cars.
And worries over the nation's high unemployment rate may have scared some would-be new-car buyers back into hiding. Surveys have said consumer confidence in the economy also fell in July after six consecutive months of improvement.
"The auto industry cannot outgrow the economy," said Doug Laughlin, an auto analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "This is an atypical recovery. Everybody gives lip service to it, but people make too much out of it when it's better than expected and too much out of it when it's worse than expected."
The strength in truck sales, often apparent at the end of a recession, has led the domestic industry's modest recovery all year. Some of those sales have come from car buyers' crossing over to mini-vans, sport trucks and inexpensive pickups.
End of model year incentives on trucks like Chevrolet's S-10 Blazer lifted G.M.'s truck sales in the latest sales period.
Chrysler truck sales, estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports, reflected mini-van incentives and surging demand for its new Jeep Grand Cherokee.
Ford's car sales rose 8.2 percent while G.M.'s car sales dipped 1.3 percent. As estimated by Ward's, Chrysler's car sales fell 24.5 percent.
There were eight selling days in this year's Aug. 1-10 period, compared with nine last year.
American Honda said its early August car sales had fallen 9.7 percent. Several weeks ago, the Japanese company decided to slow production of its Accord mid-size car for the rest of the year.
Toyota and Mitsubishi car sales also fell during the period, by 8.6 percent and 54.2 percent respectively.
Nissan car sales surged 108.2 percent on the strength of a lease promotion on its Sentra compact sedan, which got a new design in June.
Mazda car sales rose 21.7 percent in response to recently introduced 1993 models. Subaru reported 30.2 percent higher sales.
Wide swings in sales percentages are possible among Japanese companies that build vehicles in the United States because their share of the overall market is so small compared with the American Big Three.

HEADLINE: G.M.'s '93 Price Increases Trail Ford's and Chrysler's

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that it would raise prices on its 1993 models an average of 1.6 percent, below the tentative increases announced by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.
At the same time G.M. also said it would lower some prices for 1993. Its Chevrolet division rolled back the price on its base models of the Cavalier and Geo Metro and kept the 1992 price on its Lumina sedan. 
 The three models have accounted for 52 percent of Chevrolet sales so far this model year, a division spokesman, Dave Hudgens, said.
Some near-luxury full-size models for 1993 -- including the Oldsmobile 88, Buick LeSabre and Pontiac Bonneville -- will go up 2.5 percent to 3 percent, in part because of making anti-lock brakes standard.
One industry analyst said G.M.'s move may prompt Ford and Chrysler to rethink their 1993 price increases, which range between 2.6 percent and 3 percent.
"This is interesting for G.M. because this is a company that in a sense should be going with a profit, not a market share, strategy," said Joe Phillippi, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. "Yet they are wrestling with realities out there that the customer thinks the product is too expensive."
G.M. lost an industry record $7 billion making cars and trucks in North America last year.
Michael Grimaldi, G.M.'s director of finance for marketing in North American operations, said the price increases are less than the auto maker needs to cover the costs of inflation and safety equipment improvements to many models. Cost-cutting and downsizing will make up for money G.M. will not collect from consumers, he said.
Mr. Grimaldi said G.M. is holding the line on price increases in hopes of weaning customers off incentives as a regular part of buying a car.
"If we could, we would like not to have incentives," Mr. Grimaldi said. "It would reduce the complexity that customers are facing out there in purchasing an automobile."
Mr. Grimaldi said some incentives will still be used, for example, to match a competitor or move a slow-selling model.
Saturn, G.M.'s import-fighting small-car subsidiary, set an industry example of prosperity without incentives. The cars have been so successful that dozens of dealerships have sold out of 1992 models and have weeks to wait before they will get any 1993's.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mortgage Banks Scrape For Profits

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
WITH interest rates at their lowest level in 20 years, the opportunity for millions of homeowners to refinance their houses has created a boom for the mortgage banking companies that serve as middlemen between borrowers and lenders.
Recognizing that the surge in refinancing cannot last forever, and could end quickly if Treasury bond yields turned upward, many mortgage companies and their Wall Street advisers are taking this opportunity to sell new stock. Much of the selling has been by large corporate parents that are not willing to say the market for mortgage banking companies is overvalued, but which probably would not have sold shares if they expected prices of those companies to continue rising rapidly. 
 Major sellers include Primerica Corporation, which earlier this year sold Margaretten Financial of Perth Amboy, N.J., to the public for $300 million; Fleet Financial Group, Providence, R.I., which received $191 million for a 17 percent share of Fleet Mortgage Corporation, the second-largest mortgage banker in the country, and the Bank of New York Company, which plans to sell slightly less than half of ARCS Mortgage Holdings for about $60 million.
In total, at least five mortgage banking companies have made their debut with new stock offerings this year, and another five have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but have not yet offered new shares.
If so many have decided that this is a good time to sell, does that mean investors are buying at the top of a market? The slowdown in the rate of creation of new households -- to about 1.14 million annually in the 1990's from 1.33 million in the 1980's and 1.74 million in the 1970's -- will limit demand for new housing. And until the economy shows signs of mounting a brisk recovery, housing activity will be dampened further.
For now, such concerns seem to be more widespread among economists than mortgage bankers, who are prospering as the volume of new mortgages increased to an estiamted $690 billion this year from $453 billion in 1990. The weakness of the savings and loan industry has allowed mortgage bankers to increase their share of the market to about 50 percent this year from only 16 percent in the 1970's.
Bruce Harting, an analyst at Salomon Brothers predicts that once the boom in refinancing is past, it will become more clear that the best mortgage banking companies are those with strong revenues from mortgage servicing as well as the more volatile revenues that come from making new loans.
Servicing is the record keeping and the handling of monthly payments that occurs after a mortgage is issued, for which the servicer receives an annual fee, usually about quarter of 1 percent of the mortgage's unpaid principal.
Although selling a mortgage's servicing to a third party has traditionally been an important source of revenues for most mortgage bankers, many are now changing their strategy and trying to accumulate more servicing.
Margaretten Financial, for example, has sold the servicing for most of its new loans in recent years, and the revenues from those sales have been crucial to the company's profitability. But in late 1990, according to the prospectus of its recent stock sale, Margaretten shifted course and is now trying to expand its servicing operation by acquiring such business from other lenders while keeping the servicing of the mortgages it originates.
Countrywide Credit Industries, a Pasadena, Calif., concern that is the largest independent mortgage banker in the country and the most widely recommended stock in the industry, has long followed a policy of keeping the servicing of the loans it originates and then sells.
But some other companies rely on servicing sales, which produce a big immediate gain, but rob the company of future revenues. The North American Mortgage Company, for example, which issued new stock in July, has consistently sold the servicing of more than half the mortgages it has orginated since 1989, and the revenues from those sales have been an integral part of the company's profit in each of the last three years.
Edward D. Lagarde, president of Farragut Mortgage Company, a Mansfield, Mass., unit of the Merchants Bank of Boston says that improved productivity in the origination of loans is the key to providing companies with enough revenue that they are not obliged to sell mortgage servicing in order to earn a respectable profit, or in some cases, any profit at all. Amazingly enough to anybody who has paid closing costs, most mortgage bankers actually lose money in the origination of a loan.
The leader of the pack in efficiency is Countrywide Credit. Jonathon E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said that in 1990 Countrywide's cost of originating new loans was 2.02 percent of the loan amount; that was offset by fees and profits on the sale of the loan totaling 1.83 percent, for a net loss of 19-hundredths of 1 percent.
For the average mortage banking firm, the average cost was 2.59 percent of the loan amount, and the net loss was 1.11 percent. In 1991, thanks to productivity gains, Countrywide's cost fell to 1.55 percent, and it managed to eke out a profit of nine-hundredths of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops as Traders Test For Moves by Central Banks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday as traders tested the waters to see whether central banks would intervene again to prop up the currency.
Data on the economy provided no surprises and had little impact on the dollar market, said Mike Faust, senior currency strategist with MMS International. 
 The Labor Department said its Consumer Price Index edged up by just one-tenth of 1 percent in July. The Commerce Department, meanwhile, said retail sales managed only a modest five-tenths of 1 percent rebound in July.
The Government also reported weekly filings for unemployment benefits dropped by 66,000 in the week ending Aug. 1. In a fourth report, the Labor Department said Americans' purchasing power declined two-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Traders focused yesterday on what central banks would do to stop the dollar's slide, said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange with the Bank of Boston.
On Tuesday, 14 central banks bought dollars to shore up the currency, but the coordinated effort failed to generate any interest in buying or holding dollars. It was the second time in less than a week that central banks entered the market to support the tumbling dollar.
"Basically, the underlying fundamentals don't favor holding dollars," Mr. Lawrie said.
Already-low interest rates and fears the Federal Reserve might ease again, as well as the sluggish economy and the uncertain political situation ahead of the Presidential election were unsettling potential dollar-buyers, Mr. Faust said.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, thereby decreasing the need for dollars.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 127.37 Japanese yen, down from 127.87 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 127.08 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 126.50 yen, down from 127.30 late Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9315 from $1.9285 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.9340 from $1.9305 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York compared with late Wednesday: 1.4555 German marks, down from 1.4630; 1.3075 Swiss francs, down from 1.3205; 4.9375 French francs, down from 4.9585; 1,106.00 Italian lire, down from 1,108.00, and 1.19375 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19225.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Coors Files Suit Over Ads by Anheuser-Busch

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Coors adds Virginia water to its beer.
Some people think this is a big deal.
The Anheuser-Busch Companies for one, which recently attacked Coors in an advertising campaign for mixing "local water" from Virginia with its vaunted Rocky Mountain spring water -- on which Coors built its reputation -- to make beer for East Coast guzzlers. Coors responded by suing Anheuser-Busch. 
 The fight, analysts say, isn't really about water. Rather it reflects the brutal marketing climate in the beer industry. Indeed, Bud Light and Coors Light are locked in a fight over third place on the list of the country's best-selling beers, which is led by Budweiser and Miller Lite. Coors Light has been gaining popularity in the Northeast, and Anheuser-Busch is fighting back with the new campaign. But it is using its Natural Light brand, currently ranked 10th, to throw the punches rather than Bud Light.
 
'Water Is the Franchise"
 Whether the campaign will hurt sales of Coors is naturally a matter of opinion. Some experts contend that Coors drinkers do not care about the source of their beer's water, and that the ads are little more than Anheuser-Busch tweaking Coors's nose. But others say that because Coors has built so much of its reputation on its Rocky Mountain water, the ads will put Coors in a bad light.
"Water is the franchise," said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., Los Angeles beverage consultants.
The Adolph Coors Company certainly is taking the attack seriously. Last week, it sued Anheuser-Busch in Federal District Court in Manhattan, demanding that the big St. Louis brewer stop running the ads. Coors got a temporary injunction barring the ads, which Coors contends have false and misleading statements. In the action, Coors seeks at least $10 million in damages.
A court hearing scheduled for today is sure to add to the ruckus over the advertising campaign, which industry watchers say is extraordinary for the pointedness of its attack.
"It is the most significant fight ever between Coors and Anheuser- Busch," said Jerry Steinman, publisher of Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter based in West Nyack, N.Y.
The advertisements are also undoubtedly an issue for some hard-core Coors drinkers who helped elevate the beer to near-Holy Grail status in the early 1970's, a time when demand far outstripped supply. Available in only 11 Western states, Coors was smuggled by car, truck and plane east of the Mississippi and sold at a premium.
Legend has it that President Gerald R. Ford loaded Coors onto Air Force One and Henry A. Kissinger hauled cases back to Washington after trips west. Clint Eastwood and Paul Newman drank it on movie sets. Only Corona Extra, the Mexican beer that grew almost overnight in 1987 to become the nation's second-best-selling imported beer, came close to matching the Coors magic.
 
Hard Choices
 Central to that mystique was the Rocky Mountain water flowing through Golden, Colo., where Coors built the world's largest brewery. To be sure, it is the yeast, barley malt and hops that make a beer distinct, not the water. And water became an issue only after 1985, when Coors decided to risk extending the franchise eastward, a preferable alternative to being drowned out by the heavy advertising of its larger competitors, Anheuser-Busch and Miller, produced by the Philip Morris Companies.
It built the packaging plant in Virginia because the capacity for bottling and canning beer at its Golden plant was reaching its limits. It ships the Colorado-brewed beer to Virginia in railroad tank cars. In keeping with industry practices, Coors brews a higher-alcohol beer, then adds water before packaging. It does this in Virginia to reduce shipping costs.
The move symbolized the Coors quandary that exists to this day. The brewer had no choice but to try to become a national force. But with advertisements showcasing partying twentysomethings, its image has blurred with the others. At the same time, it continued to use traditional Rocky Mountain images.
The combination, industry watchers say, opened Coors to almost inevitable criticism, ignited by Coors Light's popularity in the Northeast at the expense of its main rival, Anheuser-Busch's Bud Light. "They've left themselves exposed," said Mr. Pirko.
Or have they?
 
Flagship Brands Less Important
 Some beer industry analysts wave off the potential damage of the Anheuser-Busch ad campaign, arguing that the spring water is no longer the reason many people buy Coors, especially Coors Light. The beer industry is changing rapidly, after all, with growth driven by product introductions in categories like light beer, rather than by pumping up Budweiser's and Coors's original flagship brands.
Coors Light, for example, is already the driving brand of Coors, representing 63 percent of the company's beer sales last year, up from 47 percent in 1986. (Coors introduced the Light version in 1978.) Coors also rolled out its new budget-priced Keystone and Keystone Light in 1989, and it is reportedly testing Zima (pronounced ZEE-ma), a clear, carbonated malt beverage. "The key to success is really the introduction of new products," said Robert S. Weinberg, a beverage industry consultant in St. Louis.
And Coors Light conjures up advertising images of "The Silver Bullet" rocketing through a gaggle of firm bodies, not the beer's storied past. "Today's beer drinkers don't have any knowledge of what its reputation used to be," said Ray Schramm, general manager and bartender of the Hi Life Bar & Grill on Manhattan's Upper West Side, who sells about 15 cases of Coors Light a week.
After the froth of this legal spat subsides, the Anheuser-Busch advertisement will probably warrant only a page in the already rich history of controversy that Coors has survived during its 119-year history.
In 1977, a clash with union workers, who struck the plant, prompted an A.F.L.-C.I.O. boycott that helped to wear down Coors's share of the California market to about 14 percent in 1984, from more than 40 percent in 1977. The boycott lasted 10 years.
Through the years, blunt language from Coors's patriarch, William K. Coors, has angered minority groups. In 1984, for example, The Rocky Mountain News in Denver quoted Mr. Coors as saying that blacks "lack the intellectual capacity to succeed." The company has since spent hundreds of millions of dollars supporting various projects in black and Hispanic communities.
A Coors television ad was dropped in 1989 after it was criticized by Polish-Americans. The commercial was set in a rock-and-roll bar, where an actor passes on a tip for patrons having trouble reaching the bar to get another Coors Extra Gold: He goes to the jukebox and plays a polka, and the bar empties out.
These and other skirmishes, however, will pale if and when Coors tries to achieve economies of scale by brewing Coors-brand beer outside Colorado and uses water not from the Rocky Mountain springs. Mr. Pirko believes that Coors, with a 10 percent share of the industry, needs to reach a 15 to 18 percent share to start taking advantage of economies of scale. Its advertising costs, for example, are more than $14 a barrel, twice those of Anheuser-Busch, according to Beer Marketer's Insights.
Far-flung packaging plants are viewed as only a short-term solution, as shipping beer by railcar eliminates many of the savings Coors reaps at its huge brewery in Golden. By comparison, Anheuser-Busch's strategy of building breweries spread around the country helps it, to a small degree, earn more than five times the operating profits of Coors per barrel of beer.
Anheuser-Busch will no doubt apply some of that muscle to more advertising aimed at Coors if the Colorado brewer ever starts using anything but Rocky Mountain water as the main ingredient in Coors. "This is just a donnybrook compared to the war that will ensue," Mr. Pirko said. "These guys play mean and tough."

HEADLINE: Sluggish Tax Collections Contribute to $37.6 Million Budget Gap

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Saying that New Jersey is "paying the price for the static national economy," Treasurer Samuel F. Crane today announced that the state finished the latest budget year $37.6 million in the hole, largely because it collected less sales tax than expected.
The gap represents about three-tenths of 1 percent of the $11.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that ended June 30. 
 Mr. Crane said sales-tax collections, which provide nearly 35 percent of all state revenue, were "anemic," coming in $26.5 million under expectations. The revenue figures reflect tax collections on the previous month and year through July 31.
"The abysmal pace of the sales tax is a telling sign of the lack of disposable income and the absence of consumer confidence," he said. "The momentum in retail activity that was grudgingly starting to build earlier in the year has greatly diminished."
 
Taxes Under Expectations
 During the third quarter, January to March, sales-tax collections increased 3.9 percent, but the growth tapered off to a year-ending rate of just four-tenths of 1 percent, despite inflation of 3 percent to 4 percent.
Corporation taxes were under expectations by $29.2 million, and 15.8 percent below the 1991-92 budget year.
Income taxes came in $26 million ahead of expectations, but those targets were lowered during the budget year, Mr. Crane said. Collections were 22 percent above the previous year because the income tax was raised starting in January 1991.
Legally, the state cannot finish a budget year with a deficit, but Mr. Crane said the books are not completely closed.
The $37.6 million gap will be made up with fees collected by state agencies, interest earnings and other sources, such as reimbursements from the Federal Government for benefits provided to state workers who do federally financed work.
"The most dire economic figures both statistically and personally are the unemployment and payroll numbers," Mr. Crane said, noting that unemployment rose from 6.6 percent to 9.8 percent during the fiscal year.
"These numbers translate directly into human hardship and sacrifice that is not easily calculated," he said. "Higher unemployment not only means more people facing hardship, it results in lost revenue for the state through lower income tax and sales tax collections."
The state collected $574 million from the lottery, $4 million more than expected and $46.1 million more than in 1990-91. Taxes on horse racing brought in nearly $1 million more than expected, but $208,000 less than 1990-91.
Casino taxes, which are separate from the overall budget because they are dedicated to specific programs, came in $1.9 million under expectations, but $9.7 million ahead of 1990-91.
