HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Change In Israel

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
In a column last March I told the story of a Palestinian professor, Dr. Khalil Shikaki, whom Israel had forbidden to return from the United States to his home and family in the West Bank. The story has now taken an encouraging turn.
Dr. Shikaki, who got his Ph.D. in America, came here in 1989 because Israel had closed his university, al-Najah in Nablus. He taught political science in Wisconsin and Florida. When Israel allowed West Bank universities to reopen, he tried to go back. But he was excluded at the border last January by Israeli military authorities. 
 He was given no reason. But when American academic colleagues asked Israel to reconsider, saying that Dr. Shikaki was a fair-minded scholar, Israeli officials said he was a security risk because his brother was a founder of Islamic Jihad, a terrorist organization.
After the case was publicized, authorities in the occupied territories took another look at it. In May, Dr. Shikaki was informed that he would be given a visitor's permit to teach at al-Najah for six months.
Last month Dr. Shikaki returned to the West Bank. His movements are restricted. He is not allowed to go to Gaza, where his father lives. He was refused permission to go to Tel Aviv to hear a lecture by Dennis Ross, a top aide to Secretary of State James Baker.
"But I am not complaining," Dr. Shikaki said in a letter. "I am finally home with my wife and children. I am back at my university doing what I know how to do best, teaching history. I'm really very happy."
When he wrote me, Dr. Shikaki had been called twice to meet with Israeli security officials. He was not asked about his brother.
There the story rests for the moment: not exactly a happy ending, because Dr. Shikaki has the right to stay only until the end of this year, but a great improvement over his previous Kafkaesque status.
The story has wider implications. It suggests, as I have always believed, that the rigidities and inhumanities of occupation do not represent the true character of Israel. It shows how much Israel has to gain if it can now negotiate an interim self-governing arrangement for the Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza.
Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's new Prime Minister, plainly sees the advantage of such an agreement. It would get Israel out of the burdensome and corrupting business of ordering the daily lives of 1.5 million Palestinians -- of saying who may live where, who may build a house and so on.
The previous Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, was never an enthusiast for the autonomy idea set out in the Camp David agreement. He went into the present negotiations reluctantly and offered a strangulated version of "autonomy."
Mr. Rabin campaigned, and won, on the theme that Israel's main priorities should be economic growth and reform to create jobs for new immigrants. That means reducing the emphasis of recent years on the occupied territories -- the ideological obsession with them.
The essential aim of an interim agreement on the occupied territories -- essential for both sides -- must be that Palestinians have the sense of controlling their own lives. Only then can there be the psychological conditions for the two peoples to try living together in peace.
Mr. Rabin understands that. Accordingly, he is ready to carry out crucial terms of the Camp David agreement that call on Israel to end its civil administration of the West Bank and Gaza, and withdraw its troops to specified security locations there. And by all signs the mood of his people is also turning from ideology toward political and economic realism.
Dr. Shikaki said he had found Palestinians, who have so much ineffectual political romance in their history, also in a realistic mood. He was impressed when al-Najah students, often susceptible to radical movements, gave 57 percent of their votes in student elections to candidates supporting the peace process.
As for his own hopes, he said: "I intend to write soon to Gen. Danny Rothschild, the Coordinator of Government Activities in the West Bank and Gaza, to discuss an application for family reunification. That is the only route through which someone like me can regain permanent residency."

HEADLINE: We Gain. Mexico Gains. Canada Gains.

BYLINE: By Michael Boskin; Michael Boskin is chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United States, Mexico and Canada, by completing the groundwork for the North American Free Trade Agreement, have taken a significant step toward defining a new world order of expanded trade and brisk competition. The pact, eliminating all tariffs on North American goods over 15 years, would create the world's largest free-trade area, with 360 million consumers and total annual output exceeding $6 trillion.
Critics say the pact would inspire U.S. companies to relocate plants in Mexico and encourage polluters to slip into Mexico and establish operations. Neither assertion holds up. 
 The accord offers tremendous advantages for U.S. workers, consumers and businesses. Mexico is our No. 3 trading partner (Canada is No. 1) and fastest growing export market. The pact would help President Carlos Salinas de Gortari push forward his aggressive program of environmental protection and economic reform.
Recent history tantalizingly hints at what the accord can do for U.S. workers. Since Mexico began reducing import tariffs in 1986, U.S. exports have leaped to $33.3 billion from $12.4 billion. This expansion has affected virtually every U.S. industry, and, since 1987, 47 out of our 50 states have increased exports to Mexico.
Agricultural exports grew by the end of 1991 to $2.9 billion from $1.1 billion. Consumer exports more than tripled, to $3.4 billion from $1 billion. Exports of capital goods leaped to about $11 billion from $5 billion.
The accord would build on this promising start. Trade liberalization would create more jobs and export opportunities. The more we export, the better: 70 cents of every dollar Mexicans spend on imports goes for U.S. goods. Furthermore, what is good for Mexico is good for the U.S.: For every dollar in growth of Mexico's gross domestic product, 15 cents goes toward U.S. goods.
Research by the Institute for International Economics suggests that the pact would create as many as 175,000 net new U.S. jobs. The jobs would pay well. According to Commerce and Labor Department data, U.S. workers in export-related jobs earn 17 percent more than average U.S. workers.
Opponents says businesses will move south to take advantage of low-wage labor. False. Mexico's low wages will not give it a strong competitive advantage. Mexican workers are far less productive on average than ours. As a result, a U.S. company that moves to Mexico would have to hire more workers to achieve its desired output -- and might not save a penny in total labor costs.
Nor does Mexico offer a haven from international labor standards. Mexico has ratified 73 International Labor Organization conventions on working rights, including those on occupational safety and health.
Moreover, in 1991 the U.S. and Mexico signed a memorandum of understanding to share information and cooperate on a wide range of labor issues, including worker rights, enforcement and programs to improve workplace health and safety.
Better yet, Mexico needs U.S. products and technology to improve its productivity. As Mexico's productivity rose, so would Mexico's appetite for U.S. products. Mexican prosperity and stability would reduce pressures for illegal immigration and alleviate international strains that sometimes occur because of cross-border traffic.
Critics say the agreement would encourage environmental cheating. False again. President Salinas has made clear that Mexico has no interest in becoming a haven for U.S. polluters. In 1988, Mexico adopted a comprehensive environmental law, based on U.S. law and experience. Mexican authorities can, for instance, shut down industrial facilities that violate the law -- and they have ordered more than 1,000 such shutdowns since 1989.
All new investments must meet these new standards, which in some cases are more stringent than ours. The U.S. and Mexican environmental agencies also have designed a plan to address pollution in the border area. We have committed ourselves to spending $241 million in fiscal 1993 for the plan. Mexico has pledged $460 million over the next three years.
The Administration has worked hard to insure that the free-trade agreement would impose no undue burdens on U.S. working families. Of course, any economic reforms with long-term benefits could hurt some people in the short run. Therefore, we would phase in the provisions gradually. And the Administration is committed to working with Congress to insure effective adjustment assistance, including job training and placement, for affected workers.
In sum, the North American Free Trade Agreement promotes growth, raises standards of living and creates jobs in the U.S., Mexico and Canada. When people wonder what a world of economic interdependence will be like, they can find intimations in the agreement, for in a world of fair and free trade we all win.

HEADLINE: Air-Noise Pledge for U.S. Open Won't Cost New York a Cent

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Public Trust Betrayed" (letter, July 30), on "subsidized" sports facilities, Benjamin Haber asks who in the New York City administration agreed to the provision in the United States Tennis Association business terms allowing limited rent reductions for significant La Guardia Airport-related airplane overflight, with its accompanying noise, during United States Open tournament play.
I did. And the reasons are compelling. The Tennis Association is investing in the city -- it will spend $180 million of its own money to build the National Tennis Center expansion. Compared with other major sports facilities around the country, this is about as unsubsidized as one can get. 
 The Tennis Association has agreed to keep the United States Open -- one of the world's premier tennis events -- here for 25 years and, unlike other professional sports venues, the National Tennis Center is open to the public, except during tournaments. Few people would feel that a privately developed facility that is open for public use and that generates approximately $130 million a year in economic activity for the city constitutes a violation of the public trust.
Anyone who follows tennis knows that constant noise from airplanes threatened the United States Open's ability to continue to attract world-class players to the tournament and, therefore, threatened the continued presence of the tournament in New York City.
Besides what the Tennis Association is investing, the rent to the city will increase threefold -- to $900,000 in the first year alone. Given the success we have recently had working with the Federal Aviation Administration to abate airplane noise during tournament play, I think it is safe to say that although this has proved a pivotal bargaining point, this part of the agreement will end up costing us nothing.
 
CARL WEISBROD
President, New York City Economic Development Corporation
New York, July 31, 1992

HEADLINE: Abortion Rights Law Wouldn't Work Anyway;
Only the Poor Suffer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Is it only people active in the protection of poor women's access to contraception who see through the Governmentspeak of Bush Administration officials? In "What Abortion Isn't" (letter, July 28), Dr. William R. Archer thrusts the abortion issue where it has no place and distorts facts about the program he administers, Title X of the Public Health Service Act, which provides family planning services to poor women.
Dr. Archer maintains that Title X funds have increased for 20 years. In reality, the program was funded at $162 million in 1981 and is now at $150 million, a significant cut, without allowing for inflation. 
 Title X's restriction that "none of the funds appropriated under this title shall be used in programs where abortion is a method of family planning" has been scrupulously observed, and even the General Accounting Office has not been able to find otherwise. Yet the Bush Administration, in an effort to promote its political agenda, has created the "gag rule," which prohibits apprising a pregnant woman of all her options -- childbirth, abortion and adoption -- when she requests information at a Title X clinic.
The gag rule is back in the courts, with the Administration pressing hard to force family planning clinics to deny poor women the same information that any woman who can pay for her health care can easily obtain.
I agree with Dr. Archer that abortion is not a method of family planning. Who ever said it was? But please spare us the righteous tone and the attempts to force a political position on poor women trying to take responsibility for their reproductive lives.
 
LIBBY ANTARSH
President, National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association
Washington, Aug. 3, 1992

LENGTH: 1298 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Broken Pledge of Change Comes Back to Haunt Its Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Japan is struggling with a deepening economic downturn that may prove to be the harshest in two decades, but what most troubles some economists is that the Japanese Government vowed this type of decline would not happen.
Six years ago, the Government committed itself to transforming its export-driven economy into one led by consumer demand. The Prime Minister at the time, Yasuhiro Nakasone, promised President Ronald Reagan a "historic change" as his Government sought to reduce the yawning trade surplus, head off protectionist pressure from the United States and let the long-suffering Japanese consumer enjoy more of Japan's growing prosperity. 
 But the economic downturn, caused largely by a steep decline in corporate investment, is making it clear that the promise has gone unfulfilled, many economists say. And economic policy is still shaped to benefit manufacturers over consumers, giving Japanese corporations an advantage in global competition. During the last six years, Japanese consumers have had to bear an increasingly heavy tax burden, and they are still paying prices that are among the world's highest.
 
Shadow Over Commitments
 Japan's failure to carry through on its 1986 commitment raises a host of troubling questions. These include how much the West should trust other Japanese commitments, whether such a transformation is possible in the short term, and what measures might be effective in bringing greater balance to Japan's trade and economic practices.
Japan's economy is expected to grow 1 to 2 percent this year, a steep decline from 4.5 percent in 1991. That compares with growth in the United States of 1 percent in 1990, a decline of seven-tenths of a percent in '91, and a projected gain of 2.1 percent this year.
But as Japan's economy skids, its trade surplus is expected to exceed $120 billion this year, a record.
When times are tough, the Japanese still look to stronger exports, not consumer demand, to lift the economy out of its rut. In the first half of this year, for instance, exports rose 8.3 percent while imports declined 6.5 percent, making for a six-month surplus of $62.88 billion. The surplus with the United States has stabilized at a little more than $40 billion a year, economists say. Most of the sharp growth is coming in Japan's surplus with Europe and Asia.
Japan's failure has already worsened tensions with its trading partners, including the United States. The situation has also dashed the West's hopes that the Japanese economy, by bolstering imports, would become an engine for global growth.
"The point was to unlock this tremendous pent-up demand among Japanese consumers," said Paul Summerville, an economist here with Jardine Fleming Securities. "Japan would have benefited enormously, but it would not have benefited a lot of political interests."
He added, "It's now that we need Japan to consume more, but it can't."
 
 
No Push for Tax Cuts
 While the Government has been announcing new measures by the week to rescue the stock market from its two-and-a-half-year collapse and stabilize the economy -- which has not yet officially been declared in a recession -- little thought is being given to stimulating consumer demand directly through tax cuts or other means. The Government argues that consumers would only save the money from the tax cuts, not spend it, and that the budget surplus might be turned into a deficit.
"We are moving in the right direction, but we have made less progress than was expected," commented Yutaka Kosai, president of the Japan Center for Economic Research and a member of the commission that proposed the economic shift. "Economic growth would have been a little slower if all the proposals had been adopted, but the economy would have been more stable because consumer spending is usually more stable than business investment."
Some economists argue that Japanese consumers have actually had their spending power reduced by a variety of Government policies. An analysis by Jesper Koll, an economist here with S. G. Warburg Securities (Japan), found that individual income taxes had increased 14.5 percent a year since 1989.
Taxes rose, Mr. Koll said, nearly twice as fast as household incomes, which increased 7.7 percent a year.
Mr. Koll added that social security contributions had increased an average of 11.7 percent a year since 1989. Together, he estimated, these extra costs have cut consumer spending by about 12 trillion yen, or more than $90 billion at current exchange rates, in the last three years.
 
 
Crisis in Mid-1980's
 Japan's commitment was developed in an atmosphere of crisis. In 1985, the trade surplus was heading toward what seemed an astronomical level of more than $50 billion.
In September 1985, Japan and the United States agreed to increase the value of the yen sharply against the dollar and other currencies in what became known as the Plaza Accord, after a meeting at the Plaza Hotel in New York. The idea was that a weaker dollar would reduce American imports by making foreign goods more expensive, and raise exports by cutting the overseas prices of American-made goods.
In addition, then-Prime Minister Nakasone assembled what became known as the Maekawa Commission, after its leader, Haruo Maekawa, a respected former governor of the Bank of Japan. To promote domestic consumption, the commission proposed in a report in 1986 that the Japanese work fewer hours, take more vacations, receive tax breaks and save less.
The Government appeared unwavering in its commitment to the transformation. Mr. Nakasone said the restructuring would be difficult. "But we think we can do it," he insisted. "And it will be done."
The Government did slowly begin a campaign aimed at inducing the Japanese to work less and spend more. It also opened some markets to imports, making it cheaper for the Japanese to buy goods like foreign cigarettes, beef and citrus fruits. But the far more urgent task the Government tackled was helping manufacturers deal with the burden of a much stronger yen. The principal tools they used were lower interest rates and an easy monetary policy.
Corporate investment hurtled ahead at three and four times the rate of the economy's expansion. Japanese industrial companies expanded their purchases of new equipment by trillions of yen, with the growth rate hitting 25.4 percent in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, 1989.
Meanwhile, private consumption barely kept up with the overall growth of the economy, hovering at 3.6 to 5.5 percent a year.
The consumer enjoys few of the benefits of the new growth. According to a Government survey, already-built houses cost 7.1 times the average annual income of the Japanese.
Japanese individuals also fled the stock market, helping drive down trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange; the average daily trading volume recently fell to a 10-year low.
Economists say that about 60 percent of the economy's high-octane growth since 1986 was fueled by business investment. "It's true that domestic demand increased during those years, but this was due to business investment rather than a change in personal consumption," said Yukio Noguchi, an economics professor at Hitotsubashi University in Tokyo.
He said the excesses of these policies contributed to Japan's current malaise. The Government, he said, relied too heavily on monetary policy in its efforts to ease the trade surplus. The current slowdown was initiated in late 1989 when the Government began to raise interest rates, seeking to gain control the inflationary spiral in the financial markets.
Capital investment by corporations fell sharply. The Economic Planning Agency said recently that manufacturers would reduce their capital investment by 8.3 percent this year.

HEADLINE: FREE TRADE ACCORD EXPECTED TO TRIM NATION'S FOOD BILL

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
For the American consumer, the biggest effect of the new North American Free Trade Agreement will take place in the neighborhood supermarket, where fresh fruits and vegetables will become more plentiful, more readily available in winter and will almost certainly become cheaper.
The free trade pact that the United States, Canada and Mexico reached this week will, if ratified, eliminate the taxes now imposed on tomatoes, cantaloupes, cucumbers and many other foods imported from Mexico. The taxes, or tariffs, are intended to protect American farmers from imports, and they add significantly to the price of these foods. The accord will also reduce transportation costs by opening long-haul cross-border truck routes to low-wage Mexican carriers.
 
Cheaper Roses
 The agreement may even lower the cost of romance -- cutting out the 8 percent tax on cut roses from Mexico.
"You will find a greater availability of fruits and vegetables in your store, and the prices will be lower," said Colin A. Carter, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of California at Davis. "There is a saving for consumers -- there's no question -- because many of these products have been protected right now from import competition." 
 A family of four living in a state on the Mexican border could save up to $50 a year on its food bills once the tariffs are eliminated, Mr. Carter said. Families living farther from the border would save less, because high transportation costs mean that fewer Mexican fruits and vegetables are eaten in Eastern and Northern states, he added.
The Agriculture Department has not yet tried to estimate the savings, said Roger D. Runningen, the department's chief spokesman. "On certain fruits and vegetables in certain times of the year, we would expect some price reductions," he said.
 
Which Farmers Are Angry
 But while shoppers may be pleased, some American farmers are furious. From Florida and Georgia to California and Michigan, they fear that more competition from Mexico may result in foreclosure signs on their fences. Citrus, peanut and winter vegetable growers are especially upset.
Ben C. Abatti raises cucumbers, lettuce, asparagus and other vegetables on a 14,000-acre farm near Holtville, Calif., just five miles north of the Mexican border. He competes directly with Mexican farmers in nearby Mexicali, and relies on tariffs of up to 35 percent to offset the difference between American labor costs of $6 an hour and Mexican wages as low as $5 a day.
"If we didn't have the tariffs today, they'd run us out of business tomorrow, that's for sure," Mr. Abatti said.
Farmers like Mr. Abatti who harvest labor-intensive crops make up a small and vocal minority pitted against the many American farmers who grow crops that do not thrive in the heat and sun of Mexico. They look forward eagerly to selling more corn, hogs and other highly mechanized commodities to its 92 million people.
John C. Kintzle, who is raising a bumper crop of corn this summer on 980 acres near Coggon, Iowa, said he supported the free trade accord because it would mean more demand and higher prices for his harvests as Mexico eliminates its import limits. "Any time we can create demand, we're better off," he said. "And we know that with the crop this year, and the new technology, we need all the markets we can get."
These differences within the American agricultural community have split farm-state legislators more along crop lines than party lines. Lawmakers representing farmers whose crops are also produced efficiently in Mexico tend to oppose the pact, while legislators from districts that will benefit from access to Mexican markets are more favorable to the accord.
For example, Mr. Abatti's Congressman, Representative Duncan Hunter, is a Republican who vehemently opposes President Bush's agreement. But Iowa's representatives, including two Democrats, generally support it.
Free trade in fruits and vegetables could also have an enormous effect on the flow of legal and illegal Mexican immigrants, many of whom find jobs in the United States picking vegetables for lack of comparable employment at home. Mr. Abatti employs up to 700 immigrants at harvest time. As trade barriers fall, it will make sense for some of those workers to harvest crops in Mexico for shipment across the border.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, cited one study this week that showed the free trade accord would persuade 1.6 million potential Mexican immigrants to "forgo those lower-skilled jobs in the United States and stay at home."
 
Trade Barriers
Consumers Paying For Farm Profits
 Agriculture is the world's most protected industry, and American farmers are no exception. The United States imposes steep taxes on many imports and even more restrictive quantitative limits on imports of peanuts, sugar and dairy products. The tonnage limits restrict peanut imports to an amount that averages out to seven nuts for every American.
The changes from the new trade pact will be slow because some of the highest taxes will be phased out over 15 years, but the results at the end will be striking. Peanuts, for example, sell for $700 a ton in the United States but only $300 a ton on world markets.
When the 1990 crop failed in the United States, prices soared. The Agriculture Department removed peanut butter from the school lunch program because it could not import cheaper peanut butter from overseas.
"I consider it a way in which the peanut growers enhance their incomes at the expense of consumers," said Dale E. Hathaway, the director of the National Center for Food and Agriculture Policy, a nonprofit research group in Washington. "They transfer income from peanut eaters to peanut growers."
The accord will, over 15 years, waive the peanut-import restriction, which many economists welcome. The growers, however, are understandably hostile, insisting that their peanuts are better than foreign peanuts and more likely to be free from disease and pesticide contamination.
Danny O. Fillingame, who farms 2,000 acres in Dawson, Ga., with his father, notes that American consumers say in surveys that they want a quality product. "But they're willing to accept a lot lower-quality product," he said. "In my opinion, it's not fair."
Like the peanut farmers, American citrus growers also enjoy considerable protection from imports at the expense of consumers. People who like orange juice pay a stiff price: up to 35 cents in extra taxes for each imported gallon, which also allows Florida growers to charge more for their crop. After heavy lobbying by the growers, the tariff will be phased out over 15 years, the longest possible period under the accord.
 
Against the Pact
California Growers Are Frightened
 When Mrs. Hills introduced the free trade agreement at a White House new conference last Wednesday, she mentioned that consumers would benefit from being able "to get a cantaloupe a couple of months later than you can get one down at your Safeway this morning."
In practice, the United States already waives its 35 percent duty on Mexican cantaloupes during winter months when they do not compete with American producers. But the free trade accord will also eliminate the summer duty over the next 15 years, and American growers are very unhappy.
Southern California farmers estimate that it costs them nearly $5 to grow, harvest and pack a 24-pound box of cantaloupes, while it costs Mexican farmers just $3.50. Labor is slightly more than half the cost of growing cantaloupes, and American workers earn 10 times as much, including fringe benefits, as workers in Mexico.
The 35 percent tariff currently balances this difference, at a cost to consumers of about 5 cents extra for a one-pound cantaloupe. The result has been a fierce fight here to keep the tariff -- a fight that puts the fiercely independent and strongly Republican farmers here in a difficult position.
"Competition is great, and I believe in competition, and I support a great competition with the other guy, but when you can't compete because of dollars and wages, it's just like banging your head against the wall," said George C. Stergios, who has a 4,000-acre farm near Mr. Abatti's and who is the president of the Imperial Valley Vegetable Growers Association.
The Agriculture Department contends that American farmers opposed to the agreement may be exaggerating their troubles. The same growers, of produce like tomatoes, have invested more money than their Mexican counterparts in irrigation and harvesting equipment. The American producers have reduced their costs and thus become more competitive than their Mexican rivals, department officials say.
 
For the Accord
Midwest Farmers Anticipate Gains
 Midwestern farmers are counting on the free trade accord to help them earn more money. They hope that by pulling down Mexico's trade barriers, the agreement will make the average Mexican prosperous enough to buy more American products from the Midwest.
"Instead of eating a diet that is very low on protein and very high on tortillas and refried beans, they'll eat more meat," said Steven C. Noah, the director of the Midwest Agribusiness Trade Research and Information Center in Des Moines.
Before the collapse of oil prices in the early 1980's stunned the Mexican economy, American farmers had a strong market across the border. When Mexico lost much of its oil income, American food sales there fell by 37.4 percent in just three years, to a $1.11 billion in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, 1986.
At that time the Mexican economy started to recover and began to grow even faster than the United States economy. American agricultural shipments across the nation's southern border nearly tripled.
Throughout the world, people in poor countries tend to buy more American meat and grain as they become more affluent. The pattern has been repeated in Japan since World War II, in the Middle East in the 1970's, and now again in Mexico.
If Mexico has a competitive advantage in melons and oranges, the United States is an overwhelming rival in hogs and grain. Much of the Mexican landscape is too arid for these commodities, and farmers there have small, inefficient plots. Large tractors and combines are in short supply in Mexico and the winters are not cold enough for long-term grain storage.
The United States has none of these problems, while it has a highly efficient food storage, processing and transportation system. For example, some wheat that has been stored in grain elevators in North Dakota and Montana by the Federal Government since the late 1950's is still edible.
Through a complicated system of import licenses, Mexico has prevented American farmers from dominating its food markets -- and perhaps bankrupting hundreds of thousands of peasant corn farmers in southern Mexican states. Under the free trade accord, Mexico will allow the duty-free import of 2.5 million tons of corn a year, an amount roughly comparable to shipments in recent years.
Any extra shipments will be subject to an initial tariff of 215 percent that will be phased out over 15 years. American corn growers welcome the move because the Federal Government has been cutting its subsidies since 1985.
"Government support to agriculture has declined since the mid-1980's, and implicit in reduced Government support has been a promise to find new markets," said Peter J. Wenstrand, who raises corn on his 1,500-acre farm near Essex, Iowa. "Any time you talk about increased trade, it helps corn."
 
The Politics
The Farm Lobby Is Deeply Divided
 The North American Free Trade Agreement has split the farm vote in Congress, and eventual approval of the agreement will depend partly on whether this split persists.
Florida, Texas, California and Hawaii will be hurt the most by Mexican competition because they have very similar growing seasons and crops, and lawmakers from rural areas in these states have been critical of the agreement. But the unusual alliances within American agriculture have also produced some other critics in Congress.
The nation's severe restrictions on sugar imports, for example, have the support not only of sugar cane growers but also of sugar beet growers and corn farmers, whose product is used to make corn sweetener. Sugar beets are grown in states like North Dakota that would otherwise be expected to support the pact.
Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, criticized the free trade pact in a speech on Wednesday to members of the American Sugar Alliance, a Washington-based industry group. "It's unfair, it's outrageous and it's a sellout of American sugar interests," he said.
But other Democrats from farm states have raced to the agreement's defense. "Right now, if you want to get big applause -- there's a lot of unemployment -- you just say anything against foreigners," Representative Neal Smith of Iowa said. "But that's not responsible."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Host City;
A Houston-Style Convention: Republicans in Heavy Traffic

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
For the first time ever, urban sprawl may be one of the defining experiences of a national political convention, when the Republican Party gathers here beginning this weekend.
Many delegates will travel as far as 30 miles through Houston's notorious rush-hour traffic on freeways with nicknames like "The Beast" to get from their hotels to the Astrodome, where the speech-making will happen. And even partying will require long treks to the vast prairie that stretches west of the city, and to Galveston Bay 40 miles to the southeast. 
 To ready Houston for the Republicans, city fathers coaxed thousands of unenthusiastic Houston residents to sign on as volunteer workers, raised more than $4 million to remake a cavernous sports stadium into a convention hall for one week, and persuaded the Houston Astros to embark on the longest road trip any major league team has taken since the invention of the airplane.
But in the end, those challenges may pale in comparison to the efforts it will take simply to get delegates from one part of this city to another.
"Nothing has been done like this before, when you consider the size of the area and how spread out things are," said Paul Klepper, a retired Marine Corps colonel who commands hundreds of vehicles and even distant traffic lights from the convention's transportation control center.
"This is like a war room," Mr. Klepper said of his headquarters packed with computers and radios, "because managing traffic and transportation for this convention is going to be a war."
Spread out over 581 square miles and with a metropolitan area larger than Rhode Island, Houston has a dazzling downtown skyline but lacks any real center.
The Astrodome itself, nearly six miles from downtown, is one of many isolated nodules of urban development. Since it sits, surrounded by vast parking lots, at the center of its own 260-acre complex, the convention site cannot be reached from anywhere on foot without breaking into a serious sweat in the August heat. And the thousands of Houston Oiler fans who have listened to kickoffs on their car radios will attest that reaching it by automobile can be equally maddening.
As a result, almost all the groups involved in the convention are operating their own mass transit systems. Even the Galleria, Houston's premier mall, will run shuttle buses decorated as elephants with four-foot trunks.
Getting 6,000 gift bags from corporate donors to delegates and Republican officials this weekend will involve an elaborate distribution system with a fleet of trucks on loan from local companies. The trucks will also make the rounds of more than 50 hotels every day of the convention carrying additional gifts, like plastic cowboy boots filled with red, white and blue M&M's.
 
Elephantine Efforts
 In addition to transportation problems, there were hundreds of smaller challenges as the convention neared.
Rendering the Republican mascot in Texas proportions resulted in two giant topiary elephants, one at the Astrodome and the other at the Houstonian Hotel and Conference Center, President Bush's Houston residence, both evidence of painstaking pruning. Delegates will also be greeted by an 11-foot chocolate elephant weighing 227 pounds, and by a live one, with feet painted red, white and blue.
There was a last-minute scare when, just as construction was due to start inside the Astrodome, local officials demanded an independent inspection of the 27-year-old stadium's roof to make sure it could hold a 3 1/2-ton curtain as well as the dozens of lights and speakers now suspended from it. The dome passed muster.
Specially installed electrical and telephone systems at the stadium were reinforced to withstand a hurricane. And tons of sound-absorbing material have been placed all over the Astrodome to dampen a notorious echo that delights cheering sports fans by magnifying their din but bedevils speakers.
And simply filling the vast spaces of the Astrodome complex required considerable artistic and political ingenuity. Adjoining the stadium is the Astrohall, which many Houstonians associate with the mooing, braying and snorts of the livestock show that accompanies the city's annual rodeo. Now the news media inhabit it.
 
Filling Empty Space
 Responding to a Presidential request for innovative events, Republican planners created an "American Spirit Pavilion" in the Astroarena, another large building next to the stadium. Workers installed a 4-foot-wide section of the Berlin Wall there on Thursday not far from where an 8-foot bronze statue of the President will be erected.
But most of the effort went into the great cavern of the Astrodome itself.
"The hardest part was to create something that will focus attention on the podium so the speakers don't just get lost in here," said Bob Keene, an art director based in Los Angeles who is the design chief for the convention.
His solution: A square-topped arch faced with faux limestone now towers 60 feet above what used to be shallow left field. The arch, flanked by two video panels of 49 television screens each, serves as the backdrop for a podium that juts 44 feet toward second base.
 
Prefabricated Podium
 Getting the Houston Astros to leave their home field for a 28-day road trip, required rounds of legal and financial wrangling. So, with just three weeks to prepare the Astrodome, the entire podium structure was first built in a warehouse, disassembled, trucked to the Astrodome in sections, then reassembled. Altogether, 500,000 man-hours went into remaking the stadium.
Much of the construction costs were covered by $4.3 million collected by the Houston Host Committee, mostly from corporate donors. Republican officials praised the committee for the biggest convention fund-raising effort ever.
But the response from the general public did not set records for enthusiasm. The host committee fell 1,000 people short of its goal of recruiting 12,000 volunteers to help as drivers, baby-sitters, ushers and in many other roles. Clean Houston, another volunteer organization, expected 15,000 people to help pick up garbage from the streets but drew only 7,000.
That was a little more than half the number that turned out for the clean-up campaign prior to the 1990 Economic Summit, but this year they picked up slightly more garbage: 2,231 tons.

LENGTH: 654 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 International
Consumers will find fruits and vegetables cost less as a result of the new North American Free Trade Agreement -- which is infuriating to American farmers who must compete with low-wage Mexican producers. But farmers growing corn in the Midwest cheer the pact for the new markets it opens to them. Agriculture is the most protected of industries, and consequently the changes to be wrought by the accord are the greatest. [Page 1.]
A troubling aspect of Japan's deepening economic malaise is that the nation has not lived up to a Government promise made to the U.S. to transform itself from an export-driven economy, which has produced a yawning trade surplus with the U.S., into one led by consumer demand, which would help foreign producers. [1.]
Opponents of the trade accord are gearing up to prevent its enactment or significantly change it. Among them are environmentalists, church and labor groups. Some plan to campaign for Bill Clinton in the belief he would change it. [34.]
India's struggle to restructure its economy is faltering, threatening to drag South Asia's largest country deeper into poverty. [2.]
 
Companies
Citicorp cut its previously reported second-quarter earnings by $28 million to $143 million, saying regulators had forced it to do so, and to sign a formal acknowledgement that the company's problems are great enough to require extra close attention. Bank officials immediately went into their version of spin control to persuade the rest of the world its problems were minor. [31.]
First City Bancorporation of Texas said it would sell major subsidiaries and try to persuade investors to supply it with $100 million of fresh capital. The effort to avoid collapse came after months of unsuccessful efforts to find a merger partner. [31.]
WNEW-AM may soon begin broadcasting financial and investment news. Westwood One and Robert Sillerman, owners of the legendary but troubled New York radio station, agreed to sell it to Michael Bloomberg L.P., which provides data on stock, bonds and other financial instruments for securities traders. [33.]
Computervision went public at $12 a share. That price for the former Prime Computer was lower than expected and led Shearson Lehman Brothers, the investment firm that financed a previous leveraged buyout of Prime, to say it would report an additional loss of $40 million or more. Computervision also sold $300 million in bonds. Proceeds of both issues will be used to pay down debt. [33.]
 
The Economy
Production by the nation's industrial plants rose 0.4 percent in July to erase an identical drop in June, the Federal Reserve reported. But important manufacturing areas were weak. [31.]
 
Markets
The Dow rose 15.67 points to end at 3,328.94, but for the week, the average lost 3.24 points. Both its ups and its downs followed those in the bond market. [41.]
Treasury bond prices rebounded. Economists said bonds appeared to gain strength from the latest survey by the University of Michigan, which showed consumer confidence remained low. The price of the long Treasury bond rose $7.19 per $1,000 in face amount, regaining some of its $12 drop on Thursday. [41.]
The dollar was mixed as traders waited to see if interest rates would fall in the United States and rise in Germany. [42.]
Platinum futures prices fell again on low inflation and relative calm in South Africa, but gold and silver rose slightly. [42.]
 
Today's Columns
Few women have taken charge of family financial planning and investing, a study commissioned by Oppenheimer Management shows, and few understand financial markets. But demographic statistics show the need to learn. Jan M. Rosen: Your Money. [32.]
Arthritis patients are getting relief from magnetic fields produced by a machine invented by a Long Island doctor. Cartilage grows and is repaired. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [32.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Media;
Why Candidates Like Public's Questions

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Taking his turn at a recent "Ask George Bush" question-and-answer session in Philadelphia, a high school student sounded as if he was about to put the President on the spot.
"I hate to sound like Barbara Walters, but I need to know," the teen-ager, Angelo Cruz, said at the start of a question about financing a costly education project. "Where is the money coming from? Is it going to be taken out of taxes because, you know, we're in so much debt?" 
 Mr. Bush must have been relieved because the question turned out to be not so tough at all. The President tossed off a stock reply: that it was up to Congress to free itself from "the grips of a very powerful union" and pay for the project. Mr. Cruz had no chance to follow up.
 
The Public Wants to Know
 No wonder that in this talk-show campaign, Mr. Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton -- encouraged by Ross Perot's initial success in such formats -- often bypass national reporters, leaving their jobs to ordinary citizens.
A review of the hundreds of questions posed to the Presidential candidates in the last four months reveals a striking difference between those asked by reporters or talk-show hosts and those asked by people in the audience or calling in. Reporters dwell on the process, asking about polls, tactical strategy and, of course, the story of the day. Questions from the public are far less confrontational, and an overwhelming number of people ask candidates how they would solve problems that affect the questioner.
"While we were all trying to run Bill Clinton to the ground on the subject of Gennifer Flowers," said Peter Jennings, the ABC News anchor of "World News Tonight," "the voters in New Hampshire wanted to know about the economy. And we were getting in their way."
Explaining that regular voters can sometimes elicit more information from a candidate than more intimidating journalists, he said, "You could have had a Donaldson or a Koppel hammer away at him, but as a human being he'd be less forthcoming."
 
Concern With Policies
 Michael J. Robinson, an associate professor of government at Georgetown University, said questions from the public were a refreshing change from the "bored, burned-out reporters' questions." Too often, he said, the press "focuses on what may be the most trivial message of the day and does not come back to policy concerns."
Indeed, at a session with high school students in East St. Louis, Ill., during his bus tour last week, Mr. Clinton was asked only substantial questions about issues like affirmative action and spending on AIDS. But on his way out he was confronted by reporters who asked him mostly political questions, like whether his trip to East St. Louis was in response to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's criticism that he had avoided black areas in his first bus tour.
Some political analysts argue that the downside of allowing citizens to ask questions -- and the reason the campaigns clearly prefer this format -- is that most are too timid to ask pointed questions and often let candidates off the hook by not following up. The citizens can also be so concerned with their own interests, the analysts say, that they do not ask timely, important questions.
Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia and author of "Feeding Frenzy: How Attack Journalism has Transformed American Politics," has even less patience for the questions nonjournalists ask. "The average voters asking politicians questions is like the blind leading the evasive," he said. "Reporters are trained to have the guts to egg the politicians on. Frequently, we only see the real person when they get angry."
 
Difference in Questions
 In posing a question about Social Security to Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, on the CBS News program "This Morning" on Monday, a woman did anything but anger the candidate. She held up her hands, fingers crossed, and said, "Good morning, Governor Clinton, Senator Gore, our future President and Vice President."
Mr. Clinton replied, "Nothing like an unbiased question, right?"
Here, in compressed form, are the first six questions that callers asked Mr. Clinton recently on the CNN program "Larry King Live." They are for the most part issue-oriented.
1) Your views on trade between the United States and Mexico?
2) Why didn't you attend a black newspaper publishers meeting and why do you not speak about black nations?
3) Would you give money to Russia?
4) Would you release loans to Israel?
5) How would you make the economy more competitive?
6) Have you changed your campaign approach by going on talk shows?
By contrast, here, again condensed and not including follow-ups, are the first six questions that Stone Phillips asked Mr. Bush on "Dateline NBC" this week. He was not asked much about policy.
1) Are you prepared to accept the recommendation of top Republicans for an across-the-board income tax cut?
2) With tensions rising around the world, can you afford to bring James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State, to the White House?
3) If you felt it was in the best interest of the nation, would you withdraw from the race?
4) Did Dan Quayle offer to step aside if you thought that would help?
5) If your granddaughter said she was pregnant and wanted to have an abortion, what would you do?
6) What do you mean when you say "family values"?
In an interview, Mr. Phillips defended his questions, including his asking Mr. Bush later in the broadcast if he had ever had an affair. Given that the President had been asked earlier in the day at a news conference about an unsubstantiated report on his private life, Mr. Phillips said, it was legitimate for him to raise the subject.
"If you had 25 voters in the Oval Office on that day, I don't think you can say that it wouldn't have been asked," Mr. Phillips said. "It was a difficult question to ask, but it became a fair question because they have made it an issue in the campaign."
 
Punches Pulled, Usually
 James Lake, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, acknowledged that when ordinary citizens question the President, "people pull their punches a little."
Mr. Bush admitted as much. After voters in the Rose Garden politely quizzed him on the economy, education and gang violence in a session broadcast on the CBS program "This Morning" recently, Paula Zahn of the program hit a nerve by asking him why his Administration was adrift.
Mr. Bush scolded Ms. Zahn and her co-anchor, Harry Smith. "Why are these people not asking me all of this?" he said, surveying the audience of non-reporters. "It is you and Harry that have the controversial questions."
But while the questions from citizens are generally friendlier, it is the amateur who sometimes dares to ask the most mortifying question.
After almost making it through his two-hour live appearance on "This Morning" on Monday, Mr. Clinton got hit with this from an educator in Wisconsin: "Strong family values is No. 1 on my list of qualifications," she said. "From all the reports of your marital problems, et cetera, I'd like you to convince me that you would take the Presidential oath seriously."
After stammering for a few seconds, Mr. Clinton began his response, "If I haven't convinced you now, I don't know that I can."

HEADLINE: July Output Increased 0.4%, Erasing the Decline of June

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Production by the nation's industrial plants rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July to erase an identical drop in June, the Federal Reserve Board said today. But it noted a marked weakness in important manufacturing areas.
The Fed attributed the rise to increased output from mines and utilities, which offset weakness in the more significant manufacturing sector. Manufacturing was unchanged after declining two-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
 Private economists warned that the economy was losing steam after a burst of activity in the spring and early summer, much the same as happened a year ago.
"The economy is not gaining momentum; it is coasting to a stop," said Jack Albertine, an analyst for Albertine Enterprises Inc. "The manufacturing sector, once the proud engine of growth in the American economy, is barely breathing."
Also, the Commerce Department reported that business inventories jumped six-tenths of 1 percent in June to the highest level in 16 months at $833.37 billion.
The rise in inventories was the largest since an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in May 1990 and followed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in May.
The bulge in supplies of goods on the shelves may cause retailers and wholesalers to hold back on placing new orders until they see signs that consumers are more willing to buy.
The Fed said a second straight monthly cutback in auto production, as well as steadily weakening output in military industries, restrained manufacturing activity last month.
"Much of this weakness is attributable to curtailed motor vehicle production, but output in some other major industries such as textiles, furniture, instruments and electrical machinery also dropped back," the Fed said.
Consumer confidence has been undermined by high unemployment and poor opportunities for increasing incomes. Recent signs are that average wage earners' hopes for the future are growing more pessimistic rather than brightening.
A private study called the University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index, which is released to paying subscribers, showed a drop in its preliminary August reading to 75.3 from 76.6 in July, people in the financial markets said.
There was evidence in the Fed's report on industrial output that manufacturers already were responding to weak consumer demand by scaling back their production plans.
"Output of consumer durable goods, which includes motor vehicles and appliances, declined for a second straight month in July," the Fed said. "In addition, output of aerospace and miscellaneous transportation equipment, which has been weak for some time, fell further in June and July.'

HEADLINE: Opponents Start to Plan But Lack Unified Theme

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
President Bush has hailed a trade agreement between North American countries as the beginning of a new era, but opponents of the measure are gearing up to prevent its enactment or significantly change it.
The opponents, who represent different groups with widely different interests, have yet to coalesce, however, and form any unified plan of attack. 
 Some say the best way to proceed is to prevent the President's re-election and scrap the trade pact, which United States, Mexico and Canada agreed upon Wednesday and now faces ratification by the legislative bodies of all three countries.
These critics say that, although Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential candidate, has said he agrees that the nation needs some form of new trade treaty, he would do more than President Bush has done to protect American jobs from being lost that might be lost under it.
 
Environmentalists Concerned
 Other opponents, like the winter-vegetable farmers of Southern California's Imperial Valley, are dead set against the agreement but still solidly behind the President.
And still others accept the economic aspects of the agreement but object to what they predict will be adverse environmental effects.
The opposition organizations say their strategies will come together quickly after the full details of the agreement, but how that will happen is not clear.
What is clear, however, is the ire of many of these groups, with names ranging from Friends of the Earth and the Sierra Club to the United Steelworkers of America, National Farmers Union and the United Methodist Church.
"The emphasis of each group is going to be different," said Mark A. Anderson, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s task force on trade. "But all share a common concern that the implementation of this agreement is not going to be beneficial."
 
Sales Pitch Awaited
 Lori M. Wallach, who chairs the executive board of Citizen Trade Watch Campaign, a coalition of 60 environmental, labor and farm groups that monitor trade issues, said: "There will be a lot of activity on this. Carla Hills said her job is to sell this agreement. Well, we say to her: 'Bring it on.' " Mrs. Hills is the United States trade representative and the chief negotiator of the agreement.
Kevin L. Kearns, a fellow with the Economic Strategy Institute, a public policy research group here, said: "There is no question that after September, when the details of this agreement come out, people will go over this with a fine-tooth comb. And when that happens you're going to see a grand-scale coalition forming."
The groups said their efforts will inevitably be varied, because of the divergent nature. Labor groups, for example, complain that the trade agreement would cause nearly 500,000 manufacturing jobs to move to Mexico from the United States. Environmental groups complain that the agreement would create ecological problems, particularly along the border.
"We believe that Mexico cannot be a haven for polluters and that's what would happen under this agreement," said Roni Lieberman, a spokeswoman with the Sierra Club. "This agreement would give industry the right to go to Mexico and pollute and then send the dirty products back to the United States."
Farmers say that the agreement would cause prices for sugar, peanuts and dairy products to plunge. "We don't know all the details of the agreement yet," said Clay Pederson, vice president of the National Farmers Union, a trade association representing 250,000 farm families. "But what little we do know, we don't like."
He said his group had decided to work for Mr. Clinton in the Presidential campaign, citing trade issues as an important factor. "Our PAC endorsed Governor Clinton and Senator Gore last week, the first time we have made an endorsement," Mr. Pederson said of his political action committee. "Some of the statements Governor Clinton has made -- about protecting jobs, environment and farms -- reflect how we feel." The Sierra Club, too, plans to work for Mr. Clinton.
Not all of the opponents favor the defeat of President Bush, however. Large-scale sugar-cane farmers of Hawaii join the Southern California vegetable growers in vehemently opposing the treaty but retaining strong support for the President.
Some religious groups, like the United Methodist Church, complain that the agreement does not call for enough to bolster wage levels in Mexico.
In a church publication, Mark Harrison, a program associate, said that the church would seek a trade agreement that included "an affirmation of a country's social economic and environmental priorities."
The National Consumers League is worried that the agreement would encourage exploitation of children in the workplace. "We're concerned that consumers in the United States will be unknowingly faced with products that are made as the result of child labor exploitation," said Darlene Moore, a senior associate.
The Bush Administration has said that, because of the lower wage rates in Mexico, the agreement will make North Amercian companies far more competitive with their counterparts in Asia. The President contends, too, that the agreement will open the once-closed Mexican markets for a number of products made in the United States, namely automobiles and computers.
Mr. Clinton has pledged to accompany any trade agreement he would reach with assurances that jobs in the United States and environmental standards would not be threatened.
After the agreement was announced, he said he was still reviewing it and wishes to study its potential effect on labor and the environment before taking a stand.
The Administration lawyers say they are still fine tuning the treaty language and that it will be several weeks before a complete text is released.
